SENTENCES AND THEIR PERPLEXITY


1. thus the transformation of adam	smith's ideal entrepreneur into a mythological detective coincides	closely with the decline of the real entrepreneur in economic life.	10.626664617239829
2. driven	from the marketplace by the course of history our hero disguises	himself as a private detective.	11.489893803010617
3. the birth of the myth compensates	for the death of the ideal.	16.836097229511964
4. even on the fictional level however	the contradictions which give rise to the mystery story are not fully	resolved.	12.349935379706862
5. the individualism and public service of the private detective	both stem from his dedication to a personal code of conduct:	he enforces the law without being told to do so.	8.62373324678828
6. the private eye is therefore	a moral man; but his morality rests upon that of his society.	13.486586201410178
7. the basic premise of all mystery stories is that the distinction between	good and bad coincides with the distinction between legal and illegal.	10.003220143079167
8. unfortunately this assumption does not always hold good.	14.194136851269583
9. as	capitalism in the 20th century has become increasingly dependent upon	force and violence for its survival the private detective is placed	in a serious dilemma.	8.798533941852485
10. if he is good he may not be legal; if he is	legal he may not be good.	18.706353864320263
11. it is the gradual unfolding and deepening	of this contradiction which creates the inner dialectic of the evolution	of the mystery story.	12.429610205591537
12. with the advent of sir arthur	conan doyle's sherlock holmes the development of the modern private	detective begins.	16.431872604798432
13. sherlock holmes is not merely an individualist;	he is very close to being a mental case.	12.269851177992978
14. a brief list of the great	detective's little idiosyncrasies would provide dr freud with	ample food for thought.	12.542304199933893
15. holmes is addicted to the use of cocaine and	other refreshing stimulants; he is prone to semi-catatonic trances	induced by the playing of the vioiln; he is a recluse an incredible	egotist a confirmed misogynist.	9.474719895986942
16. holmes rebels against the social	conventions of his day not on moral but rather on aesthetic grounds.	10.254940765435954
17. his	eccentricity begins as a defense against boredom.	11.118618003375188
18. it was in order	to avoid the stuffy routine of middle class life that holmes became	a detective in the first place.	0.0
19. as he informs watson my life is	spent in one long effort to escape from the commonplaces of existence.	12.034255955572066
20. these little problems help me to do so.	15.69105466572749
21. holmes is a public servant	to be sure; but the society which he serves bores him to tears.	8.83153751019816
22. the curious relationship between holmes and scotland yard	provides an important clue to the deeper significance of his eccentric	behavior.	11.525020720478054
23. although he is perfectly willing to cooperate with scotland	yard holmes has nothing but contempt for the intelligence and mentality	of the police.	9.914816339602515
24. they for their part are convinced that holmes	is too unorthodox and theoretical to make a good detective.	14.708780229763613
25. why do the police find holmes unorthodox?	13.82198152098748
26.  on the face of	it it is because he employs deductive techniques alien to official	police routine.	15.516817867554002
27. another more interesting explanation is hinted at by	watson when he observes on several occasions that holmes would have	made a magnificent criminal.	8.066200373475011
28. the great detective modestly agrees.	22.538740073640646
29. watson's	insight is verified by the mysterious link between holmes	and his arch-opponent dr moriarty.	8.834168570742513
30. the two men resemble each other	closely in their cunning their egotism their relentlessness.	13.810636212939405
31. the	first series of sherlock holmes adventures ends with holmes and moriarty	grappling together on the edge of a cliff.	11.329289177129665
32. they are presumed	to have plunged to a common grave in this fatal embrace.	13.76045842468169
33. linked to holmes	even in death moriarty represents the alter-ego of the great	detective the image of what our hero might have become were he not a	public servant.	8.125222053035374
34. just as holmes the eccentric stands behind holmes the	detective so holmes the potential criminal lurks behind both.	12.02809575327848
35. in the modern english whodunnit this insinuation of	latent criminality in the detective himself has almost entirely disappeared.	11.589594004596323
36. hercule poirot and lord peter whimsey	have retained	holmes'	egotism but not his zest for life and eccentric habits.	9.723773562266802
37. poirot and	his counterparts are perfectly respectable people; it is true that	they are also extremely dull.	9.719819398675485
38. their dedication to the status quo has	been affirmed at the expense of the fascinating but dangerous individualism	of a sherlock holmes.	11.426658321681197
39. the latter's real descendents were unable	to take root in england; they fled from the victorian parlor	and made their way across the stormy atlantic.	8.58813561050702
40. in the american hardboiled	detective story of the '20s and '30s the spirit of the	mad genius from baker street lives on.	15.386259591792971
41. like holmes the	american private eye rejects the social conventions of his time.	10.303766801850994
42. but	unlike holmes he feels his society to be not merely dull but also corrupt.	10.725826538405688
43. surrounded by crime and violence everywhere the hardboiled	private eye can retain his purity only through a life of self-imposed	isolation.	8.11858028311182
44. his alienation is far more acute than holmes'; he	is not an eccentric but rather an outcast.	11.315269183109283
45. with rex stout's nero	wolfe alienation is represented on a purely physical plane.	10.998619552217056
46. wolfe	refuses to ever leave his own house and spends most of his time drinking	beer and playing with orchids.	11.184515264157607
47. more profound and more disturbing	however is the moral isolation of raymond chandler's philip marlowe.	10.126803403066264
48. in a society where everything is for sale marlowe is the only	man who cannot be bought.	14.414533906206763
49. his tough honesty condemns him to a solitary	and difficult existence.	12.05306113109747
50. beaten bruised and exhausted he pursues	the elusive killer through the demi-monde of high society and low	morals always alone always despised.	9.159936216703418
51. in the end he gets his man but	no one seems to care; virtue is its own and only reward.	12.559601406945568
52. a similar	tone of underlying futility and despair pervades the spy thrillers	of eric ambler and dominates the most famous of all american mystery	stories dashiell hammett's the maltese falcon.	9.212240056081402
53. sam spade	joins forces with a band of adventurers in search of a priceless jeweled	statue of a falcon; but when the bird is found at last it turns	out to be a fake.	8.915143037943395
54. now the detective must save his own skin by informing	on the girl he loves who is also the real murderer.	12.0557556990861
55. for sam spade	neither crime nor virtue pays; moreover it is increasingly difficult	to distinguish between the two.	10.127701579209113
56. because the private eye	intends to save society in spite of himself he invariably finds himself	in trouble with the police.	13.085512424084955
57. the latter are either too stupid to	catch the killer or too corrupt to care.	11.019262863115445
58. in either case they do not	appreciate the private detective's zeal.	17.838332831278663
59. perry mason and hamilton	burger nero wolfe and inspector cramer spend more time fighting	each other than they do in looking for the criminal.	8.620700661341417
60. frequently enough	the police are themselves in league with the killer; dashiell	hammett's	red harvest provides a classic example of this theme.	10.399901506915656
61. but even when the police are honest they do not trust the private	eye.	16.37515310291044
62. he is like phillip marlowe too alienated to be reliable.	17.802086057413756
63. finally	in the maltese falcon among others the clash between detective	and police is carried to its logical conclusion: sam spade	becomes the chief murder suspect.	7.556878632736834
64. in order to exonerate himself he	is compelled to find the real criminal who happens to be his girl friend.	14.843491050495684
65. what was only a vague suspicion in the case of sherlock holmes	now appears as a direct accusation: the private eye is in danger of	turning into his opposite.	12.620226060409722
66. it is the growing contradiction	between individualism and public service in the mystery story which	creates this fatal dilemma.	17.68070771971906
67. by upholding his own personal code of behavior	the private detective has placed himself in opposition to a society	whose fabric is permeated with crime and corruption.	9.519083832104135
68. that society	responds by condemning the private eye as a threat to the status quo	a potential criminal.	13.366529245036569
69. if the detective insists upon retaining his	personal standards he must now do so in conscious defiance of his society.	10.707834214088361
70. he must in short cease to be a detective and become a rebel.	16.128209339970162
71. on the other hand if he wishes to continue in his chosen profession	he must abandon his own code and sacrifice his precious individualism.	11.414224687177947
72. dashiell hammett resolved this contradiction by ceasing to write	mystery	stories and turning to other pursuits.	10.11881746645696
73. his successors have adopted	the opposite alternative.	13.630455385097621
74. in order to save the mystery story they	have converted the private detective into an organization man.	17.076513075169736
75. the first of two possible variations on this theme is symbolized by	mickey spillane's mike hammer.	14.255082638012235
76. at first glance this hero seems	to be more rather than less of an individualist than any of his predecessors.	13.442701580595445
77. for hammer nothing is forbidden.	18.089283221630154
78. he kills when he pleases	takes his women where he finds them and always acts as judge jury	and executioner rolled into one.	10.395561669380484
79. it will be shown that the objectives of the cooperative people in	an organization determine the type of network required because the	type of network functions according to the characteristics of the messages	enumerated in table 1.	10.052507899833152
80. great stress is placed on the role that	the monitoring of information sending plays in maintaining the effectiveness	of the network.	11.124447147029283
81. by monitoring we mean some system of control	over the types of information sent from the various centers.	8.95884813743039
82. as a word of caution we should be aware that in actual practice no	message is purely one of the four types question command statement	or exclamation.	14.645035685398177
83. for example suppose a man wearing a $200 watch driving	a 1959 rolls royce stops to ask a man on the sidewalk what	time is it?	9.607600146909316
84.  this sentence would have most of the characteristics	of a question but it has some of the characteristics of a statement	because the questioner has conveyed the fact that he has no faith in	his own timepiece or the one attached to his car.	12.252183663991884
85. if the man on the	sidewalk is surprised at this question it has served as an exclamation.	11.605697823819012
86. also since the man questioned feels a strong compulsion to answer	the question	has assumed some measurable properties of a command.	9.83566804009632
87. however for	convenience we will stick to the idea that information can be classified	according to table 1.	11.391724128334884
88. on this basis certain extreme kinds of networks	will be discussed for illustrative purposes.	14.062353033402466
89. some special types of organization	presumably a cocktail party is expected to fulfill the host's desire	to get together a number of people who are inadequately acquainted	and thereby arrange for bringing the level of acquaintance up to adequacy	for future cooperative endeavors.	9.862969798145977
90. the party is usually in a room	small enough so that all guests are within sight and hearing of one another.	12.612142697066268
91. the information is furnished by each of the guests is sent by	oral broadcasting over the air waves and is received by the ears.	10.224087104094586
92. since	the air is a continuum the network of communication remains intact	regardless of the positions or motions of the points	in the net.	9.369072950020222
93. as shown in figure 1 there is a connection for communication	between every pair of points.	14.016903911143515
94. this and other qualifications make	the cocktail party the most complete and most chaotic communication	system ever dreamed up.	12.285005881374289
95. all four types of message listed in table	1 are permitted although decorum and cocktail tradition require holding	the commands to a minimum while exclamations having complimentary	intonations are more than customarily encouraged.	8.020732391490792
96. the completeness	of the connections provide that for n people there are f	lines of communication between the pairs which can become a large number	for a party of fifty guests.	9.420211060413381
97. looking at the diagram we	see that f connection lines come in to each member.	10.373555417954535
98. thus the cocktail	party would appear to be the ideal system but there is one weakness.	22.46877008148263
99. in spite of the dreams of the host for oneness in the group the	f incoming messages for each guest overload his receiving system beyond	comprehension if n exceeds about six.	10.80880528192896
100. the crowd consequently	breaks up into temporary groups ranging in size from two to six with	a half-life for the cluster ranging from three to twenty minutes.	10.053983740858714
101. for the occasion on which everyone already knows everyone else	and the host wishes them to meet one or a few honored newcomers then	the open house system is advantageous because the honored guests	are fixed connective points and the drifting guests make and break connections	at the door.	7.680393507416722
102. we consider a rural	community as an assemblage of inhabited dwellings whose configuration	is determined by the location and size of the arable land sites necessary	for family subsistence.	10.703728494176577
103. we assume for this illustration that the	size of the land plots is so great that the distance between dwellings	is greater than the voice can carry and that most of the communication	is between nearest neighbors only as shown in figure 2.	10.696407044974293
104. information	beyond nearest neighbor is carried second- third- and fourth-hand	as a distortable rumor.	10.635267499930531
105. in figure 2 the points in the network are	designated by a letter accompanied by a number.	11.482582160749589
106. the numbers indicate	the number of nearest neighbors.	16.386222825564015
107. it will be noted that point f	has seven nearest neighbors h and e have six and p	has only one while the remaining points have intermediate numbers.	10.983492024550126
108. in any social system in which communications have an importance	comparable with that of production and other human factors a point	like f in figure 2 would be the dwelling	place for the community leader while e and h would	house the next most important citizens.	10.573544794721437
109. a point like p gets	information directly from n but all information beyond n	is indirectly relayed through n.	8.988146053999083
110. the dweller at p is	last to hear about a new cure the slowest to announce to his neighbors	his urgent distresses the one who goes the farthest to trade and the	one with the greatest difficulty of all in putting over an idea or	getting people to join him in a cooperative effort.	9.14661436141702
111. since the hazards	of poor communication are so great p can be justified as a habitable	site only on the basis of unusual productivity such as is made	available by a waterfall for milling purposes a mine or a sugar maple	camp.	8.265816695034907
112. location theorists have given these matters much consideration.	12.3482207866056
113. the networks for military communications	are one of the best examples of networks which not only must be	changed with the changes in objectives but also must be changed with the	addition of new machines of war.	9.832839889237803
114. they also furnish proof that in	modern war message sending must be monitored.	13.898701860496624
115. without monitoring a	military hookup becomes a noisy party.	11.605216425738629
116. the need for monitoring became	greater when radio was adopted for military signaling.	18.129945777744897
117. alexander the	great who used runners as message carriers did not have to worry about	having every officer in his command hear what he said and having	hundreds of them comment at once.	9.201235731754654
118. as time has passed and science has	progressed the speed of military vehicles has increased the range of	missiles has been extended the use of target-hunting noses on the projectiles	has been adopted and the range and breadth of message sending	has increased.	10.133537574247173
119. next to the old problem of the slowness of decision	making network structure seems to be paramount and without monitoring	no network has value.	11.18710518677676
120. on the parade ground the net may be similar	to that shown in figure 3.	14.459250796844767
121. the monitoring is the highest and	most restrictive of any organization in existence.	10.61385277229228
122. no questions statements	or explanations are permitted- only commands.	14.92628101460717
123. commands go only	from an officer to the man of nearest lower rank.	10.892140101576791
124. the same command	is repeated as many times as there are levels in rank from general to	corporal.	14.78878636778352
125. all orders originate with the officer of highest rank and	terminate with action of the men in the ranks.	13.054036105049532
126. even the officer in charge	be it a captain or a general is restrained	by monitoring.	13.130383702050258
127. this is done for simplicity of commands and to bring the	hidden redundancy up to where misunderstanding has almost zero possibility.	11.794325826435562
128. the commands are specified by the military regulations; are	few in number briefly worded all different in sound; and are combinable	into sequences which permit any marching maneuver that could be	desired on a parade ground.	8.827480710636815
129. this monitoring is necessary because on	a parade ground everyone can hear too much and without monitoring	a confused social event would develop.	8.84235919011082
130. with troops dispersed	on fields of battle rather than on the parade ground it may seem that	a certain amount of monitoring is automatically enforced by the lines	of communication.	10.100848444054044
131. years ago this was true but with the replacement	of wires or runners by radio and radar these	restrictions have disappeared and now again too much is heard.	8.848414156139748
132. in contrast to cocktail parties military organizations even	in the field are more formal.	15.914160834864521
133. in the extreme and oversimplified example	suggested in figure 3 the organization is more easily understood	and more predictable in behavior.	10.863127006475501
134. a military organization has an objective	chosen by the higher command.	13.12566368285538
135. this objective is adhered to throughout	the duration of the action.	12.718093931360345
136. the connective system or network	is tailored to meet the requirements of the objective and it is therefore	not surprising that a military body acting as a single coordinated	unit has a different communication network than a factory a college	or a rural village.	9.989901336294901
137. the assumptions upon which the example	shown	in figure 3 is based are: one man can direct about six subordinates	if the subordinates are chosen carefully so that they do not	need too much personal coaching indoctrinating etc.	9.093226367983398
138. a message	runs too great a risk of being distorted if it is to be relayed more	than about six consecutive times.	14.087949141882465
139. decisions of a general kind	are made by the central command.	11.062981495053428
140. and all action of a physical kind	pertinent to the mission is relegated to the line of men on the lower	rank.	13.364867658825048
141. these assumptions lead to an organization with one man at the	top six directly under him six under each of these and so on until	there are six levels of personnel.	0.0
142. the number of people acting as one	body by this scheme gives a surprisingly large army of f 55987	men.	15.328502912926306
143. this organizational network would be of no avail if there	were no regulations pertaining to the types of message sent.	9.311430574802475
144. of types	of message listed in table 1 commands and statements are the only	ones sent through the vertical network shown in figure 3.	11.01311060333863
145. a further	regulation is that commands always go down unaccompanied by statements	and statements always go up unaccompanied by commands.	8.810595225531808
146. questions	and particularly exclamations are usually channeled along informal	horizontal lines not indicated in figure 3 and seldom are carried	beyond the nearest neighbor.	9.051154372622117
147. it will readily be seen that	in this suggested network	greater emphasis on monitoring is implied than	is usually put into practice.	11.214719474796318
148. furthermore the network in figure	3 is only the basic net through which other networks pertaining to logistics	and the like are interlaced.	9.369072950020222
149. not discussed here are some	military problems of modern times such as undersea warfare where the	surveillance sending transmitting and receiving are all so inadequate	that networks and decision making are not the bottlenecks.	8.099719486060966
150. such	problems are of extreme interest as well as importance and are so much	like fighting in a rain forest or guerrilla warfare at night in tall	grass that we might have to re-examine primitive conflicts for what they	could teach.	9.025476953187276
151. this is an unsolved	problem which probably has never been seriously investigated although	one frequently hears the comment that we have insufficient specialists	of the kind who can compete with the germans or swiss for example	in precision machinery and mathematics or the finns in geochemistry.	8.85848357340128
152. we hear equally fervent concern over the belief that we have	not enough generalists who can see the over-all picture and combine	our national skills and knowledge for useful purposes.	10.177331230510694
153. this problem	of the optimum balance in the relative numbers of generalists and	specialists can be investigated on a communicative network basis.	8.791100132086969
154. since	the difficulty of drawing the net is great we will merely discuss	it.	11.224691946259922
155. first we realize that a pure specialist does not exist.	12.110651067881887
156. but	for practical purposes we have people who can be considered as such.	12.642087247073846
157. for example there are persons who are in physical science in the	field of mineralogy trained in crystallography who use only x-rays	applying only the powder technique of x-ray diffraction to clay	minerals only and who have spent the last fifteen years concentrating	on the montmorillonites; or persons in the social sciences in the	field of anthropology studying the lung capacity of seven andean	indians.	7.701187758979849
158. so we see that a specialist is a man who knows more and more	about less and less as he develops as contrasted to the generalist	who knows less and less about more and more.	10.945603271752214
159. american democratic thought pointed up the relation between the	protestant movement in this country and the development of a social	religion which he called the american democratic faith.	11.070986225653664
160. those familiar	with his work will remember that he placed the incipience of the	democratic faith at around 1850.	10.68281135249726
161. and he describes it as a balanced polarity	between the notions of the free individual and what he called	the fundamental law.	10.771333362081924
162. i want to say more about gabriel's so-called	fundamental law.	20.06814843568875
163. but first i want to quote him on the relationship	that he found between religion and politics in this country and	what happened to it.	10.768968154851692
164. he points out that from the time of jackson on	through world war 1 evangelical protestantism was a dominant influence	in the social and political life of america.	12.925285618362528
165. he terms this	early enthusiasm romantic christianity and concludes that its	similarity to democratic beliefs of that day is so great that the doctrine	of liberty seems but a secular version of its counterpart in evangelical	protestantism.	9.110406167049629
166. let me quote him even more fully for his	analysis is important to my theme.	14.438982416052422
167. he says: beside the	protestant philosophy of progress as expressed in radical or conservative	millenarianism should be placed the doctrine of the democratic	faith which affirmed it to be the duty of the destiny of the united	states to assist in the creation of a better world by keeping lighted	the beacon of democracy.	8.99554859158968
168. he specifies in the middle period	of the nineteenth century it was colored by christian supernaturalism	in the twentieth century it was affected by naturalism.	16.389179345460608
169. but in	every period it has been humanism.	18.451413705355222
170. and let me add utopianism also.	18.698297498029078
171. some fourteen or fifteen years ago in an essay i called	the leader follows- where?	12.357433137802806
172.  i used his polarity to illustrate	what i thought had happened to us in that form of liberalism we call	progressivism.	11.849482651163308
173. it seemed to me that the liberals had scrapped the	balanced polarity and reposed both liberty and the fundamental law	in the common man.	12.688652036704719
174. that is to say gabriel's fundamental law had been	so much modified by this time that it was neither fundamental nor	law any more.	16.466549949438626
175. it is a weakness of gabriel's analysis that he never	seems to realize that his so-called fundamental law had already been	cut loose from its foundations when it was adapted to democracy.	11.20839425189115
176. and	with progressivism the religion of humanity was replacing what gabriel	called christian supernaturalism.	10.736481944814718
177. and the common man was developing	mythic power or charisma on his own.	13.901142389483454
178. during the decade	that followed the common man as that piece put it grew uncomfortable	as the voice of god and fled from behind saint woodrow	only to learn from science to his shocked relief that after all there	was no god he had to speak for and that he was just an animal anyhow-	that there was a chemical formula for him and that too much couldn't	be expected of him.	10.661011437467115
179. the socialism implicit in the slogan	of the roosevelt revolution freedom from want and fear seems a	far cry from the individualism of the first amendment to the constitution	or of the jacksonian frontier.	8.729892858164698
180. what had happened to the common	man?	23.566361202526945
181.    french egalitarianism had had only nominal influence	in this country before the days of popularism.	10.037263334584896
182. the riotous onrush	of industrialism after the war for southern independence and the general	secular drift to the religion of humanity however prepared	the way for a reception of the french revolution's socialistic offspring	of one sort of another.	10.378659451079832
183. the first of which to find important place	in our federal government was the graduated income tax under wilson.	13.148590120215168
184. moreover the centralization of our economy during the 1920s the	dislocations of the depression the common ethos of materialism everywhere	all contributed in various ways to the face-lifting that replaced	mike fink and the great gatsby with the anonymous physiognomy	of the little people.	9.120777860147378
185. however it is important to trace the	philosophy of the french revolution to its sources to understand the	common democratic origin of individualism and socialism and the influence	of the latter on the former.	10.926551452395936
186. that john locke's philosophy of	the social contract fathered the american revolution with its declaration	of independence i believe we generally accept.	10.84949569647901
187. yet after	rousseau had given the social contract a new twist with his notion	of the general will the same philosophy it may be said became	the idea source of the french revolution also.	9.075044788426853
188. the importance	of rousseau's twist has not always been clear to us however.	12.445450562798397
189. this	notion of the general will gave rise to the commune of paris in	the revolution and later brought napoleon to dictatorship.	9.025512235847062
190. and it	is clearly argued by lord percy of newcastle in his remarkable long	essay the heresy of democracy and in a more general way by	voegelin in his new science of politics that this same rousseauan	idea descending through european democracy is the source of	marx's theory of the dictatorship of the proletariat.	9.33056309673833
191. this is important	to understanding the position that doctrinaire liberals found themselves	in after world war 2 and our great democratic victory	that brought no peace.	11.677438759152873
192. the long road that had taken liberals in	this country into the social religion of democracy into a worship of	man led logically to the marxist dream of a classless society under	a socialist state.	9.642362316758227
193. and the ussr existed as the revolutionary	experiment in radical socialism the ultimate exemplar.	11.773028020681092
194. and by the	time the war ended liberal leadership in this country was spiritually	marxist.	16.37636803723313
195. we will recall that the still confident liberals of	the truman administration gathered with other western utopians in	san francisco to set up the legal framework finally and at last to	rationalize war- to rationalize want and fear- out of the world:	the united nations.	8.66479672218091
196. we of the liberal-led world got all set for peace	and rehabilitation.	16.790218457322926
197. then suddenly we found ourselves in the middle	of another fight an irrational an indecent an undeclared and immoral	war with our strongest ally.	8.539685232232568
198. during the next five years the leaders of the fair deal reluctantly	backed down from the optimistic expectations of the new deal.	16.766027185184857
199. during	the next five years liberal leaders in the united states sank in	the cumulative confusion attendant upon and manifested in a negative	policy of containment- and the bitterest irony- enforced and enforceable	only by threat of a weapon that we felt the greatest distaste	for but could not abandon: the atom bomb.	8.031723163142482
200. in 1952 it will be remembered	the gop without positive program campaigned on the	popular disillusionment with liberal leadership and won overwhelmingly.	12.075622740754579
201. all of this i know is recent history familiar to you.	16.483287423730566
202. but	i have been at some pains to review it as the drama of the common	man to point up what happened to him under eisenhower's leadership.	10.776869011420148
203. a perceptive journalist sam lubell has phrased it in the	title of one of his books as the revolt of the moderates.	10.329146678590092
204. he opens	his discourse however with a review of the eisenhower inaugural	festivities at which a sympathetic press had assembled its massive talents	all primed to catch some revelation of the emerging new age.	10.639121528756696
205. the	show was colorful indeed exuberant but the press for all its assiduity	could detect no note of a fateful rendezvous with destiny.	8.05353195141302
206. lubell offers his book as an explanation of why there was no clue.	12.293196714863017
207. and i select this sentence as its pertinent summation: in essence	the drama of his presidency can be described	as the ordeal of a nation turned conservative and struggling- thus far	with but limited and precarious success- to give effective voice	and force to that conservatism.	7.7809369282948655
208. i will assume that we are	all aware of the continuing struggle with its limited and precarious	success toward conservatism.	13.345977208585841
209. it has moved on various levels it has	been clamorous and confused.	16.1320324454189
210. obviously there has been no agreement on	what american conservatism is or rather what it should be.	12.912572954069018

212. i saw a	piece the other day assailing william buckley author of man and	god at yale and publisher of the national review as no conservative	at all but an old liberal.	10.677821190566803
213. i would agree with this view.	22.029682176672733

216. one of the obvious conclusions we can make on the basis of	the last election i suppose is that we the majority were dissatisfied	with eisenhower conservatism.	17.197268048422142

218. this is however symptomatic of our national malaise.	23.029711963517855

220. i will mention two	volumes of specific comment on this malaise that appeared last year.	14.898306677291863
221. the earlier of them was an unofficial enterprise sponsored by life	magazine under the title of the national purpose.	12.037648280693157
222. the contributors	to this testament were all well-known: a former democratic	candidate for president a new deal poet the magazine's chief	editorial writer two newspaper columnists head of a national broadcasting	company a popular protestant evangelist etc.	9.030148867313864
223. what i want	to point out here is that all of them are ex-liberals or modified liberals	with perhaps one exception.	15.803123592613636
224. i suppose we might classify billy	graham as an old liberal.	16.21272133212653
225. and i would further note that they all-	with one exception again- sang in one key or another the same song.	10.605692248663189
226. its refrain was: let us return to the individualistic democracy	of our forefathers for our salvation.	11.759718424507723
227. adlai stevenson	expressed some reservations about this return.	11.118618003375188
228. others invoked technology	and common sense.	18.425563280497766
229. only walter lippman envisioned the possibility	of our having outlived most of what we used to regard as the program	of our national purposes.	9.853628378223764
230. but the most notable thing about	the incantation of these ex-liberals was that the one-time shibboleth	of socialism was conspicuously absent.	13.827379443635978

232. they perhaps gave the pitch	of their position in the preface where it was said that eisenhower	requested that the commission be administered by the american assembly	of columbia university because it was non-partisan.	10.579185815084557

235. this group is secularist	and their program tends to be technological.	15.55616626831249
236. but it is	the need to undertake these testaments that i would submit here as	symptom of the common man's malaise.	15.003340335368183
237. and let me add murray's new	book as another symptom of it particularly so in view of the attention	time magazine gave it when it came out recently.	9.903848824687177
238. father murray	goes back to the declaration of independence too though i may	add with considerably more historical perception.	12.807766186544182
239. i will reserve	discussion of it for a moment however to return to president kennedy.	17.863723299234707
240. as symptomatic of the common man's malaise he is most significant:	a liberal and a catholic elected by the skin of his teeth.	10.719882635173505
241. does that not suggest to you an uncertain and uneasy not to say confused	state of the public mind?	11.143863583343759
242.    what is the common man's	complaint?	33.90591789918547
243.  let's take a panoramic look back over the course we	have come.	8.36537443497688
244. has not that way been lit always by the lamp of liberalism	up until the turning back under eisenhower?	10.662117651209332
245.  and the basic character	of that liberalism has been spiritual rather than economic.	12.306328520829847
246. ralph	gabriel gave it the name of protestant philosophy of progress.	13.119527703202275
247. but	there's a subjective side to that utopian outlook.	10.530932308755343
248. does our society have a runaway uncontrollable growth of	technology which may end our civilization or a normal healthy growth?	10.765272748981467
249. 	here there may be an analogy with cancer: we can detect cancers	by their rapidly accelerating growth determinable only when related	to the more normal rate of healthy growth.	8.309318115442148
250. should the accelerating	growth of technology then warn us?	14.451639446906915
251.  noting such evidence is the first	step; and almost the only cure is early detection and removal.	8.737700305869902
252. one way to determine whether we have so dangerous a technology	would be to check the strength of our society's organs to see if their	functioning is as healthy as before.	12.613041416383297
253. so an objective look at our	present procedures may move us to consider seriously this possibly analogous	situation.	9.388560110563343
254. in any event whether society may have cancer or merely	a virus infection the disease we shall find is political	economical social and even medical.	11.99274405157438
255. have not our physical abilities	already deteriorated because of the more sedentary lives we are now	living?	12.902105953697184
256.  hence the prime issue as i see it is whether a democratic	or free society can master technology for the benefit of mankind	or whether technology will rule and develop its own society compatible	with its own needs as a force of nature.	10.939596466466103
257. we are already committed	to establishing man's supremacy over nature and everywhere	on earth not merely in the limited social-political-economical context	we are fond of today.	9.479227309370383
258. otherwise we go on endlessly trying to draw	the line color and other as to which kind of man we wish to see dominate.	10.15571246242766
259. we have proved so able to solve technological problems that to	contend we cannot realize a universal goal in the immediate future is	to be extremely shortsighted if nothing else.	9.126134775207971
260. we must believe we have	the ability to affect our own destinies: otherwise why try anything?	13.099378390369507
261. 	so in these pages the term technology is used to include any	and all means which could amplify project or augment man's control	over himself and over other men.	7.804659140729613
262. naturally this includes all communication	forms eg languages or any social political economic	or religious structures employed for such control.	9.984610574209123
263. properly mindful	of all the cultures in existence today throughout the world we must	employ these resources without war or violent revolution.	0.0
264. if	we were creating a wholly new society we could insist that our social	political economic and philosophic institutions foster rather than	hamper man; best growth.	9.148757032765333
265. but we cannot start off with a clean slate.	19.97500039273399
266. so we must first analyze our present institutions with respect to	the effect of each on man's major needs.	11.910255894124841
267. asked which institution	most needs correction i would say the corporation as it exists in america	today.	10.32352990515417
268. at first glance this appears strange: of all people	was not america founded by rugged individualists who established a new	way of life still inspiring undeveloped societies abroad?	10.32325105844697
269.  but	hear harrison e salisbury former moscow correspondent of the	new york times and author of to moscow- and beyond.	9.32635228082935
270. in a book review of the soviet cultural offensive he says	long before the state department organized its bureaucracy into	an east-west contacts staff in order to wage a cultural counter-offensive	within soviet borders the sharp cutting-edge of american	culture had carved its mark across the russian steppes as when the enterprising	promoters of 'porgy and bess' overrode the state department	to carry the contemporary 'cultural warfare' behind the	enemy lines.	9.362034388804565
271. they were not diplomats or jazz musicians or even organizers	of reading-rooms and photo-montage displays but rugged capitalist	entrepreneurs like henry ford hugh cooper thomas campbell	the international harvester co and david w griffith.	8.467866750906403
272. their	kind created an american culture superior to any in the world an	industrial and technological culture which penetrated russia as it did	almost every corner of the earth without a nickel from the federal	treasury or a single governmental specialist to contrive directives or	program a series of consultations of interested agencies.	10.623921098376297
273. this favorable	image of america in the minds of russian men and women is still	there despite years of energetic anti-american propaganda h	perhaps the public's present attitude	toward business stems from the fact that the rugged capitalist entrepreneur	no more exists in america.	10.768131216573002
274. in his stead is a milquetoast	version known as the corporation.	18.905356623181152
275. but even if we cannot see	the repulsive characteristics in this new image of america foreigners	can; and our loss of prestige abroad is the direct result.	10.543595658527142
276. no amount of ballyhoo will cover up the sordid facts.	16.195282930425336
277. if we want respect	from ourselves or others we will have to earn it.	17.71932458041797
278. first let us	realize that whatever good this set-up achieved in earlier times now	the corporation per se cannot take economic leadership.	10.097950395557927
279. businesses	must develop as a result of the ideas energies and ambitions of an	individual having purpose and comprehensive ability within one mind.	10.873836307158458
280. when we forced individuals to assume the corporate structure	by means of taxes and other legal statutes we adopted what i would	term pseudo-capitalism and so took a major step toward socialism.	9.99921678239643
281. the biggest loss of course was the individual's lessened desire	and ability to give his services to the growth of his company and	our economy.	10.4254369824733
282. socialism i grant has a definite place in our society.	11.33819267263277
283. but let us not complain of the evils of capitalism by referring to	a form that is not truly capitalistic.	11.242800289677797
284. some forms of capitalism do indeed	work- superb organizations a credit to any society.	11.675794299150496
285. but the pseudo-capitalism	which dictates our whole economy as well as our politics	and social life will not stand close scrutiny.	11.314608773941595
286. its pretense to operate	in the public interest is little more than a sham.	15.101733459608232
287. it serves	only its own stockholders and poorly at that.	15.164128120861005
288. as a creative enterprise	its abilities are primarily in swallowing creative enterprises	developed outside its own organization	.	13.458219426485217
289. as to benefits to employees it is notorious	for its callous disregard except where it depends on them for services.	10.229881986633483
290. the corporation in america is in reality our form of socialism	vying in a sense with the other socialistic form that has emerged	within governmental bureaucracy.	12.924696593975314
291. but while the corporation has all	the disadvantages of the socialist form of organization	it cannot constructively do much of anything not compatible with its	unluckily it	does not have the desirable aspect of socialism the motivation to operate	for the benefit of society as a whole.	8.318046916587575
292. so we are faced with a	vast network of amorphous entities perpetuating themselves in whatever	manner they can without regard to the needs of society controlling	society and forcing upon it a regime representing only the corporation's	needs for survival.	11.115707908321598
293. the corporation has a limited specific	place in our society.	13.226625067609465
294. ideally speaking it should be allowed to operate	only where the public has a great stake in the continuity of supply	or services and where the actions of a single proprietor are secondary	to the needs of society.	11.07692050743708
295. examples are in public utilities making	military aircraft and accessories or where the investment and risk	for a proprietorship would be too great for a much needed project impossible	to achieve by any means other than the corporate form eg	constructing major airports or dams.	7.487209090274386
296. thus if corporations are not	to run away with us they must become quasi-governmental institutions	subject to public control and needs.	11.127504229249496
297. in all other areas private initiative	of the proprietorship type should be urged to produce the	desired goods and services.	10.596824577685155
298. avoiding runaway	technology can be done only by assuring a humane society; and for this	human beings must be firmly in control of the economics on which our	society rests.	10.447312856126917
299. such genuine human leadership the proprietorship can	offer corporations cannot.	11.96832811414073
300. it can project long-range goals for itself.	26.01085700804706
301. corporations react violently to short-range stimuli e g	quarterly and annual dividend reports.	9.070074471681158
302. proprietorships can establish	a unity and integrity of control; corporations being more amorphous	cannot.	10.635267499930531
303. proprietorships can establish a meaningful identity representing	a human personality and thus establish sincere relationships with	customers and community.	8.1523940120599
304. corporations are apt by nature to be impersonal	inhumane shortsighted and almost exclusively profit-motivated	a picture they could scarcely afford to present to the public.	9.860667025266434
305. the	proprietor is able to create a leadership impossible in the corporate	structure with its board of directors and stockholders.	10.366156242098981
306. leadership is	lacking in our society because it has no legitimate place to develop.	12.10285334462375
307. men continuously at the head of growing enterprises can acquire experiences	of the most varied complicated and trying type so that at maturation	they have developed the competence and willingness to accept	the personal responsibility so sorely needed now.	8.050311458253127
308. hence government	must establish greater controls upon corporations so that their	activities promote what is deemed essential to the national interest.	11.722223839304318
309. proprietorships should get the tax advantages now accruing to corporations	e g the chance to accumulate capital so vital for growth.	8.47444872869046
310. corporations should pay added taxes to be used for educational purposes	.	15.084343184941782
311. the right to leave legacies	should be substantially reduced and ultimately eliminated.	15.968820079465889
312. to perpetuate	wealth control led by small groups of individuals who played no	role in its creation prevents those with real initiative from coming to	the fore and is basically anti-democratic.	9.485627511408039
313. when the proprietor dies	the establishment should become a corporation until it is either acquired	by another proprietor or the government decides to drop it.	9.867507841569562
314. strikes	should be declared illegal against corporations because disagreements	would have to be settled by government representatives acting as	controllers of the corporation whose responsibility to the state would	now be defined against proprietorship because employees and proprietors	must be completely interdependent as they are each a part of the	whole.	9.969190111062899
315. strikes threatening the security of the proprietorship if internally	motivated prevent a healthy relationship.	8.834168570742513
316. certainly external	forces	should not be applied arbitrarily out of mere power available to	do so.	11.373954853670284
317. if we cannot stop warfare in our own economic system how can	we expect to abolish it internationally?	11.736546563234015
318. 	these proposals would go far toward creating the economic	atmosphere favoring growth of the individual who in turn would help	us to cope with runaway technology.	11.056172763454672
319. individual human strength is	needed to pit against an inhuman condition.	9.669550099771405
320. the battle is not easy.	19.926638570224114
321. we are tempted to blame others for our problems rather than look them	straight in the face and realize they are of our own making and possible	of solution only by ourselves with the help of desperately needed	enlightened competent leaders.	9.61649068281106
322. persons developed in to-day's corporations	cannot hope to serve here- a judgment based on experiences	of my own in business and in activities outside.	9.057255130779156
323. in my own company in	effect a partnership although legally a corporation i have been able	to do many things for my employees which normal corporations	of comparable size and nature would have been unable to do.	9.2575858733153

327. perhaps a list of some of the practices	of my company will help here.	18.493418333289473
328. the company grew	out of efforts by two completely inexperienced men in their late twenties	neither having a formal education applicable to or experience in	manufacturing or selling our type of articles.	9.712682041130998
329. from an initial investment	of $1200 in 1943 it has grown with no additional capital investment	to a present value estimated by some as exceeding $10000000	.	8.24721237802209

332. during the last years of woodrow wilson's administration	a red scare developed in our country.	16.070082615624194
