398. but is that not	like going to a chemistry laboratory and blindly pouring out liquids	and powders from an array of bottles and then after stirring expecting	a new wonder drug inevitably to result?	10.059068431278002
399.    what of the efficiency	of this natural instrument of free discussion?	12.027864760275495
400.  is there some	magic in it that assures results?	21.08145704785199
401.    when peter b kyne	informed us in 1921 that we had an instinctive	dislike for the japanese did the heated debates of the californians	settle the truth or falsity of the proposition?	8.43816215575093
402.    the	leopard's spots came from the pen of thomas dixon in 1902	and in this he announced an unchangeable law.	10.659748484641154
403. if a child had	a single drop of negro blood he would revert to the ancestral line which	except as slaves under a superior race had not made one step of	progress in 3000 years.	8.81914262051124
404. that doctrine has been accepted by many but	has it produced good results?	12.949566671261206
405.    in the same vein a certain	short-story plot has been overworked.	17.858607539670427
406. the son and heir of a prominent	family marries a girl who has tell-tale shadows on the half-moons of	her finger nails.	13.632940482893407
407. in time she presents her aristocratic husband with	a coal-black child.	13.781255853785437
408. is the world better for having this idea thrust upon	it?	17.685001130451365
409.  will argument and debate decide its truth or falsity?	12.045319261353159
410. 	for answers to such questions we must turn to the anthropologists	the biologists the historians the psychologists and the sociologists.	10.096675271787365
411. long ago they consigned the notions of kyne and dixon to the scrap	heap.	10.252686605070428
412. false ideas surfeit another sector of our life.	12.919117098695102
413. for	several generations much fiction has appeared dealing with the steprelationship.	11.059189214877165
414. the stepmother almost without exception has been presented	as a cruel ogress.	12.957840546200554
415. children conditioned by this mistaken notion	have feared stepmothers while adults by their antagonistic attitudes	have made the role of the substitute parents a difficult one.	8.276100876688245
416. debate	is not likely to resolve the tensions and make the lot of the stepchild	a happier one.	12.000769768292406
417. research on the other hand has shown many stepmothers	to be eminently successful some far better than the real mothers.	11.268705627618152
418. helen deutsch informed us	that in all cultures the term 'stepmother'	automatically evokes deprecatory implications a conclusion accepted	by many.	9.559225930701576
419. will mere debate on that proposition even though it be	free and untrammeled remove the dross and leave a residue of refined	gold?	9.549718747212925
420.  that is questionable to say the least.	21.942782191180346
421. research into several	cultures has proven her position to be a mistaken one.	10.912778093346255
422. most	assuredly ideas are invaluable.	16.6462465444584
423. but ideas just for the sake of having	them are not enough.	14.799406533276631
424. in the 1930's cures for the depression literally	flooded washington.	19.10610348648294
425. for a time the president received hundreds	of them every day most of them worthless.	16.332534712281316
426. ideas need to be	tested and not merely by argument and debate.	11.9493378842528
427. when some question arises	in the medical field concerning cancer for instance we do not	turn to free and open discussion as in a political campaign.	9.54364998475027
428. we have	recourse to the scientifically-trained specialist in the laboratory.	15.328138173534445
429. the	merits of the salk anti-polio vaccine were not established on the	forensic platform or in newspaper editorials but in the laboratory	and by tests in the field on thousands of children.	8.482749541275552
430. our presidential	campaigns provide much debate and argument.	14.509194571811173
431. but is the result	new barnsful of tested knowledge on the basis of which we can with confidence	solve our domestic and international problems?	12.177837336811372
432.  man we are	told is endowed with reason and is capable of distinguishing good from	bad.	13.209397228804459
433. but what a super-herculean task it is to winnow anything of value	from the mud-beplastered arguments used so freely particularly since	such common use is made of cliches and stereotypes in themselves	declarations of intellectual bankruptcy.	8.86674869991014
434. we are reminded however	that freedom of thought and discussion the unfettered exchange	of ideas is basic under our form of government.	11.758344371777676
435. assuredly in	our political campaigns there is freedom to think to examine any and	all issues and to speak without restraint.	8.104114449891131
436. but	have the results been heartening?	15.068811854765874
437.  may we state with confidence that	in such an exhibition a republic will find its greatest security?	8.496699580743604
438. 	we must not forget to be sure that free discussion and debate	have produced beneficial results.	13.220325267436278
439. in truth we can say that this broke	the power of senator joseph mccarthy who was finally exposed	in full light to the american people.	10.74797641082219
440. if he had been liquidated	in some way he would have become a martyr a rallying point for people	who shared his ideas.	15.947809122349225
441. debate in the political arena can be productive	of good.	10.28906378590409
442. but it is a clumsy and wasteful process: it can produce	negative results but not much that is positive.	18.203293984765796
443. debate rid us of	mccarthy but did not give us much that is positive.	11.256500001974366
444. it did something	to clear the ground but it erected no striking new structure; it	did not even provide the architect's plan for anything new.	11.013052281004235
445. in the field of the natural sciences scientifically verified data are	quite readily available and any discussion can be shortened with good	results.	12.356527315778035
446. in the field of the social sciences a considerable fund of	tested knowledge has been accumulated that can be used to good advantage.	18.761116390792083
447. by no means would we discourage the production of ideas:	they provide raw materials with which to work; they provide stimulations	that lead to further production.	10.16979934372916
448. we would establish no censorship.	27.67942407812947
449. the president's personality would have opened that office to him.	11.572314230763848
450. and for the first time a representative of the highest office in the	land would have been liable to the charge that he had attempted to make	it a successorship by inheritance.	16.2715960333518
451. it is testimony to the deep respect	in which mr eisenhower was held by members of all parties that	the moral considerations raised by his approach to the matter were	not explicitly to be broached.	9.61765823300218
452. these began to be apparent in a	press conference held during the second illness in order that the consulting	specialists might clarify the president's condition for the	nation.	10.675439900107015
453. and if howard rutstein felt impelled thereafter to formulate	the ethics of the medical profession his article in the atlantic	monthly accomplished a good deal more.	11.074267557023026
454. it forced us to fix the responsibility	for the position in which all medical commentators had been	placed.	13.278955802267507
455. the discussion of professional ethics inevitably reminded	us that in the historical perspective the president's decision will	finally clarify itself as a moral rather than a medical problem.	9.124970853684234
456. because	the responsibility for resolving the issue lay with the president	rather than with his doctors nothing raises more surely for us	the difficulties simple goodness faces in dealing with complex moral problems	under political pressure.	8.77521642155812
457. for the president had dealt with the	matter humbly in what he conceived as the democratic way.	12.320731630814656
458. but the	problem is one which gives us the measure of a man rather than a group	of men whether a group of doctors a group of party members assembled	at a dinner to give their opinion or the masses of the voters.	11.364162319113
459. any attempt to reconcile this statement of the central issue in	the campaign of 1956 with the nature of the man who could not conceive	it as the central issue will at least resolve our confusions about the	chaotic and misleading results of the earnestness of both doctors and	president in a situation which should never have arisen.	8.857209456440104
460. it was a	response to the conflict between political pressure and the moral intuition	which resulted in attempts at prediction.	14.502008228301495
461. in no other situation	would a group of doctors struggling competently to improve the life	expectancy of a man beloved by the world be subjected to such merciless	and persistent questioning and before they were prepared to demonstrate	the kind of verbal precision which alone can clarify for mankind	the problems it faces.	8.108589532836197
462. and though we can look back now and see their	errors we can look back also to the ultimate error.	10.98820926794175
463. it recurred	in the press conferences: the president's remarks about his running	developed a singular tone one which we find in few statements	made by public individuals on such a matter.	9.02901550784969
464. the press conference became	a stage which betrayed the drift of his private thinking rather than	his convictions.	11.470061218625109
465. he commented- thoughtfully a reporter told us-	that it was not too important for the individual how he ends up.	10.15071367228567
466. he gave us a simile to explain his admission that even at the worst	period of his second illness it never occurred to him there was any	renewed question about his running: as in the battle of the bulge	he had no fears about the outcome until he read the american newspapers.	11.35484613810077
467. yet the attitude that the fate of the presidency demands in such	a situation is quite distinct from the simple courage that can proceed	with battles to be fought regardless of the consequences.	9.27329975465072
468. in this	case others should not have had to raise the doubts and fears.	18.240511881953836
469. the	presidency demands an incisive awareness of the larger implications	of the death of any incumbent.	10.994546996895716
470. it is of the utmost importance to the	people of america and of the world how their governing president ends	up during the four years of his term.	17.41458088349082
471. only when that term is	ended and he is a private citizen again can he be permitted the freedom	and the courage to discount the dangers of his death.	9.900316298726928
472. ironically enough	in this instance such personal virtues were a luxury.	11.461595236710806
473. at	the national and international level then what is the highest kind	of morality for the private citizen represents an instance of political	immorality.	8.899187487635391
474. and we had the uneasy sense that the cleavage between the	moral and the political progressed amid the events which concern us.	12.169525606947051
475. for the tone of the editorials which greeted mr eisenhower's	original announcement of his running had been strangely disquieting.	10.189721087989247
476. neither the vibrant enthusiasm which bespeaks a people's intuitive	sense of the fitness of things at climactic moments nor the vital argumentation	betraying its sense that something significant has transpired	was in evidence.	9.11918354088194
477. nothing testifies more clearly to that cleavage than	the peculiar editorial page appearing in a july issue of life magazine	the issue which also carried the second announcement of the	candidacy.	7.801852578047582
478. the double editorial on two aspects of the u s	spirit was subtly calculated to suggest a moral sanction for gambles	great as well as small reflecting popular approval of this questionable	attitude toward the highest office in the land.	10.776252603914239
479. the moral	creed and the will to risk live happily together if we	do not examine where the line is to be drawn.	9.529880863924301
480. i may possibly be a	greater risk than is the normal person of my age the president had	said on february 29th of the election year ignoring the fact that	no one of his age had ever lived out another term.	9.497772093408505
481. my doctors assure	me that this increased percentage of risk is not great.	9.788699130504304
482. but by	the time the risk was doubled events had dismissed from his mind both	increased percentages and a previously stated intention of considering	carefully anything more serious than a bout of influenza.	9.413838475716577
483. only infrequently	did the situation color his thinking.	13.884859222195189
484. ironically no president	we have had would have regretted more than president eisenhower the	possibility to which his own words in the press conference held at	the beginning of august testified: that unable as he was himself	to say his running was best for the country unconsciously he had placed	his party before his nation.	9.489622885487504
485. so it is that we relive his opening	statement in the first television address with the dramatic immediacy	of the present.	15.24042922617643
486. no consideration of risk urges itself upon him	now: for this is what the mind does with the ideas on which it has not	properly focussed.	12.705523470052716
487. yet with a mind less shallow if less sharp than	some of the fortune-happy syndicates which back him he feels what	he cannot formulate; and we watch him amid the overtones which suggest	he could never in any conscience urge a risk upon the voters.	7.171167027304237
488. moving	as he is into the phase of the campaign which demands conviction of	him he adopts a position that is morally indefensible.	9.421411858468362
489. he ascribes	to the mercy of god the peace which this personal matter- the assurance	that he can physically sustain the burden of the office longer	than any individual in the history of our nation has been able to do-	has brought him.	10.530221235761346
490. what is simply an opinion formed in defiance of the	laws of human probability whether or not it is later confirmed has	become by september of the election year a firm conviction.	11.395830344948594
491. as	a means of silencing a discussion which ought to have taken place the	statement is an effective one: we sympathize with the universal confusion	which gives rise to such convictions.	8.454254762350164
492. but it is also the climax	to one of the absorbing chapters in our current political history.	21.753770264930008
493. in assigning to god the responsibility which he learned could	not rest with his doctors eisenhower gave evidence of that weakening	of the moral intuition which was to characterize his administration	in the years to follow.	8.22190847805486
494. in any other man this reassurance to the electorate	would have caused us a profound moral shock.	13.16823058680082
495. about this man we	had to think twice.	13.276062151403123
496. we knew that it was as reassurance the ironic	fruit of a deeply moral nature.	13.914274492555274
497. but the fact remains that even the unconscious	acceptance of himself as a man of destiny divinely protected	must be censored in any man who evades the responsibility for his major	decisions and thus for imposing his will on the people.	11.31135233812159
498. and in the	context of drifting personal utterances we have examined there was	occasional evidence of the origin of all such evasions.	12.46434254412458
499. when the possibility	that he had not given reconsideration to so weighty a decision	seemed	to disconcert his questioners mr eisenhower was known to	make his characteristic statement to the press that he was not going	to talk about the matter any more.	9.378560017504407
500. thinking had stopped; it was not	to be resumed.	12.3482207866056
501. the portrait that had developed fragmentarily	but consistently was the portrait of a man to whom serious thinking	is alien enough that the making of a decision inhibits when it does not	forestall any ability to review the decision in the light of new evidence.	10.172307535721474
502. this does not mean that the decision to run for office should	inevitably have been revoked.	19.28855535873663
503. instead it means that the thinking in	which decision issues has the power to determine the morality of the	decision as in this instance the pressure for renewed practical or legislative	attention to the constitutional problems the decision had uncovered	might have done.	9.809652530823293
504. drifting through a third illness apparently	without any provision for the handling of a major national emergency	other than a talk with the vice-president eisenhower revealed the singularly	static quality of his thinking.	9.07011250796162
505. despite three warnings no	sense of moral urgency impelled him to distinguish his situation and	thus his responsibilities from wilson's.	8.795361677128112
506. by contrast the	energetic reaction of the leader to the full demands his decision imposes	upon him strengthens the moral intuition and gives us the measure	of the man.	10.221258512137952
507. only by means of an intensive preoccupation with the detailed	considerations following from any decision can he ensure attention	to the practical details to be dealt with if the implications of immorality	in the major decision are effectively to be checked.	8.3149716293498
508. in the	incessant struggle with recalcitrant political fact he learns to focus	the essence of a problem in the significant detail and to articulate	the distinctions which clarify the detail as significant with what	is sometimes astounding rapidity.	10.362376168285593
509. like lincoln he can distinguish	his relation to god from the constitutional responsibilities a questionable	decision exacts of him.	8.984282195859107
510. like roosevelt he can distinguish an	attitude toward a russian leader he may share with a host of americans	from the responsibilities diplomatic convention may impose upon him.	9.556731439859504
511. he chooses to subordinate one to the other sometimes reluctantly	accepting criticism for the lesser immoralities facts breed.	11.964969493240575
512. the very	nature of a choice so grounded in distinction and fact leads to the	valid convictions which become force of will in the manifest leader.	9.602164633469624
513. the capacity for making the distinctions of which diplomacy is compact	and the facility with language which can render them into validity	in the eyes of other men are the leader's means for transforming the	moral intuition into moral leadership.	8.11220137918219
514. the making of distinctions	like the perception of the great distinctions made is an inordinately	difficult business.	13.763562992808644
515. lincoln's slow progress towards the several	marking his achievement is even now unrecognizable as such and loosely	interpreted as the alternation of inconsistency with vision.	7.817158228673359
516. but	because it is the function of the mind to turn the one into the other	by means of the capacities with which words endow it we do not unwisely	examine the type of distinction in the sphere of politics on which	decisions hang.	10.893659622670251
517. only recently and perhaps because a television debate	can so effectively dramatize president kennedy's extraordinary	mastery of detail have the abilities on which the capacity for making	distinctions depend begun to be clearly discernible at the level of	politics.	8.660128064450143
518. in his recent evaluation of kennedy's potentialities for	leadership walter lippmann has cited the precision of his mind	his immense command of factual detail and his instinct for	the crucial point as impressive in the extreme; and it is surely	clear that the first of these is the result of the way in which the	individual's command of language interacts with the other two.	12.430634352316725
519. for this change is not a change from one positive position to another	but a change from order and truth to disorder and negation.	10.696040605344075
520. the	liberal-conservative	division we might observe in passing is not of itself	directly involved in a private interest conflict nor even in struggle	between ruling groups.	9.986294753703476
521. rather it is rooted in a difference of response	to the threat of social disintegration.	11.710067595183027
522. the division is not between	those who wish to preserve what they have and those who want change.	18.106984098438915
523. rather it is a division established by two absolutely different ways	of thought with regard to man's life in society.	10.63002910703058
524. these ways are	absolutely irreconcilable because they offer two different recipes for	man's redemption from chaos.	11.134059678696923
525. the civilizational crisis the	third type of change raises the question what are we to do?	10.416295925107828
526. 	on the most primitive level.	15.068811854765874
527. for the answer cannot be derived from any	socially cohesive element in the disrupting community.	12.147208215066925
528. there is no	socially existential answer to the question.	33.05863159956165
529. for the truth formerly experienced	by the community no longer has existential status in the community	nor does any answer elaborated by philosophers or theoriticians.	9.178460109121565
530. in this phase of change no idea has social acceptance and so none	has ontological status in the community.	12.445736881556911
531. an interregnum ensues in which	not men but ideas compete for existence.	10.396143870453175
532. if we examine the	three types of change from the point of view of their internal structure	we find an additional profound difference between the third and the	first two one that accounts for the notable difference between the	responses they evoke.	11.868531022100054
533. the first two types of change occur within the	inward and immanent structure of the society.	12.881605881912188
534. the first involves a simple	shift of interests in the society.	15.69409224410976
535. the second involves something	deeper but its characteristic form focuses on a shift in policy for	the community not in the truth on which the community rests.	10.165143273644492
536. thus in	both types attention is focused on the community itself and its phenomenological	life.	11.70989417906224
537. the third type however wrenches attention from	the life of action and interests in the community and focuses it on the	ground of being on which the community depends for its existence.	9.66000672005429
538. voegelin	has analyzed this experience in the case of the stable healthy	community.	21.603517803547653
539. there the community faced with the need to formulate policy	on the level of absolute justice can find the answer to its problem	in the absolute truth which it holds as partially experienced.	10.839226378738584
540. this	however cannot be done by a community whose very experience of truth	is confused and incoherent: it has no absolute standard and consequently	cannot distinguish the absolute from the contingent.	9.391978398011739
541. it has	lost its ground of being and floats in a mist of appearances.	12.09254085852554
542. relativism	and equality are its characteristic diseases.	13.915190642667962
543. precisely at the moment	when it has lost its vision the mind of the community turns out	from itself in a search for the ontological standard whereby it can measure	itself.	9.12942865127599
544. for paradigmatic history breaks rather than unfolds	precisely when the movement is from order to disorder and not from	one order to a new order.	10.862348369863795
545. the liberal-conservative split to define	it further derives from a basic difference concerning the existential	status of standard sought and about the spiritual experience that leads	to its identification.	8.735625895254493
546. when disruptive change has penetrated	to the third level of social order the process of disruption rapidly	reaches a point of no return.	12.14916133153301
547. indeed it is probable that this point	is reached the moment the third level of change begins.	11.263445697305286
548. at that point	we reach the closed historical situation: the situation in	which man is no longer free to return to a status quo ante.	13.14987715190725
549. at that	point men become aware of the mystery of history called variously fate	or destiny or providence and feel themselves	caught helplessly in the writhing of a disrupted society.	10.315137564846895
550. the reasons	for this experience are rooted in the metaphysical characteristics of	such a change.	12.420830230345356
551. of all forms of being society or community	has the greatest element of determinability.	13.86321993672811
552. its ontological status is	itself most tenuous because apart from individual men who are its matter	tradition the form of society exists only as a shared	perception of truth.	10.925751496230939
553. the ontological status of society thus is constituted	by the psychological-intellectual-volitional status of society's	members.	10.242653103537407
554. the content of that psychological status determines	ultimately the content of civilization.	16.491883786679594
555. those social civilizational	factors not rooted in the human spirit of the group ultimately cease	to exist.	13.451540380306147
556. civilization itself- tradition- falls out of existence	when the human spirit itself becomes confused.	10.358652090748608
557. civilization is what	man has made of himself.	11.118618003375188
558. its massive contours are rooted in the simple	need of man since he is always incomplete to complete himself.	10.22595053868721
559. it is not enough for man to be an ontological esse.	26.354458687007977
560. he needs existential	completion he needs that is to move in the direction of completion.	18.539357493544667
561. and the direction of that movement is determined by his perception	of the truth about himself.	13.091003074793447
562. he must consequently exist as a	self-perceived substantive developing agent or he does not exist as	man.	15.702699617428756
563. thus it is no mystical intuition but an analyzable conception	to say that man and his tradition can fall out of existence.	9.099798230431686
564. this	happens at the moment man loses the perception of moral substance	in himself of a nature that in maritain's words is perceived as	a locus of intelligible necessities.	9.65356691670736
565. an existentialist is a man	who perceives himself only as esse as existence without substance.	9.431209500815976
566. thus human perception and human volition is the immanent	cause of all social change and this most truly when the change reaches	the civilizational level.	9.572108569029782
567. thus with regard to the loss of tradition	in the change from order to disorder the metaphysics of change works	itself out as a disruption of the individual soul a change in which man	continues as an objective ontological existent but no longer as a	man.	9.489223758650581
568. further change is a form of motion it occurs as the act	of a being in potency insofar as it is in potency and has not yet reached	the terminus of the change.	11.478737145829568
569. with regard to the change we are examining	the question is at what point does the change become irreversible?	11.469195013804834
570. 	a number of considerations suggest that this occurs early in	the process.	10.957705180640192
571. change involves the displacement of form.	14.90447970041415
572. this means that	the inception of change itself can begin only when the factors conducive	to change have already become more powerful than those anchoring	the existent form in being.	10.57467653918704
573. if the existent form is to be retained new	factors that reinforce it must be introduced into the situation.	12.588256445858661
574. in	the case of social decay form is displaced simply by the process of	dissolution with no form at the terminus of the process.	9.287687644678446
575. now in the	mere fact of the beginning of such displacement we have prima-facie evidence	of the ontological weakness of the fading form.	12.183987981815463
576. and when we consider	the tenuous hold tradition has on existence any weakening of that	hold constitutes a crisis of existence.	12.913762161249597
577. the retention of a tradition	confronted with such a crisis necessitates the introduction of new	spiritual forces into the situation.	10.087497005037322
578. however the crisis occurs precisely	as a weakening of spiritual forces.	15.326863132413063
579. it would seem therefore that	in a civilizational crisis man cannot save himself.	19.835933218964403
580. the emergence	of the crisis itself would seem to constitute a warranty for the victory	of disorder.	13.066327256517155
581. and it would seem that history is a witness to this	truth.	18.22524620299027
582. as a further characterization of the liberal conservative	split we may observe that it involves differences in the formula for	escaping inevitabilities in history.	13.094858918664169
583. these differences in turn derive	from prior differences concerning the friendly or hostile character	of change.	9.495459372186279
584. anxiety and deep insecurity	are the characteristic responses evoked by the crisis in tradition.	10.358652090748608
585. to experience them it is not necessary for a people to be actively	aware of what is happening to it.	13.957276992084624
586. the process of erosion need only	undermine the tradition and a series of consequences begin unfolding	within the individual while in institutions a quiet but deep transformation	of processes occurs.	11.619817753953429
587. within the individual the reaction has been	called various names all however pointing to the same basic experience.	10.820311517218242
588. weil identifies it as being rootless guardini as being	placeless riesman as being lonely.	10.358652090748608
589. others call it alienation	and mean by that no simple economic experience	but a deep spiritual sense of dislocation.	8.88622581898661
590. within institutions	there is a marked decline of the process of persuasion and the substitution	of a force-fear process which masquerades as the earlier one	of persuasion.	11.15931207300495
591. we note the use of rhetoric as a weapon the manipulation	of the masses by propaganda the mobilization of effort and	resources.	10.087828044273675
592. within this context of spontaneous and unanalyzed	responses to the experience of civilizational crisis two basic organizations	of response are observable: reaction and ideological progressivism.	11.792759678530023
593. these responses are explicable in terms of characteristics inherent	in the crisis.	12.029409820358078
594. both are predictably destined to fail.	19.843528935441054
595. the	response of reaction is dominated by a concern for what is vanishing.	9.521882735323508
596. its essence lies in its attempt to recover previous order through	the repression of disruptive forces.	10.516426501676232
597. to this end political authority	is called upon to exercise its negative and coercive powers.	11.687871687744227
598. the implicit	assumption of this response is that history is reversible.	13.569310574206803
599. seemingly	order is perceived as a kind of subsistent entity now covered by	adventitious accretions.	12.104967975023735
600. the problem is to remove the accretions and	thereby uncover the order that was always there.	15.94318274057682
601. such a response of	course misses the point that in crisis order is going out of existence.	11.147534518668849
602. moreover its posture of stubborn but simple resistance is doomed	to failure because of the metaphysical weakness of the existent form of	order once the activation of change has reached visible proportions.	9.600224904081502
603. the most reaction can achieve is stasis and a stasis that can be maintained	only by the expenditure of an effort which ultimately exhausts	itself.	9.462447362308476
604. despite the hopelessness of the response it is explicable	in terms of the crisis of tradition itself.	14.349422188024823
605. since a civilizational	crisis involves also a crisis in private interests and in the ruling	class reaction is normally found among those who feel themselves	to be among the ruling class.	8.713275851573387
606. their great error is to mingle the responses	typical of each of the three types of change.	13.200462446559204
607. since civilizational	change is the most difficult to perceive and analyze it seldom is	given adequate attention.	10.832214432906673
608. and the anxiety it generates is misinterpreted	as anxiety over private interest and threatened social status.	12.812119524546368
609. the basic truth in the reactionary response is to be found in its	realistic assumption of the primacy of the real over the ideational.	13.011695145045195
610. but this truth is distorted by its extreme application: the assumption	of the separate existence of tradition.	13.747849361541393
611. the reactionary misses	the point that tradition exists ontologically only in the form of	psychological-intellectual	relations.	16.126133178918323
612. reactionary theories for this reason	usually assume some form of organismic theory.	12.601367513989699
613. in its defensive	formulations the theory will attack conscious change on the grounds of	the independent existence of the community.	11.99672928392683
614. in its dynamic form it	visualizes the community as the embodiment of an ontological force-	the race for instance which unfolds in history.	11.530376003202782
615. in both cases the	individual tends to be treated as an instrument of the organic reality.	16.050908751715927
616. when the reactionary response is thus bolstered by an intellectual	defense the characteristics of that defense are explicable only	in terms of the basic attitudes of unanalyzed reaction.	11.400491827653253
617. reaction is	rooted in a perception of tradition as a whole.	9.669550099771405
618. it is a total situation	that is defended: the good old days.	25.907882955779115
619. there is no selectivity;	even the questionable features of the past are defended.	24.52956696995469
620. the point	is that the reactionary for whatever motive perceives himself to	have been part or a partner of something that extended beyond himself	something which consequently he was not able to accept or reject	on the basis of subjective preference.	9.543690835006105
621. the reactionary is confused about	the existential status of a decaying tradition but he does perceive	the unity tradition had when it was healthy.	9.196692880353178
622. all of which brings up another problem in the use of psychoanalytic	insight in a literary work.	19.351456349493116
623. is the oedipus complex the clinical	syndrome material for a tragedy?	13.916760472870717
624.  if we remove ourselves for a moment	from our time and our infatuation with mental disease isn't there	something absurd about a hero in a novel who is defeated by his infantile	neurosis?	10.164544190055087
625.  i am not making a clinical judgment here for such	personal tragedies are real and are commonplace in the analyst's	consulting room but literature makes a different claim upon our sympathies	than tragedy in life.	8.606904075063344
626. a man in a novel who is defeated in his childhood	and condemned by unconscious forces within him to tiredly repeat	his earliest failure in love only makes us a little weary of man;	his tragedy seems unworthy and trivial.	9.62017806585764
627. now we can argue that	the irresistible fate of oedipus rex was nothing more than the irresistible	unconscious longings of oedipus projected outward but this	externalization of unconscious conflict makes all the difference between	a story and a clinical case history.	9.319042101628975
628. we can also argue that the	three brothers karamazov and smerdyakov were the external representatives	of an internal conflict within one man dostoevsky a conflict	having to	do with father-murder and the wish to possess the father's woman.	9.520272765813406
629. but	a novel in which one man karamazov explored the divisions within	his personality would scarcely merit publication in the psychoanalytic	quarterly.	8.701199743142457
630. it is a mistake to look upon the oedipus of	oedipus complex as a literary descendant of oedipus rex.	16.71712771340973
631. whatever	the psychological truth in the oedipus myth an oedipus who is drawn	to his fate by irresistible external forces can carry the symbol of	humanity and its archaic crime and the incest that is unknowing renews	the mystery of the eternal dream of childhood and absorbs us in the	secret.	6.824828964873485
632. but a modern oedipus who is doomed because he cannot oppose	his own childhood is only pathetic and for renouncing the mystery	in favor of psychological truth he gives up the claim on our sympathies.	9.598399176544799
633. i am suggesting that a case-history approach to the oedipus	complex is a blind alley for a storyteller.	11.601168999968012
634. the best gifts of the novelist	will be wasted on the reader who is insulated against any surprises	the novelist may have in store for him.	10.544724327170558
635. incest is still a durable	theme but if it wants to get written about it will have to find ways	to surprise the emotions and there is no better way to do this than	that of concealment and symbolic representation.	12.74703939112169
636. and the best way to	conceal and disguise the elements of an incest story is not to set out	to write an incest story.	15.048640981443661
637. which brings to mind another lawrence story	and some interesting comparisons in the treatment of the oedipal	theme.	11.181456414694594
638. the rocking horse winner is also a story about	a boy's love for his mother.	12.681641678167264
639. if i now risk some comparisons with	sons and lovers let it be clear that i am not comparing the two	works or judging their merits; i am only singling out differences	in treatment of a theme and the resultant effects.	9.19017488816383
640. the rocking horse	winner is a fantasy with extraordinary power to disturb the	reader- but we do not know why.	12.703347892537371
641. it is the story of the hopeless love	of a little boy for his cold and vain mother.	16.7914089684962
642. there are ghostly scenes	in which the little boy on his rocking horse rocks madly toward the	climax that will magically give him the name of the winning horse.	12.29381250034236
643. the	child grows rich on his winnings and conspires with his uncle to make	secret gifts of his money to his mother.	7.811867791937725
644. the story ends in the child's	illness and delirium brought on by the feverish compulsion to	ride his horse to win for his mother.	12.011831693128917
645. the child dies with his mourning	mother at his bedside.	14.001135454550269
646. i had read the story many times without	asking myself why it affected me or caring why it did.	12.188812722439529
647. but on one	occasion when i encountered a similar fantasy in a little boy who was	my patient i began to understand the uncanny effects of this story.	9.786997635652432
648. it was of course a little boy's fantasy of winning his mother to	himself and replacing the father who could not give her the things she	wanted- a classical oedipal fantasy if you like- but if it were	only this the story would be banal.	11.45165471418652
649. why does the story affect us?	15.952050508642948
650.  how	does the rocking exert its uncanny effect upon the reader?	12.04824024138872
651.  the	rocking is actually felt in the story a terrible and ominous rhythm that	prophesies the tragedy.	9.411428944112574
652. the rocking i realized is the single element	in the story that carries the erotic message the unspoken and	unconscious undercurrent that would mar the innocence of a child's fantasy	and disturb the effects of the work if it were made explicit.	9.195692843384133
653. the	rocking has the ambiguous function of keeping the erotic undercurrent	silent and making it present; it conceals and yet is suggestive;	a perfect symbol.	8.330360244553352
654. and if we understand the rocking as an erotic symbol	we can also see how well it serves as the symbol of impending tragedy.	13.496254121584023
655. for this love of the boy for his mother is a hopeless and forbidden	love doomed by its nature.	10.231737216887648
656. we are also struck by the fact	that this story of a boy's love for his mother does not offend while	the incestuous love of the man paul morel sometimes repels.	11.189884979452588
657. it's	easy to see why.	14.19641732877796
658. this love belongs to childhood; we accord it	its place there and in lawrence's treatment we are given the innocent	fantasy of a child in fact the form in which oedipal love is expressed	in childhood.	0.0
659. and when the child dies in lawrence's story	in a delirium that is somehow brought on by his mania to win and to make	his mother rich the manifest absurdity of such a disease and such	a death does not enter into our thoughts at all.	8.632390127456253
660. we have so completely	entered the child's fantasy that his illness and his death are the	plausible and the necessary conclusion.	12.90289743193962
661. i am sure that none	of the effects of this story were consciously employed by lawrence to	describe an oedipal fantasy in childhood.	12.429197351919038
662. it is most probable that	freud and the oedipus complex never entered his head in the writing	of this story.	16.42889741325053
663. he was simply writing a story that wanted to be told	and in the writing a childhood fantasy of his own emerged.	11.89835381965564
664. he would not	have cared why it emerged he only wanted to capture a memory to play	with it again in his imagination and somehow to fix and hold in the	story the disturbing emotions that accompanied the fantasy.	9.370611740371132
665. in	our own time we have seen that the novelist's debt to psychoanalysis	has increased but that the novel itself has not profited much from	this marriage.	8.7752676981046
666. ortega's hope that modern psychology might yet bring	forth a last flowering of the novel has only been partially fulfilled.	9.41376326541715
667. the young writer seems intimidated by psychological knowledge; he	has lost confidence in his own eyes and in the validity of his own psychological	insights.	11.390987133473793
668. he borrows the insights of psychology to improve	his impaired vision but cannot bring to his work the distinctive vision	that should be a novelist's own.	10.927587856149215
669. he has been seduced by the marvels	of the unconscious and has lost interest in studying the surfaces	of character.	11.848121703241244
670. if many of the characters in contemporary novels appear	to be the bloodless relations of characters in a case history it is	because the novelist is often forgetful today that those things that	we call character manifest themselves in surface behavior that the ego	is still the executive agency of personality and that all we know of	personality must be discerned through the ego.	8.770577806168266
671. the novelist who has	been badly baptized in psychoanalysis often gives us the impression that	since all men must have an oedipus complex all men must have the	same faces.	8.095436280654093
672. i have argued that oedipus of the oedipus	complex has a doubtful future as a tragic figure in literature.	12.579454866720571
673. but a	writer who has a taste for irony and who sees incest in all its modern	dimensions can let his imagination work on the disturbing joke in the	incest myth the joke that strikes right at the center of man's humanness.	10.579036320758545
674. moral dread is seen as the other face of desire and here psychoanalysis	delivers to the writer a magnificent irony and a moral problem	of great complexity.	8.700181695682264
675. there is probably some significance	in the fact that two of the best incest stories i have encountered	in recent years are burlesques of the incest myth.	13.402170362948219
676. the ancient types	are reassembled in gloom and foreboding to be irresistibly drawn to their	destinies but the myth fails before the modern truth; the oracle	speaks false and the dream speaks true.	9.294914972676366
677. in both the farmer's tale	in ralph ellison's invisible man and in thomas mann's the	holy sinner the incest hero rises above the myth by accepting	the wish as motive; the heroic act is the casting off of pretense.	8.332281315701803
678. thomas mann wrote the holy sinner in 1951.	13.399906883201648
679. it was conceived	as a leave-taking a kind of melancholy gathering-in of the myths	of the west bevor die nacht sinkt eine lange nacht vielleicht	und ein tiefes vergessen.	10.17925602208184
680. he chose a medieval legend of	incest gregorius vom stein and freely borrowed and parodied other	myths of the west mixing themes language peoples and times in a master	myth in which the old forms continually renew themselves as in his	previous treatment of joseph.	9.425241734613603
681. but the holy sinner is	not simply a retelling of old stories for an old man's entertainment.	11.42787674614598
682. mann understood better than most men the incest comedy at the center	of the myth and the psychological truth in which dread is shown as	the other face as longing was for him just the kind of deep and complicated	joke he liked to tell.	9.058302736879158
683. and when he retold the legend of gregorius	he interpolated a modern version in which the medieval players speak	contemporary thoughts in archaic language; while they move through	the pageantry of the ancient incest myth and cover themselves through	not-knowing they reveal the unconscious motive in seeking each other	and in the last scene make an extraordinary confession of guilt in the	twentieth-century manner.	7.625636134165381
684. grigorss is the child of an incestuous	union between a royal brother and sister the twins sibylla and	wiligis.	10.392461855791495
685. he is born in secrecy after the death of his father and cast	adrift soon after birth.	14.96774598733468
686. the infant is discovered by a fisherman who	brings him home to rear him.	12.010194183656237
687. an ivory tablet in the infant's cask	recounts the story of his sinful origins and is preserved for the child	by the monks of a monastery in the fishing village.	8.384448649902836
688. grigorss at	seventeen learns his story and goes forth as a knight to uncover his	origins.	10.710215524939649
689. his sailing vessel is guided by fate to the shores of his own	country at a time when sibylla's domain is overrun by the armies	of one of her rejected suitors.	9.09154912744501
690. grigorss overcomes the suitor in battle	delivers the city from its oppressors and marries sibylla who had	fallen in love with the beautiful knight the moment she saw him.	8.868590831500464
691. sibylla is pregnant with their second child when she finds the ivory	tablet concealed by her husband and the identities of mother and son	are revealed.	8.185301807500297
692. grigorss goes off to do penance on a rock for seventeen	years.	10.957705180640192
693. at the end of this period two pious christians in rome receive	the revelation which leads them to seek the next pope on the rock.	11.928839656823333
694. grigorss comes to rome and becomes a great and beloved pope.	10.957705180640192
695. in	the last pages of the book sibylla comes to rome to seek an audience	with the great pope and to give her confession.	8.776347839673564
696. mother and son recognize	each other and in mann's version of this legend make a remarkable	confession of guilt to each other the confession of unconscious	motive and unconscious knowledge of their true identities from the	time they had first set eyes on each other.	8.496678298955377
697. in recollection he has said: natural or man-made objects kept coming	into my head but i would suppress them sternly.	10.22158279159855
698. moreover	he organized the movement of his forms within his rigorously shaped space	into highly complex equilibriums; and used gradations of color	value as well as sharply contrasting elementary colors.	9.552891784410386
699. the worthy	mondrian seeing these pictures said in a tone of kindly reproof:	but you are really an artist of the naturalistic tradition!	helion did not realize it at the time but it was true.	10.443262310573198
700. his	monumental abstraction made up of smooth metallic non-objects	acting upon each other with great tension won helion much	acclaim during the 'thirties.	9.969213054681358
701. the play of novel lighting effects also	entered into these compositions whose controlled power and varied	activity made them well worth meditating.	9.190705605346782
702. as helion's work	showed more and more nostalgia for the world of man and nature the pure	abstractionists expressed some disapproval; but leger arp lipchitz	and alexander calder at the time gave him their blessing.	11.566828976010392
703. his	canvases nowadays bore titles frankly declaring them to be figures	in space or blue figure or pink figure; and	they had heads and feet.	7.921237043437305
704. exhibited in shows in london in	1935 and in new york the following year the new more elaborated	abstracts were much favored in the circles of the modernists as three-dimentional	dramas of great intellectual coherence.	9.119645214758153
705. at this period	the thirty-year old helion was ranked as one of the mature leaders	of the modern movement according to herbert read and in the	direct line of descent from cezanne seurat gris and leger.	9.84900580432608
706. in	america meyer schapiro observed that unlike the mondrian school	helion sought a return path to the fullness of nature within the	framework of abstract art.	8.860944413918231
707. it is notable that at this time	he was writing with admiration of cimabue's and poussin's way	of filling space.	11.930157865150644
708. abstract art was still the right path for him; but	he	held instead of continuing as an art of reduction it must grow	must make a place for the contributions of the raphaels and poussins	as well as for those of the early cubists and mondrian.	10.219755157584524
709. later	helion wrote of this phase: for years i built for myself	a subtle instrument of relationships- colors and forms without a name.	8.012715441890187
710. i played on it my secret songs unexplained passionate and peaceful.	13.977553257793254
711. but his own work was evolving further.	17.822137599866455
712. the extreme limitations	he sensed in all current abstract art made that seem to him increasingly	arid and cold.	11.367296473428217
713. he was engaged in constant experiments that	searched for new directions.	15.823820498722922
714. where would it all lead?	19.2245848694212
715.  he himself	did not know as he said in 1935.	14.192444330436182
716. but he was afraid of the future-	he would in fact welcome a way back to social integration a functional	art of some kind.	12.52891744320267
717. during the 1920's the abstractionists	the german bauhaus group of industrial designers and the new	architects all had the dream of some well ordered utopia or welfare	state in which their neat and logical constructions might find their	proper place.	8.144729725976715
718. but whereas the postwar american abstractionists seem	to helion to be determined to escape from the real world or simply	to rebel against it the ordered abstractions which he and his	associates of the 1930's were painting embodied the hope of improving	things.	10.456150759303947
719. we were possessed by visions of a new civilization	to come very pure and elevated he has said in fact some ideal	form of socialism such as we had dreamed of since the war of 1914-1918.	9.636988708405442
720. instead of this the 1930's witnessed a tragic economic	depression the rise of fascist dictators in europe the wasting	civil war in spain.	11.813236666114767
721. very much the political man helion felt himself	deeply affected by the increasingly pessimistic atmosphere of france	and all europe whose foundations seemed to him more and more shaky.	8.95288349247569
722. in 1936 he decided to migrate to america.	19.577093454513435
723. the rooseveltian america	was a haven of liberalism and progress and seemed to him to constitute	the last best hope for civilization.	9.353917450386227
724. helion also hoped that	america's mastery of technology and industrial efficiency would be	accompanied by the production of new and beautiful art works.	9.730278311764925
725. i arrived	in the united states with the idea of establishing myself there	more or less permanently and finding inspiration for new compositions.	11.623488905645031
726. in new york he was well received by what was then only	a small brave band of non-figurative artists including alexander calder	george k l morris de kooning holty and a few others.	12.432761586076928
727. after a year in a studio on sheridan square having married an	american girl who was a native of virginia helion moved to a village	in the blue ridge mountains where he produced some of the most	imposing of his abstract canvases.	9.202928193366178
728. the darkening world scene	at the time of the munich pact continued to trouble his mind even in	his remote virginia studio.	12.407145516226326
729. fear possessed me and the certainty	of war he has related.	11.624782530604882
730. i truly smelled blood death heaps of	corpses everywhere.	16.739551443331074
731. in haste he labored to finish some last abstract	paintings: a three-panel frieze with a flying figure and a fallen	figure; a double-figure which went to the chicago art	institute and is considered by him the most successful of his abstracts;	and in early 1939 a fallen figure of very ominous character	which concluded his abstract phase.	7.816507143109458
732. i knew i was carrying	on with abstraction to its very end- for me he said of the two	years' output in virginia.	11.86405192009562
733. with those paintings of big constructions	crashing down he felt he could stop.	10.998619552217056
734. they were in effect his last	testament to non-objective art.	19.93414474687307
735. he had taken out first papers	for american citizenship; but after war came to europe he decided	to return to france arriving there in january 1940.	9.448571018451105
736. i hated	the war he said but thought i ought to go because i was perhaps	one of those who hadn't done enough to prevent it.	12.653471143773983
737. in june 1940 sergeant helion with a company of reserve troops waiting	to go into battle was sketching the hills south of the loire	river when the war suddenly rolled in upon him.	9.090741842249743
738. its first apparition	was a long gloomy column of refugees riding in farm wagons or pushing	prams.	10.516426501676232
739. his company then carried out a confused retreating movement	until it was surrounded by the germans a few days before france capitulated.	9.508896042057964
740. after a sort of death march during four days without food	helion and his comrades were shipped by cattle-car to a labor camp	at an estate farm in east germany.	10.377546302136379
741. a year later they were removed to	a stalag in the harbor of stettin.	14.3636368027225
742. at the time of his capture helion	had on his person a sketchbook he had bought at woolworth's in	new york.	17.171014241703038
743. when he was stripped deloused and numbered by his guards	his much-thumbed sketchbook was seized and thrown on a pile of prisoners'	goods to be confiscated.	10.108672531479332
744. it was then i knew that they were	making war against man the individual within!- who questioned	things when given orders.	14.03521005725349
745. at stettin the university-educated	artist who had studied german was chosen to serve as interpreter	and clerk in the office of the stalag commander.	11.90190113517412
746. in secret he also	acted as a member of the prisoners' central committee which plotted	sabotage planned a few escapes and maintained a hidden control over	the wretched french slave-laborers.	12.428173694670106
747. in the stalag helion	came to know and love his comrades most of them plain folk who in	their extremity showed true courage and ran great risks to help each	other.	9.516873672712112
748. how much they esteemed him is shown by the fact that their underground	committee selected him as one of the few who would be helped	to escape.	15.873582083878357
749. in the prison camp's black market civilian clothes were	quietly bought and forged papers were devised for him; during long	weeks the plan for his flight was rehearsed.	9.069972709595639
750. every morning	contingents of prisoners would be sent out to labor in nearby factories.	11.727822646441703
751. one evening while a volley-ball game was being played in the yard	among the prisoners remaining there a simulated melee was staged-	just as the gates were opened to admit other prisoners returning from	work.	7.7527755691764675
752. as helion wrote afterward:   their sentry followed	h four hands were stretched toward me by my comrades behind me.	11.05739119427178
753. marquet	held my briefcase; finot held a wallet with my money and papers;	moineau and david held nothing but their fingers h they felt	rough and kind and warm.	7.491016806109364
754. at this moment the volley-ball hit the ground.	24.734425477052994
755. duclos ran toward desprez with fists raised.	11.118618003375188
756. the guards all	rushed up to intervene h   shedding his prison cloak helion	shot through the gates now clad in civilian garments and with the	passport of a flemish worker.	9.28613009907557
757. riding trains hitching hikes on trucks	across germany slipping through guarded frontiers with the help of	secret guides he eventually reached vichy france and by the winter	of 1943 was back in virginia.	8.46947620954903
758. he wrote:   to escape from	a prison camp required a very special state of mind; not only loathing	of captivity but a faith a hope that is even stronger.	8.673600200919685
759. i left	behind me brave men whom captivity had robbed of all hope.	11.39502876035506
760. they too	loved their families longed for their villages: yet lacked the faith	that drove one to dare h the fearful chance of escape.	10.070431970951558
761. it was a time of revelations for him.	27.939830987354394
762. even the most rational of men	under great stress may be transported by a new faith and behave like	mystics.	13.392408914618
763. helion knew that he owed his freedom as much to the self-sacrifice	of his fellow-men in arbeitskommando 13 stettin as to	his own fierce	will and love of life.	8.681689291258845
764. after that he declared to return to	freedom was to fall to one's knees before the real world and adore	it.	11.669574411819653
765. in prison he had been able to sketch nothing but figures from	life his guards his companions in misery.	11.713346667053546
766. now all his desires centered	on rediscovering and singing of the prosaic and yet beautiful	world of men and objects so long barred from me by a barbed wire fence.	9.125868111066753
767. and he added: during the many months in prison camp all	abstract images vanished from my mind.	10.750799557710204
768. before leaving for america	he happened to see his old friend jean arp and confided to	him his new resolutions.	10.815399813654365
769. arp protested: but it is impossible!	everything in the way of representation has already been done by the	old masters.	12.71890112460255
770. helion however clung to the belief that in escaping	from the stalag i had also escaped from abstraction.	11.72739803403208
771. while convalescing in his virginia home he wrote a book recording	his prison experiences and escape entitled: they shall not have	me h published originally in english by dutton	+ co of new york in 1943 the book was received by the press	as a work of astonishing literary power and one of the most realistic	accounts of world war 2 from the french side.	0.0
772. it was very widely	read too; and the author who seemed the embodiment of france's	rising spirit of resistance to her conquerors was much complimented	for his daring military action.	11.619505848077122
773. but when he showed his new figurative	pictures to his artist friends of the abstract camp they paid him	no compliments and drew long faces.	9.803235113315028
774. between 1944 and 1947 helion	had a series of one-man shows- at the paul rosenberg gallery	in new york and in paris- of his new realistic pictures.	11.048026138029497
775. they reincarnated	the figures of human beings banished from his canvases since	the 1920's.	10.98253957699321
776. these new pictures focussed on the familiar and commonplace	objects that he had heard the men in his prison camp talking	about as the things they missed most hence associated with the sense	of lost freedom: the cafe at the corner the newspaper kiosk the girls	in doorways and windows along the street the golden-crusted french	bread they lacked the cigarettes denied them.	8.91449453341488
777. one of the pictures	was of a man with hat drawn over his face ceremoniously lighting a cigarette;	others were of men doffing their hats to each other carrying	umbrellas with pomp reading newspapers or simply showing loaves of	bread spread out.	10.798279002546279
778. important as was mr o'donnell's essay his thesis is	so restricting as to deny faulkner the stature which he obviously has.	9.159936216703418
779. he and also mr cowley and mr warren have fallen to the temptation	which besets many of us to read into our authors- nathaniel	hawthorne for example and herman melville- protests against	modernism material progress and science which are genuine protests of	our own but may not have been theirs.	8.633885691306586
780. faulkner's total works today	and in fact those of his works which existed in 1946 when mr cowley	made his comment or in 1939 when mr o'donnell wrote his	essay reveal no such simple attitude toward the south.	8.649140806869656
781. if he is a	traditionalist he is an eclectic traditionalist.	20.84815796347185
782. if he condemns the	recent or the present he condemns the past with no less force.	14.207112426088159
783. if he	sees the heroic in a sartoris or a sutpen he sees also- and he	shows- the blind and the mean and he sees the compson family disintegrating	from within.	8.459405173172051
784. if the barn-burner's family produces a flem	snopes who personifies commercialism and materialism in hyperbolic	crassness the compson family produces a jason compson 4.	11.255736170072643
785. faulkner	is a most untraditional traditionalist.	12.851133807717682
786. others writing on	faulkner have found the phrase traditional moralist either inadequate	or misleading.	11.909078541408611
787. among them are frederick j hoffman william	van o'connor and mrs olga vickery.	12.540492328654198
788. they have indicated	the direction but they have not been explicit enough i believe in	pointing out faulkner's independence his questioning if not indeed	challenging the southern tradition.	12.153885612188937
789. faulkner's is not the mind	of the apologist which mr o'donnell implies that it is.	9.59112685554823
790. he is	not one to remain more comfortably and unquestioningly within a body	of social cultural or literary traditions than he was within the traditions-	or possibly the regulations- governing his tenure in the	post office at oxford mississippi thirty-five years ago.	8.953845090245515
791. that	is not to deny that he has been aware of traditions of course that	he is steeped in them in fact or that he has dealt with them in	his books.	8.560177264164002
792. it is to say rather i believe that he has brought to bear	on the history the traditions and the lore of his region a critical	skeptical mind- the same mind which has made of him an inveterate	experimenter in literary form and technique.	12.820422423801734
793. he has employed from	his section rich immediate materials which in a loose sense can be termed	southern.	12.031475454603587
794. the fact that he has cast over those materials the light	of a skeptical mind does not make him any the less southern i rather	think for the south has been no more solid than other regions except	in the political and related areas where patronage and force and	intimidation and fear may produce a surface uniformity.	11.80895883433475
795. some of us might	be inclined to argue in fact that an independence of mind and action	and an intolerance of regimentation either mental or physical	are particularly southern traits.	10.162977316714983
796. there is no necessity i suppose	to assert that mr faulkner is southern.	22.13637695185652
797. it would not be	easy to discover a more thoroughly southern pedigree than that of his	family.	17.367478201560075
798. and after all he has lived comfortably at both oxford mississippi	and charlottesville virginia.	14.599563684635566
799. the young william faulkner	in new orleans in the 1920's impressed the novelist hamilton	basso as obviously conscious of being a southerner and there is no	evidence that since then he has ever considered himself any less so.	8.563287258399386
800. besides showing no inclination apparently to absent himself from his	native region even for short periods and in addition writing a shelf	of books set in the region he has handled in those books an astonishingly	complete list of matters which have been important in the south	during the past hundred years.	9.072452968782798
801. it is more difficult with faulkner	than with most authors to say what is the extent and what is	the source of his knowledge.	14.338104196373132
802. his own testimony is that he has read very	little in the history of the south implying that what he knows of	that history has come to him orally and that he knows the world around	him primarily from his own unassisted observation.	12.184057632011994
803. his denials of extensive	reading notwithstanding it is no doubt safe to assume that he	has spent time schooling himself in southern history and that he has	gained some acquaintance with the chief literary authors who have lived	in the south or have written about the south.	8.485414666289675
804. to believe otherwise	would be unrealistic.	20.316658383077467
805. but in looking at faulkner against	his background in mississippi and the south it is important not to	lose the broader perspective.	13.263539781266996
806. his earliest work reflected heavy influences	from english and continental writers.	12.517407265378024
807. evidence is plentiful that	early	and later also he has been indebted to the gothic romancers	who deal in extravagant horror to the symbolists writing at the end	of the preceding century and in particular to the stream-of-consciousness	novelists henry james and james joyce among them.	7.6527640598260716
808. his repeated	experimentation with the techniques of fiction testifies to an independence	of mind and an originality of approach but it also shows him	touching at many points the stream of literary development back of him.	9.307809338405729
809. my intention therefore is not to say that faulkner's awareness	has been confined within the borders of the south but rather that	he has looked at his world as a southerner and that presumably his outlook	is southern.	9.388700322896524
810. the ingredients of faulkner's novels and	stories are by no means new with him and most of the problems he takes	up have had the attention of authors before him.	15.097638234091747
811. a useful comment	on his relation to his region may be made i think by noting briefly	how in handling southern materials and southern problems he has deviated	from the pattern set by other southern authors while remaining	faithful to the essential character of the region.	7.588672080845083
812. the planter	aristocracy has appeared in literature at least since john pendleton	kennedy published swallow-barn in 1832 and in his genial portrait	of frank meriwether presiding over his plantation dominion initiated	the most persistent tradition of southern literature.	9.551276264969097
813. the thoroughgoing	idealization of the planter society did not come however	until after the civil war when southern writers were eager to defend	a way of life which had been destroyed.	10.766568201338114
814. as they looked with nostalgia	to a society which had been swept away they were probably no more	than half-conscious that they painted in colors which had never existed.	10.651204499788054
815. their books found no less willing readers outside than inside the	south even while memories of the war were still sharp.	9.043494076704487
816. the tradition	reached its apex perhaps in the works of thomas nelson page toward	the end of the century and reappeared undiminished as late as 1934	in the best-selling novel so red the rose by stark young.	12.184488135647893
817. although faulkner was the heir in his own family to this tradition	he did not have stark young's inclination to romanticize and sentimentalize	the planter society.	9.432204891602842
818. the myth of the southern plantation	has had only a tangential relation with actuality as francis	pendleton gaines showed forty years ago and i suspect it has had a	far narrower acceptance as something real than has generally been supposed.	10.60288342561383
819. faulkner has found it useful but he has employed it with his	habitual independence of mind and skeptical outlook.	9.845942834363331
820. without saying or	seeming to say that in portraying the sartoris and the compson families	faulkner's chief concern is social criticism we can say nevertheless	that through those families he dramatizes his comment on the	planter dynasties as they have existed since the decades before the civil	war.	8.994238311694115
821. it may be that in this comment he has broken from the conventional	pattern more violently than in any other regard for the treatment	in his books is far removed from even the genial irony of ellen	glasgow who was the only important novelist before him to challenge	the conventional picture of planter society.	9.622913581935327
822. faulkner's low-class	characters had but few counterparts in earlier southern novels	dealing with plantation life.	10.358652090748608
823. they have an ancestry extending back	however at least to 1728 when william byrd described the lubberlanders	he encountered in the back country of virginia and north carolina.	10.87165815776839
824. the chief literary antecedents of the snopes clan appeared in the	realistic humorous writing which originated in the south and the	southwest in the three decades before the civil war.	10.736275290547193
825. these narratives	of coarse action and crude language appeared first in local newspapers	as a rule and later found their way between book covers though	rarely into the planters' libraries beside the morocco-bound volumes	of horace mr addison mr pope and sir walter scott.	7.278872160057525
826. there is evidence to suggest in fact that many authors of the humorous	sketches were prompted to write them- or to make them as indelicate	as they are- by way of protesting against the artificial refinements	which had come to dominate the polite letters of the south.	12.415625704900188
827. william	gilmore simms sturdy realist that he was pleaded for a natural	robustness such as he	found in his favorites the great elizabethans	to vivify the pale writings being produced around him.	7.743550703070935
828. simms admired	the raucous tales emanating from the backwoods but he had himself social	affiliations which would not allow him to approve them fully.	10.433698154769708
829. augustus	baldwin longstreet a preacher and a college and university president	in four southern states published the earliest of these backwoods	sketches and in the character ransy sniffle in the accounts of	sharp horse-trading and eye-gouging physical combat and in the shockingly	unliterary speech of his characters he set an example followed	by many after him.	7.421930747762768
830. others who wrote of low characters and low	life included thomas bangs thorpe creator of the big bear of arkansas	and tom owen the bee-hunter; johnson jones hooper whose	character simon suggs bears a close kinship to flem snopes in	both his willingness to take cruel advantage of all and sundry and the	sharpness with which he habitually carried out his will; and george	washington harris whose tennessee hillbilly character sut lovingood	perpetrated more unmalicious mischief and more unintended pain	than any other character in literature.	8.218745688065384
831. it would be profitable i believe	to read these realistic humorists alongside faulkner's works	the thought being not that he necessarily read them and owed anything	to them directly but rather that they dealt a hundred years ago with	a class of people and a type of life which have continued down to our	time to faulkner's time.	8.6519335470365
832. such a comparison reminds us that in employing	low characters in his works faulkner is recording actuality	in the south and moreover is following a long-established literary precedent.	10.33302596488572
833. such characters with their low existence and often low morality	produce humorous effects in his novels and tales as they did in	the writing of longstreet and hooper and harris but it need not be	added that he gives them far subtler and more intricate functions than	they had in the earlier writers; nor is there need to add that among	them are some of the most highly individualized and most successful	of his characters.	7.859092041911255
834. one of the early humorists already mentioned	thomas bangs thorpe can be used to illustrate another point	where faulkner touches authentic southern materials and also earlier	literary treatment of those materials.	14.528676825775833
835. thorpe came to louisiana from	the east as a young man prepared to find in the new country the setting	of romantic adventure and idealized beauty.	9.720910701527535
836. but thorpe saw also	the hardships of pioneer existence the cultural poverty of the frontier	settlements and the slack morality which abounded in the new regions.	10.781154151808089
837. as a consequence of the tensions thus produced in his thoughts and	feelings he wrote on the one hand sketches of idealized hunting trips	and on the other an anecdote of the village of hardscrabble arkansas	where no one had ever seen a piano; and he wrote also the masterpiece	of frontier humor the big bear of arkansas in which	earthy realism is placed alongside the exaggeration of the backwoods	tall-tale and the awe with which man contemplates the grandeur and the	mysteries of nature.	8.148801414635306
838. some years ago julian huxley proposed to an audience made	up of members of the british association for the advancement of	science that man's supernormal or extra-sensory faculties are now	in the same case as were his mathematical faculties during the ice	age.	10.282745044528713
839. as a humanist dr huxley interests himself in the possibilities	of human development and one thing we can say about this	suggestion which comes from a leading zoologist is that so far as he	is concerned the scientific outlook places no rigid limitation upon	the idea of future human evolution.	8.819577019403038
840. this text from dr huxley	is sometimes used by enthusiasts to indicate that they have the permission	of the scientists to press the case for a wonderful unfoldment	of psychic powers in human beings.	11.875532373786843
841. there may be a case of this sort	but it is not one we wish to argue here.	18.010408348397167
842. even if people do in a	not far distant future begin to read one another's minds there will	still be the question of whether what you find in another man's mind	is especially worth reading- worth more that is than what you can	read in good books.	9.380435517062025
843. even if men eventually find themselves able to	look through walls and around corners one may question whether this	will help them to live better lives.	9.461804672512063
844. there would be side-conclusions	to be drawn of course; such capacities are impressive evidence pointing	to a conception of the human being which does not appear in the accounts	of biologists and organic evolutionists; but the basic puzzles	of existence would still be puzzling and we should still have to work	out the sort of problems we plan to discuss in this article.	10.372308996033029

846. it seems quite obvious that all the really difficult tasks of human	beings arise from the fact that man is not one but many.	17.36903978166056
847. each man	that is is both one and many.	12.141006964183084
848. he is a dreamer of the good society with	a plan to put into effect and he is an individual craftsman with	something to make for himself and the people of his time.	15.432078547501128
849. he is a parent	with a child to nurture here and now and he is an educator who worries	about the children half way round the world.	11.617320431694937
850. he is a utopian with	a stake in tomorrow and he is a vulnerable human made captive by the	circumstances of today.	15.384704026908588
851. he can sacrifice himself for tomorrow and	he can sacrifice tomorrow for himself.	12.699678478708153
852. he is a craig's wife who agonizes	about tobacco ash on the living room rug and he is a forgetful	genius who goes boating with the town baker when dignitaries from the	local university have come to call.	12.56899629194557
853. he is the stern guardian of the status	quo who has raised the utilitarian structures of the age and he	is the revolutionary poet with a gun in his hand who writes a tragic	apologetic to posterity for the men he has killed.	10.609445525231731
854. what will be	the final symmetry of the good society?	15.838330233706856
855.  for what do the utopians	labor?	18.089283221630154
856.  here on a desk is a stack of pamphlets representing the efforts	of some of the best men of the day to penetrate these questions.	15.227482228621364
857. the pamphlets are about law the corporation forms of government the	idea of freedom the defense of liberty the various lethargies which	overtake our major institutions the gap between traditional social	ideals and the working mechanisms that have been set in motion for their	realization.	7.708696617364773
858. the thing that is notable in all these discussions is	the lack of ideological ardor.	15.584737040554824
859. there is another kind of ardor a quiet	sure devotion to the fundamental decencies of human life but no	angry utopian contentions.	12.302046881483125
