864. a characteristic expression of such concern	and inquiry is found in joseph p lyford's introduction to the	agreeable autocracies a recent paperback study of the institutions	of modern democratic society.	10.56206916353871
865. mr lyford gives voice to a temper	that represents we think an achieved plateau of reflective thinking.	9.209486886273746
866. after casting about for a way of describing this spirit we decided	that it would be better to use mr lyford's introduction as	an illustration.	12.199696282190114
867. he begins:   at one time it seemed as if	the soviet union had done us a favor by providing a striking example	of how not to behave towards other peoples and other nations.	9.073294780237223
868. as	things turned out however we have not profited greatly from the lesson:	instead of persistently following a national program of our own	we have often been satisfied to be against whatever soviet policy seemed	to be at the moment.	9.083423652774396
869. such activity may or may not have irritated	the kremlin but it has frequently condemned america to an unnatural	defensiveness that has undermined our effort to give leadership to the	free world.	10.234686030898159
870. the defensiveness has been exaggerated by another	bad habit our tendency to rate the goodness or badness	of other nations by the extent to which they applaud the slogans we circulate	about ourselves.	10.549985041917255
871. since the slogans have little application to	reality and are sanctimonious to boot the applause is faint even in areas	of the world where we should expect to find the greatest affection	for free government.	8.567686394307866
872. shocked at the response to our proclamations	we grow more defensive and worse we lose our sense of humor and proportion.	11.04027719297576
873. mr nehru is subjected to stern lectures on neutralism by	our department of state and an american president observes sourly	that sweden would be a little less neurotic if it were a little more	capitalistic.	9.39962668503266
874. one thing you can say about mr lyford is	that he does not suffer from any insecurity as an american.	14.342991133573655
875. those	who are insecure fear to be candid in self-examination.	11.672239317009712
876. only the strong	look squarely at weakness.	21.252153568900752
877. the maturity in this point of view lies	in its recognition that no basic problem is ever solved without being	clearly understood.	9.923870435782753
878. mr lyford continues:   even if the	self portrait we distribute for popular consumption were accurate it	would be dangerous to present it as a picture of the ideal society.	10.711179043756891
879. we	would be ignoring the special circumstances of other countries.	10.057988591011652
880. the	picture is the more treacherous when it misrepresents the facts of american	life.	13.134257968474927
881. the discrepancy between what we commonly profess and what	we practice or tolerate is great and it does not escape the notice	of others.	9.48488101319057
882. if our sincerity is granted and it is granted the discrepancy	can only be explained by the fact that we have come to believe	hearsay and legend about ourselves in preference to an understanding	gained by earnest self-examination.	13.350031974507013
883. what is more the legends have become	so sacrosanct that the very habit of self-examination or self-criticism	smells of low treason and men who practice it are defeatists and	unpatriotic scoundrels.	9.42139065211706
884. h although we continue to pay our	conversational devotions to free private enterprise individual	initiative the democratic way government of the people	competition of the marketplace etc we live rather comfortably	in a society in which economic competition is diminishing in	large areas bureaucracy is corroding representative government technology	is weakening the citizen's confidence in his own power to make	decisions and the threat of war is driving him economically and physically	into the ground.	8.700729746365928
885. the interesting thing about mr	lyford's approach and the approach of the contributors to the	agreeable autocracies to the situation	of american civilization is that it is concerned with comprehending	the psychological relationships which are having a decisive effect	on american life.	9.766290105541161
886. in an ideological argument the participants tend	to thump the table.	16.639086177834077
887. they are determined to prove something.	27.45870445310963
888. the	new spirit so well illustrated by mr lyford's work is wholly	free of this anxiety.	10.204371885396943
889. the problem is rather to find out what is actually	happening and this is especially difficult for the reason that we	are busily being defended from a knowledge of the present sometimes	by the very agencies- our educational system our mass media our	statesmen- on which we have had to rely most heavily for understanding	of ourselves.	11.524722143214541
890. the introduction continues:   we experience	a vague uneasiness about events a suspicion that our political	and economic institutions like the genie in the bottle have escaped	confinement and that we have lost the power to recall them.	10.241997532461724
891. we feel	uncomfortable at being bossed by a corporation or a union or a television	set but until we have some knowledge about these phenomena and	what they are doing to us we can hardly learn to control them.	8.138924878439626

893. the agreeable autocracies	is an attempt to explore some of the institutions which both reflect	and determine the character of the free society today.	11.66525071422639
894. the men who	speculate on these institutions have for the most part come to at least	one common conclusion: that many of the great enterprises and associations	around which our democracy is formed are in themselves autocratic	in nature and possessed of power which can be used to frustrate	the citizen who is trying to assert his individuality in the modern	world.	12.103102659301179
895. these institutions which mr lyford names agreeable	autocracies- where did they come from?	10.100086864412003
896.  of one thing we	can be sure: they were not sketched out by the revolutionary theorists	of the eighteenth century who formulated the political principles	and originally shaped the political institutions of what we term the free	society.	10.645021782914112
897. no doubt there are historians who can explain to a	great extent what happened to the plans and projects of the eighteenth	century.	11.078218343349032
898. going back over this ground and analyzing the composition	of forces which have created the present scene is one of the tasks undertaken	by the center for the study of democratic institutions in	santa barbara.	12.52015030025825
899. but however we come finally to explain and account	for the present the truth we are trying to expose right now is that	the makers of constitutions and the designers of institutions find	it difficult if not impossible to anticipate the behavior of the host	of all their enterprises.	7.838894742689819
900. the host is the flowing life of the human race.	18.926003981872626
901. this life has its own currents and rhythms its own multiple cycles	and adaptations.	10.795142792559794
902. on occasion it produces extraordinary novelties.	20.051102976987014
903. should rousseau have been able to leave room in his social theory	for the advent of television atomic energy and ibm machines?	9.504486635221678
904. 	how would thomas jefferson feel after reading factories in the	field?	11.33819267263277
905.  they tell us sir that we are free because we have in one	hand a ballot and in the other a stock certificate.	13.231063447258167
906. with these we	shape our destiny and own private property and that sir makes ours	the best of all possible societies.	12.747603711644329
907. the reality of the situation however	is described by mr lyford:   many of us may even	be secretly relieved at having a plausible excuse to delegate ancient	civic responsibilities to a new bureaucracy of experts.	10.673243094692772
908. thus the member	of an industrial union comes to regard his officers as business	agents who may proceed without interference or recall; the stockholder	delivers his proxy; and the citizen narrows his political participation	to the mere act of voting- if he votes at all.	8.73776155659174
909. copernicus did not question it ptolemy could not.	10.530932308755343
910. given the conceptual	context within which ancient thought thrived how could anyone have	questioned this principle?	11.486185329148212
911.  the reasons for this are partly observational	partly philosophical and reinforced by other aesthetic and	cultural factors.	0.0
912. the obvious	natural fact to ancient thinkers was the diurnal rotation of the	heavens.	12.445450562798397
913. not only did constellations like draco cepheus and cassiopeia	spin circles around the pole but stars which were not circumpolar	rose and set at the same place on the horizon each night.	9.269624121870203
914. nor did	a constellation's stars vary in brightness during the course of their	nocturnal flights.	14.041362749953795
915. the conclusion- the distances of the constellations	did not vary and their paths were circular.	9.923610580026844
916. moreover the sun's	path over earth described a segment of a great circle; this was	clear from the contour of the shadow traced by a gnomon before and after	noon.	10.262519220020877
917. as early as the 6th century bc the earth	was seen to be spherical.	14.154408351131273
918. ships disappear hull-first over the horizon;	approaching shore their masts appeared first.	10.957705180640192
919. earth being at	the center of the universe would have the same shape as the latter;	so eg did aristotle argue although this may not be an observational	reason in favor of circularity.	11.316093563972716
920. the discoid shapes of	sun and moon were also felt to indicate the shape of celestial things.	13.44956000297554
921. in light of all this one would require special reasons for	saying that the paths of the heavenly bodies were other than circular.	10.005214732009838
922. why for example should the ancients have supposed the diurnal rotation	of the heavens to be elliptical?	11.817214040116216
923.  or oviform?	25.961705577610427
924.  or angular?	30.44183203064129
925. 	there were no reasons for such suppositions then.	10.530932308755343
926. this conjoined	with the considerations above made the circular motions of heavenly	bodies appear an almost directly observed fact.	10.940520249915352
927. additional philosophical	considerations advanced notably by aristotle supported further	the circularity principle.	10.28439750487086
928. by distinguishing superlunary	and sublunary existence and reinforcing this with	the four-element physics of empedocles aristotle came to speak of	the stars as perfect bodies which moved in only a perfect way viz	in a perfect circle.	8.910140641450697
929. now what is perfect motion?	16.5381575797386
930.  it must	apparently be motion without termini.	23.729432886271383
931. because motion which begins and	ends at discrete places would be incomplete.	11.992542053365437
932. circular motion however since it is eternal and perfectly continuous	lacks termini.	13.094705794367433
933. it is never motion towards something.	29.999633864088118
934. only imcomplete	imperfect things move towards what they lack.	15.13750041235544
935. perfect complete	entities if they move at all do not move towards what they lack.	10.557230476263664
936. they move only in accordance with what is in their natures.	20.571306028009726
937. thus circular	motion is itself one of the essential characteristics of completely	perfect celestial existence.	11.504233005732154
938. to return now to the four-element	physics a mixture of muddy frothy water will when standing in	a jar separate out with earth at the bottom water on top and the	air on top of that.	11.129260105793302
939. a candle alight in the air directs its flame and	smoke upwards.	12.187205796510757
940. this gives a clue to the cosmical order of elements.	19.689201935790898
941. thus earth has fallen to the center of the universe.	18.58423002023878
942. it is covered	with water air is atop of that.	23.061826067636904
943. pure fire is in	the heavens.	12.851133807717682
944. when combined with the metaphysical notion that pure forms	of this universe are best appreciated when least embodied in a material	substratum it becomes clear that while earth will be dross on a	scale of material-formal ratios celestial bodies will be of a subtle	quickened ethereal existence in whose embodiment pure form will be	the dominant component and matter will be absent or remain subsidiary.	8.66183752734138
945. the stars constitute an order of existence different from what	we encounter on earth.	10.890343919578495
946. this is clear when one distinguishes the types	of motion appropriate to both regions.	15.5513439616328
947. a projectile shot up from earth	returns rectlinearly to its 'natural' place of rest.	9.966061740790925
948. but the	natural condition for the heavenly bodies is neither rest nor rectilinear	motion.	14.415712260916205
949. being less encumbered by material embodiments they partake	more of what is divine.	11.512228928699907
950. their motion will be eternal and perfect.	14.39488340464845
951. let us re-examine the publicized contrasts between ptolemaic	and copernican astronomy.	13.8561624543094
952. bluntly there never was a ptolemaic system	of astronomy.	12.3482207866056
953. copernicus' achievement was to have invented	systematic astronomy.	13.76415303011198
954. the almagest and the hypotheses outline	ptolemy's conception of his own task as the provision of computational	tables independent calculating devices for the prediction	of future planetary perturbations.	10.06134916292793
955. indeed in the halma edition of theon's	presentation of the hypotheses there is a chart setting	out otherwise unrelated diagrams for describing	the planetary motions.	9.087952781789342
956. no attempt is made by ptolemy to weld	into a single scheme these independent predicting-machines.	12.082610142849163
957. they all have this in common: the earth is situated	near the center of the deferent.	14.045194889584856
958. but that one should superimpose all	these charts run a pin through the common point and then scale each	planetary deferent larger and smaller	this is contrary to any intention ptolemy ever expresses.	10.135299254943483
959. he might even suppose the planets to move at infinity.	14.608277612379107
960. ptolemy's	problem is to forecast where against the inverted bowl of night some	particular light will be found at future times.	9.501504478359598
961. his problem concerns	longitudes latitudes and angular velocities.	12.610740830014443
962. the distances of these	points of light is a problem he cannot master beyond crude conjectures	as to the orderings of the planetary orbits viewed outward from earth.	10.151943416599801
963. but none of this has prevented scientists philosophers and even	historians of science from speaking of the ptolemaic system in	contrast to the copernican.	9.943559043260201
964. it is engendered by	confounding the aristotelian cosmology in the almagest with the	geocentric astronomy.	17.298960344313976
965. ptolemy recurrently denies that he could	ever explain planetary motion.	10.057988591011652
966. this is what necessitates the nonsystematic	character of his astronomy.	23.263905732124034
967. so when textbooks like that	of baker set out drawings of the 'ptolemaic system' complete	with earth in the center and the seven heavenly bodies epicyclically arranged	on their several deferents we have nothing but a misleading 20th-century	idea of what never existed historically.	8.58104873048367
968. it is	the chief merit in copernicus' work that all his planetary calculations	are interdependent.	14.69272383905615
969. he cannot eg compute the retrograde	arc traveled by mars without also making suppositions about the	earth's own motion.	10.200963639264403
970. he cannot describe eclipses without entertaining	some form of	a three-body problem.	15.870035203704841
971. in ptolemaic terms however eclipses	and retrograde motion were phenomena simpliciter to be explained	directly as possible resultants of epicyclical combinations.	9.360495243822294
972. in a	systematic astronomy like that of copernicus retrogradations become	part of the conceptual structure of the system; they are no longer	a puzzling aspect of intricately variable local planetary motions.	11.400204365805086
973. another contrast stressed when discussing ptolemaic vs	copernican astronomy turns on the idea of simplicity.	11.558390176802149
974. it is often	stated that copernican astronomy is 'simpler' than ptolemaic.	21.134190031152382
975. some even say that this is the reason for the ultimate acceptance of	the former.	19.146648940761978
976. thus margenau remarks: a large number of unrelated	epicycles was needed to explain the observations but otherwise the	ptolemaic system served well and with quantitative precision.	12.295689919677812
977. copernicus	by placing the sun at the center of the planetary universe	was able to reduce the number of epicycles from eighty-three to seventeen.	14.425443320762508
978. historical records indicate that copernicus was unaware of the	fundamental aspects of his so-called 'revolution' unaware perhaps	of its historical importance he rested content with having produced	a simpler scheme for prediction.	8.482247297478708
979. as an illustration of the principle	of simplicity the heliocentric discovery has a peculiar appeal because	it allows simplicity to be arithmetized; it involves a reduction	in the number of epicycles from eighty-three to seventeen.	9.38836837677288
980. without careful qualification this can be misleading.	17.073061919935167
981. if in any one	calculation ptolemy had had to invoke 83 epicycles all at once	while copernicus never required more than one third this number then	ptolemaic astronomy would be simpler	than copernican.	9.621356228029107
982. but no single planetary problem ever required	of ptolemy more than six epicycles at one time.	13.056297168426227
983. this of course results	from the non-systematic 'cellular' character of ptolemaic	theory.	15.045086802071664
984. calculations within the copernican framework always raised questions	about planetary configurations.	11.33819267263277
985. these could be met only by considering	the dynamical elements of several planets at one time.	10.050802006624581
986. this	is more ambitious than ptolemy is ever required to be when he faces	his isolated problems.	11.232850909607327
987. thus in no ordinary sense of 'simplicity'	is the ptolemaic theory simpler than the copernican.	11.498148176062141
988. the latter required	juggling several elements simultaneously.	21.60616976697304
989. this was not simpler	but much more difficult than exercises within ptolemy's astronomy.	14.534764959644006
990. analogously anyone who argues that einstein's theory of	gravitation is simpler than newton's must say rather more to explain	how it is that the latter is mastered by student-physicists while	the former can be managed only by accomplished experts.	9.52455970073556
991. in a sense einstein's theory is simpler than newton's	and there is a corresponding sense in which copernicus' theory	is simpler than ptolemy's.	12.05394956235242
992. but 'simplicity' here refers to	systematic simplicity.	20.586081728985903
993. the number of primitive ideas in systematically-simple	theories is reduced to a minimum.	16.776711103964328
994. the axioms required to	make the theoretical machinery operate are set out tersely and powerfully	so that all permissible operations within the theory can be traced	rigorously back to these axioms rules and primitive notions.	8.891886196032393
995. this	characterizes euclid's formulation of geometry but not ptolemy's	astronomy.	10.530932308755343
996. there are in the almagest no rules for determining	in advance whether a new epicycle will be required for dealing with	abberations in lunar solar or planetary behavior.	13.61524686624641
997. the strongest	appeal of the copernican formulation consisted in just this: ideally	the justification for dealing with special problems in particular	ways is completely set out in the basic 'rules' of the theory.	8.719096024778251
998. the	lower-level hypotheses are never 'ad hoc' never introduced ex	post facto just to sweep up within the theory some recalcitrant datum.	9.159936216703418
999. copernicus to an extent unachieved by ptolemy approximated to	euclid's vision.	9.964895422211068
1000. de revolutionibus is not just a collection of	facts and techniques.	11.596445149948742
1001. it is an organized system of these things.	24.413779695661123
1002. solving	astronomical problems requires for copernicus not a random search	of unrelated tables but a regular employment of the rules defining	the entire discipline.	9.051154372622117
1003. hence noting the simplicity achieved	in copernicus' formulation does not provide another reason for	the acceptance of de revolutionibus another reason beyond its	systematic superiority.	8.28492014882349
1004. it provides exactly the same reason.	33.33999471958268
1005. 1543 ad is often venerated as the birthday of the scientific	revolution.	9.345058977386529
1006. it is really the funeral day of scholastic science.	24.01992799423903
1007. granted	the cosmological philosophical and cultural reverberations	initiated by the de revolutionibus were felt with increasing violence	during the 300 years to follow.	7.811867791937725
1008. but considered within technical	astronomy a different pattern can be traced.	14.997980485393471
1009. in what does the	dissatisfaction of copernicus-the-astronomer consist?	18.85751301149178
1010.  what in the	almagest draws his fire?	20.959134280836253
1011.  geocentricism per se?	16.13502295689442
1012.  no.	28.49691246350829
1013. the	formal displacement of the geocentric principle far from being copernicus'	primary concern was introduced only to resolve what seemed	to him intolerable in orthodox astronomy namely the 'unphysical'	triplication of centric reference-points: one center from which	the planet's distances were calculated another around which planetary	velocities were computed and still a third center from	which the observations originated.	6.87477534737257
1014. this arrangement was for copernicus	literally monstrous: with the ptolemaists it is as though	an artist were to gather the hands feet head and other members	for his images from divers models each part excellently drawn but not	related to a single body; and since they in no way match each other	the result would be a monster rather than a man.	9.023829952863872
1015. copernicus	required a systematically integrated physically intelligible astronomy.	11.118618003375188
1016. his objective was essentially to repair those aspects of orthodox	astronomy responsible for its deficiencies in achieving these ends.	10.02372951974057
1017. that such deficiencies existed within ptolemy's theory was not	discovered de novo by copernicus.	11.087096821797813
1018. the critical rigorous examinations	of nicholas of cusa and nicholas of oresme provided the context	for nicholas copernicus' own work.	10.551876137849225
1019. the latter looked backward upon inherited deficiencies.	16.586996006267984
1020. without abandoning	too much copernicus sought to make orthodox astronomy systematically	and mechanically acceptable.	11.43900460802661
1021. he did not think himself to be	firing the first shot of an intellectual revolution.	14.223006558004323
1022. henrietta's feeling of identity with sara sullam was crowned by her	discovery of the coincidence that sara's epitaph in the jewish	cemetery in venice referred to her as the sulamite.	9.004182265081264
1023. into	the texture of this tapestry of history and human drama henrietta	as every artist delights to do wove strands of her own intuitive insights	into human nature and-	especially in the remarkable story of the	attraction and conflict between two so disparate and fervent characters	as this pair- into the relations of men and women: in their	relations she was the giver and he the receiver nay the demander.	6.794092412040163
1024. his	feeling always exacted sacrifices from her.	13.915190642667962

1029. she was exposing herself to temptation which it is best to avoid where	it can consistently be done.	12.36045892157295
1030. one who invites such trials of character	is either foolhardy overconfident or too simple and childlike in faith	in mankind to see the danger.	11.729815010088274
1031. in any case but the last such a course	is sure to avenge itself upon the individual; the moral powers	no more than the physical and mental can bear overstraining.	10.675597249319734
1032. and in	the last case a bitter disappointment but too often meets the confiding	nature h.	11.923800709004192

1666. of all the whig tracts	written in support of the succession the crisis is perhaps the	most significant.	16.90255195904177

1671. in his comment on these laws steele sounds all the usual notes	of current whig propaganda ranging from a criticism of the tory	peace to an attack on the dismissal of marlborough; but his principal	theme is that the intrigues of the tories our popish or jacobite	party pose an immediate threat to church and state.	7.769603983825712

2021. the coolidges	did not always live at the white house during the presidency.	13.236282074577105
2022. impressive as this enumeration is it barely hints at the diverse	perceptions of jews collectively or individually that have been	attested by their gentile environment.	8.860944413918231
2023. it is reasonable to affirm	two propositions: jews have been perceived by non-jews as all things	to all men; some jews have in fact been all things to all men.	9.520180383645625
2024. in the arena of power jews have at one time or another been somebody's	ally; they have observed correct neutrality; they have been	someone's enemy.	13.131855704531944

2026. and so on through the roles referred	to in the previous paragraph.	0.0
2027. diversity of perception yes; diversity	of fact yes.	11.118618003375188
2028. but the two do not invariably or even	typically coincide.	18.29952855112787
2029. the conventional image of a particular time	and place is not necessarily congruent with the image of the facts as	established over the years by scholarly and scientific research.	11.661724051271445
2030. conventional	images of jews have this in common with all perceptions of	a configuration in which one feature is held constant: images can be	both true and false.	9.540570909812432
2031. the genuinely interesting question then	becomes: what factors determine the degree of realism or distortion	in conventional images of jews?	9.794120749425755
2032.  the working test of the facts	must always be the best available description obtainable from scholars	and scientists who have applied their methods of investigation	to relevant situations.	10.089625932131222
2033. granted such functional images are subject	to human error; they are self-correcting in the sense that they	are subject to disciplined procedures that check and recheck against	error.	9.46143476615998
2034. in accounting for realism or distortion two sets of factors	can be usefully distinguished: current intelligence; predispositions	regarding intelligence.	12.926445785331156
2035. general grant may have been the victim	of false information in the instance reported in this book; if so	he would not be the first or last commanding officer who has succumbed	to bad information and dubious estimates of the future.	8.613668109696762
2036. but general	grant may have been self-victimized.	24.351763663856342
2037. he may have entered the situation	with predispositions that prepared him to act uncritically in the	press of affairs.	11.680197241145525
2038. predispositions in turn fall conveniently	into two categories for purposes of analysis.	10.957705180640192
2039. to some extent predispositions	are shaped by exposure to group environments.	13.852310841101138
2040. in some measure	they depend upon the structure of individual personality.	19.60058864015781
2041. the anti-semitism	of hitler owed something to his exposure to the ideology of	lueger's politically successful christian socialist movement in vienna.	9.193648379736588
2042. but millions of human beings were exposed to lueger's propaganda	and record.	14.226867914495054
2043. after allowing for group exposures it is apparent	that other factors must be considered if we are to comprehend fanaticism.	10.976319013232885
2044. these are personality factors; they include harmonies and conflicts	within the whole man and mechanisms whereby inner components are	more or less smoothly met.	10.195876024295437
2045. modern psychiatric knowledge provides us	with many keys to unlock the significance of behavior of the kind.	10.279379573124546
2046. the foregoing factors are pertinent to the analysis of perceptual	images and the broad conditions under which they achieve realism or	fall short of it.	9.725942325839862
2047. undoubtedly one merit of the vast panorama of gentile	conceptions of the jew unfolded in the present anthology is that	it provides a formidable body of material that invites critical examination	in terms of reality.	8.143426793487734

2051. since we can neither undo nor redo the	past we are limited to the events of today and tomorrow.	11.55513244158896
2052. in this	domain the simple fact of coexistence in the same local national and	world community is enough to guarantee that we cannot refrain from having	some effect large or small upon gentile-jewish relations.	10.276770013449559
2053. what	shall these effects be?	14.19641732877796
2054.    i am deliberately raising the policy	problems involved in gentile-jewish relations.	16.75575887611948
2055. comprehensive examination	of any policy question calls for the performance of the intellectual	tasks inseparable from any problem-solving method.	9.296876526093957
2056. the tasks	are briefly indicated by these questions: what are my goals in gentile-jewish	relations?	12.010194183656237
2057.  what are the historical trends in this country	and abroad in the extent to which these goals are effectively realized?	11.854905706284326
2058. 	what factors condition the degree of realization at various	times and places?	12.406630128670246
2059.  what is the probable course of future developments?	20.16896080255446
2060. 	what policies if adopted and applied in various circumstances will	increase the likelihood that future events will coincide with desired	events and do so at least cost in terms of all human values?	9.14223364994142
2061. 	it is beyond the province of this epilogue to cover policy questions	of such depth and range.	8.666718734744567

2063. as a groundwork for the proposal	i give some attention to the first task enumerated above the clarification	of goal.	12.410631656240543
2064. my reply is that i associate myself with	all those who affirm that gentile-jewish relations should contribute	to the theory and practice of human dignity.	9.270500861711284
2065. the basic goal finds partial	expression in the universal declaration of human rights a statement	initiated and endorsed by individuals and organizations of many	religious and philosophical traditions.	8.500823240940065
2066. within this frame of	reference policies appropriate to claims advanced in the name of the	jews depend upon which jewish identity is involved as well as upon	the nature of the claim the characteristics of the claimant the justifications	proposed and the predispositions of the community decision	makers who are called upon to act.	10.13516969476369
2067. if jews are identified as a religious	body in a controversy that comes before a national or international	tribunal it is obviously compatible with the goal of human dignity	to protect freedom of worship.	8.638500136821978
2068. when decision makers act within this	frame they determine whether a claim put forward in the name of religion	is to be accepted by the larger community as appropriate to religion.	10.683553895517223
2069. since the recognition of israel as a nation state claims are made	in many cases which identify the claimant as a member of the new body	politic.	12.3146435624379

2071. in free countries	many controversies involve self-styled jews who use the symbol in asserting	a vaguely cultural rather than religious or political identity.	9.336556360250325
2072. the decision maker who acts for the community as a whole must	decide whether the objectives pursued and the methods used are appropriate	to public policy regarding cultural groups.	10.616643627227548
2073. we know that	much is made of the multiplicity and ambiguity of the identities that	cluster around the key symbol of the jew.	11.407447019810268

2078. it	is not implied that formal principles and procedures are so firmly entrenched	within the public order of the world community or even of free	commonwealths that they will control in all circumstances involving jews	and gentiles during coming years.	11.203525767883386
2079. social process is always anchored	in past predisposition; but it is perennially restructured in situations	where anchors are dragged or lost.	9.404722337810972
2080. in conformance with the	maximization principle we affirm that gentile-jewish relations will	be harmonious or inharmonious to the degree that one relation or the	other is expected by the active participants to yield the greatest net	advantage taking all value outcomes and effects into consideration.	9.105105527264515

2083. when we consider the disorganized	state of the world community and the legacy of predispositions adversely	directed against all who are identified as jews it is obvious	that the struggle for the minds and muscles of men needs to be prosecuted	with increasing vigor and skill.	10.20638083148911
2084. during moments of intense crisis	the responsibility of political leaders is overwhelming.	14.718685504484396
2085. but their	freedom of policy is limited by the pattern of predisposition with which	they and the people around them enter the crisis.	10.715931732786816
2086. at such critical	moments predispositions favorable to human dignity most obviously pay	off.	14.054695083469458
2087. by the same test predispositions destructive of human personality	exercise their most sinister impact with the result that men	of good will are often trapped and nullified.	10.50397572013082
2088. among measures	in anticipation of crisis are plans to inject into the turmoil as assistants	of key decision makers qualified persons who are cognizant of	the corrosive effect of crisis upon personal relationships and are also	able to raise calm and realistic voices when overburdened leaders near	the limit of self-control.	8.358583378157935
2089. we are learning how to do these things	in some of the vast organized structures of modern society; the process	can be accelerated.	11.245660573504429

2093. now an abiding	difficulty of paragraphs like the foregoing is that they appear to preach;	and in contemporary society we often complain of too much reaffirmation	of the goodness of the good.	8.403014917931925

2096. properly used the present book is an excellent instrument	of enlightenment.	11.664882534919581

2127. this is in large part a code	of behavior and a glossary of values: what is it that people do and	should do and how one should regard it.	11.809378876254994

2137. one of the most salient features	of literary value has been deemed to be its influence upon and	organization of emotion.	13.469197339558411
2138. let us differentiate a few of these ideas.	27.458102683304435
2139. the	aristotelian notion of catharsis the purging of emotion is a persistent	and viable one.	8.834168570742513

2145. fsc	northrop in his discussion of the functions and future	of poetry suggests this: one of the things which makes	our lives drab and empty and which leaves us at the end of the day	fatigued and deflated spiritually is the pressure of the taxing practical	utilitarian concern of common-sense objects.	10.058609489725775

2150. but there is one in particular which it seems	to me deserves special attention.	24.858000061336103
2151. in the wide range of experiences	common to our earth-bound race none is more difficult to manage more	troublesome and more enduring in its effects than the control of love	and hate.	9.7569516262012

2153. william wimsatt and cleanth brooks it seems to me have	a penetrating insight into the way in which this control is effected:	for if we say poetry is to talk of beauty and love	and if it is to talk of anger and murder	- then it may be that the poetic way of dealing	with these emotions will not be any kind of intensification compounding	or magnification or any direct assault upon the affections	at all.	9.090385998936402
2154. something indirect mixed reconciling tensional might well	be the strategem the devious technique by which a poet indulged in all	kinds of talk about love and anger and even in something like expressions	of these emotions without aiming at their incitement or	even uttering anything that essentially involves their incitement.	8.9124997295217

2158. there is a second feature of the influences	of literature good literature on emotional life which may have	some special value for our time.	15.238464298499714

2160. perhaps it is only an analogy but one of the most	obvious differences between cheap fiction and fiction of an enduring	quality is the development of a theme or story with leisure and anticipation.	11.68208357649943
2161. anyone who has watched children develop a taste for literature	will understand what i mean.	10.935797288333498

2166. one of the	most frequent views of the value of literature is the education of sensibility	that it is thought to provide.	21.161222917238323

2180. the late r g collingwood a philosopher whose work	has proved helpful to many students of literature once wrote we	are all though many of us are snobbish enough to wish to deny it in	far closer sympathy with the art of the music-hall and picture-palace	than with chaucer and cimabue or even shakespeare and titian.	9.623842402011467

2184. there results a study of literature freed from the tyranny of the	contemporary.	18.392527205050744

2186. the study of ideas in	literature is one of these.	33.49608417898641
2187. of course it goes without saying that no	student of ideas can justifiably ignore the contemporary scene.	12.440011797605589

2195. he may also consider	ideas.	30.368575130042583
2196. it is true that this distinction between style and idea often	approaches the arbitrary since in the end we must admit that style and	content frequently influence or interpenetrate one another and sometimes	appear as expressions of the same insight.	13.25494741699772

2199. the term idea refers to our	more reflective or thoughtful consciousness as opposed to the immediacies	of sensuous or emotional experience.	9.135417957822767
2200. it is through such reflection	that literature approaches philosophy.	29.239651597249072
2201. an idea let us say may be	roughtly defined as a theme or topic with which our reflection may	be concerned.	8.483670987024539
2202. in this essay we are	along with most historians interested	in the more general or more inclusive ideas that are so to speak	writ large in history of literature where they recur continually.	10.297381953214872
2203. outstanding among these is the idea of human nature itself including	the many definitions that have been advanced over the centuries;	also secondary notions such as the perfectibility of man the depravity	of man and the dignity of man.	8.421710728281054
2204. one might indeed argue that the	history of ideas in so far as it includes the literatures must center	on characterizations of human nature and that the great periods of	literary achievement may be distinguished from one another by reference	to the images of human nature that they succeed in fashioning.	10.165736879146445
2205. we need not to be sure expect to find such ideas in every piece of	literature.	15.457632028709382
2206. an idea of the sort that we have in mind although of	necessity readily available to imagination is more general in connotation	than most poetic or literary images especially those appearing in	lyric poems that seek to capture a moment of personal experience.	11.725373517287467
2207. thus	burns's my love is like a red red rose and hopkins'	the thunder-purple sea-beach plumed purple of	thunder although clearly intelligible in content hardly present	ideas of the sort with which we are here concerned.	8.803720802785561
2208. on the other hand	arnold's the unplumbed salt estranging sea	taken in its context certainly does so.	16.1378667357311
2209. understanding a work	of art involves recognition of the ideas that it reflects or embodies.	10.95926671610873
2210. thus the student of literature may sometimes find it helpful to classify	a poem or an essay as being in idea or in ideal content or subject	matter typical or atypical of its period.	9.535602198153601
2211. again he may discover embodied	within its texture a theme or idea that has been presented elsewhere	and at other times in various ways.	8.731358931447748
2212. our understanding will very	probably require both these commentaries.	15.011475056270628
2213. very likely it will also include	a recognition that the work we are reading reflects or belongs	to some way of thought labelled as a school or an -ism	ie a complex or syndrome of ideas occurring together	with sufficient prominence to warrant identification.	7.2077110424053386
2214. thus ideas like	grace salvation and providence cluster together	in traditional christianity.	13.158434145732949
2215. usually the work studied offers us a special	or even an individualized rendering or treatment of the ideas in	question so that the student finds it necessary to distinguish carefully	between the several expressions of an -ism or mode of thought.	9.339567683408502
2216. accordingly we may speak of the platonism peculiar to shelley's	poems or the type of stoicism present in henley's invictus	and we may find that describing such platonism or such stoicism	and contrasting each with other expressions of the same attitude or	mode of thought is a difficult and challenging enterprise.	9.587180953656985
2217. after all	shelley is no orthodox or hellenic platonist and even his	romantic platonism can be distinguished from that of his contemporaries.	9.742412340799225
2218. again henley's attitude of defiance which colors his ideal	of self-mastery is far from characteristic of a stoic thinker like	marcus aurelius whose gentle acquiescence is almost christian	comparable to the patience expressed in milton's sonnet on his own	blindness.	8.941721635304607
2219. in recent years we have come increasingly to recognize	that ideas have a history and that not the least important chapters	of this history have to do with thematic or conceptual aspects of literature	and the arts although these aspects should be studied in conjunction	with the history of philosophy of religion and of the sciences.	9.701758877087457
2220. when these fields are surveyed together important patterns of	relationship emerge indicating a vast community of reciprocal influence	a continuity of thought and expression including many traditions primarily	literary religious and philosophical but frequently including	contact with the fine arts and even to some extent with science.	9.55427785931031
2221. here we may observe that at least one modern philosophy of history	is built on the assumption that ideas are the primary objectives	of the historian's research.	9.997943495155086
2222. let us quote once more from r g	collingwood: history is properly concerned with the actions	of human beings h regarded from the outside an action is an event	or series of events occurring in the physical world; regarded from the	inside it is the carrying into action of a certain thought h the	historian's business is to penetrate to the inside of the actions	with which he is dealing and reconstruct or rather rethink the thoughts	which constituted them.	9.458189906934841
2223. it is a characteristic of thoughts that h	in re-thinking them we come ipso facto to understand why they were	thought.	12.722748278803733
2224. such an understanding although it must seek to be sympathetic	is not a matter of intuition.	14.406613572197763
2225. history has this in common	with every other science: that the historian is not allowed to claim	any single piece of knowledge except where he can justify his claim	by exhibiting to himself in the first place and secondly to any one	else who is both able and willing to follow his demonstration the grounds	upon which it is based.	8.68087831776581
2226. this is what was meant above by describing	history as inferential.	21.306097337622827
2227. the knowledge in virtue of which a man	is an historian is a knowledge of what the evidence at his disposal proves	about certain events.	10.731852132331243
2228. it is obvious that the historian who seeks	to recapture the ideas that have motivated human behavior throughout	a given period will find the art and literature of that age one of	his central and major concerns by no means a mere supplement or adjunct	of significant historical research.	11.045318467214225
2229. the student of ideas and	their place in history will always be concerned with the patterns of	transition which are at the same time patterns of transformation whereby	ideas pass from one area of activity to another.	10.199978651653904
2230. let us survey	for a moment the development of modern thought- turning our attention	from the reformation toward the revolutionary and romantic movements	that follow and dwelling finally on more recent decades.	10.945726525918205
2231. we may thus	trace the notion of individual autonomy from its manifestation in religious	practice and theological reflection through practical politics	and political theory into literature and the arts.	8.758349992290292
2232. finally we may note	that the idea appears in educational theory where its influence is	at present widespread.	12.043895680818977
2233. no one will deny that such broad developments	and transitions are of great intrinsic interest and the study of ideas	in literature would be woefully incomplete without frequent reference	to them.	9.52167989322384
2234. still we must remember that we cannot construct and justify	generalizations of this sort unless we are ready to consider many special	instances of influence moving between such areas as theology philosophy	political thought and literature.	11.021554973152758
2235. the actual moments of contact	are vitally important.	14.48913098287042
2236. these moments are historical events in the	lives of individual authors with which the student of comparative literature	must be frequently concerned.	11.317551528967225
2237. perhaps the most powerful	and most frequently recurring literary influence on the western world	has been that of the old and new testament.	13.653508298938817
2238. certainly one of	the most important comments that can be made upon the spiritual and cultural	life of any period of western civilization during the past sixteen	or seventeen centuries has to do with the way in which its leaders	have read and interpreted the bible.	13.044994548200076

2336. trevelyan's liberalism was above all a liberalism of the spirit a	deep feeling of communion with men fighting for country and for liberty.	10.775436594875824

2346. thus trevelyan repeats the story	which pictured victor emmanuel as refusing to abandon the famous statuto	at the insistence of general radetzky.	10.773120422435184

2349. but fifty years later the trilogy still	maintains a firm place in the list of standard works on the unification	of italy a position cautiously prophesied by the reviewers at	the time of publication.	9.723789974416734
2350. trevelyan's manin and the venetian	revolution of 1848 his last major volume on an italian theme	was written in a minor key.	9.159936216703418

2354. already trevelyan had begun to parallel	his nineteenth-century italian studies with several works on english	figures of the same period.	11.445162641221364
2355. first the life of john bright appeared	and seven years later lord grey of the reform bill.	12.617927349825072
2356. of	the two the life of bright is incomparably the better biography.	13.690784622972503
2357. trevelyan	centers too exclusively on bright is insufficiently appreciative	of the views of bright's opponents and critics and makes light	of the genuine difficulties faced by peel.	8.087448802501262

2359. in	the story of bright and the corn law agitation the crimean war	the american civil war and the franchise struggle trevelyan reflects	something of the moral power which enabled this independent man	to exercise so immense an influence over his fellow countrymen for so	long.	7.3197197510232614

2362. nineteenth-century virtues however seem somehow to have gone out	of fashion and the bright book has never been particularly popular.	10.248964846740106
2363. the biography of lord grey is strictly speaking not a biography	at all.	10.956636136957574

2365. the volume is a piece of passionate	special pleading written with the heat- and often with the wisdom	it must be said- of a liberal damning the shortsightedness of politicians	from 1782 to 1832.	9.142171007715653
2366. characteristically trevelyan enjoyed writing	the work.	15.068811854765874
2367. the theme of glorious summer coming after a long winter	of discontent and repression was he has told us congenial to his artistic	sense.	10.02384120075947

2370. some historians have found his point of view not	to their taste others have complained that he makes the tory tradition	appear contemptible rather than intelligible while a sympathetic	critic has remarked that the intricate interplay of social dynamics	and political activity of which at times politicians are the	ignorant marionettes is not a field for the exercise of his talents.	9.019118385119617

2373. research in the period of grey and bright led naturally to	a more ambitious work.	9.242743962447554
2374. britain in the nineteenth century is a textbook	designed to give the sense of continuous growth to show how	economic led to social and social to political change how the political	events reacted on the economic and social and how new thoughts and	new ideals accompanied or directed the whole complicated process.	9.961694908607784
2375. the plan is admirably fulfilled for the period up to 1832.	13.851018259377332
2376. more temperately	than in the study of grey and despite his liberal bias trevelyan	vividly sketches the england of pre-french revolution days	portrays the stresses and strains of the revolutionary period in rich	colors and brings developments leading to the reform bill into sharp	and clear focus.	9.613695397195778
2377. his technique is genuinely masterful.	16.59111679669348

2379. but after	1832 the narrative tends to lose its balanced many-sided quality	and to become a medley of topics often unconnected by any single thread.	9.514580737507934

2382. finally the period after 1870 receives	little attention and that quite superficial.	12.116423288136446
2383. yet britain in the nineteenth	century became the vade mecum of beginning students of	history went through edition after edition and continues to be reprinted	up to the very present.	8.435465380324752
2384. its success is a tribute above all to	trevelyan's brilliance as a literary stylist.	11.901893423153721
2385. in 1924 trevelyan	traveled to the united states where he delivered the lowell	lectures at harvard university.	15.870534958066875
2386. these lectures formed the nucleus of	a general survey of english development which took form afterward as	a history of england.	10.000667142840305
2387. in short order the general history became	his most popular work and has remained aside from his later social	history the work most widely favored by the public.	9.133040084583298
2388. the	history of england has often been compared with green's short	history.	11.33819267263277

2390. the history takes too much for	granted to serve as a text for other than english schoolboys and like	britain in the nineteenth century it deteriorates badly as it goes	beyond 1870.	13.228182667984445
2391. trevelyan's excursions into contemporary history were	rarely happy ones.	10.530932308755343

2393. living	pictures of the early boroughs country life in tudor and stuart	times the impact of the industrial revolution compete with sensitive	surveys of language and literature the common law parliamentary development.	8.287437071528851
2394. the strength of the history is also its weakness.	19.573720223947266

2396. his	nationalism was not a new characteristic but its self-consciousness	even its self-satisfaction is more obvious in a book that stretches	over the long reach of english history.	10.08458244631935
2397. and yet the elements which	capture his liberal and humanistic imagination are those which make the	english story worth telling and worth remembering.	10.106581289236523
2398. tolerance and	compromise social justice and civil liberty are today too often in short	supply for one to be overly critical of trevelyan's emphasis on	their central place in the english tradition.	10.267229936217696
2399. like most major works	of synthesis the history of england is informed by the positive	views of a first-class mind and this is surely a major work.	10.16172987415926
2400. four years after the publication of the history of england the	first volume of trevelyan's queen anne trilogy appeared.	13.663841137255195
2401. by now	he had become regius professor of modern history at cambridge	and had been honored by the award of the order of merit.	11.728240956098437
2402. his academic	duties had little evident effect on his prolific pen.	13.124284270623187
2403. blenheim	was followed in rapid succession by ramillies and the union with	scotland and by the peace and the protestant succession the	three forming together a detailed picture of england under queen anne.	7.834283885688894
2404. like his volume on wycliffe the work was accompanied by the	publication of a selected group of documents in this case illustrative	of the history of queen anne's reign down to 1707.	11.77358109252179
2405. trevelyan	was at least in part attracted to the period by an almost unconscious	desire to take up the story where macaulay's history of england	had broken off.	10.291021643944664
2406. in addition he believed in the dramatic	unity and separateness of the period from 1702-14 lying between the stuart	and hanoverian eras with a special ethos of its own.	12.877882662758138
2407. he saw	the age as one in which britain settled her free constitution	and attained her modern place in the world.	11.19580781968378
2408. to most observers there	is little doubt that he placed an artificial strait jacket of unity upon	the years of anne's reign which in reality existed only in the	pages	of his history.	10.74440137613658
2409. of the three volumes blenheim is easily	the best.	21.95930214034891
2410. in four opening chapters reminiscent of macaulay's famous	third chapter trevelyan surveys the state of england at the opening	of the eighteenth century.	11.936654202856769
2411. his delightful picture of society and	institutions is filled with warm detail that brings the period vividly	to life.	8.708276189313924
2412. he tends to underestimate- or perhaps to view charitably-	the brutality and the violence of the age so that there is an idyllic	quality in these pages which hazes over some of its sharp reality.	12.598679368352467

2982. his contemporaries	in massachusetts called him an arch-heretic a beast a miscreant	a proud and pestilent seducer a prodigious minter of exorbitant	novelties.	9.704174639530388
2983. edward rawson secretary of the colony of massachusetts	bay described him as a man whose spirit was stark drunk with blasphemies	and insolence a corrupter of the truth a disturber of the peace	wherever he comes.	9.60140330789079
2984. nathaniel morton stated he was deeply leavened	with blasphemous and familistical opinions.	10.957705180640192
2985. he was thrown	out more or less from boston plymouth pocasset newport and providence.	13.462240893999063
2986. on the other hand dr ezra styles recorded the	following testimony of john angell the last disciple of gorton:	he said gorton was a holy man; wept day and night for	the sins and blindness of the world h had a long walk through the trees	and woods by his house where he constantly walked morning and evening	and even in the depths of the night alone by himself for contemplation	and the enjoyment of the dispensation of light.	10.483281119797219
2987. he was universally	beloved by his neighbours and the indians who esteemed him	not only as a friend but one high in communion with god in heaven.	10.090846259972666
2988. gorton sometimes signed himself a professor of the mysteries of	christ.	11.33819267263277
2989. there is plenty more to recommend gorton the facts	of whose life are given in the life and times of samuel gorton	by adelos gorton.	16.819447057292287
2990. he fought like a fiend for the helpless and	oppressed worked for the abolition of slavery helped the quakers	and indians and worked against the prosecution of witches.	9.877027435822393
2991. he defied	the boston hierarchy and after they sent a small army to get him	he befuddled the court including john cotton with one of the most	complicated religious discourses ever heard.	9.537986293245577
2992. samuel gorton was	born at gorton england near the present city of manchester about	1592.	11.214641888410943
2993. although he did not attend any celebrated schools or universities	he was a master of greek and hebrew and could read the bible	in the original.	9.569382141589296
2994. he worked as a clothier in london but was greatly	concerned with religion.	14.062142884177845
2995. gorton left england he said	to enjoy libertie of conscience in respect to faith towards god	and for no other end.	8.265429581704932
2996. with his wife and three or more children he	arrived in boston in march 1637 and soon found it was no place for	anyone looking for liberty of conscience.	11.099819194459009
2997. roger williams had recently	been thrown out and anne hutchinson and her antinomians were slugging	it out with the powers-that-be.	8.026882005052693
2998. gorton and his family moved to	plymouth.	16.42506127238193
2999. soon he was in trouble there for defending a woman	who was accused of smiling in church.	11.161921376962978
3000. she was ellen aldridge a widow	of good repute who was employed by gorton's wife and lived with	the family.	11.537498263011523
3001. the report was:   it had been whispered privately	that she had smiled in the congregation and the governor prence	sent to knoe her business and command after punishment as the bench	see fit her departure and also anyone who brought her to the place	from which she came.	8.011082546091185
3002. gorton said they were preparing to deport	her as a vagabond and to escape the shame she fled to the woods for	several days returning at night.	9.251821595493626
3003. he advised the poor woman not to	appear in court as what she was charged with was not in violation of	law.	11.089165700364216
3004. gorton appeared for her however and what he told the magistrates	must have been plenty for he was charged with deluding the court	fined and told to leave the colony within fourteen days.	10.31651176200655
3005. he left in	a storm for pocasset december 4 1638.	13.12721662888421
3006. his wife was in delicate health	and nursing an infant with measles.	12.017813442413573
3007. the unconquerable mrs	hutchinson was residing at pocasset after having been excommunicated	by the boston church and thrown out of the colony.	9.955801723915819
3008. one can imagine	that with her and gorton there it was no place for anyone with	weak nerves.	15.572877285095313
3009. william coddington who was running the colony felt constrained	to move seven miles south where with others- as mentioned	above- he founded newport.	8.438382739336214
3010. when in march 1640 the two towns	were united under coddington gorton claimed the union was irregular	and illegally constituted and that it had never been sanctioned by the	majority of freeholders.	12.023869682313153
3011. then he became involved in a ruckus	remarkably similar to the one in plymouth.	12.593660522763747
3012. a cow owned by an old woman	trespassed on gorton's land.	13.763351182065067
3013. while driving the cow back home the	woman was assaulted by a servant maid of gorton.	9.206416554065529
3014. the old woman complained	to the deputy governor who ordered the servant brought before	the court.	13.005642328427134
3015. gorton reverted to his plymouth tactics refused to let	her go and appeared himself before the portsmouth grand jury.	8.026882005052693
3016. during	the trial he told off the jury called them just asses and	called a freeman a saucy boy and jack-an-apes.	9.658456811478818
3017. he was jailed	and banished.	29.19812536008293
3018. gorton then moved to providence and soon put the	town in a turmoil.	10.635267499930531
3019. he held that no group of colonists could set up	or maintain a government without royal sanction.	10.914887072837043
3020. since rhode island	at that time did not have such sanction his opinion was not popular.	12.863169993656081
3021. roger williams wrote his friend winthrop as follows:   master	gorton having foully abused high and low at aquidneck is now	bewitching and bemaddening poor providence both with his unclean and	foul censures of all the ministers of this country	and also denying all visible	and external ordinances in depth of familism: almost all suck in	his poison as at first they did at aquidneck.	6.705955210984494
3022. some few and myself withstand	his inhabitation and town privileges without confession and	reformation of his uncivil and inhuman practices at portsmouth; yet	the tide is too strong against us and i fear	it will force me to little patience a little isle next	to your prudence.	8.299797265512884
3023. williams also stated: our peace was like	the peace of a man who hath the tertian ague.	10.836270075574452
3024. providence finally	managed to get gorton out of the town and he and some friends	bought land at pawtuxet on the west side of narragansett bay five	miles south but still within the jurisdiction of the providence colony.	11.098181107801127
3025. this town should not be confused with pawtucket just north of providence	or pawcatuck connecticut on the pawcatuck river opposite	westerly rhode island.	9.619056628000578
3026. up to now gorton had been looking	for trouble and now that he was trying to get away from it trouble	started looking for him.	15.755030729420005
3027. upon intelligence that the formidable	agitator was to favor them with his presence the benighted inhabitants	of pawtuxet alas gave their allegiance to massachusetts and asked	that colony to expel the newcomers.	7.517232160932028
3028. as it was the custom of that alert	colony to take over the property of persons asking for protection	this was an act roughly equivalent to throwing open the door to a pack	of wolves and saying come and get it.	12.903697464310508
3029. gorton and company	however promptly bought land from miantonomi a few miles south	of pawtuxet extending from the present gaspee point south to warwick	neck and twenty miles inland.	7.979362688670735
3030. the settlement was called shawomet.	19.926638570224114
3031. it was not within the jurisdiction of anybody or anything including	providence and massachusetts.	16.546726547285665
3032. if gorton wanted peace and quiet	for his complicated meditations this is where he should have had it.	11.613179452405623
3033. instead	of that he was engulfed by bedlam.	15.536445750746786
3034. pomham and soconoco	a couple of minor sachems	under miantonomi declared that they had never assented to the sale	of land to gorton and had never received anything for it.	9.416459074448511
3035. following	the glorious lead of the heroes of pawtuxet they also submitted themselves	to the protection of massachusetts.	8.355801920451004
3036. one historical authority	presents laborious and circuitous testimony tending to arouse suspicion	that massachusetts was behind the clouds settling down on the embattled	gorton.	11.611695903718866
3037. however the general court at boston ordered	the purchasers of shawomet to appear before them to answer the sachems'	claim.	11.163710629483402
3038. the purchasers rejected the order in two letters written	in vigorous terms.	12.957840546200554
3039. then massachusetts switched to its standard tactics.	13.726478122166146
3040. it pointed out twenty-six instances of blasphemy in the letters	and ordered the writers to submit or force of arms would be used.	11.37064748204756
3041. the	next week forty soldiers were sent to get the miscreants.	11.713134894341652
3042. the latter	tried to arbitrate through a delegation from providence which offer	was declined by the invaders.	11.311263844877574
3043. the commissioners at boston wrote	the victims to see their misdeeds and repent or they should look upon	them as men prepared for slaughter.	8.409778452916047
3044. at shawomet women	and children fled in terror across the bay.	14.803595429815799
3045. the men fortified a blockhouse	and got ready to fight but meanwhile appealed to the king and	again tried to arbitrate.	10.849206519103445
3046. gorton evidently still had plenty to learn	about massachusetts but he was learning fast.	11.733301422661752
3047. governor winthrop wrote:	you may do well to take notice that besides the title	to land between the english and the indians there there are twelve	of the english that have subscribed their names to horrible and detestable	blasphemies who are rather to be judged as blasphemous than	they should delude us by winning time under pretence of arbitration.	7.427418473634292
3048. the attack started on october 2 1643 and the gortonists held	out for a day and a night.	11.948598835825877
3049. the attackers sent for more soldiers and	the defenders to save bloodshed surrendered under the promise that	they would be treated as neighbors.	8.847019011814016
3050. promptly their livestock was taken	and according to gorton the soldiers were ordered to knock down anyone	who should utter a word of insolence and run through anyone who	might step out of line.	9.066454657218076
3051. when the captives arrived in boston	the chaplain of their captors went to prayers in the open streets	that the people might take notice what they had done in a holy manner	and in the name of the lord.	9.58490197658589
3052. gorton and ten of his friends	were thrown in jail.	12.62181102088309
3053. on sunday they refused to attend church.	15.498057587789319
3054. the magistrates were determined to compel them.	16.386222825564015
3055. the prisoners agreed	provided they might speak after the sermon which was permitted.	10.61385277229228
3056. here	was gorton's chance to indulge in something at which he was supreme.	14.763806894349877
3057. the boston elders were great at befuddling the opposition with	torrents of ecclesiastical obscurities but gorton was better.	9.189554574368655
3058. reverend	cotton preached to them about demetrius and the shrines of ephesus.	11.29539260948079
3059. gorton replied with blasts that scandalized the congregation.	10.530932308755343
3060. at the trial which took place later the pomham matter was completely	omitted.	17.301209049836263
3061. the gortonists were charged with blasphemy and tried	for their lives.	12.305152356592949
3062. four ecclesiastical questions were presented by the	general court to gorton:  whether the fathers who	died before christ was born of the virgin mary were justified and	saved only by the blood which hee shed and the death which hee suffered	after his incarnation?	9.737010937801518
3063.   whether the only price of our	redemption were not the death of christ on the cross with the rest	of his sufferings and obediences in the time of his life here after	hee was born of the virgin mary?	12.599302596630286
3064.   who was the god whom hee	thinke we serve?	16.498029466632932
3065.   what hee means when hee saith wee worship	the starre of our god remphan chion moloch?	9.924969275548836
3066.    gorton	answered in writing.	18.919390992859817
3067. all of the elders except three voted for death	but a majority of the deputies refused to sanction the sentence.	13.022240809451983
3068. seven of the prisoners were sentenced to be confined in irons for as	long as it pleased the court set to work and if they broke jail or proclaimed	heresy to be executed if convicted.	9.716915966451532
3069. the three others got off	easier.	21.134284119893668
3070. the convicts were put in chains paraded before the congregation	at the reverend cotton's lecture as an example and sent to	prisons in various towns where they languished all winter chains included.	9.600810958903212
3071. when fred wheeled him back into his room the big one looking out on	the back porch and put him to bed papa told him he was very tired	but that he had enjoyed greatly the trip downtown.	8.406149194777365
3072. i've been cooped	up so long he added.	7.711699336160625
3073. getting out again seeing old friends	had given his spirits a lift.	10.130076763644453
3074. that night after supper i went	back over to 48 spruce street- ralph and i at that time were living	at 168 chestnut- and ralph went with me.	0.0
3075. papa was still elated	over his afternoon visit downtown.	10.530932308755343
3076. baby i saw a lot of old friends	i hadn't seen in a long time he told me his eyes bright.	14.053020380225963
3077. it was mighty good for the old man to get out again.	21.58200930379781
3078. the	next day he seemed to be in fairly good shape and still in excellent	spirits.	17.386478705186438
3079. but a few days after fred's return he began hemorrhaging	and that was the beginning of early and complete disintegration.	14.65439255820663
3080. it	began in the morning and very quickly the hemorrhage was a massive one.	12.807829747729036
3081. we got dr glenn to him as quickly as we could and we wired	tom of papa's desperate condition.	11.044796755079002
3082. the hemorrhage was in the prostate	region; dr glenn saw at once what had happened.	13.200246697983928
3083. he	has lost much blood he said.	12.048509495279038
3084. it'll take a lot to replace	it.	13.915190642667962
3085. dr glenn i've got a lot of blood fred	spoke up plenty of it.	10.832763902383116
3086. let me give papa blood.	24.51851527405581
3087. the doctor	agreed but explained that it would be necessary first to check fred's	blood to ascertain whether or not it was of the same type as	papa's.	12.142718094488588
3088. to give a patient the wrong type of blood said the doctor	would likely kill him.	12.965313961091072
3089. that was in the days before blood banks	of course and transfusions had to be given directly from donor to	patient.	14.755090113882039
3090. one had to find a donor and usually very quickly whose blood	corresponded with the patient's.	13.576439941724965
3091. and then it took considerably	longer to make preparations for giving transfusions.	12.512054633708269
3092. they had to take	blood samples to the laboratory to test them for one thing and there	was much required preliminary procedure.	13.879810481080897
3093. they made the tests	and came to fred; by now it was perhaps two days or longer after papa	had begun hemorrhaging.	9.012551064066388
3094. fred your blood matches your	father's all right dr glenn said.	11.33819267263277
3095. but we aren't going	to let you give him any.	16.439420077697026
3096. but why in the name of god can't	i give my father blood?	20.206524775820732
3097.  fred demanded.	19.137741945722095
3098. why can't i	doctor?	26.63408569870497
3099.    because fred it could do him no good.	14.383955325070303
3100. he's past helping.	7.860565972560897
3101. he's as good as gone.	7.962925042318041
3102. and in a few minutes papa was dead.	32.95440018806346
3103. it was well past midnight.	30.904122386255487
3104. papa had left us about the same hour of the night that ben had passed	on.	12.351901598683614
3105. the date was june 20 1922.	15.260583014183545
3106. w o wolfe	prominent business man and pioneer resident of this section died shortly	after midnight tuesday at his home 48 spruce street the asheville	times of wednesday june 21 announced.	9.525483112761323
3107. mr wolfe	had been in declining health for many years and death was not unexpected.	11.868639001208026

3109. beloved dr	r f campbell our first presbyterian church pastor was	in charge.	0.0
3110. the burial was out in riverside cemetery.	16.386222825564015
3111. all about him	stood tombstones his own sensitive great hands had fashioned.	11.204342915251186
3112. a few years before his death papa had agreed with mama to make a	joint will with her in which it would be provided that in the event of	the	death of either of them an accounting would be made to their children	whereby each child would receive a bequest of $5000 cash.	12.49315428743754
3113. at his death	fred and ralph my husband were named executors of the estate under	the terms of the will.	10.48583633200884
3114. fred and ralph qualified as executors	and paid off what debts were currently due and they were all current	since papa was never one to allow bills to go unpaid.	8.869467219217677
3115. the bills	were principally for hospitalization and doctors' fees during the	last years of his life and when he died he owed in the main only current	doctor's bills.	10.640838201286389
3116. after they had paid all his debts and the funeral	costs ralph and fred had some fourteen thousand dollars as i remember	with which to pay the bequests.	10.400376092962606
3117. this manifestly would not	provide $5000 to each of the surviving five children.	12.381554748222241
3118. so what	fred and ralph did was to attempt to prorate the money fairly by taking	into account what each of the five had received if anything from	the estate before papa's death.	10.73993669407114
3119. consequently fred and tom the	two who had been provided college educations signed statements to the	effect that each had received his bequest in full and effie and i	were each allotted $5000.	7.761850186643159
3120. frank had been given about half his legacy	to use in a business venture before papa's death; he was given the	difference between that amount and $5000.	9.718300940908714
3121. tom had received four years	of education at the university of north carolina and two at harvard	and fred had been in and out of georgia tech and carneigie	tech and part of the time had been a self-help student.	11.920595004640914
3122. so because	he had received less than tom it was felt proper that fred should receive	the few hundred dollars that remained.	10.657780126463992
3123. and that's how papa's	estate was divided.	10.19044397798569
3124. papa i should emphasize had been an	invalid the last several years of his life; his hospital and doctor	bills had been large and his income had been cut until he was receiving	little except	small rentals on some properties he still owned.	8.29233936300038
3125. had	he been able to escape this long siege of invalidism i'm convinced	papa would have left a sizable estate.	9.2098240325416
3126. but he had succeeded well	we agreed.	33.29430195757378
3127. he had left us a legacy far more valuable than houses and lands	and stocks and bonds.	11.052932230987146
3128. for years papa and mama had been large	taxpayers.	17.59727178315997
3129. i recall that several years their taxes exceeded $800.	13.722719440649124
3130. in those years of lower property valuations and lower tax rates that	payment represented ownership of much property.	14.048379389301676
3131. merciful god	julia! i have known papa to exclaim on getting his tax bill	we're going to the dogs!   but he never expected to	do that.	7.822411620371612
3132. and he didn't by a long shot!	in the spring	of his second year at harvard tom had been offered a job at northwestern	university as an instructor in the english department.	8.840415204607707
3133. but	he had delayed accepting this job and as he was leaving to come home	to papa in response to our telegram he dropped a postcard to miss	mccrady head of the harvard appointment office asking her please	to write northwestern authorities and explain the circumstances.	8.479787352534103

3135. in fact	he didn't want to teach anywhere.	15.793815426101952
3136. he wanted to go back to harvard	for another year of playwriting.	20.11340472309138
3137. but papa's death had further complicated	the financing of tom's hoped-for third year and for the	weeks following it tom did not know whether his return to harvard could	be arranged.	8.940917695967487
3138. but things were worked out in the family and	late in august he wrote miss mccrady an explanatory letter in which	he told her that matters at home had been in an unsettled condition	after papa's death and he had not known whether he would stay at home	with mama accept the northwestern job or return to harvard.	10.215046676251099

3140. and that's what he did.	12.7224155594214
3141. that third year he wrote plays	with a fury.	15.369069622934138
3142. i believe there are seventeen short plays by tom now	housed in the houghton library at harvard; i think i'm right	in that figure.	11.241353790845066
3143. that fall he submitted to professor baker the first	acts and outlines of the following acts of several plays six of them	according to some of his associates and he also worked on a play	that he first called niggertown the material for which he had collected	during the summer at home.	8.094302972069936
3144. later this play would be called welcome	to our city.	14.272537355067428
3145. in the spring it must have been he began	working on the play that he called the house which later would	be mannerhouse.	13.247347239862384
3146. that spring welcome to our city was selected	for production by the 47 workshop and it was staged in the middle	of may.	11.2032346766302
3147. it ran two nights and though it was generally praised there	was considerable criticism of its length.	11.676174551097459
3148. it ran until past one o'clock.	23.729432886271383
3149. that was tom's weakness; it was demonstrated many critics	would later point out in the length of his novels.	12.610741326244705
3150. in this play	there were so many characters and so much detail.	16.507424878165114
3151. tom never knew how	to condense to boil down.	10.772164915044634
3152. he was always concerned with life and he	tried to picture it whole; he wanted nothing compressed tight.	12.581370433928027
3153. he	was a big man and he wanted nothing little squeezed; he despised parsimony	and particularly of words.	9.904499152261817
3154. in this play there were some thirty	or more named characters and i don't know how many more unnamed.	12.227499679272697
3155. in describing it to professor baker after it had been chosen for	production he defended his great array of characters by declaring that	he had included that many not because i didn't know how to save	paint but because the play required them.	8.464627959244673
3156. and he threatened someday	to write a play with fifty eighty a hundred people- a whole	town a whole race a whole epoch.	11.32767951766734
