3160. he hung around	new york waiting to hear whether they would accept it for production	and in that time came down to asheville and also paid a short visit	to chapel hill where with almost childish delight he visited old	friends and favorite campus spots.	9.117399152206877
3161. on returning to new york he had	a job for several weeks; it was visiting university of north carolina	alumni in new york to ask them for contributions to the graham	memorial building fund.	9.691280356200647
3162. the graham memorial would be the campus	student union honoring the late and much beloved edward kidder graham	who had been president when tom entered the university.	10.12610343261758

3170. it was fantastic writing	beautiful writing the man declared but the public he insisted	wanted realism.	15.691600636925086
3171. tom was not willing to revise the play according	to the plan the man suggested.	9.250214943488718
3172. such a revision he said would ruin	it would change his whole conception of the play as well as the treatment.	15.269453122786828
3173. he thought about it and he told the man he just couldn't do	it over in accordance with the suggestions he had made.	11.276845997970874
3174. it was not until we had returned to the city to live while i	was still at brown and sharpe's that i felt the full impact of	evangelical christianity.	17.051473769500078
3175. i came under the spell of a younger group	in the church led by the pastor's older son.	10.679851126090064
3176. the spirit of this group	was that we were- and are- living in a world doomed to eternal	punishment but that god through jesus christ has provided a way of	escape for those who confess their sins and accept salvation.	11.89474743773688
3177. there are millions who accept this doctrine but few indeed are those	who accept it so truly that the fate of humanity lies as a weight on	their souls night and day.	9.336813650854188
3178. this group in park place church was made	up of the earnest few.	14.214868555585658
3179. i was drawn deeper and deeper into these concerns	and responsibilities.	14.289923224785284
3180. i engaged more and more in religious activities.	19.28561548986645
3181. besides church and sunday school i went to out-of-door meetings	on the sidewalk at the church door.	10.840261379402166
3182. i went to an afternoon service	at the ymca.	18.26113263739884
3183. i went to the christian endeavor society	and to the evening service of the church.	15.40406207955458
3184. much of this lacked the active	support of the pastor.	20.696116816354742
3185. the young people were self-energizing and	i was energized.	14.437859561797689
3186. once or twice my father asked me if i wasn't overdoing	a bit in my churchgoing.	14.31019553761028
3187. meanwhile i myself was not yet	saved.	13.687398220999578
3188. at least i had been unable to lay hold on the experience of	conversion.	22.080699238557077
3189. try as i might to confess my sins and accept salvation	no answer came to me from heaven.	9.002733151819228
3190. finally after years i gave up.	16.179734806141106
3191. the basic difficulty i suppose was in my ultimate inability	to feel a burden of sin from which i sought relief.	9.014357448449532
3192. i was familiar	with pilgrim's progress which i read as literature.	16.755888446513726
3193. no load	of sin had been laid on my shoulders nor did earnest effort enable	me to become conscious of one.	9.070989453367899
3194. there is of course the doctrine	of original sin which asserts that each of us as individuals partakes	of the guilt of our first ancestor.	15.60067159213811
3195. in the rhyming catechism this	doctrine is worded thus: in adam's fall we sin-ned all.	12.226852369311269
3196. this doctrine was repugnant to my moral sense.	15.63799501176316
3197. i did not feel	it presumptuous to expect that the creator would be at least as just	as the most righteous of his creatures; and the doctrine of original	sin is compounded of injustice.	9.921626387417305
3198. some of these thoughts- not	all of them- have taken organized form in later years.	15.431720973332949
3199. the actual	impelling force which severed me from evangelical effort was of another	sort.	10.61385277229228
3200. i became disgusted at being so preoccupied with the state of	my own miserable soul.	14.020440920934044
3201. i found myself becoming one of that group of	people who in carlyle's words are forever gazing into their own	navels anxiously asking 'am i right am i wrong'?	8.900145677143827
3202.  i bethought	me of the lord's prayer and these words came to mind:	thy kingdom come thy will be done on earth as it is in heaven.	12.410146829930165
3203. they have remained on the opened page of my mind in all the years	which since have passed.	12.05169051224121
3204. from that time to this my religious concern	is that i might give effective help to the bringing in of god's kingdom	on earth.	12.27225887745154
3205. i do not claim to be free from sin or from the	need for repentance and forgiveness.	14.95109041989331
3206. in my experience the assurance	of forgiveness comes only when i have confessed to the wronged one and	have made as full reparation as i can devise.	11.103494734832141
3207. there was one	further step in my religious progress.	21.795649825065023
3208. this was taken after i came	to live in springfield and it was made under the guidance of the reverend	raymond beardslee a young preacher who came to the congregational	church there at about the same time that i moved from new york.	13.475775543196916
3209. his father was a professor at hartford theological seminary	and from him he acquired a conviction which he passed along to me that	there is in the universe of persons a moral law the law of love	which is a natural law in the same sense as is the physical law.	9.071208933647709
3210. it is most important that we recognize the law of love as being unbreakable	in all personal relationships whether individually socially	or as between whole nations of people.	12.74737919014889
3211. if obeyed the law brings order	and satisfaction.	16.122160126925362
3212. if disobeyed the result is turmoil and chaos.	22.041575253524577
3213. as we observe moral law and physical law they appear as being inevitable.	12.477218151579738
3214. we can conceive of no alternatives.	24.477229024319502
3215. their basis seems deeper	than mere authority.	13.233458217711917
3216. they are not true because scientists or prophets	say they are true.	17.02235149217569
3217. it is not the authority of god himself which	makes them true.	25.520115018584843
3218. because god is what he is the laws of the universe	material and spiritual are what they are.	16.0660922589225
3219. deity and law are one	and inseparable.	11.867291106449708
3220. with this conviction the partition between	the sacred and the secular disappears.	14.937285534434128
3221. one's daily work becomes sacred	since it is performed in the field of influence of the moral law	dealing as it does with people as well as with matter and energy.	9.556496145124761
3222. in his book civilization and ethics albert schweitzer faces	the moral problems which arise when moral law is recognized in business	life for example.	11.35219524987438
3223. his ethics defines possessions as the	property of the community of which the individual is sovereign steward.	11.843132464036742
3224. one serves society by conducting a business from which a certain	number of employees draw their means of subsistence; another by giving	away his property in order to help his fellow man.	10.334321611299853
3225. each will decide	on his own course somewhere between these two extreme cases according	to the sense of responsibility which is determined for him by the particular	circumstances of his own life.	10.159607026694554
3226. no one is to judge others.	21.45485911580018
3227. he is uncompromising in assigning guilt to the man who finds	it necessary to inflict or permit injury to one individual or group for	the sake of a larger good.	11.702255613754234
3228. for this decision a man must take personal	responsibility.	25.934567024847325
3229. says he i may never imagine that in the struggle	between personal and supra-personal responsibility it is possible	to make a compromise between the ethical and the purposive in the shape	of a relative ethic; or to let the ethical be superseded by the purposive.	7.784842088250489
3230. on the contrary it is my duty to make my own decision as between	the two.	14.831233989139731
3231. schweitzer seems in fact to acquire for himself	a burden of sin not bequeathed by adam but accumulated in the	inevitable judgments which life requires of him as between greater and	lesser responsibilities.	7.577975536232771
3232. this viewpoint i find interesting but it	has never weighed on my soul.	12.817239845831333
3233. my own experience	has followed simpler lines.	14.195054884578044
3234. an uncompromising belief in the	moral law has the advantage of making religion natural even as physical	law is natural.	11.723343799622928
3235. neither the engineer nor the ordinary citizen feels	any self-consciousness in obeying the laws of matter and energy	nor can he achieve a sense of self-righteousness in such obedience.	9.32365384712625
3236. to	obey the moral law is just ordinary common sense applied to a neglected	field.	10.358652090748608
3237. religion thus becomes integrated with life.	11.867291106449708
3238. this	truth that the moral law is natural has other important corollaries.	11.330154800079951
3239. one	of them is that it gives meaning and purpose to life.	17.06565313392752
3240. in seeking	for such meaning and purpose albert schweitzer seized upon the concept	of the sacredness of life.	12.30667194255898
3241. it is puzzling to the occidental	mind to assign sacredness to animal insect	and plant life.	14.006699129233729
3242. these lives are in themselves outside of the moral order	and are unburdened with moral responsibility.	12.469900628999811
3243. there is indeed a	moral responsibility on man himself for his own soul's sake to respect	lower life and to avoid the infliction of suffering but this viewpoint	schweitzer rejects.	11.068341890854024
3244. so far as sacredness inheres	in any aspect of creation it seems to me to be found in human personality	whether in lambarene africa or in washington dc.	18.97791844173108
3245. one	cannot read the records of scientists officials and travelers who	have penetrated to the minds of the most savage races without realizing	that each individual met with is a person.	9.155415174137275
3246. read for instance	in	malcolm macdonald's borneo people of segura and her wise	father tomonggong koh and her final adjustment to encroaching civilization.	10.059945423152644
3247. above all read in jens bjerre's the last cannibals	how the old man of the wailbri tribe in central australia	gave to the white man his choicest possession while the tears	streamed down his face.	8.995262226755544
3248. the australian aborigine is the conventional	exemplar of degraded humanity; yet here was a depth of sensibility	which is lacking in a considerable portion of the beneficiaries of our	civilization.	11.7462353009374
3249. persons whether white black brown or yellow	are a concern of god.	9.536539998875496
3250. respect for personality is a privilege and a	duty for us as brothers.	10.635267499930531
3251. such is the field for exercising our	reverence.	16.040513590643297
3252. as to our action let us align ourselves with the purpose	expressed by jesus in the lord's prayer: thy kingdom come	thy will be done on earth as it is in heaven.	12.136115749645768
3253. with the knowledge	that the kingdom comes by obedience to the moral law in our relations	with all people we have a firm intellectual grasp on both the means	and the ends of our lives.	9.207625365681812
3254. this intellectual approach to spiritual	life suited me well because i was never content to lead a divided	life.	11.349709341667586
3255. as i have said words from tennyson remain ever in my memory:	that mind and soul according well may make one music as	before.	11.034771271405587
3256. let us now give some thought to the soul.	18.66610714441994
3257. when the	young biologist dr ballard began to show interest in our daughter	elizabeth this induced a corresponding interest on our part in	him.	10.791405307164071
3258. i asked one day what he was doing.	22.736424624315983
3259. he told me that he had a big	newt and a little newt and that he was transplanting a big eye of the	big newt onto the little newt and a little eye of the little newt onto	the big newt.	11.216031698619032
3260. he was then noting that the big eye on the little newt	hung back until the little eye had grown up to it while the little	eye on the big newt grew rapidly until it was as big as the other.	10.913035433612153
3261. then	i asked what does that teach you?	11.118618003375188
3262.  said he it teaches	me to wonder.	19.690626594549265
3263. this was a profound statement.	27.290859906480517
3264. in the face	of the unfolding universe our ultimate attitude is that of wonder.	17.527956030728074
3265. wonder is indeed the intellectual gateway to the spiritual world.	10.04760905749492
3266. gone are the days when in the nineteenth century scientists thought	that they were close to the attainment of complete knowledge of	the physical universe.	12.541707633092093
3267. for them only a little more needed to be learned	and then all physical knowledge could be neatly sorted packaged	and put in the inventory to be drawn on for the solution of any human	problem.	8.84054290068626
3268. this complacency was blown to bits by the relativity	of einstein the revelation of the complex anatomy of the atom and the	discovery of the expanding universe.	10.851535758506452
3269. none of these discoveries were	neatly rounded off bits of knowledge.	14.83807406354196
3270. each faded out into the unexplored	areas of the future.	15.478559401626605
3271. it is as if we in our center of human	observation from time to time penetrate more deeply into the unknown.	14.209060643026062
3272. as our radius of penetration r increases the area of new	knowledge	increases by f and the total of human knowledge becomes measured	in terms of f.	11.107085582649312
3273. there are	some people intelligent people who seem to be untouched by the sea	of wonder in which we are immersed and in which we spend our lives.	12.632146212448058
3274. one	such is abraham meyer the writer of a recent book speaking of	man.	10.635267499930531
3275. this is a straightforward denial of the spiritual world and	a vigorous defense of pure materialism.	14.491260285637608
3276. his inability to wonder vitiates	his argument.	15.982618402857776
3277. the subject of immortality brings to mind a	vivid incident which took place in 1929 at montreux in switzerland.	11.41539809658874
3278. criticism is as old as literary art and we can set the stage for	our study of three moderns if we see how certain critics in the past	have dealt with the ethical aspects of literature.	8.802983096919936
3279. i have chosen five	contrasting pairs ten men in all and they are arranged in roughly	chronological order.	13.21562373214274
3280. such a list must naturally be selective and the	treatment of each man is brief for i am interested only in their general	ideas on the moral measure of literature.	9.952852594952178
3281. altogether the list	will give us considerable variety in attitudes and some typical ones	for these critics range all the way from censors to those who consider	art above ethics all the way from plato to poe.	10.198377592203865
3282. and most of the	great periods are represented because we will compare plato and aristotle	from the golden age of greece; stephen gosson and sir philip	sidney from renaissance england; dr johnson and william	hazlitt of the eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries in england;	and james russell lowell and edgar allan poe of nineteenth	century american letters.	9.284006914075846
3283. plato and aristotle	agree on some vital literary issues.	10.530932308755343
3284. they both measure literature	by moral standards and in their political writings both allow for	censorship but the differences between them are also significant.	10.972352180711574
3285. while	aristotle censors literature only for the young plato would banish	all poets from his ideal state.	9.701978006754235
3286. even more important in his poetics	aristotle differs somewhat from plato when he moves in the	direction of treating literature as a unique thing separate and apart	from its causes and its effects.	9.54889039472692
3287. all through the republic	plato attends to the way art relates to the general life and ultimately	to a good life for his citizens.	9.82876480811514
3288. in short he is constantly concerned	with the ethical effects.	17.45036638236957
3289. when he discusses the subject matter	of poetry he asks what moral effect the scenes will have.	11.285217239752688
3290. when he	turns briefly to literary style in the third book he again looks to	the effect on the audience.	12.910871424777044
3291. he explains that his citizens must not	be corrupted by any of the misrepresentations of the gods or heroes that	one finds in much poetry and he observes that all these pantomimic	gentlemen will be sent to another state.	8.319927938479195
3292. only those story tellers	will remain who can imitate the style of the virtuous.	15.316969417103932
3293. plato is at times just as suspicious of the poets themselves as he	is of their work.	8.29272515769823
3294. when he discusses tyrants in the eighth book of	the republic he pictures the poets as willing to praise the worst	rulers.	12.438927802281698
3295. but the most fundamental objection he has to poets appears	in the tenth book and it is derived from his doctrine of ideal forms.	12.3480043595302
3296. in plato's mind there is an irresolvable conflict between the	poet and the philosopher because the poet imitates only particular objects	and is incapable of rising to the first level of abstraction much	less the highest level of ideal forms.	10.904429288176576
3297. true reality of course is	the ideal and the poet knows nothing of this; only the philosopher	knows the truth.	8.896750385073009
3298. poets moreover dwell on human passions.	13.915190642667962
3299. and	with this point about the passions we encounter plato's dualism.	10.419242411823294
3300. the same sort of thinking plays so large a part in both babbitt and	more that we must examine it in some detail.	11.872017513463552
3301. plato feels that man	has two competing aspects his rational faculty and his irrational.	8.834168570742513
3302. we can be virtuous only if we control our lower natures the passions	in this case and strengthen our rational side; and poetry with all	its emphasis on the passions encourages the audience to give way to	emotion.	9.95200063415919
3303. for this reason then poetry tends to weaken the power of	control the reason because it tempts one to indulge his passions and	even the best of men he maintains may be corrupted by this subtle	influence.	9.109097718189835
3304. plato's attitude toward poetry has always been something	of an enigma because he is so completely sensitive to its charm.	11.440349199062675
3305. his whole objection indeed seems to rise out of a deep conviction	that the poets do have great power to influence but plato seldom	pays any attention to what might be called the poem itself.	7.968735621124694
3306. he is	rather concerned with the effect on society and he wants the poets	to join his fight for justice.	11.998880136005956
3307. he wants them to use their great power	to strengthen man's rational side to teach virtue and to encourage	religion.	10.932254493944441
3308. while plato finally allows a few acceptable hymns	to the gods and famous men still he clearly leaves the way open for	further discussion of the issue.	9.90898796298475
3309. he even calls upon the poets to defend	the muse and to show that poetry may contribute to virtue.	10.766817556135246
3310. he says:	we	may further grant to those of her poetry's defenders	who are lovers of poetry and yet not poets the permission to	speak in prose on her behalf: let them show not only that she is pleasant	but also useful to states and to human life and we will listen	in a kindly spirit; for if this can be proved we shall surely be the	gainers- i mean if there is a use in poetry as well as a delight.	9.898767283934676
3311. when we turn to aristotle's ideas on the moral measure	of literature it is at once apparent that he is at times equally concerned	about the influence of the art.	13.922328866295535
3312. in the ideal state for instance	he argues that the young citizens should hear only the most carefully	selected tales and stories.	11.89554387735105
3313. for this reason he would banish indecent	pictures and speeches from the stage; and the young people should	not even be permitted to see comedies till they are old enough to	drink strong wine and sit at the public tables.	8.931155629401205
3314. by the time they reach	that age however aristotle no longer worries about the evil influence	of comedies.	14.333300982812961
3315. in aristotle's analysis of tragedy in the	poetics we find an attempt to isolate the art to consider only	those things proper to it to discover how it differs from other arts	and to deal with the effects peculiar to it.	8.741743274941093
3316. he assures us early	in the poetics that all art is imitation and that all imitation	gives pleasure but he distinguishes between art in general and	poetic art on the basis of the means manner and the objects of the	imitation.	10.11532852150244
3317. once the poetic arts are separated from the other forms	he lays down his famous definition of tragedy which sets up standards	and so lends direction to the remainder of the work.	10.325495661904213
3318. a tragedy by	his definition is an imitation of an action that is serious of a certain	magnitude and complete in itself.	10.70371139476269
3319. it should have a dramatic form	with pleasing language and it should portray incidents which so arouse	pity and fear that it purges these emotions in the audience.	10.8244886798934
3320. any	tragedy he maintains has six elements: plot character and thought	diction and melody	and spectacle.	10.358652090748608
3321. throughout the rest of	the poetics aristotle continues to discuss the characteristics	of these six	parts and their interrelationship and he refers frequently to the	standards suggested by his definition of tragedy.	8.194250882197736
3322. aristotle's	method in the poetics then does suggest that we should isolate	the work.	11.632297328443187
3323. the chicago contingent of modern critics follow aristotle	so far in this direction that it is hard to see how they can compare	one poem with another for the purpose of evaluation.	12.490106404524958
3324. but there are	however several features of aristotle's approach which open the	way for the moral measure of literature.	14.339670278437945
3325. for one thing aristotle mentions	that plays may corrupt the audience.	17.647409788245668
3326. in addition his definition	of a tragedy invites our attention because a serious and important	action may very well be one that tests the moral fiber of the author	or of the characters.	10.554135772333233
3327. and there is one other point in the poetics that	invites moral evaluation: aristotle's notion that the distinctive	function of tragedy is to purge one's emotions by arousing pity	and fear.	12.391495865873676
3328. he rejects certain plots because they do not contribute to	that end.	15.586249198110746
3329. the point is that an ethical critic with an assist from freud	can seize on this theory to argue that tragedy provides us with	a harmless outlet for our hostile urges.	8.754072057952898
3330. in his study samuel johnson	joseph wood krutch takes this line when he says that what aristotle	really means by his theory of catharsis is that our evil passions	may be so purged by the dramatic ritual that it is less likely	that we shall indulge them through our own acts.	10.572517485853858
3331. in krutch's view	this is one way to show how literature may be moral in effect without	employing the explicit methods of a moralist.	9.645359721770136
3332. and we can add that	krutch's interpretation of purgation is also one answer to plato's	fear that poetry will encourage our passions.	10.851024531509594
3333. if krutch is correct	tragedy may have quite the opposite effect.	12.94788651077971
3334. it may allay our passions	and so restore the rule of reason.	21.631655094936967
3335. or in more freudian terms	the experience may serve to sublimate our destructive urges and strengthen	the ego and superego.	9.140263172310235
3336. the second half of	the sixteenth century in england was the setting for a violent and long	controversy over the moral quality of renaissance literature especially	the drama.	12.520506140105363
3337. no one suggested that the ethical effects of the art	were irrelevant.	15.108506178688629
3338. both sides agreed that the theater must stand a moral	test but they could not agree on whether the poets were a good or	a bad influence.	9.792491115404575
3339. both sides claimed that plato and aristotle supported	their cause.	13.67851763362287
3340. those who wanted to close the theaters for example	pointed to plato's republic and those who wished to keep them	open called on the plato of the ion to testify in their behalf.	10.300655420937103
3341. the most famous document that comes out of this dispute is perhaps	sir philip sidney's an apologie for poetrie published	in 1595.	10.175731001067163
3342. many students of literature know that classical defense.	15.003179019087538
3343. what is not so well known however and what is quite important for	understanding the issues of this early quarrel is the kind of attack	on literature that sidney was answering.	11.587548952090032
3344. for this reason then i want	to describe first two examples of the puritanical attacks: stephen	gosson's the school of abuse 1579 and his later playes	confuted published in 1582.	11.131352124429952
3345. second we will see how sidney	answered the charges for while sidney's essay was not specifically	a reply to gosson his arguments do support the new theater.	7.971474452968774
3346. according to william ringler's study stephen gosson the theater	business in london had become a thriving enterprise by 1577 and	in the opinion of many a thoroughly bad business.	11.563698809913557
3347. aroused by what	they considered an evil influence some members of the clergy joined	by city authorities merchants and master craftsmen began the attack	on the plays and the actors for what they called the abuses of the	art but by 1582 some of them began to denounce the whole idea of	acting.	7.879300542691438
3348. although this kind of wholesale objection came at first from	some men who were not technically puritans still once the puritans	gained power they climaxed the affair by passing the infamous ordinance	of 1642 which decreed that all public stage-plays shall cease	and be forborne.	9.150235852293463
3349. with that act of parliament the opponents of the	stage won the day and for more than two decades after that england	had no legitimate public drama.	10.124181471942185
3350. in the early days of this controversy	over the theater one of the interested parties stephen gosson	published a little tract in which he objected mildly to the abuses	of art rather than the art itself.	13.947709306098645
3351. but his opposition hardened and	by 1579 in the school of abuse he was ready to banish all players.	12.480146633555794
3352. he advises women to beware of those places which in sorrows	cheere you and beguile you in mirth.	11.272564027374363
3353. he does not really approve	of levity and laughter but sex is the deadly sin.	13.879153912032917
3354. he warns that	a single glance can lead us into temptation for looking eies have	lyking hartes and lyking hartes may burne in lust.	10.226931923435139
3355. but it would not be very satisfactory to leave our conclusions	at the point just reached.	18.106890777391804
3356. fortunately it is possible to be somewhat	more concrete and factual in diagnosing the involvement of values in	education.	16.7929183591628
3357. for this purpose we now draw upon data from sociological and	psychological studies of students in american colleges and universities	and particularly from the cornell values studies.	9.004970144161177
3358. in the latter	research program	information is available for 2758 cornell students	surveyed in 1950 and for 1571 students surveyed in 1952.	12.188727874127855
3359. of the	latter sample 944 persons had been studied two years earlier; hence	changes in attitudes and values can be analyzed for identical individuals	at two points in time.	8.304736790953791
3360. in addition the 1952 study collected	comparable data from 4585 students at ten other colleges and universities	scattered across the country: dartmouth harvard yale wesleyan	north carolina fisk texas university of california at	los angeles wayne and michigan.	10.660406723882456
3361. we find in the first	place that the students overwhelmingly approve of higher education	positively evaluate the job their own institution is doing do not	accept most of the criticisms levelled against higher education in the	public prints and on the whole approve of the way their university	deals with value-problems and value inculcation.	9.140101556249848
3362. it is not our impression	that these evaluations are naively uncritical resultants of blissful	ignorance; rather the generality of these students find their	university experience congenial to their own sense of values.	13.830588783961657
3363. students	are approximately equally divided between those who regard	vocational preparation as the primary goal of an ideal education and those	who chose a general liberal education.	8.216910365488
3364. other conceivable goals	such as character-education and social adjustment are of secondary	importance to them.	11.131427923863393
3365. the ideal of a liberal education impresses itself	upon the students more and more as they move through college.	10.700382736436936
3366. even	in such technical curricula as engineering the senior is much more	likely than the freshman to choose as an ideal liberal education over	specific vocational preparation.	8.777324869432913
3367. in the university milieu of scholarship	and research of social diversity of new ideas and varied and	wide-ranging interests socialization into a campus culture apparently	means heightened appreciation of the idea of a liberal education	in the arts and sciences.	9.926116572609455
3368. students' choices of ideal	educational goals are not arbitrary or whimsical.	11.33819267263277
3369. there is a clear	relationship between their educational evaluations and their basic	pattern of general values.	16.517170887491677
3370. the selective and directional qualities of	basic value-orientations are clearly evident in these data: the	success-oriented	students choose vocational preparation the other-directed	choose goals of social adjustment	the intellectuals choose a liberal arts emphasis.	9.11199125168746
3371. the same patterned consistency shows itself in occupational choices.	14.009697241889988
3372. there is impressive consistency between specific occupational	preferences and the student's basic conception of what is for him a	good way of life.	14.650112042819657
3373. and contrary to many popular assertions the goal-values	chosen do not seem to us to be primarily oriented to materialistic	success nor to mere conformity.	10.043303061405329
3374. our students want occupations	that permit them to use their talents and training to be creative	and original to work with and to help other people.	10.523852585069104
3375. they also want	money prestige and security.	18.21012427828325
3376. but they are optimistic about their	prospects in these regards; they set limits to their aspirations-	few aspire to millions of dollars or to imperial power and	glory.	12.977938458580455
3377. within the fixed frame of these aspirations they can afford	to place a high value on the expressive and people-oriented aspects of	occupation and to minimize the instrumental-reward values of power	prestige and wealth.	8.618202948071742
3378. occupational choices are also useful-	and interesting- in bringing out clearly that values do not constitute	the only component in goals and aspirations.	9.051154372622117
3379. for there is also the	face of reality in the form of the individual's perceptions	of	his own abilities and interests of the objective possibilities open	to him of the familial and other social pressures to which he is exposed.	10.616278132861764
3380. we find reluctant recruits whose values are not in line with	their expected occupation's characteristics.	13.51247461108391
3381. students develop occupational	images- not always accurate or detailed- and they try to	fit their values to the presumed characteristics of the imagined occupation.	8.101513743852289
3382. the purely cognitive or informational problems are often acute.	14.310793878502059
3383. furthermore many reluctant recruits are yielding to social demands	or compromising in the face of their own limitations of opportunity	or of ability and performance.	10.430884533150833
3384. thus many a creativity-oriented aspirant	for a career in architecture drama or journalism resigns himself	to a real estate business; many a people-oriented student who dreams	of the md decides to enter his father's advertising agency;	and many a hopeful incipient business executive decides it were	better to teach the theory of business administration than to practice	it.	8.667329436724199
3385. the old ideal of the independent entrepreneur is extant- but	so is the recognition that the main chance may be in a corporate bureaucracy.	10.432320814914952
3386. in their views on dating courtship sex and family	life our students prefer what they are expected to prefer.	14.21510310530959
3387. for them	in the grim words of a once-popular song love and marriage go together	like a horse and carriage.	9.89073019082323
3388. their expressed standards concerning	sex roles desirable age for marriage characteristics of an ideal mate	number of children desired are congruent with the values and stereotypes	of the preceding generation- minus compulsive rebellion.	8.66283501238716
3389. they	even accept the double standard of sex morality in a double sense	ie both sexes agree that standards for men differ from standards	for women and women apply to both sexes a standard different from	that held by men.	7.274587416197399
3390. conservatism and traditionalism	seem implied by what has just been said.	11.33819267263277
3391. but these terms are treacherous.	23.65061755049962
3392. in the field of political values it is certainly true that	students are not radical not rebels against their parents or their peers.	14.190385967692233
3393. and as they go through college the students tend to bring their	political position in line with that prevalent in the social groups	to which they belong.	9.515761997081265
3394. yet they have accepted most of the extant welfare	state provisions for health security and the regulation of	economic affairs and they overwhelmingly approve of the traditional	liberalism of the bill of rights.	10.606956541314933
3395. when their faith in civil	liberties is tested against strong pressures of social expediency in specific	issues eg suppression of dangerous ideas many waver	and give in.	8.482650910768692
3396. the students who are most willing to acquiesce in the	suppression of civil liberties are also those who are most likely to	be prejudiced against minority groups to be conformist and traditionalistic	in general social attitudes and to lack a basic faith in people.	9.027454141736426
3397. as one looks at the existing evidence one finds a correlation	although only a slight one between high grades and libertarian	values.	9.742383208691285
3398. but the correlation is substantial only among upperclassmen.	19.874437701433678
3399. in other words as students go through college those who are	most successful academically tend to become more committed to a bill	of rights orientation.	10.344358372405571
3400. college in gross- just the general experience-	may have varying effects but the the students who are successful	emerge with strengthened and clarified democratic values.	9.347576056083255
3401. this finding is consistent also with the fact that student leaders are	more likely to be supporters of the values implicit in civil liberties	than the other students.	9.513881971187033
3402. there is now substantial evidence	from several major studies of college students that the experience of	the college years results in a certain selective homogenization of	attitudes and values.	13.234516190781767
3403. detached from their prior statuses and social	groups and exposed to the pervasive stimuli of the university milieu	the students tend to assimilate a new common culture to converge	toward norms characteristic of their own particular campus.	8.383242381125177
3404. furthermore	in certain respects there are norms common to colleges and universities	across the country.	10.829833106340251
3405. for instance college-educated people consistently	show up in study after study as more often than others supporters	of the bill of rights and other democratic rights and liberties.	8.999413712922804
3406. the interesting thing in this connection is that the norms upon which	students tend to converge include toleration of diversity.	13.282194849507942
3407. to the extent that our sampling of the orientations of american college	students in the years 1950 and 1952 may be representative of our	culture- and still valid in 1959- we are disposed to question the	summary characterization of the current generation as silent beat	apathetic or as a mass of other-directed conformists who are guided	solely by social radar without benefit of inner gyroscopes.	7.893140835856442
3408. our data	indicate that these students of today do basically accept the existing	institutions of the society and in the face of the realities of complex	and large-scale economic and political problems make a wary and	ambivalent delegation of trust to those who occupy positions of legitimized	responsibility for coping with such collective concerns.	10.706833402764959
3409. in	a real sense they are admittedly conservative but their conservatism	incorporates a traditionalized embodiment of the original radicalism	of 1776.	9.719592036667228
3410. although we have no measures of its strength or intensity	the heritage of the doctrine of inalienable rights is retained.	13.726458058163576
3411. as they move through the college years our young men and women are socialized	into a broadly similar culture at the level of personal	behavior.	10.658665151992839
3412. in this sense also they are surely conformists.	24.696696320088087
3413. it is	even true that some among them use the sheer fact of conformity- everyone	does it- as a criterion for conduct.	9.757475451646688
3414. but the extent of	ethical robotism is easily overestimated.	19.874437701433678
3415. few students are really so	faceless in the not-so-lonely crowd of the swelling population in our	institutions of higher learning.	8.522476217538351
3416. and it may be well to recall that to	say	conformity is in part another way of saying orderly human	society.	14.98047990238408
3417. in the field of religious beliefs and values the	college students seem to faithfully reflect the surrounding culture.	13.535971960784542
3418. their commitments are for the most part couched in a familiar idiom.	15.42565700579438
3419. students testify to a felt need for a religious faith or ultimate	personal philosophy.	10.76046447084964
3420. avowed atheists or freethinkers are so rare as	to be a curiosity.	10.957705180640192
3421. the religious quest is often intense and deep	and there are students on every campus who are seriously wrestling with	the most profound questions of meaning and value.	8.115239882301966
3422. at the same time	a major proportion of these young men and women see religion as a means	of personal adjustment an anchor for family life a source of emotional	security.	12.926120423069094
3423. these personal and social goals often overshadow the	goals of intellectual clarity and spiritual transcendence.	9.495459372186279
3424. the cult	of adjustment does exist.	19.926638570224114
3425. it exists alongside the acceptance of	traditional forms of organized religion	.	14.157168776918788
3426. still another segment of the student population consists	of those who seek in what they regard as religion intellectual clarity	rational belief and ethical guidance and reinforcement.	10.248349127920367
3427. our first impression of the data was that the students were surprisingly	orthodox and religiously involved.	9.790072039264118
3428. upon second thought we were	forced to realize that we have very few reliable historical benchmarks	against which we might compare the present situation and that conclusions	that present-day students are more or less religious	could not be defended on the basis of our data.	11.501502218494755
3429. as we looked more intently	at the content of our belief and the extent of religious participation	we received the impression that many of the religious convictions	expressed represented a conventional acceptance of low intensity.	11.850234358468954
3430. but here again comparative benchmarks are lacking and we do not	know in any case what measure of profoundity and intensity to expect	from healthy young secure and relatively inexperienced persons;	after all feelings of immortality and invulnerability are standard illusions	of youth.	9.149696129884314
3431. nor are optimistic and socially-oriented themes at	all rare in the distinctive religious history of this country.	9.99283090031335
3432. kluckhohn recently has summarized evidence regarding changes in values	during a period of years primarily 1935-1955 but extending much farther	back in some instances.	10.036199955114311
3433. a variety of data are assembled to bear	upon such alleged changes as diminished puritan morality work-success	ethic individualism achievement lessened emphasis on future-time	orientation in favor of sociability moral relativism consideration and	tolerance conformity hedonistic present-time orientation.	8.395082757858734
3434. although	he questions the extent and nature of the alleged revival of religion	and the alleged increase in conformity and thinks that hedonistic	present-time orientation does not have the meaning usually attributed	to it he does conclude that americans increasingly enjoy leisure	without guilt do not stress achievement so much as formerly are more	accepting of group harmony as a goal more tolerant of diversity and	aware of other cultures.	9.042340129050046
3435. from new jersey morgan hastened to the headquarters of washington	at whitemarsh pennsylvania arriving there on november 18th.	9.96692165399657

3463. apparently still sensitive	about the idea with which general gates had approached him at saratoga	namely that george washington be replaced morgan was vehement	in his support of the commander-in-chief during the campaign around	philadelphia.	8.266776103303174

3468. in	late december the american army moved from whitemarsh to valley	forge and although the distance was only 13 miles the journey took	more than a week because of the bad weather the barefooted and almost	naked men.	9.208418598759918

3513. it was not merely a hunger for money gold and precious objects	that delayed the papal pronouncement that could have brought the war	to an end; the pope was playing a dangerous game with so many balls	in the air at once that a misstep would bring them all about his ears	and his only hope was to temporize so that he could take advantage	of every change in the delicate balance of european affairs.	8.532531923613972
3514. when the	negotiations began his quarrel with the king of france was temporarily	in abeyance and he had no intention of reviving it so long as there	was hope that french money would come to pay the troops who under	charles of valois	the papal vicar of tuscany were so valuable in	the crusade against the colonna cardinals and their sicilian allies.	10.537263206179462

3524. tact by	its very derivation implies that its possessor keeps in touch with other	people but the author of clericis laicos and unam sanctam	the wielder of the two swords the papal sun of which the imperial	moon was but a dim reflection the peer of caesar and vice-regent	of christ was so high above other human beings that he had forgotten	what they were like.	9.009840741930043
