3700. at	this point of course the issue has become complicated by a development	unforeseen by lappenberg and kemble.	10.683075001441855
3701. they however much they were	in disagreement with the late victorians over the method by which	britain was germanized agreed with them that the end result was the	complete extinction of the previous celtic population and civilization.	8.322471590033524
3702. but beginning for all practical purposes with frederick seebohm's	english village community scholars have had to reckon	with a theory involving institutional and agrarian continuity between	roman and anglo-saxon times which is completely at odds with the reigning	concept of the anglo-saxon invasions.	9.830768495295192
3703. against seebohm formidable	foes have taken the field notably f w maitland whose	domesday book and beyond was written expressly for this purpose	and sir paul vinogradoff whose the growth of the manor had	a similar aim.	8.44714927202177
3704. largely due to their efforts the catastrophic invasion-theory	has maintained its position although seebohm has always found	supporters.	9.723773562266802
3705. hl gray in his english field systems and	zachrisson's romans kelts and saxons defended in part the	seebohm thesis while at the present time hpr finberg and	gordon copley seem to fall into the celtic survivalist camp.	0.0
3706. this	is nevertheless a minority view.	19.63613844052011
3707. most scholars while willing to accept	a survival of celtic art forms and a considerable proportion	of the celtic population reject any institutional legacy from	pre-anglo-saxon britain.	8.16966468548336
3708. therefore it is plain that the	clear distinctions of the nineteenth century are no longer with us.	17.420341011820142
3709. in the main stream of historical thinking is a group of scholars hm	chadwick rh hodgkin sir frank stenton et al	who are in varying degrees sceptical of the native traditions of the conquest	but who defend the catastrophic type of invasion suggested by	them.	8.88223587846767
3710. they in effect have compromised the opposing positions of the	nineteenth century.	13.43850623403577
3711. on the other side are the celtic survivalists who	have taken a tack divergent from both these schools of nineteenth century	thought.	13.200237079954979
3712. as a group they should be favorable to a concept of gradual	germanic infiltration although the specialist nature of much of	their work eg seebohm gray and finberg tends to obscure	their sympathies.	12.064383465936814
3713. those who do have occasion to deal with the invasions	in a more general way like tw shore and arthur wade-evans	are on the side of a gradual and often peaceful germanic penetration	into britain.	12.19223561783057
3714. wade-evans in fact denies that there were any anglo-saxon	invasions at all other than a minor jutish foray in ad	514.	9.935181008986339
3715. now omitting for a moment some recent developments	we can say the saxon shore hypothesis of lappenberg and kemble has	undergone virtual eclipse in this century.	8.968987081373632
3716. it is no longer possible	to say that a sceptical attitude towards the received accounts of the	invasions almost automatically produces a shore occupied by interpretation.	14.05361741869562
3717. everyone is more or less sceptical and virtually no one has	been willing to accept lappenberg or kemble's position on that	point.	8.70515921666629
3718. one reason is of course that the new scepticism has been willing	to maintain the general picture of the invasions as portrayed in	the traditional sources.	13.964524252610454
3719. the few scholars who have adopted the shore	occupied by interpretation howorth shore and wade-evans	have all been celtic survivalists.	9.400280577130196
3720. moreover they have done so in rather	special circumstances.	18.68634384228653
3721. the primary reason for the abandonment	of the shore occupied by thesis has been the assimilation and	accumulation of archaeological evidence the most striking feature	of early english studies in this century.	8.862366382842458
3722. again omitting recent developments	et	leeds' dictum of 1913 has stood unchallenged: so far	as archaeology is concerned there is not the least warrant for the	second of these theories.	11.669395237737792
3723. even earlier haverfield	had come to the same conclusion.	18.056269821220585
3724. what they meant was that there	was no evidence to show that the south and east coasts of britain received	germanic settlers conspicuously earlier than some other parts of	england.	12.438779120190507
3725. that is there was no trace of anglo-saxons in britain	as early as the late third century to which time the archaeological	evidence for the erection of the saxon shore forts was beginning to	point.	8.857344061761403
3726. in the face of a clear judgment from archaeology therefore it	became impossible for a time for scholars to re-adopt the shore settled	by theory.	15.4370440631581
3727. in recent years however a wind of change	seems to be blowing through early english historical circles.	12.73955057840778
3728. the	great increase in the amount of archaeological activity and therefore	information in the years immediately preceeding and following the second	world war has brought to light data which has changed the complection	of the saxon shore dispute.	10.70166684532074
3729. where there were none fifteen years	ago several scholars currently are edging their way cautiously towards	the acceptance of the shore occupied by position.	10.671328325182275
3730. we must	therefore have a look at the new archaeological material and re-examine	the literary and place-name evidence which bears upon the problem.	13.362375197888573
3731. what exactly are we trying to prove?	14.678537531441105
3732.  we know that the	saxon shore was a phenonenon of late roman defensive policy; in	other words its existence belongs to the period of roman britain.	11.96709631811562
3733. so	whenever the romans finally withdrew from the island the saxon shore	disappeared in the first decade of the fifth century.	11.886624507777697
3734. we also know	that the saxon shore as reflected in the notitia was created	as a part of the theodosian reorganization of britain	.	14.664817011931127
3735. my argument is that there was no saxon shore prior to that	time even though the forts had been in existence since the time of carausius.	12.546651084855368
3736. therefore what we must prove or disprove is that there were	saxons in the broad sense in which we must construe the word in	the area of the saxon shore at the time it was called the saxon shore.	12.202927960497538
3737. that is we must find saxons in east anglia kent sussex and	hampshire in the last half of the fourth century.	12.905697877816097
3738. the problem	in other words is strictly a chronological one.	14.310793878502059
3739. in gaul the saxon	element on its saxon shore was plainly visible because there the	saxons were an intrusive element in the population.	9.0082069863666
3740. in britain obviously	the archaeological and place-name characteristics of the saxon	shore region are bound to be saxon.	11.794370699993864
3741. it is a matter of trying to	sort out an earlier fourth-century saxon element from the later fifth-century	mainstream of anglo-saxon invasions.	13.9767449420763
3742. this naturally will	be difficult to do since both the archaeological and place-name evidence	in this period with some fortunate exceptions is insufficient	for precise chronological purposes.	9.712333998600402
3743. it might be well to consider	the literary evidence first because it can provide us with an answer	to one important question; namely is the idea that there were saxon	mercenaries in england at all reasonable?	10.025129667452635
3744. 	to do so something was necessary beyond volunteering because there was	little glamour or romance in the european war; it meant instead	hardship dirt and death.	8.777324869432913
3745. baker gave leonard wood credit for	the initiation of the draft of soldiers; from the general's idea	a chain reaction occurred.	7.9139724503302755
3746. wood took the proposal to chief of staff	hugh l scott who passed it on to baker a month before the actual	declaration of war against germany.	8.935664881287627
3747. the secretary of war gave	his assent after studying the history of the draft in the american	civil war as well as the british volunteer system in world war 1.	12.697482362343406
3748. he concluded that selective service would not only prevent the disorganization	of essential war industries but would avoid the undesirable	moral effects of the british reliance on enlistment only- where	the feeling of the people was whipped into a frenzy by girls pinning	white feathers on reluctant young men orators preaching hate of the	germans and newspapers exaggerating enemy outrages to make men enlist	out of motives of revenge and retaliation.	9.01503187093228
3749. baker took the plan	to wilson who said: baker this is plainly right on any ground.	8.450640073948662
3750. start to prepare the necessary legislation so that if i am obliged	to go to congress the bills will be ready for immediate consideration.	13.080293549411573
3751. the result was that by secret agreement draft machinery was actually	ready long before the country knew that the device was to take	the place of the volunteering method which theodore roosevelt favored.	9.417627266474375
3752. before the draft act was passed baker had confidentially briefed	governors sheriffs and prospective draft board members on the administration	of the measure- and the confidence was kept so well that	only one newspaper learned what was going on.	9.269650898309106
3753. it was baker working	through provost marshal enoch crowder and major hugh s	johnson who arranged for a secret printing by the	million of selective service blanks- again before the act was passed-	until corridors in the government printing office were full	and the basement of the washington post office was stacked to the ceiling.	7.936516232261229
3754. general crowder proposed that regular army officers select	the draftees in cities and towns throughout the nation; it was baker	who thought of lessening the shock which conscription always brings	to a country by substituting greetings from your neighbors for	the recruiting sergeant and registration in familiar voting places	rather than at military installations.	7.910627592245061
3755. even so the draft act	encountered rough sledding in its progress through the congress.	12.136534707872007
3756. democratic	speaker champ clark saw little difference between a conscript	and a convict.	11.685627036032388
3757. democrat stanley h dent chairman of the	house military affairs committee declined to introduce the bill.	8.450640073948662
3758. democratic floor leader claude kitchin would have no part of the	measure.	11.874164060090717
3759. in the judgment of chief of staff scott it was ironic that	the draft policy of a democratic president aimed at germany had	to be pushed through the house of representatives by the ranking minority	member of the military affairs committee- a republican jew	born in germany! he was julius kahn for whom the chief of staff	thought no honor could be too great.	7.906523249108071
3760. after kahn's death in 1924	scott wrote: may he rest in peace with the eternal gratitude	of his adopted country.	12.118827562579934
3761. in spite of powerful opposition the	draft act finally passed congress on may 17 1917.	12.975306596598324
3762. in early june	ten million young men registered by name and number.	14.174449266743885
3763. the day passed	without incident in spite of the warning of senator james a reed	of missouri: baker you will have the streets of our american	cities running with blood on registration day.	11.592780486277787
3764. on july 20 the	first drawing of numbers occurred in the senate office building before	a distinguished group of congressmen and high army officers.	12.088592376446435
3765. secretary	of war baker blindfolded put his hand into a large glass	bowl and drew the initial number of those to be called.	7.719095379114949
3766. a man in mississippi wired: thanks for drawing 258- that's	me.	18.810589512966207
3767. he was the first of 2800000 called to the army through the	selective service system.	17.74043693596121
3768. it was one thing to call men to the	colors; it was another to house feed and train them.	14.202899577639277
3769. the existing	army posts were wholly inadequate.	15.260583014183545
3770. in a matter of months the war	department built thirty-two camps each one accommodating fifty thousand	men- sixteen were under canvas in the south and sixteen with frame	structures in the north.	12.588537782763375
3771. it was a gargantuan task; a typical	cantonment in the north had twelve hundred buildings an electric-sewer-water	system and twenty-five miles of roads.	12.458523436119087
3772. at camp taylor in kentucky	a barracks was built in an hour and a half from timber that had	been standing in mississippi forests one week before.	13.17300228742428
3773. the total	operation	was a construction project comparable in magnitude with the panama	canal but in 1917 time was in short supply; in three months	the army spent three-quarters as much as had been expended on the big	ditch in ten years.	8.277929675983822
3774. in later years josephus danielswas	to	claim that world war 1 was the first in american history in which	there was great concern for both the health and morals of our soldiers.	13.069727976524035
3775. it was the first american war in which the death rate from disease	was lower than that from battle due to the provision of trained	medical personnel compulsory	vaccination rigorous camp sanitation and adequate hospital	facilities.	11.720847548671518
3776. to the middle of september 1918 there had been fewer than	10000 deaths from disease in the new army.	17.510474033753884
3777. this enviable record	would have been maintained but for a great and unexpected disaster which	struck	the world with murderous stealth.	9.130568048735583
3778. it was the influenza pandemic	of 1918-19.	37.418055266756554
3779. the malady was popularly known as the spanish flu	from the alleged locale of its origin.	11.26189007519089
3780. the world-wide total of deaths	from spanish flu was around twenty million; in the united	states 300000 succumbed to it.	11.405218283491637
3781. in mid-september 1918 the influenza-pneumonia	pandemic swept through every american military camp; during	the eight-week blitz attack 25000 soldiers died from the disease	and the death rate increased almost	fifty times to 4 per week per 1000 men.	8.146348881236557
3782. in spite of this catastrophe	the final mortality figure from disease in the american army	during world war 1 was 15 per 1000 per year contrasted with	110 per 1000 per year in the mexican war and 65 in the american civil	war.	12.277341316582637
3783. both secretary of war baker and secretary of navy	daniels devoted much time and effort to the problem of providing	reasonably normal and wholesome activities in camp for the millions of	men who had been removed from their home environment.	8.776867257795377
3784. their policy	ran counter to the traditional idea that a good fighter was usually a	libertine and that in sex affairs god-given passion was a proof	of manliness.	9.570294252539515
3785. baker moved first; six days after war was declared	he appointed raymond fosdick chairman of the commission on training	camp activities.	10.81533599051441
3786. fosdick a brother of minister	harry emerson fosdick was a graduate of princeton and a member of	phi beta kappa and the american philosophical association.	11.865448529567647
3787. his	assignment was not a new one because baker had sent him to the mexican	border in 1916 to investigate lurid newspaper stories about lack	of discipline drunkenness and venereal disease in american military	camps.	8.66657510597812
3788. fosdick had found the installations surrounded by a battery of	saloons and houses of prostitution with filles de joie from all	over the country flocking to san antonio laredo and el paso to	woman the cribs.	8.473791467228605
3789. he also ascertained that many officers were	indifferent to the problem including commanding general frederick	funston who gave fosdick the nickname of reverend.	10.535230559416593
3790. on the basis	of the long chronicle of military history funston and his brethren	assumed that the issue was insoluble and that anyone interested in a	mission like fosdick's was an impractical idealist or a do-gooder.	10.458814712579565
3791. during the brief mexican venture fosdick's report to the	secretary recommended a definite stand by the war department against	the saloon and the excesses of prostitution.	9.902301202724091
3792. the problem involved military	necessity as much as morality for in pre-penicillin days venereal	disease was a crippling disability.	13.484771495712602
3793. fosdick insisted that a strong	word was needed from washington and it was immediately forthcoming.	9.742088144514208
3794. baker put the cribs and the saloons out of bounds ordered the	co-operation of military officers with local law authorities and told	communities that the troops would be moved unless wholesome conditions	were restored.	8.90516556096576
3795. both baker and fosdick knew that a substitute was	necessary that a verboten approach was not the real answer.	10.089705343174327
3796. they	were aware that soldiers went to town in more ways than one because	of the monotony of camp life to find the only release available in	the absence of movies reading rooms and playing fields with adequate	athletic equipment.	9.296351231732928
3797. both knew that when trains stopped at texan crossroads	bored soldiers would sometimes enter to ask the passengers if	they had any reading material to spare even a newspaper.	7.6805848723165395
3798. there was	no time in the short mexican encounter to evolve a solution but the	area provided a proving ground for new departures in the near future.	12.552226854321821
3799. when the united states entered the first world war baker	made certain that the draft act of 1917 prohibited the sale of liquor	to men in uniform and that it provided for broad zones around the camps	in which prostitution was outlawed.	10.603115059563622
3800. even so fosdick as the new	chairman of the commission on training camp activities encountered	strong and vociferous opposition.	14.350499992381096
3801. new orleans had a notorious red-light	district extending over twenty-eight city blocks and the business-minded	mayor of the city journeyed to washington to present the	case for the god-given right of men to be men.	8.42787947260908
3802. in europe premier	clemenceau showing his animal proclivities as the tiger of	france asked pershing by letter for the creation of special houses	where the sexual desires of american men could be satisfied.	10.48826849829031
3803. when	fosdick showed the letter to baker his negative response was: for	god's sake raymond don't show this to the president or	he'll stop the war.	8.547875249341322
3804. ultimately fosdick's fit to fight	slogan swept across the country and every well-known red-light district	in the united states was closed a hundred and ten of them.	12.632644249020515
3805. the	result was that the rate of venereal disease in the american army	was the lowest in our military history.	10.721107303423995
3806. this was the negative	side of the situation.	28.297907460129245
3807. affirmatively baker worked on the premise that	young men spontaneously prefer to be decent and that opportunities	for wholesome recreation are the best possible cure for irregularities	in conduct which arise from idleness and the baser temptations.	7.673752029006506
3808. the wholesome activities were to be provided by many organizations including	the ymca the knights of columbus the jewish welfare	board the american library association and the playground and	recreation association- private societies which voluntarily performed	the job that was taken over almost entirely by the special services	division of the army itself in world war 2.	9.097480850202931
3809. over these	voluntary agencies in 1917-18 the ctca served as a co-ordinating	body in carrying out what survey called the most stupendous	piece of social work in modern times.	8.615059805733186
3810. under fosdick the first	executive officer of the ctca was richard byrd whose name in	later years was to become synonymous with activities at the polar antipodes.	10.20198897279547
3811. from the point of view of popularity the best-known member of	the commission was walter camp the yale athlete whose sobriquet	was the father of american football.	10.036305697089594
3812. he was placed in charge of	athletics and among other things adapted the type of calisthenics known	as the daily dozen.	13.709374952630588
3813. the ctca program of activities was profuse:	william farnum and mary pickford on the screen elsie janis	and harry lauder on the stage books provided by the american	library association full equipment for games and sports- except that	no bones were furnished for the all-time favorite pastime played	on any floor and known as african golf.	7.58667664129348
3814. the ctca distributed	a khaki-bound songbook that provided the impetus for spirited	renditions of the selections found therein plus a number of others	whose lyrics were more earthy- from johnny get your gun to	keep the home fires burning to mademoiselle from armentieres.	8.905097240988033
3815. in the imagination of the nineteenth century the greek tragedians and	shakespeare stand side by side their affinity transcending all the	immense contrarieties of historical circumstance religious belief and	poetic form.	12.930334846460218
3816. we no longer use the particular terms of lessing	and victor hugo.	15.321685707098714
3817. but we abide by their insight.	22.47706267988082
3818. the word tragedy	encloses for us in a single span both the greek and the elizabethan	example.	13.855257688737604
3819. the sense of relationship overreaches the historical	truth that shakespeare may have known next to nothing of the actual	works of aeschylus sophocles and euripides.	9.713158381059479
3820. it transcends the	glaring fact that the elizabethans mixed tragedy and comedy whereas	the greeks kept the two modes severely distinct.	12.697026961642726
3821. it overcomes our emphatic	awareness of the vast difference in the shape and fabric of the	two languages and styles of dramatic presentation.	12.588836520024199
3822. the intimations of	a related spirit and ordering of human values are stronger than any	sense of disparity.	11.026675696446196
3823. comparable visions of life are at work in antigone	and romeo and juliet.	9.192705502239976
3824. we see at once what victor hugo	means when he calls macbeth a northern scion of the house of atreus.	13.406429631779487
3825. elsinore seems to lie in a range of mycenae and the fate of orestes	resounds in that of hamlet.	9.573684258706386
3826. the hounds of hell search out their	quarry in apollo's sanctuary as they do in the tent of richard 3.	13.372975198384887
3827. oedipus and lear attain similar insights by virtue of similar blindness.	10.542676094873617
3828. it it not between euripides and shakespeare that the western	mind turns away from the ancient tragic sense of life.	12.666608066716472
3829. it is after	the late seventeenth century.	28.377235298007196
3830. i say the late seventeenth century because	racine stands on the far side	of the chasm.	15.33795679601783
3831. the image of man which enters into force with aeschylus	is still vital in phedre and athalie.	12.299574401423175
3832. it is the	triumph of rationalism and secular metaphysics which marks the point	of no return.	16.42378929693989
3833. shakespeare is closer to sophocles than he is to pope	and voltaire.	14.507422949066763
3834. to say this is to set aside the realness of time.	19.10010501930574
3835. but	it is true nevertheless.	25.410777313215416
3836. the modes of the imagination implicit in	athenian tragedy continued to shape the life of the mind until the age	of descartes and newton.	14.606453541687603
3837. it is only then that the ancient habits	of feeling and the classic orderings of material and psychological experience	were abandoned.	13.03298652947806
3838. with the discours de la methode and the	principia the things undreamt of in horatio's philosophy seem	to pass from the world.	11.361477376821597
3839. in greek tragedy as in shakespeare	mortal actions are encompassed by forces which transcend man.	10.694184739355702
3840. the reality	of orestes entails that of the furies; the weird sisters wait	for the soul of macbeth.	12.591381973032304
3841. we cannot conceive of oedipus without a	sphinx nor of hamlet without a ghost.	11.61546602894831
3842. the shadows cast by the personages	of greek and shakespearean drama lengthen into a greater darkness.	11.867210091086676
3843. and the entirety of the natural world is party to the action.	13.985742872590475
3844. the thunderclaps over the sacred wood at colonus and the storms in	king lear are caused by more than weather.	10.834326386071012
3845. in tragedy lightning	is a messenger.	19.735694605127364
3846. but it can no longer be so once benjamin franklin	has flown a kite to it.	20.508164748162333
3847. the	tragic stage is a platform extending precariously between heaven and	hell.	9.669550099771405
3848. those who walk on it may encounter at any turn ministers of grace	or damnation.	13.028875451397203
3849. oedipus and lear instruct us how little of	the world belongs to man.	9.070074471681158
3850. mortality is the pacing of a brief and dangerous	watch and to all sentinels whether at elsinore or on the battlements	at mycenae the coming of dawn has its breath of miracle.	9.482478153800749
3851. it	banishes the night wanderers to fire or repose.	10.530932308755343
3852. but at the touch of	hume and voltaire the noble or hideous visitations which had haunted	the mind since agamemnon's blood cried out for vengeance disappeared	altogether or took tawdry refuge among the gaslights of melodrama.	10.731720590348235
3853. modern roosters have lost the art of crowing restless spirits back to	purgatory.	11.64265507223918
3854. in athens in shakespeare's england and at	versailles the hierarchies of worldly power were stable and manifest.	11.794370699993864
3855. the wheel of social life spun around the royal or aristocratic centre.	11.717792340103959
3856. from it spokes of order and degree led to the outward rim of the	common man.	12.659159953820822
3857. tragedy presumes such a configuration.	12.851133807717682
3858. its sphere is that	of royal courts dynastic quarrels and vaulting ambitions.	11.815485504043828
3859. the same	metaphors of swift ascent and calamitous decline apply to oedipus	and macbeth because they applied also to alcibiades and essex.	8.674870936306482
3860. and	the fate of such men has tragic relevance because it is public.	12.695934191639111
3861. agamemnon	creon and medea perform their tragic actions before the eyes	of the polis.	9.070074471681158
3862. similarly the sufferings of hamlet othello	or phedre engage the fortunes of the state.	11.351647747808283
3863. they are enacted at the	heart of the body politic.	17.802313136824733
3864. hence the natural setting of tragedy is the	palace gate the public square or the court chamber.	11.791527870581819
3865. greek and elizabethan	life and to a certain extent the life of versailles shared	this character of intense publicity.	9.339010842554865
3866. princes and factions clashed	in the open street and died on the open scaffold.	11.461944118285162
3867. with the	rise to power of the middle class the centre of gravity in human affairs	shifted from the public to the private.	13.610959163235096
3868. the art of defoe and richardson	is founded on an awareness of this great change.	17.461919154729003
3869. heretofore	an action had possessed the breadth of tragedy only if it involved high	personages and if it occurred in the public view.	10.088754744996828
3870. behind the tragic	hero stands the chorus the crowd or the observant courtier.	12.579710649622275
3871. in the	eighteenth century there emerges for the first time the notion of a	private tragedy	number of elizabethan domestic tragedies such as the famous arden	.	12.004430967458266
3872. in la nouvelle-heloi^se and werther	tragedy is made intimate.	17.034822554424267
3873. and private tragedy became the chosen ground	not of drama but of the new unfolding art of the novel.	12.242791121665332
3874. the novel was not only the presenter of the new secular rationalistic	private world of the middle class.	17.916031585430687
3875. it served also as a literary form	exactly appropriate to the fragmented audience of modern urban culture.	10.829199914662594
3876. i have said before how difficult it is to make any precise statements	with regard to the character of the greek and elizabethan public.	19.55242447432118
3877. but one major fact seems undeniable.	21.11290113259676
3878. until the advent of rational	empiricism the controlling habits of the western mind were symbolic	and allegoric.	13.666020651385168
3879. available evidence regarding the natural world the	course of history and the varieties of human action were translated	into imaginative designs or mythologies.	8.424415450715127
3880. classic mythology and christianity	are such architectures of the imagination.	11.793662721363662
3881. they order the manifold	levels of reality and moral value along an axis of being which	extends from brute matter to the immaculate stars.	8.588365825225
3882. there had not yet	supervened between understanding and expression the new languages of	mathematics and scientific formulas.	15.004540007728046
3883. the poet was by definition a realist	his imaginings and parables being natural organizations of reality.	9.646584389395406
3884. and in these organizations certain primal notions played a radiant	part radiant both in the sense of giving light and of being a pole	toward which all perspectives converge.	13.285912329596902
3885. i mean such concepts as the presence	of the supernatural in human affairs the sacraments of grace	and divine retribution the idea of preordainment	the prophecy of the witches to macbeth or god's covenant with	.	8.496308937694899
3886. i refer to the notion that the structure	of society is a microcosm of the cosmic design and that history	conforms to patterns of justice and chastisement as if it were a morality	play set in motion by the gods for our instruction.	11.096712547292709
3887. these	conceptions and the manner in which they were transposed into poetry or	engendered by poetic form are intrinsic to western life from the time	of aeschylus to that of shakespeare.	9.694256913878332
3888. and although they were as i	have indicated under increasing strain at the time of racine they	are still alive in his theatre.	14.31480816791822
3889. they are the essential force behind	the conventions of tragedy.	16.74534619098603
3890. they are as decisively present in the oresteia	and oedipus as in macbeth king lear and phedre.	13.80043266152703
3891. after the seventeenth century the audience ceased to	be an organic community to which these ideas and their attendant habits	of figurative language would be natural or immediately familiar.	8.94554005849344
3892. concepts	such as grace damnation purgation blasphemy or the chain of	being which are everywhere implicit in classic and shakespearean tragedy	lose their vitality.	9.051154372622117
3893. they become philosophic abstractions of	a private and problematic relevance or mere catchwords in religious customs	which had in them a diminishing part of active belief.	8.350369773860487
3894. after shakespeare	the master spirits of western consciousness are no longer	the blind seers the poets or orpheus performing his art in the face	of hell.	9.872309018460065
3895. they are descartes newton and voltaire.	19.23144912003902
3896. and their chroniclers	are not the dramatic poets but the prose novelists.	13.847265734140931
3897. the	romantics were the immediate inheritors of this tremendous change.	10.057988591011652
3898. they were not yet prepared to accept it as irremediable.	25.268576800264263
3899. rousseau's	primitivism the anti-newtonian mythology of blake coleridge's	organic metaphysics victor hugo's image of the poets as the magi	and shelley's unacknowledged legislators are related elements	in the rear-guard action fought by the romantics against the new	scientific rationalism.	7.404315842331646
3900. from this action sprang the idea of somehow uniting	greek and shakespearean drama into a new total form capable	of restoring to life the ancient moral and poetic responses.	10.500363219752513
3901. the dream	of achieving a synthesis between the sophoclean and the shakespearean	genius inspired the ambitions of poets and composers from the time	of shelley and victor hugo to that of bayreuth.	8.35266804339194
3902. it could not really	be fulfilled.	39.29379647642292
3903. the conventions into which the romantics tried to breath	life no longer corresponded to the realities of thought and feeling.	10.434399572520682
3904. but the attempt itself produced a number of brilliant works and	these form a transition from the early romantic period to the new age	of ibsen and chekhov.	12.861276903808378
3905. the wedding of the hellenic to the northern	genius was one of the dominant motifs in goethe's thought.	12.505862827467698
3906. his	italian journey was a poet's version of those perennial thrusts	across the alps of the german emperors of the middle ages.	10.818667212171446
3907. the dream	of a descent into the gardens of the south always drew german ambitions	toward rome and sicily.	12.093488559070714
3908. goethe asks in wilhelm meister	whether we know the land where the lemon trees flower and the light	of the mediterranean glows through torquato tasso and the roman	elegies.	9.141071651479482
3909. goethe believed that the germanic spirit with its	grave strength but flagrant streaks of brutality and intolerance should	be tempered with the old sensuous wisdom and humanism of the hellenic.	7.409221547716014
3910. on the narrower ground of poetic form he felt that in the drama	of the future the greek conception of tragic fate should be joined to	the shakespearean vision of tragic will.	11.03383315509481
3911. the wager between god and	satan brings on the destiny of faust but faust assumes his role	voluntarily.	9.646069374099351
3912. the third act of faust 2 is a formal celebration	of the union between the germanic and the classic between	the spirit of euripides and that of romantic drama.	10.052218951896311
3913. the motif of faust's	love for helen of troy goes back to the sources of the faustian	legend.	15.430209215013011
3914. it tells us of the ancient human desire to see the highest	wisdom joined to the highest sensual beauty.	14.519827943384263
3915. there can be no greater	magic than to wrest from death her in whom the flesh was all in whom	beauty was entirely pure because it was entirely corruptible.	10.48979599058333
3916. it is	thus that the brightness of helen passes through marlowe's faustus.	16.179913762157334
3917. goethe used the fable to more elaborate ends.	10.530932308755343
3918. faust rescuing	helen from menelaus' vengeance is the genius of renaissance europe	restoring to life the classic tradition.	9.723773562266802

3988. the fall of rome the discovery of precious metals and the protestant	reformation were all links and could only be explained and understood	by comprehending the links that preceded and those that followed.	9.435723362429936
3989. often the historian must consider the use of intuition or instinct	by those individuals or nations which he is studying.	10.067872361127787
3990. unconsciously	governments or races or institutions may enter into some undertaking	without fully realizing why they are doing so.	9.949043896514427
3991. they react in obedience	to an instinct or urge which has itself been impelled by natural	law.	9.92799960869505
3992. a court may strike down a law on the basis of an intuitive feeling	that the law is inimical to the numerical majority.	12.033100850115433
3993. a nation may	go to war on some trifling pretext when in reality it may have been	guided by an unconscious instinct that its very life was at stake.	8.467907667334694
3994. when	the historian encounters a situation in which he can perceive no visible	cause and effect sequence he should be alert to intuition and unconscious	instinct as possible guides.	10.879426254930754
3995. adams firmly contended	that the historian must never underrate the impact of the geographical	environment on history.	9.294657860348424
3996. here was another indispensable tool.	30.23437949304722
3997. indeed	he concluded that geographical conditions have exercised a great	possibly a preponderating influence over man's destiny.	8.450640073948662
3998. the failure	of greece to reach the imperial destiny that periclean athens	had seemed to promise was almost directly attributable to her physical	conformation.	10.72625815352673
3999. all areas of history were either favorably or adversely	affected by the geographical environment and no respectable historian	could pursue the study of history without a thorough knowledge of	geography.	9.183177096468363
4000. brooks adams was consistent in his admonishments	to historians about the necessary tools or insights they needed to possess.	9.599218841280045
4001. however as a practicing historian he himself has left few clues	to the amount of professional scholarship that he used when writing	history.	9.611699723253004
4002. in fact if judgments are to be rendered upon the soundness	of his historicism they must be based on scanty evidence.	14.522047823664575
4003. what evidence	is available would seem to indicate that brooks unlike his older	brother henry had most of the methodological vices usually found	in the amateur.	11.282839684924364
4004. a credulousness a distaste for documentation an uncritical	reliance on contemporary accounts and a proneness to assume	a theory as true before adequate proof was provided were all evidences	of his failure to comprehend the use of the scientific method or to evaluate	the responsibilities of the historian to his reading public.	8.917078238613783
4005. this	is not to assume that his work was without merit but the validity	of his assumptions concerning the meaning of history must always be	considered against this background of an unprofessional approach.	8.873557026233753
4006. his credulity is perhaps best illustrated in his introduction to the	emancipation of massachusetts which purports to examine the	trials of moses and to draw a parallel between the leader of the israelite	exodus from egypt and the leadership of the puritan clergy in	colonial new england.	10.225131859636846
4007. much criticism has been leveled at this rather	forced analogy but what is equally significant is adams' complete	acceptance of the biblical record as good and trustworthy history.	8.709871024268203
4008. in light of the scholarly reappraisals engendered by the higher	criticism this is a most remarkable statement particularly coming	from one who was well known for his antifundamentalist views.	12.83927380196016
4009. the desire	to substantiate a thesis at the expense of sound research technique	smacks more of	the propagandist than the historian.	10.343336487412788
4010. a similar amateurish	characteristic is revealed in adams' failure to check the	accuracy and authenticity of his informational sources.	10.788862536317781
4011. if he found data	that fitted his general plan he used it and counted his sources trustworthy.	12.005731854753032
4012. conversely if statistics were uncovered which contradicted	a cherished theory the sources were denounced as faulty.	9.908939338115298
4013. such manipulations	are frequently encountered in his essay on the suppression	of the monasteries during the english reformation.	9.28510455277153
4014. adams depended largely	on the dispatches of foreign ambassadors and observers in england	claiming that the reports of such agents had to be accurate because	there were no newspapers.	9.801722102940747
4015. this is certainly an irrational dogmatism	in which the modern mind attempts to understand the spirit of the sixteenth	century on twentieth-century terms.	13.314970119283027
4016. moreover he rejects the	contemporary accounts of englishmen casually adjudging them to be distorted	by prejudice because the opinions of englishmen are of no	great value.	10.249525335014722
4017. what is exposited by this observation is not the inherent	prejudices of englishmen but the anglophobia of brooks adams.	11.17851537401088
4018. in all fairness it must be admitted that adams made no pretense	at being an impartial historian.	14.500118814300233
4019. impartiality to him meant an unwillingness	to generalize and to search for a synthesis.	9.304861537289883
4020. he deplored the	impact of german historiography on the writing of history terming	it a dismal monster.	12.21204982240423
4021. ranke and his disciples had reduced history	to a profession of dullness; brooks adams preferred the chronicles	of froissart or the style and theorizing of edward gibbon for	at least they took a stand on the issues about which they wrote.	7.034978856337534
4022. he wrote	eloquently to william james that impartial history was not only	impossible but undesirable.	12.698437526613032
4023. if the historian was convinced of his own	correctness then he should not allow his vision to become fogged by	disturbing facts.	10.76221013748968
4024. it was history that must be in error not the historian.	19.63254559479157
4025. it was this basic trait that separated adams from the ranks	of professional historians and led him to commit time and time again what	was his most serious offense against the historical method- namely	the tendency to assume the truth of an hypothesis before submitting	it to the test of facts.	8.414636412867775
4026. all of adams' work reflects this	dogmatic characteristic.	22.38442805853881
4027. no page seems to be complete without the statement	of at least one unproved generalization.	12.457314794049376
4028. one example of this	was his assertion that h all servile revolts must be dealt with by	physical force.	12.406318360696153
4029. there is no explanation of terms nor a qualification	that most such revolts have been dealt with by force- only a bald	dogmatism that they must because of some undefined compulsion be	so repelled.	10.414032169852524
4030. on matters of race he was similarly inflexible: most	of the modern latin races seem to have inherited h the rigidity	of the roman mind.	11.12123250827898
4031. he cites the french revolution as typifying	this rigidity but makes no mention of the italians who have been able	to	adapt to all types of circumstances.	9.849942619390252
4032. he pontificates that one	of the first signs of advancing civilization is the fall in the value	of women in men's eyes.	11.419291352653845
4033. it made no difference that most evidence	points to an opposite conclusion.	15.166168101843144
4034. for adams had made up his mind before	all the facts were available.	14.057144796092455
4035. all critics of adams and	his methods have observed this particular deficiency.	11.03807633186204
4036. j t shotwell	was appalled by such spurious history as that which attributed the	fall of the carolingian empire to the woolen trade and he urged adams	to transform his essay into a real history embodying not merely	those facts which fit into his theory but also the modifications	and exceptions.	8.430500186080765
4037. a m wergeland called the adams method literally	antihistorical while clive day maintained that the assumptions	were not confined to theories alone but were also applicable to straight	factual evidence.	8.666714188986195
4038. moreover stated day he always omits	facts which tend to disprove his hypothesis.	12.385487267806257
4039. even d a wasson	who compared the emancipation of massachusetts to the lifting	of a fog from ancient landscapes was also forced to admit the methodological	deficiencies of the author.	8.14280903290637
4040. in summary brooks adams	felt that the nature of history was order and that the order so discovered	was as much subject to historical laws as the forces of nature.	11.811041422287405
4041. moreover he believed that most professional historians lacked some	of the essential instruments for a proper study of history.	10.008408282470514
4042. however	despite the insight of many of his observations his own conclusions	are open to suspicion because of his failure to employ at all times the	correct research methods.	11.099113801997682
4043. this should not prejudice an evaluation of	his findings but they were not the findings of a completely impartial	investigator.	11.587068334485355
4044. what was perhaps more important than his concept of	the nature of history and the historical method were those forces which	shaped the direction of his thought.	13.469671057317164
4045. in the final analysis his contribution	to american historiography was founded on almost intuitive insights	into religion economics and darwinism the three factors which	conditioned his search for a law of history.	9.515449166745022
4046. brooks adams considered religion as an extremely significant	manifestation of man's fear of the unknown.	10.365291799692745
4047. but it was nothing	more than that.	31.732146340986674
4048. religion and the churches were institutions which	had been created by man not god.	11.049330415611552
4049. he did not deny god; he simply	did not believe that a creator intervened or interfered in human	affairs.	13.283243727077622
4050. the historian need not be concerned with the philosophical problems	suggested by religion.	16.50021198356306
4051. there was no evidence either of a positive	or negative type of the actions of a divine being in this world;	and since the historian should only be interested in strictly terrestrial	activity his research should eliminate the supernatural.	9.604236135172096
4052. furthermore	he must regard religion as the expression of human forces.	11.33819267263277
4053. certainly he must recognize its power and attempt to ascertain its	influence on the flow of history but he must not confuse the natural	and the mundane with the divine.	8.303589482151606
4054. adams was not breaking new ground	when he claimed that the worship of an unseen power was in reality	a reflection of man's inability to cope with his environment.	9.179871000155046
4055. students	of anthropology and comparative religion had long been aware that	there was indeed a direct connection.	9.51786758101864
4056. but adams was one of the first	to suggest that this human incompetence was the only motivating factor	behind religion.	16.61927654743345
4057. it was this fear which explained the development	of a priestly caste whose function in society was to mollify and appease	the angry deities.	10.827052243750234
4058. to keep themselves entrenched in power the	priests were forced to demonstrate their unique status through the miracle.	11.467785906354605
4059. it was the use of the supernatural that kept them in business.	24.718623385788533
4060. the german barbarians of the fourth century offered an excellent example:	the germans in the fourth century were a very simple	race who comprehended little of natural laws and who therefore referred	phenomena they did not understand to supernatural intervention.	10.121748654562419
4061. this intervention could only be controlled by priests and thus the	invasions caused a rapid rise in the influence of the sacred class.	10.15953692925924
4062. the	power of every ecclesiastical organization has always rested on the	miracle and the clergy have always proved their divine commission as	did elijah.	9.051154372622117
4063. adams contended that once such a special class	had been created it became a vested interest and sought to maintain	itself by assuming exclusive control over the relationships between	god and man.	7.639989688350249
4064. thus the church was born and because of its intrinsic	character was soon identified as a conservative institution determined	to resist the forces of change to identify itself with the political	rulers and to maintain a kind of splendid isolation from the masses.	9.931866661088199
4065. doctrine was not only mysterious; it was also sacred and no	believer in an inspired church could tolerate having her canons examined	as we should examine human laws.	7.855698086666683
4066. these basic ideas concerning the	nature of religion were adams believed some of the major keys to	the understanding of history and the movement of society.	11.877276074896624
4067. the dark views	about the puritans found in the emancipation of massachusetts	were never altered.	12.26566025977324

4069. in the	law of civilization and decay brooks adams traced this evolution	always pointing to the fact that although the forms became more	rational the substance remained unchanged.	10.53964324905203
4070. the relic worship and monasticism	of the middle ages were more advanced forms than were primitive	fetish worship and nature myths.	10.995003513046813

4072. to adams that age in which religion exercised power over the entire	culture of the race was one of imagination and it is largely the	admiration he so obviously held for such eras that betrays a peculiar	religiosity- a sentiment he would have probably denied.	11.680554279411437
