5060. forty-seven states assign or provide vehicles for employees on state	business.	11.33819267263277
5061. two other states provide vehicles but only with legislative	approval.	13.740674095102555
5062. states which provide automobiles for employees	assign them variously to the agency the individual or to a central pool.	10.287452469065112
5063. twenty-six states operate a central motor pool for acquisition	allocation andor maintenance of state-owned vehicles.	8.62963042412541
5064. nineteen states report laws policies or regulations for assigning state	vehicles in lieu of paying mileage allowances.	9.974202494994882
5065. of these states the	average change-over point	is 13200 miles per year.	13.113408036540985
5066. mileage	allowances for state employees are of two types: actual mileage	and fixed monthly allowances.	10.358652090748608
5067. actual mileage allowances	are itemized reimbursements allowed employees for the use of personally-owned	vehicles on state business at the rate of .	11.534526671026315
5068. fixed	monthly allowances are reimbursements for the same purpose except	on a non-itemized basis.	12.084837088582432
5069. both allowances are governed by conditions and	restrictions set forth in detail in the state's travel regulations.	7.846743086098584
5070. rhode island's reimburseable rate of .	14.61245517643054
5071. 07 per mile for	use of personally-owned cars compares favorably with other states'	rates.	9.070074471681158
5072. the average of states' rates is .	18.415074455168735
5073. rhode island's rate of .	13.568592936511694
5074. 07 per mile is considerably lower than	reimburseable rates in the federal government and in industry nationally	which approximate a .	11.85958680945785
5075. actual mileage	allowances are well-administered and not unduly expensive for the state.	9.345058977386529
5076. the travel regulations requirements and procedures governing reimbursement	are controlled properly and not overly restrictive.	12.214907163657244
5077. fixed monthly allowances are a controversial subject.	11.118618003375188
5078. they have a great	advantage in ease of audit time and payment.	17.490688087592535
5079. however they lend themselves	to abuse and inadequate control measures.	12.62980217800384
5080. flat payments over	$50 per month are more expensive to the state than the assignment of	state-owned vehicles.	11.173051488585791
5081. travel allowances including	subsistence have been revised by administrative officials recently	and compare favorably with other states' allowances.	9.701933331657218
5082. with few	exceptions travelers on state business are allowed actual travel expenses	and $15 per day subsistence.	11.65559349365635
5083. travel allowances are well-regulated	and pose little problem in administration andor audit control.	9.070074471681158
5084. of state automobile practices	it	is difficult to pinpoint the time of origin of the state purchasing automobiles	for use of employees in rhode island.	12.514132539556346
5085. few records are available	concerning the subject prior to 1940.	11.131229975813381
5086. those that are available	shed little light.	20.812447449144667
5087. the registry of motor vehicles indicates that	at least one state automobile was registered as far back as 1917.	10.2353719867555
5088. it	should be enough to say that the practice of the state buying automobiles	is at least forty years old.	15.935222972514834
5089. the best reason that can be	advanced for the state adopting the practice was the advent of expanded	highway construction during the 1920s and '30s.	9.645487984377398
5090. at that time highway	engineers traveled rough and dirty roads to accomplish their duties.	0.0
5091. using privately-owned vehicles was a personal hardship for such employees	and the matter of providing state transportation was felt perfectly	justifiable.	10.096090893732828
5092. once the principle was established the increase	in state-owned vehicles came rapidly.	14.773599009014827
5093. and reasons other than employee	need contributed to the growth.	14.657135961268706
5094. table 1 immediately below shows	the rate of growth of vehicles and employees.	10.635267499930531
5095. this rate of increase	does not signify anything in itself.	12.508271769542546
5096. it does not indicate loose management	ineffective controls or poor policy.	22.848248966479893
5097. but it does show that automobiles	have increased steadily over the years and in almost the same	proportion to the increase of state employees.	12.533952344966915
5098. in the past twenty	years the ratio of state-owned automobiles per state employees has varied	from 1 to 22 then to 1 to 23 now.	12.481300045214203
5099. whether there were too few automobiles	in 1940 or too many now is problematical.	9.968167398228813
5100. the fact is simply	that state-owned vehicles have remained in practically the same proportion	history and operation of the motor	pool.	18.188869787744785
5101. subsequent developments concerning the assignment use and management	of state automobiles can be related more clearly.	8.518314539970453
5102. prior to 1942	automobiles were the individual responsibility of the agency to which	assigned.	16.063287025926904
5103. this responsibility included all phases of management.	17.24102039109483
5104. it	embraced determining when to purchase and when to trade vehicles who	was to drive when and where repairs were to be made where gasoline	and automobile services were to be obtained and other allied matters.	10.135536995972425
5105. in 1942 however the nation was at war.	16.649932638888277
5106. gasoline and automobile tires	were rationed commodities.	13.915190642667962
5107. the state was confronted with transportation	problems similar to those of the individual.	17.65940373208185
5108. it met these problems	by the creation of the state automobile maintenance unit	a centralized operation for the maintenance	and control of all state transportation.	13.64317598431261
5109. the motor pool then	as now had headquarter facilities in providence and other garages located	throughout the state.	9.403879097775112
5110. it was organizationally the responsibility	of the department of public works and was financed on a rotary fund	basis with each agency of government contributing to the pool's operation.	12.437202272831106
5111. in 1951 the pool's operation was transferred to the newly-created	department of administration an agency established as the	central staff and auxiliary department of the state government.	9.659918704744044
5112. the management	of state-owned vehicles since that time has been described in	a recent report in the following manner:   under this new	management considerable progress appears to have been made.	10.149309045717699
5113. the agencies	of government are now billed for the actual cost of services provided	to each passenger car rather than the prior uniform charge for all	cars.	8.728015104895293
5114. whereas the maintenance rotary fund had in the past sustained	losses considerably beyond expectations the introduction of the cost-billing	system plus other control refinements has resulted in keeping	the fund on a proper working basis.	10.375265811314838
5115. one indication of the merits of	the new management is found in the fact that during the period 1951-1956	while total annual mileage put on the vehicles increased 35% the	total maintenance cost increased only 11%.	10.644735810722683
5116. in order	to further refine the management of passenger vehicles on july 1 1958	the actual title to every vehicle was transferred by executive	order to the division of methods research and office services.	9.448108208611803
5117. the objective behind this action was to place in one agency the responsibility	for the management assignment and replacement of all vehicles.	8.995044693120356
5118. this tied in closely with the	current attempt to upgrade state-owned cars to the extent that vehicles	are not retained beyond the point where maintenance costs	become excessive.	11.173041775883181
5119. moreover it allows the present management	to reassign vehicles so that mileage will be more uniformly	distributed throughout the fleet; for example if one driver puts on	22000 miles per year and another driver 8000 miles per year their	cars will be switched so that both cars will have 30000 miles after two	years rather than 44000 miles	and 16000 miles respectively.	7.302444287163835
5120. the motor pool is a completely	centralized and mechanized operation.	14.310793878502059
5121. it handles all types of	vehicle maintenance but concentrates more on service station activities	than on extensive vehicle repairs.	10.511513581761168
5122. it contracts with outside	repair garages for much of the latter work.	24.478806238628515
5123. where the pool excels is	in its compilation of maintenance and cost-data studies and analyses.	10.744061234705763
5124. pool records reveal in detail the cost per mile and miles per gallon	of each vehicle the miles traveled in one year or three years the periods	when vehicle costs become excessive and when cars should be traded	for sound economies.	8.686104641306262
5125. from this motor pool personnel develop other	meaningful and related data.	13.079853198786925
5126. in 1959-60 vehicles averaged an operating	cost of .	17.034822554424267
5127. based on this figure and considering depreciation	costs of vehicles pool personnel have determined that travel	in excess of 10000 miles annually is more economical by state car	than by payment of allowances for use of personally-owned vehicles.	7.790762939958001
5128. they	estimate further that with sufficient experience and when cost-data	of compact cars is compiled the break-even point may be reduced to	7500 miles of travel per year.	8.700181695682264
5129. table 2 shows operating cost data of	state vehicles selected at random.	9.345058977386529
5130. one matter of concern to	the complete effectiveness of pool operations is the lack of adequate	central garage facilities.	12.230555999932825
5131. present pool quarters at two locations in	providence are crowded antiquated and in general make for inefficient	operation in terms of dispersement of personnel and duplication of	such operational needs as stock and repair equipment.	7.558728746565181
5132. good facilities	would be a decided help to pool operations and probably reduce vehicle	costs even more.	10.587372751202253
5133. the purchase of state-owned	vehicles is handled in the same manner as all other purchases	of the state.	16.264559338196296
5134. requests are made by the motor pool along with any necessary	cooperation from the agencies to which assignments of cars will	be made.	9.859906987947285
5135. bids are evaluated by the division of purchases with the	assistance of pool staff and awards for the purchase of the automobiles	are made to the lowest responsible bidders.	8.50329149750689
5136. unit prices for state	vehicles are invariably lower than to the general public.	12.382599157725819
5137. the reasons	are obvious: it has no	federal excise or state sales tax to pay.	10.68885502559245
5138. until 1958 the state was also	entitled to a special type of manufacturers' discount through the	dealers.	11.072024394773203
5139. in that ownership of all vehicles rests with the state	motor pool cars are paid for with funds appropriated to the agencies	but transferred to the rotary fund mentioned earlier.	8.982535245622907
5140. this is a normal	governmental procedure which reflects more accurately cost-accounting	principles.	21.11834132074209
5141. the assignment and use of vehicles after purchase is	another matter to be covered in detail later.	10.374321372709895
5142. assignment and use policies	probably the most important of all matters	for review are the broad administrative policies governing the purchase	assignment use and management of state vehicles.	9.451052994413269
5143. the legislature's	role in policy determination in this area for years has been	confined almost solely to the amount of funds appropriated annually	for the purchase and operation of vehicles.	10.261537155906478
5144. the more meaningful policies	have been left to the judgment of the chief administrative officer	of the state- the director of administration.	14.978785724092832
5145. there was a time some years ago when	local taxation by the cities and towns was sufficient to support their	own operations and a part of the cost of the state government as	well.	16.113058548167395
5146. for many years a state tax on cities and towns was paid by the	several municipalities to the state from the proceeds of the general property	tax.	14.306710391999466
5147. this tax was discontinued in 1936.	15.755914550576229
5148. since that time	the demands of the citizens for new and expanded services have placed	financial burdens on the state which could not have been foreseen in	earlier years.	12.74422486653561
5149. at the same time there has been an upgrading and expansion	of municipal services as well.	17.553651446032145
5150. thus there has come into being	a situation in which the state must raise all of its own revenues and	in addition must give assistance to its local governments.	11.943015594014655
5151. this	financial assistance from the state has become necessary because	the local governments themselves found the property tax or at least at	the rates then existing insufficient for their requirements.	8.628731565703204
5152. consequently there have developed several forms of grants-in-aid and	shared taxes as well as the unrestricted grant to local governments	for general purposes whose adoption accompanied the introduction of a	sales tax at the state level.	10.130337966948657
5153. notwithstanding state aid the local	governments are continuing to seek additional revenue of their own	by strengthening the property tax.	8.026882005052693
5154. this is being done both by the revaluation	of real property and by seeking out forms of personal property	hitherto neglected or ignored.	13.392123766496516
5155. taxation of tangible movable	property in rhode island has been generally of a hands off nature	due possibly to several reasons: local assessors in the main	are not well paid and have inadequate office staffs the numerous	categories of this component of personal property make locating extremely	difficult and the inexperience of the majority of assessors	problems of taxing personal	property.	6.850730434583621
5156. and of movable tangible property in particular two are significant:	situs fair and equitable assessment of value.	12.7053601534082
5157. these	problems are not local to rhode island but are recognized as common	to all states.	8.953104285872618
5158. although the laws of the various	states in general specify the situs of property ie residence	or domicile of the owner or location of the property the exceptions	regarding boats airplanes mobile homes etc seem to add to	the uncertainty of the proper origination point for assessment.	9.366272345181192
5159. rhode island law specifies that all real estate is taxable in the	town in which it is situated.	11.040677119576495
5160. it also provides for the taxation of all	personal property belonging to inhabitants of the state both tangible	and intangible and the tangible personal property of non-residents	in this state.	12.29158557418094
5161. in defining personal property it specifically mentions	all ships or vessels at home or abroad.	10.694184739355702
5162. intangible	property is taxable wherever the owner has a place of abode the greater	portion of the year.	10.191933462586043
5163. although a similar situs for tangible property	is mentioned in the statute this is cancelled out by the provision	that definite kinds of property and all other tangible property	situated or being in any town is taxable where the property is situated.	7.8784131527065595
5164. this would seem to fix the tax situs of all movable personal property	at its location on december 31.	14.196316848028681
5165. both boats and aircraft would	fall within this category as well as motor vehicles.	11.2277422881734
5166. the location	of the latter now is determined for tax purposes at the time of registration	and it is now accepted practice to consider a motor vehicle	as being situated where it is garaged.	12.363266841569956
5167. obviously it would be impossible	to determine where every vehicle might be on the 31st day of december.	9.958379045755782
5168. in view of the acceptance accorded the status of motor vehicles	for tax purposes in the absence of any specific provision it would	seem entirely consistent to apply the same interpretation to boats or	aircraft.	13.899858332912174
5169. a recent example of this problem is the flying of six	airplanes on december 31 1960 from the newport airpark in middletown	to the north central airport in smithfield.	8.775710643070676
5170. this situation	resulted in both towns claiming the tax and probably justifiably.	13.236737574390107
5171. middletown bases its claim on the general provision of the law that all	rateable property both tangible and intangible shall be taxed	to the owner thereof in the town in which such owner shall have had his	actual place of abode for the larger portion of the twelve months	next preceding the first day of april in each year.	8.251152829926388
5172. the	smithfield tax assessor in turn claims the tax under the provision	of law h and all other tangible personal property situated or being	in any town in or upon any h place of storage h shall be taxed	to such person h in the town where said property is situated.	8.09620252935721
5173. this problem of fair and equitable assessment	of value is a difficult one to solve in that the determination of	fair valuation is dependent on local assessors who in general are	non-professional	and part-time personnel taking an individualistic approach	to the problem.	8.660259669856533
5174. this accounts for the wide variance in assessment	practices of movable tangible property in the various municipalities in	rhode island.	11.719520690663831
5175. this condition will undoubtedly continue until	such time as a state uniform system of evaluation is established	or through mutual agreement of the local assessing officials for a method	of standard assessment practice to be adopted.	8.240174905516072
5176. the rhode	island public expenditure council in its publication once commented:	the most realistic way of facing up to this problem would	be to have the state take over full responsibility for assessing	all taxable property.	9.365723329496017
5177. an adequately staffed and equipped state assessing	office could apply uniform methods and standards which would go far	toward producing equitable assessments on all properties throughout	the state.	7.8403234978990435
5178. a single statewide assessing unit would eliminate the differences	and complications that are inherent in a system of 39 different	and independent assessing units.	10.952608062700822
5179. the institute of public	administration in its report to the state fiscal study commission	in 1959 recommended consolidating and centralizing all aspects	of property tax administration in a single state agency professionally	organized and equipped for the job.	8.499516337613267
5180. the resulting setup it was	declared would be similar to that which is in successful operation	in a number of metropolitan counties as large or larger than rhode	island.	13.247424869223828
5181. to determine the practice	and attitude of municipal governments concerning tangible movable property	a questionnaire was sent to all local government assessors or	boards of assessors in rhode island.	9.441977811551924
5182. the replies from each	individual town are not given in detail because the questions asked the	personal opinion of the several assessors and are not necessarily the	established policy of the town in each case.	11.949258369888513
5183. there are legitimate reasons	for differences of opinion among the assessors as a whole and among	the public officials in each town.	12.501676778190888
5184. these opinions of the assessors	are of significance in indicating what their thinking seems to be at	the present time.	11.28787314715209
5185. in reply to a question of whether they now	tax boats airplanes and other movable property excluding automobiles	nineteen said that they did and twenty that they did not.	10.01307337040364
5186. the wording	of the question was quite general and may have been subject to different	interpretations.	13.103912391291939
5187. one assessor checked boats only another trailers	and tractors one mentioned house trailers and two others referred	to trailers without specifying the type.	8.959652207302964
5188. in two cases airplanes only	were indicated.	20.472413001720973
5189. it is difficult to tabulate exactly what was	meant in each individual situation but the conclusion may be drawn	that 21 towns do not assess movable personal property and of the remainder	only certain types are valued for tax purposes.	9.711672193317847
5190. boats were indicated	specifically by only one of the five towns known to tax boats.	15.986254264694388
5191. it would seem then that movable property and equipment is not taxed	as a whole but that certain types are taxed in towns where this is bound	to be expedient for that particular kind of personal property.	9.822727031801735
5192. so few answered the question relating to their efforts to assess	movable property that the results are inconclusive.	11.24966558311459
5193. only four towns indicated	that they made any more than a normal effort to list property	of this kind.	11.023424042319414
5194. of greater interest is a question as to whether	movable property was assessed according to its location or ownership.	14.002902487568116
5195. fifteen stated that it was according to location four by residence	of the owner and nineteen did not answer.	10.194932204864642
5196. twenty-seven assessors	stated that they were in favor of improved means for assessing movable	personal property and only five were opposed.	12.864821380902264
5197. seven others expressed	no opinion.	16.561633532207114
5198. on this point there was fairly general agreement that	assessors would like to do more than they are doing now.	16.765876937692006
5199. it is not	clear however whether they are thinking of all movable property or	only of boats trailers aircraft or certain other types of personal	property whose assessment would be advantageous to their particular towns.	9.473483750502535
5200. another question that was asked of the assessors was whether	they favored the assessment of movable property at its location or	at the residence of the owner.	9.036413179024143
5201. eighteen voted for assessment by the	town in which it is located and eleven preferred assessment by the town	in which the owner resides.	9.330987905116682
5202. ten others made no reply.	20.896261181140837
5203. of those who	have an opinion it seems that assessment by location is preferred.	12.215664980457547
5204. there	was one vote for location being the place where the property is	situated for the greater portion of the twelve months preceding the assessment	date.	10.47320570699619
5205. to summarize it may be said that there is no one	prevailing practice in rhode island with respect to the taxation	of movable property that assessors would like to see an improvement	and of those who have an opinion that assessment by the town of location	is preferred on the basis of their present knowledge.	12.616736660335135
5206. the need for	greater knowledge is evident from their replies.	19.56568520394587
5207. property	interest has been shown for a number	of years by local assessors in the possibility of taxing boats.	8.885696171327579
5208. assessors in rhode island are charged not only with placing a valuation	upon real and personal property but they also have the responsibility	to raise by a tax a sum not less than nor more than a specified	amount as ordered by a city council or financial town meeting.	8.84949847735501
5209. it has been obvious to the assessors particularly those in shore	communities that boats comprise the largest category of tangible personal	property which they have been unable to reach.	11.596047014653148
5210. through their	professional organization the rhode island tax officials association	the question of taxing boats long has been debated and discussed.	10.154642960660597
5211. no satisfactory solution has been found but this is due more to the	difficulties inherent in the problem than to a lack of interest or diligence	on the part of the assessors.	13.422448540244933
5212. it has been estimated that	the value of boats in rhode island waters is something in excess	of fifty million dollars excluding commercial boats.	13.409792306193987
5213. it is obvious that	this is a potential and lucrative source of revenue for the assessors	of those towns where a substantial amount of such property would be	subject to taxation.	10.904492959481363
5214. it is known that at least five towns	place some	value on some boats for tax purposes.	21.707049056183326
5215. however few are taxed and	the owners and location of most boats are unknown to the assessors on	the date of assessment of town valuations.	8.564559092185357
5216. no one really knows	how many boats there actually are or what their aggregate value may	be.	12.576454955179841
5217. slightly more than 5000 boats were registered with the coast guard	prior to the recent passage of the state boating law.	9.653331031089916
5218. only a few	more than 10000 boats had been registered with the division of harbors	and rivers at the end of the 1960 boating season but many had	been taken out of the water early when the threat of a hurricane brought	the season to an early close.	12.490946971078515
5219. the assessors' association	meeting at narragansett in september 1960 devoted its session to a	discussion of the boat problem.	9.189554574368655
5220. local industry's investment in rhode island was the big story	in 1960's industrial development effort.	11.105603231977845
5221. fifty-two companies started	or committed themselves to new plant construction totaling 1418000	square feet and representing an investment of $11900000; a	new post-world war 2 record.	7.556878632736834
5222. with minor exceptions this expansion	was instituted either by firms based in rhode island or out-of-state	manufacturers already operating here.	11.159706530303236
5223. what made these new	location figures particularly impressive was the fact that although 1960	was a year of mild business recession throughout the nation rhode	island scored marked progress in new industry new plants and new jobs.	8.398192477856497
5224. of the major expansions in 1960 three were financed under	the r i industrial building authority's 100% guaranteed	mortgage plan: collyer wire leesona corporation and american	tube + controls.	11.023217308055148
5225. leading firms that arranged their own financing	included speidel corporation cornell-dubilier photek inc	division of textron narragansett gray iron foundry w r	cobb company and mays manufacturing company.	7.4197753744803165
5226. expansion	and relocation of industry in rhode island is the direct responsibility	of the development council's industrial division and the figures	quoted above indicate a successful year's operation.	9.189764792505427
5227. industrial	division personnel worked with 54 out-of-state and 97 rhode island	concerns during 1960 many of whom are still interested in a rhode	island location.	7.634437488545556

5270. division	stated in its simplest terms the main job of the	planning division is to plan for the future of the state of rhode	island.	14.874106272679542
5271. the activities of the planning division are defined in considerable	detail in the enabling act of the development council which	assigns to the agency both broad responsibilities and specific duties	in the field of planning.	9.092554251763076
5272. two years ago the institute of	public administration issued an extremely comprehensive report entitled	state-local relations in metropolitan rhode island.	14.427790210364378
5273. as	the result of an exhaustive review of the recommendations contained in	this report plus an analysis of our own enabling act the planning	division developed a number of basic planning objectives which caused	a reorientation of its work program.	8.61913887460679
5274. these objectives are stated here	because of their importance in understanding the current activities	first priority will be given to	the preparation of a meaningful state guide plan to serve as a background	recognizing	the truth of the statement by the institute of public administration	that metropolian planning means or	should mean state planning the state guide plan will take into account	the metropolitan nature of many of rhode island's problems.	8.94607744432202
5275. it will continue to be an objective of this division to encourage	the acceptance of planning as a proper and continuing responsibility	of local government.	14.923554820800216
5276. to this end the community assistance program	of the planning division will continue to be operated as a staff function	to make available on a shared cost basis technical planning	assistance to those communities in the state unable to maintain their	the planning division will take the initiative	in encouraging planning cooperation at all levels of government;	among the operating departments of the state; between the cities	and towns of the state; and on a regional basis between the six new	on the basis that all citizens of the state	are entitled to benefit equally in the development of its resources	plans for the provision of essential services will	be based on need regardless of arbitrary political boundaries within	the state development budget	will reflect the capital needs of all the state agencies and the priority	of the projects in the budget will be based on the state plan.	8.675777617803998
5277. particular attention will	be given means of strengthening the economy of the state through the	development of industry and recreation.	10.465366218628407
5278. functionally the planning	division carries out four activities: long-range state planning	current state planning local planning assistance; and the preparation	of the state development budget.	8.951887347307554
5279. the planning division has embarked on the most complete and comprehensive	state planning program in the nation.	9.895514384076868
5280. the long range aspects of	this program are divided into four distinct phases: basic mapping	inventory analysis and plan and policy formation.	0.0
5281. the work program	as it was originally proposed was to take five years to complete.	14.325543265282924
5282. recent	events- particularly the necessity of providing planning information	for the statewide origindestination study of the department	of public works- indicate that this schedule will have to be accelerated.	11.994229135750743
5283. the basic mapping phase of the program has been completed and	basic	since accurate base maps are necessary for any planning	program the first step taken by the planning division to implement the	long range state plan has been to prepare two series of base maps-	one at a scale of 1 inch to a mile and the second a series of 26 sheets	at a scale of 1 inch to 2000 feet covering the entire state.	8.517423827965471
5284. with	these maps completed the inventory phase of the plan has been started.	13.07239732400114
5285. with the aid of matching federal funds available	under section 701 of the housing act of 1954 as amended the planning	division began a one year program july 1 1960 to complete the inventory	phase of the state planning program.	9.074939436431688
5286. this phase consists of four	items: urban land use rural land use physical features and public	utility service areas.	10.940520249915352
5287. since the validity of all subsequent planning	depends on the accuracy of the basic inventory information great care	is being taken that the inventory is as complete as possible.	10.318924836217091
5288. the urban land use study carried out by the planning division staff	has consisted of identifying and mapping all urban land uses which are	of significance to statewide planning.	9.522067756698938
5289. the rural land use study is	being carried out under contract by the university of rhode island	and identifies all agricultural land uses in the state by type of use.	9.45088898453539
5290. the mapping of important physical features such as slopes and types	of soil and the collection of all available information pertaining to	public utility service areas are being conducted as staff projects and	like the other two inventory projects are scheduled for completion	july 1 1961.	8.631089185400294
5291. the collection of information is meaningless	unless it is understood and used for a definite purpose.	10.246908001130082
5292. it is not within the scope of	this report elaborate in any great detail upon special districts in	rhode island.	15.485166051611552
5293. however a word should be mentioned in regard to them	as independent units of government.	12.275762710555778
5294. there are forty-seven special	district governments in rhode island	districts four housing authorities and the kent county water	.	14.628097469367564
5295. these forty-seven special purpose governments have the	authority to levy taxes to borrow money own property sue and be sued	and in general to exercise normal corporate powers.	7.79339641154825
5296. unlike cities	and towns however they do not have to submit any financial statements	to the state bureau of audits.	13.577252315341639
5297. it is not an exaggeration to say	that the state government has little or no fiscal control over these units	of government.	15.504835205947472
5298. in addition to the collection of service charges	the special districts levy annual property taxes of approximately $450000.	17.62351739798804
5299. a	review of practices in other states regarding fiscal uniformity is pertinent	to this report.	8.834168570742513
5300. included in the findings are:  forty-six	states including rhode island end their fiscal year on june	30.	11.110676278631656
5301. the other four states end on varying dates: alabama	new york and texas	.	12.086041813787062
5302. in sixteen states the fiscal year ending of the	cities is the same as that of the state: alaska arizona	california delaware massachusetts montana nevada new mexico	north carolina north dakota oklahoma oregon vermont	.	11.94661561734379
5303. in eleven states	the fiscal year of the cities ends on december 31 while the state fiscal	year ends on june 30	hampshire new jersey ohio south dakota utah washington	.	8.27094959889156
5304. in eight states whose fiscal years close	on june 30 a majority of their cities close their fiscal year on december	31:	.	11.173973651804753
5305. one state alabama closes	its fiscal year on september 30 and all cities in the state with	one exception also close fiscal years on september 30.	9.609377101765022
5306. mississippi closes its fiscal year on june 30 while all of its cities	close their fiscal years on september 30.	10.346885012448528
5307. pennsylvania closes	its fiscal year on may 31.	11.448263580594205
5308. all of its cities close their fiscal	years on december 31.	18.778555714645254
5309. the remaining twelve states have varying	fiscal years for the state city and local governments.	11.40642924468029
5310. however	only illinois oregon louisiana and rhode island have a situation	in which the sundry units of government vary widely in relation to fiscal	uniformity.	9.959102447417672
5311. an excellent summary of advantages concerning	the uniform fiscal year and coordinated fiscal calendars was contained	in a paper presented by a public finance authority recently.	8.173522097584627
5312. he listed	among the values of fiscal uniformity:  the uniform fiscal	year requires compliance with common sense administration of local	finances: adoption of the budget or financial plan in advance of spending.	10.655356335226452
5313. the uniform fiscal year ensures conformance with another	common sense rule that of having cash in the bank before checks	are drawn.	8.674870936306482
5314. it enables towns to make more economical purchases and to	take advantage of cash discounts.	14.737749016381246
5315. the uniform fiscal year promotes	more careful budgeting and strengthens control over expenditures.	10.61385277229228
5316. by fixing the tax rate in advance of spending upper limits are set	on expenditures.	11.863440179252054
5317. the uniform fiscal year brings the town's	fiscal year into line with that of the schools which expend the largest	share of local disbursements.	10.628766999452308
5318. this greatly simplifies the town's	bookkeeping and financial reporting.	15.63799501176316
5319. the uniform fiscal	year eliminates interest charges on money borrowed in the form of tax	anticipation notes.	11.88661005323072
5320. furthermore tax collections not immediately needed	for current expenditures may be invested in short-term treasury notes	augmenting the town's miscellaneous revenues and reducing the tax	levy.	9.148757032765333
5321. the uniform fiscal year facilitates inter-town comparison	of revenues and expenditures.	11.572314230763848
5322. when towns have the same fiscal	year it is relatively easy to make meaningful comparisons; and as the	cost of local government increases the demand for such comparison also	increases.	11.842559443590948
5323. towns having different fiscal years are difficult to compare.	10.057988591011652
5324. of all advantages probably none is more important than	the elimination of tax anticipation notes.	15.172468724847844
5325. borrowing in anticipation	of current taxes and other revenues is a routine procedure of the majority	of municipalities at all times.	8.090791750569782
5326. it may be by bank loans sale	of notes or warrants or by the somewhat casual method of issuance and	registration of warrants.	13.653409383596607
5327. in any event it is a form of borrowing which	could be and should be rendered unnecessary.	20.72546178093333
5328. its elimination would	result in the saving of interest costs heavy when short-term money rates	are high and in freedom from dependence on credit which is not always	available when needed most.	9.305372028091547
5329. this type of borrowing can be reduced	to a minimum if quarterly installment payment of taxes is instituted	and the first payment placed near the opening of the fiscal year.	9.791976853928146
5330. any	approach	toward such a system looks toward saving and security.	11.793662721363662
5331. it should be noted that there are other and equally important reasons	for establishing meaningful intergovernmental reporting bases on a uniform	fiscal year.	15.632109613164427
5332. both the federal and state governments commence their	fiscal years on july 1.	12.71911184964041
5333. both units of government contribute increasingly	large sums of money to the several local governments in this	state as indicated below:    it has been said that when local	government revenues were mostly produced locally from the property	tax the lack of a uniform fiscal year was no great handicap; but with	the growth of state and federal fiscal aid the emphasis on equalization	and the state-local sharing of responsibility for certain important	functions this is no longer true.	8.270965663024619
5334. the haphazard fiscal year calendar	is an obstacle to the planning of clear and efficient state-local	revenue and expenditure relationships.	10.915042464758631
5335. although	there are many sound reasons for adopting uniform and coordinated fiscal	years in rhode island there are also certain difficulties encountered.	9.015453045322829
5336. these involve more the mechanics employed in adjusting to fiscal	uniformity than they do actual actual disadvantages to the principle.	10.506758885717412
5337. one problem is a matter of shifting dates; the other is how to	finance the transition.	12.049591940293878
5338. little can be done about the changing	of dates.	18.678812910431585
5339. this is an inherent part of adjusting fiscal calendars.	19.015423106125663
5340. it	usually means a confused and disgruntled tax-paying public for a period	of time.	10.635267499930531
5341. but cooperation and understanding between local officials	and the citizenry help lessen this problem.	11.122832744970024
5342. the other problem	is the matter of financing the transition period in the several cities	and towns.	14.096146654451879
5343. this will be covered more fully later.	20.503187814128925
5344. it should be kept	in mind that the ease or difficulty with which a town or city can	convert to the proposed plan is directly dependent upon the financial	condition of that town or city.	12.21170452944192
5345. fortunately there are no cities or towns	in the state with one or two possible exceptions that are in too	difficult a position to finance the proposed change.	10.143376340121014
5346. sacrifice will	have to be made in some cases but it is to the municipality's advantage	to finance the change-over for a short period of time rather than	pay interest on tax anticipation notes indefinitely.	13.710745488874688
5347. fiscal calendars	the advantages of a uniform fiscal year and well	synchronized fiscal and tax collection calendars are sufficiently great	for rhode island municipalities to exert effort to secure them.	7.65221038034197
5348. the	type of program desired can be determined by the nature and extent	of the adjustments needed.	11.810524393525808
5349. two features are immediately evident.	15.461937182626903
5350. first	the present situation is too varied to be systematized by any single	formula.	11.224691946259922
5351. second the shift to a uniform july 1-june 30 fiscal year	will of itself improve the tax collection calendars of the great	majority of cities and towns.	8.178453122986443
5352. there are at least two problems to consider:	one is a matter of adjusting the fiscal calendar; the other	is how to finance the adjustments when necessary.	15.207985151369792
5353. the latter matter	is considered in detail in a later section.	14.587837418384586
5354. twelve cities and	towns in rhode island presently indicate some plans to establish a	uniform andor coordinated fiscal-tax year calendar.	9.825092707759273
5355. plans vary from	the talking stage to establishing special committees to accomplish	this end.	9.070074471681158
5356. what is important here is that many of the cities and towns	recognize the need for improved fiscal practices and are taking the	initiative to obtain them.	14.936495449847854
5357. an analysis of the fiscal-tax collection	year calendars throughout the state indicates that transition	may not be as painful as is commonly thought.	9.22344765772652
5358. however it must be stressed	that much depends upon the financial condition of the individual	cities and towns involved.	14.044905726336813
5359. the adjustments needed to establish	a uniform and coordinated fiscal-tax collection year calendar throughout	rhode island based on a july 1-june 30 year are shown below.	8.672093939665313
5360. six cities and towns are presently on a	july 1-june 30 fiscal year and have coordinated their tax collection	year with it.	10.108653554926697
5361. no change is required for these towns.	13.673640231008864
5362. these municipalities	include: barrington lincoln middletown newport north	kingstown and south kingstown.	12.821284994007588
5363. one town and one city coventry and east providence require an adjustment	of their fiscal year only.	9.785626220226739
5364. this change will automatically adjust	their tax collection year calendar so as to make all tax installments	due and payable in the fiscal year collectible within that year.	10.649162926965259
5365. six cities and towns are now	on a july 1-june 30 fiscal year and will need only to adjust their	tax collection year calendar to establish uniformity.	8.05030179128445
5366. these cities and	towns include bristol glocester pawtucket cumberland central	falls and woonsocket.	12.289894396987272
5367. two cities	to be considered providence and cranston are an enigma.	10.890357443084502
5368. both have	excellent integration of their fiscal-tax collection year calendars.	13.302749444177817
5369. however neither of these two cities is on the desired july 1-june	30 fiscal year.	11.089399990554593
5370. the adjustment to a uniform and coordinated fiscal	period could be accomplished relatively easy for them.	11.671338429154341
5371. in that	both cities end their fiscal years on september 30 they could levy taxes	for an interim period of nine months commencing with september	30 and ending with june 30.	8.179501964196987
5372. these three installment dates would be:	october 26 january 26 and april 25 and november	15 february 16 and may 15.	10.000667142840305
5373. both would start their new	fiscal year on july 1.	11.34498292004372
5374. their tax collection calendar could then be:	july 25 october 26 january 26 and april 25;	and august 15 november 15 february 17 and may 15.	9.125628809282283
5375. under this plan both cranston and providence would be on the uniform	fiscal year but would still be using the same installment periods.	9.955362292247683
5376. the remaining twenty-three towns have fiscal	years which end prior to june 30.	12.445450562798397
5377. all of these towns will require	adjustments of both their fiscal and tax collection years.	12.89126389014681
5378. assuming	an adjustment to the july 1-june 30 fiscal year the required adjustment	of the tax collection years and the towns involved are shown in table	3.	9.440119929828391
5379. aside from the matter	of adjusting the fiscal and tax calendars there is the problem of financing	the adjustment when this is necessary.	12.496245426941488
5380. it should be emphasized	strongly that adjustments in fiscal dates or adoption of interim budgets	do not necessarily mean financing over and above normal governmental	requirements.	13.495706864148126
5381. in many communities there is simply no financial	problem; it is only a matter of adjusting accounting methods careful	fiscal planning and management or some like combination of techniques.	10.63967897701305
5382. in other municipalities the difficulties in overcoming the financial	burden have been sufficiently great to dishearten proponents of	fiscal year changes.	12.141626521276917
5383. fortunately such cases in rhode island are more	the exception than the rule.	10.269954422798424
5384. as shown earlier in table 1	the several cities and towns use widely varied fiscal and tax collection	calendars.	12.190314372498245
5385. in addition no two rhode island communities are identical	in relation to their over-all financial condition.	12.105817657553946
5386. these factors	practically insure that no single financing formula is feasible; each	situation must be studied and a plan developed that takes into consideration	such factors as the effect of the existing and prospective	tax calendars the financial condition of the treasuries and the length	of the transition interval.	9.199793837578769
5387. suitable plans range from those that are	very easy to develop to those that are difficult to formulate and require	borrowing ranging from short-term serial notes to long-term bonds.	7.488789718559854
5388. the financial problem where it exists usually stems from	the adoption of a budget for the transitional or adjustment period.	11.003365555671996
5389. for	those communities which have financial difficulties in effecting adjustments	there are a number of alternatives any one of which alone	or in combination with others would minimize if not even eliminate the	problem.	8.981752269222143
5390. governor	the theme of rhode island heritage week for 1961 will	be independence and union.	11.198755927126268
5391. it commemorates the 185th anniversary	of rhode island's independence when upon may 4 1776 the	general assembly by its action established the first free republic	in the new world.	8.79181545633643
5392. as this year marks the centennial of the	beginning of the civil war this fact is being commemorated with several	exhibits throughout the state but most of all paying tribute to	the first rhode island volunteers who rushed to the defense of the	city of washington putting at the disposal of president lincoln	the only fully equipped and best trained regiment at this time.	9.886360074716771
5393. on april 30 ceremonies commemorating the departure of these volunteers	will take place at 1:00 pm at the dexter training grounds	in providence.	9.506212386233173
5394. the independence day celebration will be properly	observed with a big military and civic parade from west warwick	to the greene homestead in anthony; and now therefore do i	john a notte jr governor of the state of rhode island and providence	plantations proclaim the week of april 29th to may 7th 1961	as rhode island heritage week advising our citizens that throughout	this week many historic houses and beautiful gardens will be open	to visitors as well as industrial plants craft shops museums and libraries	and i	earnestly urge all to take advantage of these opportunities	to see as many of these places as they can during this outstanding	week.	8.884726052026677
5395. in testimony whereof i have hereunto set my hand	and caused the seal of the state to be affixed this 21st day of april	in the year of our lord one thousand nine hundred and sixty-one	and on independence the one hundred and eighty-fifth.	9.010370844082448
5396. governor	the year 1961 marks the fourteenth anniversary of the unification of	our armed forces under the national security act of 1947.	10.489138765737488
5397. national defense like the continuing search for peace with freedom	and justice for all is everybody's business.	8.78645907303942
5398. our investment	in this effort the greatest in our nation's history reflects our	determination to ensure the peace and the future of freedom.	10.956193744728958
5399. it	is a sound investment.	19.193787721964462
5400. as the president has said only when our	arms are sufficient beyond doubt can we be certain that they will never	be employed.	14.3825924948557
5401. armed forces day is the annual report on	this investment a public presentation designed to give our own people	and the people of other lands who stand with us for peace with freedom	and justice the best possible opportunity to see and understand what	we have and why we have it.	8.72178570233331

5426. governor	jr governor	the ballet originated in italy about 1450.	12.3482207866056
5427. at	that time it was a series of sophisticated social dances whose steps	were often combined with other steps devised by the choreographer.	9.260099407025496
5428. ballet	flowered in italy during the next hundred years and about 1550	was carried to france when the italian princess catherine de medicis	married the king of france.	9.260099257007997
5429. the most famous ballet of that time	was called ballet comique de la reine.	11.503490921120422
5430. dances alternated	with sung or spoken verses.	13.915190642667962
5431. ballets were used in opera from its beginning.	10.530932308755343
5432. they were placed either in the middle of the acts or in the intermissions.	26.009399183504588

5435. governor	as another thanksgiving draws near let us take time out from the often	hectic pace of our lives to try and recapture the feelings that filled	the hearts of the pilgrims on the first thanksgiving.	8.254582879078777
5436. the	pilgrims gathered to thank the lord for his benevolence during	their first year in the new land.	11.214621563164703
5437. they had been through trying times	but their faith in the almighty had given them the courage and the strength	to meet and overcome the many problems and difficulties that were	the price they had to pay for freedom.	9.508641418597872
5438. and as the pilgrims bowed	their heads in humble gratitude they shared another feeling- the anticipation	of what the future held for them and their posterity.	12.300131026911343
5439. they	could not guess that from their concepts of liberty and freedom would	some day be born a new nation that for years would be the symbol of	hope to the oppressed countries of the world.	8.093454566221427
5440. they simply turned to god	filled with gratitude and faith.	14.925046296989679
5441. we who are living today may	learn a valuable lesson from those who celebrated the first thanksgiving	day.	9.833174109624084
5442. the lord has shown time and time again his love for us.	15.889631497235346
5443. we have only to compare the liberty and high standard of living we	enjoy in this great country with the oppression and frugality of other	nations to realize with humble gratitude that god's providence has	been with us since the very beginning of our country.	8.131205943370436
5444. and yet accompanying	our gratitude is the realization that we are living in a crucial	time.	16.270716602676004
5445. with world peace constantly being threatened most of us regard	the future skeptically and even with fear.	10.5384178521632
5446. it is at this time that	we should imitate the pilgrims by accompanying our prayers of thanks	with the conviction that we shall continue to be in dire need for	the lord's protection in the future if we are to have peace; now	therefore do i john a notte jr governor of the state of	rhode island and providence plantations proclaim thursday november	23rd 1961 as thanksgiving day   and so let us remember on	this day not only to thank the almighty who gave hope and courage	to the pilgrims but also to place our trust in him that he will continue	to protect us in the future as he has in the past.	10.774180711760884

5534. this resulted in an improved	appearance but was followed by an increase in printing cost that	necessitated the institution of major economies to keep within the total	of allocated funds.	12.974390497035419

5543. the first	report in this continuing series appeared in the september 1960 issue	of the journal.	11.1981141247677
5544. another recent achievement was the successful development of a method	for the complete combustion in a bomb calorimeter of a metal in fluorine	when the product is relatively non-volatile.	8.871723116700105
5545. this work gave a heat	of formation of aluminum fluoride which closely substantiates a value	which had been determined by a less direct method and raises this	property to 15 percent above that accepted a few years ago.	8.510521208596355
5546. similar measurements	are being initiated to resolve a large discrepancy in the	heat of formation of another important combustion product beryllium fluoride.	9.556508297210817
5547. the development and testing of new apparatus to measure	other properties is nearing completion.	10.242653103537407
5548. in one of these an exploding-wire	device to study systems thermodynamically up to 6000 f and	100 atmospheres pressure a major goal was achieved.	14.168238333934077
5549. the accuracy of	measuring the total electrical energy entering an exploding wire during	a few microseconds was verified when two independent types of comparison	with the heat energy produced had an uncertainty of less than 2	percent.	7.763580852895066
5550. this agreement is considered very good for such short time intervals.	14.074164469247409
5551. the method of calibration employs a fixed resistance element	as a calorimeter.	13.907246854918583
5552. the element is inserted	in the discharge circuit in place of the exploding wire	and the calorimetric heating of the element is measured with high accuracy.	11.315499618780173
5553. this is used as a reference for comparing the ohmic heating and	the electrical energy obtained from the measured current through the	element and the measured voltage across the element.	9.505677769940274
5554. a high-speed	shutter has been developed in order to permit photographic observation	of any portion of the electrical wire explosion.	12.647818222271685
5555. the shutter consists	of two parts: a fast-opening part and a fast-closing part.	10.61385277229228
5556. using	edgerton's method the fast-closing action is obtained from the	blackening of a window by exploding a series of parallel lead wires.	9.88711960874726
5557. the fast-opening of the shutter consists of a piece of aluminum foil	placed directly in front of the camera lens so that	no light may pass into the camera.	13.45828769288959
5558. the opening action is obtained	when a capacitor charged to high voltage is suddenly discharged through	the foil.	11.443194842119574
5559. during the discharge the magnetic forces set up by the	passage of current cause the edges of the foil to roll inward toward	its center line thus allowing light to pass into the camera.	9.303720359050864
5560. experiments	have shown that the shutter is 75 percent open in about 60-80 microseconds.	10.358652090748608
5561. the shutter aperture may be made larger or smaller by changing	the foil area and adjusting the electrical energy input to the foil.	8.753844336543663
5562. besides	the well-known hydrogen line at 21 cm wavelength the spectra of	extraterrestrial radio sources may contain sharp lines characteristic	of other atoms ions and small molecules.	8.777324869432913
5563. the detection and study	of such line spectra would add considerably to present information on	interstellar gas clouds and perhaps planetary atmospheres.	8.674870936306482
5564. among the	most likely producers of detectable radio line spectra are the light	diatomic hydrides oh and ch; somewhat less likely sources	are the heavier hydrides sh sih and sch.	9.489965894480786
5565. very small	concentrations of these hydrides should be detectable; in interstellar	gas concentrations as low as f moleculesf may be sufficient	as compared to the f hydrogen atoms f required for detection of	the 21-cm line.	8.194489980117554
5566. high sensitivity in radio telescopes is achieved	by reducing the bandwidth of the receiver; therefore only with	precise foreknowledge of the line frequencies is an astronomical	search for the radio spectra of these molecules feasible.	9.110362967906346
5567. to secure precise	measurements of these frequencies a research program in free radical	microwave spectroscopy has been started.	9.486264779536949
5568. since conventional methods	are insensitive at the low frequencies of these molecular transitions	the paramagnetic resonance method is being used instead.	10.286598017570356
5569. this	involves the application of a strong magnetic field to the radical vapor	which shifts the low-frequency spectra to a conveniently high microwave	range where they may be measured with optimum sensitivity.	8.423206206384604
5570. the first diatomic hydride investigated by the paramagnetic resonance	method was the oh radical.	13.538773254924651
5571. results of this experiment include	the frequencies of the two strong spectral lines by which oh may	be identified in interstellar gas; the frequencies are 1665.	7.979745365809826
5572. 36 f with an uncertainty of 0.	13.037321475654965

5653. mr speaker for several years now the commuter	railroads serving our large metropolitan areas have found it increasingly	difficult to render the kind of service our expanding population	wants and is entitled to have.	8.695523032299432
5654. the causes of the decline of the commuter	railroads are many and complex- high taxes losses of revenue to	government subsidized highway and air carriers to name but two.	11.071642932935642
5655. and	the solutions to the problems of the commuter lines have been equally	varied ranging all the way from government ownership to complete	discontinuance of this important service.	10.107019643309892
5656. there have been a number	of sound plans proposed.	32.743413601357
5657. but none of these has been implemented.	17.829496071494383
5658. instead we have stood idly by watched our commuter railroad service	decline and have failed to offer a helping hand.	12.255144128666917
5659. though the number	of people flowing in and out of our metropolitan areas each day has increased	tremendously since world war 2 total annual rail commutation	dropped 124 million from 1947 to 1957.	10.203339518584075
5660. nowhere has this decline	been more painfully evident than in the new york city area.	18.274039062442046
5661. here the	new york central railroad one of the nation's most important	carriers has alone lost 47.	7.8784449515893815
5662. 6 percent of its passengers since 1949.	13.707755784173429
5663. at this time of crisis in our nation's commuter railroads	a new threat to the continued operations of the new york central has	appeared in the form of the chesapeake + ohio railroad's proposal	for control of the baltimore + ohio railroads.	9.137536924196358
5664. the new york	central has pointed out that this control if approved by the interstate	commerce commission would give the combined c + o-b	+ o railroad a total of 185 points served in common with the	new york central.	10.399661818901178
5665. not only is this kind of duplication wasteful	but it gives the combined system the ability to take freight traffic	away from the new york central and other railroads serving the area.	11.505155303651208
5666. the new york central notes:   the freight traffic	most susceptible to raiding by the c + o-b + o provides	the backbone of central's revenues.	11.612503816074305
5667. these revenues make it	possible to provide essential freight and passenger service over the entire	new york central system as well as the new york area commuter	and terminal freight services.	9.542549446588117
5668. if these services are to be maintained	the new york central must have the revenues to make them possible.	14.516367635189226
5669. the new york central today handles 60 percent of all	southbound commuter traffic coming into new york city.	11.542157019986371
5670. this is a	$14 million operation involving 3500 employees who work on commuter	traffic exclusively.	15.5513439616328
5671. a blow to this phase of the central's operations	would have serious economic consequences not only to the railroad	itself but to the 40000 people per day who are provided with efficient	reasonably priced transportation in and out of the city.	10.207682438188849
5672. there is a workable alternative to this potentially dangerous and harmful	c + o-b + o merger scheme-   the central	has pointed out.	14.444525071470226
5673. the logic of creating a strong balanced	competitive two-system railroad service in the east is so obvious	that b + o was publicly committed to the approach outlined here.	8.603475303129162
5674. detailed studies of the plan were well underway.	14.04466177404513
5675. though	far from completion these studies indicated beyond a doubt that savings	would result which would be of unprecedented benefit to the railroads	concerned their investors their customers their users and to the	public at large.	7.825112486782558
5676. then abandoning the studies in the face of	their promising outlook for all concerned b + o entered on-again-off-again	negotiations with c + o which resulted in the present	situation.	11.006040255989118
5677. in the light of the facts at hand however	new york central intends to pursue the objective of helping to create	a healthy two-system eastern railroad structure in the public interest.	11.058495795288033

5742. from its inception in 1920 with the passage of public law 236 66th	congress the purpose of the vocational rehabilitation program has been	to assist the states by means of grants-in-aid to return disabled	men and women to productive gainful employment.	10.820379861670501
5743. the authority for	the program was renewed several times until the vocational rehabilitation	program was made permanent as title 5 of the social security	act in 1935.	8.649548345931608
5744. up to this time and for the next eight years the services	provided disabled persons consisted mainly of training counseling	and placement on a job.	13.450807603118365
5745. recognizing the limitations of such a program	the 78th congress in 1943 passed p l 113 which broadened	the concept of rehabilitation to include the provision of physical	restoration services to remove or reduce disabilities and which revised	the financing structure.	8.049298398081238
5746. despite the successful	rehabilitation of over a half million disabled persons in the first	eleven years after 1943 the existing program was still seen to be	inadequate to cope with the nation's backlog of an estimated two million	disabled.	10.253444284768515
5747. to assist the states therefore in rehabilitating handicapped	individuals so that they may prepare for and engage in remunerative	employment to the extent of their capabilities the 83rd	congress enacted the vocational rehabilitation amendments of 1954	.	9.355849127292075
5748. these amendments to the vocational rehabilitation	act were designed to help provide for more specialized rehabilitation	facilities for more sheltered and half-way workshops for	greater numbers of adequately trained personnel for more comprehensive	services to individuals	and for other administrative improvements to increase the program's	overall effectiveness.	8.78750676573639
5749. under the law as it	existed until 1943 the federal government made grants to the states	on the basis of population matching state expenditures on a 50-50	basis.	10.913127699597203
5750. under p l 113 78th congress the federal government	assumed responsibility for 100% of necessary state expenditures	in connection with administration and the counseling and placement of	the disabled and for 50% of the necessary costs of providing clients	with rehabilitation case services.	8.760165467012243
5751. throughout these years the statutory	authorization was for such sums as were necessary to carry out	the provisions of the act.	9.102792259180145
5752. the 1954 amendments completely changed	the financing of the vocational rehabilitation program providing	for a three-part grant structure- for extension	and improvement; and research demonstrations training and	traineeships for vocational rehabilitation- and in addition for	short-term training and instruction.	9.474452089955026
5753. the first part of the new structure-	that for supporting the basic program of vocational rehabilitation	services- is described in this section.	11.729707164667401
5754. subsequent sections	on grants describe the other categories of the grant structure.	11.606406736831968
5755. the following table shows for selected years the authorizations	appropriations allotment base federal grants to states and state	matching funds for this part of the grant program:	distributing funds	in order to assist	the states in maintaining basic vocational rehabilitation services section	2 of the amended act provides that allotments to states for	support of such services be based on need as measured by a state's	population and fiscal capacity as measured by its per capita	income.	8.035779780451946
5756. the act further provides for a floor or minimum allotment	set at the 1954 level which is called the base allotment	and a ceiling or maximum allotment for each state.	9.453055163142391
5757. it stipulates	in addition that all amounts remaining as a result of imposing	the ceiling	and not used for insuring the floor be redistributed	to those states still below their maximums.	10.670795245978685
5758. these provisions	are designed to reflect the differences in wealth and population among	the states with the objective that a vocationally handicapped person	have access to needed services regardless of whether he resides in	a state with a low or high per capita income or a sparsely or thickly	populated state.	8.532733986004093
5759. the provisions are also designed to avoid disruption	in state programs already in operation which might otherwise result	from the allotment of funds on the basis of wealth and population	alone.	8.759311799184614
5760. the method used in computing	the allotments is specifically set forth in the act.	14.642697855833415

5799. at the entrance side of the shelter each roof beam is rested	on the inside 4 inches of the block wall.	12.339998269915275

5864. with a spare battery a source of light for 2 weeks or more	would be assured.	14.6305864037142
