5866. there should	be a regular electrical outlet in the shelter as power may continue	in many areas.	13.438484526484014
5867. if there	are outside windows in the basement corner where you build a shelter	they should be shielded as shown in the appendix page 29.	11.077311570467865
5868. other basement	windows should be blocked when an emergency threatens.	12.957194890040192
5869. basement	walls that project above the ground should be shielded as shown in the	appendix page 29.	10.050851074074574
5870. in these shelters the entrance should be	not more than 2 feet wide.	15.97491580446844
5871. bunks or materials to build them may have	to be put inside the enclosure before the shelter walls are completed.	8.166228200570187
5872. the basement or belowground shelters also will serve for tornado	or hurricane protection.	12.445450562798397
5873. the	radioactivity of fallout decays rapidly at first.	11.118618003375188
5874. forty-nine hours	after an atomic burst the radiation intensity is only about 1 percent	of what it was an hour after the explosion.	9.922140392592352
5875. but the radiation may	be so intense at the start that one percent may be extremely dangerous.	12.579678912663441
5876. therefore civil defense instructions received over conelrad	or by other means should be followed.	11.015620856498392
5877. a battery-powered	radio is essential.	18.34168694583862
5878. radiation instruments suitable for home use are	available and would be of value in locating that portion of the home	which offers the best protection against fallout radiation.	11.155597873565158
5879. there is	a possibility that battery-powered radios with built-in radiation meters	may become available.	13.147953068783316
5880. one instrument thus would serve both purposes.	17.615700666707628
5881. your local civil defense will gather its own information and	will receive broad information from state and federal sources.	8.893757339978972
5882. it	will tell you as soon as possible:   how long to stay in your	shelter.	13.365955789742959
5883. how soon you may go outdoors.	15.332896408532532
5884. how long you	may stay outside.	21.045855440501583
5885. you should be prepared to stay in your shelter	full time for at least several days and to make it your home for 14	days or longer.	12.943850477287251
5886. a checklist in the appendix tells what is	needed.	14.647991031386455
5887. families with children will have particular problems.	14.371897095366824
5888. they	should provide for simple recreation.	15.068811854765874
5889. there should be a task	for everyone and these tasks should be rotated.	19.371055974023196
5890. part of the family should	be sleeping while the rest is awake.	28.53070592250698
5891. to break the monotony	it may be necessary to invent tasks that will keep the family busy.	10.998398447997491
5892. records such as diaries can be kept.	13.472041276775048
5893. the survival of the family	will depend largely on information received by radio.	12.938783063703605
5894. a record should	be kept of the information and instructions including the time and	date of broadcast.	11.471009452944916
5895. family rationing probably will be necessary.	15.680739612173873
5896. blowers should be operated periodically on a regular schedule.	12.236716858040163
5897. there will come a time in a basement shelter when the radiation	has decayed enough to allow use of the whole basement.	15.194599442386382
5898. however as	much time as possible should be spent within the shelter to hold radiation	exposure to a minimum.	10.740735629072274
5899. the housekeeping problems of living	in a shelter will begin as soon as the shelter is occupied.	11.625512872537108
5900. food medical	supplies utensils and equipment if not already stored in the	shelter must be quickly gathered up and carried into it.	9.317720268463072
5901. after	the family has settled in the shelter the housekeeping rules should	be spelled out by the adult in charge.	8.082367128027338
5902. sanitation in the confines	of the family shelter will require much thought and planning.	10.358652090748608
5903. provision for emergency toilet facilities and disposal of human	wastes will be an unfamiliar problem.	9.378399679698203
5904. a covered container such as a kitchen	garbage pail might do as a toilet.	12.961848137953165
5905. a 10-gallon garbage can with	a tightly fitting cover could be used to keep the wastes until it	is safe to leave the shelter.	11.838448785669494
5906. water rationing will be difficult	and should be planned carefully.	14.031964115410089
5907. a portable electric heater	is advisable for shelters in cold climates.	11.516492904103949
5908. it would take the chill from	the shelter in the beginning.	25.511769805147683
5909. even if the electric power fails after	an attack any time that the heater has been used will make the shelter	that much more comfortable.	10.890122593186716
5910. body heat in the close quarters will	help keep up the temperature.	10.957705180640192
5911. warm clothing and bedding of course	are essential.	11.118618003375188
5912. open-flame heating or cooking should be avoided.	13.037321475654965
5913. a flame would use up air.	14.566660921827188
5914. some families already have held	weekend rehearsals in their home shelters to learn the problems and to	determine for themselves what supplies they would need.	10.057931786217031
5915. an attack finds you without a prepared shelter	few areas if any	are as good as prepared shelters but they are worth knowing about.	9.30507353824616
5916. a family dwelling without a basement provides some natural shielding	from fallout radiation.	12.589811652562057
5917. on the ground floor the radiation would	be about half what it is outside.	19.84918981377598
5918. the best protection would be on	the ground floor in the central part of the house.	15.690984136666438
5919. a belowground	basement can cut the fallout radiation to one-tenth of the outside	level.	10.238518070264613
5920. the safest place is the basement corner least exposed to windows	and deepest below ground.	11.636095537390238
5921. if there is time after the warning	the basement shielding could be improved substantially by blocking	windows with bricks dirt books magazines or other heavy material.	11.877753862309392
5922. large apartment buildings	of masonry or concrete provide better natural shelter than the usual	family dwellings.	10.284069625400775
5923. in general such apartments afford more protection	than smaller buildings because their walls are thick and there is	more space.	10.24939232288813
5924. the central area of the ground floor of a heavily	constructed apartment building with concrete floors should provide	more fallout protection than the ordinary basement of a family dwelling.	11.65548334397526
5925. the basement of such an apartment building may provide as much natural	protection as the specially constructed concrete block shelter recommended	for the basement of a family dwelling.	8.786459635108981
5926. the federal	government is aiding local governments in several places to survey residential	commercial and industrial buildings to determine what fallout	protection they would provide and for how many people.	10.081336928612803
5927. the	problem for the city apartment dweller is primarily to plan the use	of existing space.	10.538228628536329
5928. such planning will require the cooperation of other	occupants and of the apartment management.	14.225349254636097
5929. a former du pont official became a general motors vice president	and set about maximizing du pont's share of the general motors	market.	9.694393284527111
5930. lines of communications were established between the two	companies and several du pont products were actively promoted.	9.936682898094263
5931. within	a few years various du pont manufactured items were filling the entire	requirements of from four to seven of general motors' eight operating	divisions.	8.102912449005771
5932. the fisher body division long controlled by the	fisher brothers under a voting trust even though general motors owned	a majority of its stock followed an independent course for many years	but by 1947 and 1948 resistance had collapsed and its purchases	from du pont compared favorably with purchases by other general	motors divisions.	8.241954020466393
5933. competitors came to receive higher percentage	of general motors business in later years but it is likely	that this trend stemmed at least in part from the needs of general	motors outstripping du pont's capacity.	10.38111235512468
5934. the fact	that sticks out in this voluminous record is that the bulk of du pont's	production has always supplied the largest part of the requirements	of the one customer in the automobile industry connected to du pont	by a stock interest.	10.39792778275641
5935. the inference is overwhelming that du pont's	commanding position was promoted by its stock interest and was not gained	solely on competitive merit.	9.426462240452924
5936. 353 u s at 605.	15.068811854765874
5937. this court agreed with the trial court that considerations of price	quality and service were not overlooked by either du pont or general	motors.	8.51373500565124
5938. 353 u s at 606.	15.068811854765874
5939. however it determined that	neither this factor nor the fact that all concerned in high executive	posts in both companies acted honorably and fairly each in the	honest conviction that his actions were in the best interests of his own	company and without any design to overreach anyone including du pont's	competitors 353 u s at 607 outweighed the government's	claim for relief.	8.267061450763965
5940. this claim as submitted to the district	court and dismissed by it 126 fsupp235 alleged violation	not only of  7 of the clayton act but also of   1 and 2 of	the sherman act.	9.858489165676556
5941. the latter provisions proscribe any contract combination	or conspiracy in restraint of interstate or foreign trade and	monopolization of or attempts combinations or conspiracies to monopolize	such trade.	8.635418435660345
5942. however this court put to one side without consideration	the government's appeal from the dismissal of its sherman	act allegations.	13.29998788862922
5943. it rested its decision solely on  7 which reads	in pertinent part:   no corporation engaged in commerce	shall acquire directly or indirectly the whole or any part of	the stock or other share capital of another corporation engaged also in	commerce where the effect of such acquisition may be to substantially	lessen competition between the corporation whose stock is so acquired	and the corporation making the acquisition or to restrain such commerce	in any section or community or tend to create a monopoly of any	line of commerce.	7.298321437865897
5944. this section shall not apply to corporations	purchasing such stock solely for investment and not using the same	by voting or otherwise to bring about or in attempting to bring about	the substantial lessening of competition h.	9.242603668562717
5945. the purpose	of this provision was thus explained in the court's opinion:	section 7 is designed to arrest in its incipiency not only	the substantial lessening of competition from the acquisition by one corporation	of the whole or any part of the stock of a competing corporation	but also to arrest in their incipiency restraints or monopolies	in a relevant market which as a reasonable probability appear at the	time of suit likely to result from the acquisition by one corporation	of all or any part of the stock of any other corporation.	7.993351860935518
5946. the section	is violated whether or not actual restraints or monopolies or the substantial	lessening of competition have occurred or are intended h.	10.847318835526345
5947. 353 u s at 589.	12.851133807717682
5948. thus a finding of conspiracy to	restrain trade or attempt to monopolize was excluded from the court's	decision.	11.216082767757548
5949. indeed as already noted the court proceeded on the assumption	that the executives involved in the dealings between du pont	and general motors acted honorably and fairly and exercised	their business judgment only to serve what they deemed the best interests	of their own companies.	7.408343833141947
5950. this however did not bar finding that du	pont had become pre-eminent as a supplier of automotive fabrics and	finishes to general motors; that these products constituted a line	of commerce within the meaning of the clayton act; that general	motors' share of the market for these products was substantial;	and that competition for this share of the market was endangered	by the financial relationship between the two concerns:   the	statutory policy of fostering free competition is obviously furthered	when no supplier has an advantage over his competitors from an acquisition	of his customer's stock likely to have the effects condemned	by the statute.	9.132243731122273
5951. we repeat that the test of a violation of  7 is	whether at the time of suit there is a reasonable probability that	the acquisition is likely to result in the condemned restraints.	11.43041329194725
5952. the	conclusion upon this record is inescapable that such likelihood was proved	as to this acquisition h.	10.188173486419053
5953. 353 u s at 607.	12.851133807717682
5954. on	the basis of the findings which led to this conclusion the court remanded	the case to the district court to determine the appropriate	relief.	12.701915154497947
5955. the sole guidance given the court for discharging the task committed	to it was this:   the judgment must therefore be reversed	and the cause remanded to the district court for a determination	after further hearing of the equitable relief necessary and appropriate	in the public interest to eliminate the effects of the acquisition	offensive to the statute.	7.424871137263504
5956. the district courts in the framing	of equitable decrees are clothed 'with large discretion to model	their judgments to fit the exigencies of the particular case'.	10.149796784726894
5957. international	salt co	v united states 332 u s 392	400-401.	10.530932308755343
5958. 353 u s at 607-608.	15.068811854765874
5959. this brings us to the	course of the proceedings in the district court.	14.81066287596369
5960. this	court's judgment was filed in the district court on july 18	1957.	12.363706091647037
5961. the first pretrial conference- held to appoint amici curiae	to represent the interest of the stockholders of du pont and general	motors and to consider the procedure to be followed in the subsequent	hearings- took place on september 25 1957.	8.259624843185112
5962. at the outset the	government's spokesman explained that counsel for the government	and for du pont had already held preliminary discussions with a view	to arriving at a relief plan that both sides could recommend to the court.	10.6662080658619
5963. du pont he said had proposed disenfranchisement of its general	motors stock along with other restrictions on the du pont-general	motors relationship.	8.420428627674902
5964. the government deeming these suggestions inadequate	had urged that any judgment include divestiture of du pont's	shares of general motors.	11.635943650809462
5965. counsel for the government invited	du pont's views on this proposal before recommending a specific program	but stated that if the court desired or if counsel for du pont	thought further discussion would not be profitable the government	was prepared to submit a plan within thirty days.	7.7495992008110886
5966. counsel for	du pont indicated a preference for the submission of detailed plans by	both sides at an early date.	10.548248288235246
5967. no previous antitrust case he said had	involved interests of such magnitude or presented such complex problems	of relief.	9.08533028224275
5968. the submission of detailed plans would place the issues	before the court more readily than would discussion of divestiture	or disenfranchisement in the abstract.	9.861026361047744
5969. the court adopted this procedure	with an appropriate time schedule for carrying it out.	11.249858121504476
5970. the	government submitted its proposed decree on october 25 1957.	11.793662721363662
5971. the	plan called for divestiture by du pont of its 63000000 shares of general	motors stock by equal annual distributions to its stockholders	as a dividend over a period of ten years.	8.346592520257799
5972. christiana securities company	and delaware realty + investment company major stockholders	in du pont and the stockholders of delaware were dealt with specially	by provisions requiring the annual sale by a trustee again over	a ten-year period of du pont's general motors stock allocable to	them as well as any general motors stock which christiana and delaware	owned outright.	8.148284135272347
5973. if in the trustee's judgment reasonable	market conditions did not prevail during any given year he was to	be allowed to petition the court for an extension of time within the	ten-year period.	9.065334719689972
5974. in addition the right to vote the general motors	stock held by du pont was to be vested in du pont's stockholders	other than christiana and delaware and the stockholders of delaware;	du pont christiana and delaware were to be enjoined from acquiring	stock in or exercising control over general motors; du pont	christiana and delaware were to be prohibited to have any director	or officer in common with general motors and vice versa; and	general motors and du pont were to be ordered to terminate any agreement	that provided for the purchase by general motors of any specified	percentage of its requirements of any du pont manufactured product	or for the grant of exclusive patent rights or for a grant by general	motors to du pont of a preferential right to make or sell any	chemical discovery of general motors or for the maintenance of any	joint commercial enterprise by the two companies.	9.015011694072749
5975. on motion of	the amici	curiae the court directed that a ruling be obtained from	the commissioner of internal revenue as to the federal income tax	consequences of the government's plan.	8.947779578724473
5976. on may 9 1958 the commissioner	announced his rulings.	20.830914874949087
5977. the annual dividends paid to du pont	stockholders in shares of general motors stock would be taxable as ordinary	income to the extent of du pont's earnings and profits.	9.665343753073625
5978. the	measure for federal income tax purposes of the dividend to individual	stockholders would be the fair market value of the shares at the time	of each annual distribution.	10.55009558047057
5979. in the case of taxpaying corporate stockholders	the measure would be the lesser of the fair market value	of the shares or du pont's tax basis for them which is approximately	$2.	11.43022065201815
5980. the forced sale of the general motors stock owned	by or allocable to christiana delaware and the stockholders of	delaware and deposited with the trustee would result in a tax to those	parties at the capital gains rate.	9.336564421357682
5981. du pont's counterproposal	was filed on may 14 1958.	10.530932308755343
5982. under its plan du pont would retain	its general motors shares but be required to pass on to its stockholders	the right to vote those shares.	10.491378925182307
5983. christiana and delaware would	in turn be required to pass on the voting rights to the general motors	shares allocable to them to their own stockholders.	9.073608583513076
5984. du pont would	be enjoined from having as a director officer or employee anyone	who was simultaneously an officer or employee of general motors and	no director officer or employee of du pont could serve as a director	of general motors without court approval.	8.590219495695113
5985. du pont would be denied	the right to acquire any additional general motors stock except	through general motors' distributions of stock or subscription rights	to its stockholders.	7.576307155387862
5986. on june 6 1958 general motors submitted	its objections to the government's proposal.	13.923040828720318
5987. it argued inter	alia that a divestiture order would severely depress the market	value of the stock of both general motors and du pont with consequent	serious loss and hardship to hundreds of thousands of innocent	investors among them thousands of small trusts and charitable institutions;	that there would be a similar decline in the market values of	other automotive and chemical stocks with similar losses to the stockholders	of those companies; that the tremendous volume of general	motors stock hanging over the market for ten years would hamper the efforts	of general motors and other automobile manufacturers to raise	equity capital; and that all this would have a serious adverse effect	on the entire stock market and on general business activity.	7.4011322107714514
5988. general	motors comprehensively contended that the government plan would	not be in the public interest as required by the mandate of this	court.	11.992465099572996
5989. the decrees proposed by the amici curiae were filed	in august of 1958.	10.61385277229228
5990. these plans like du pont's contained provisions	for passing the vote on du pont's general motors shares on	to the ultimate stockholders of du pont christiana and delaware	except that officers and directors of the three companies their spouses	and other people living in their households as well as other specified	persons were to be totally disenfranchised.	9.652835661394754
5991. both plans also prohibited	common directors officers or employees between du pont christiana	and delaware on the one hand and general motors on the	other.	10.237997836203524
5992. it is not a medieval mental quirk or an attitude unnourished by sense	to believe that husbands and wives should not be subjected to such	a risk or that such a possibility should not be permitted to endanger	the confidentiality of the marriage relationship.	12.500137184848692
5993. while it is easy	enough to ridicule hawkins' pronouncement in pleas of the crown	from a metaphysical point of view the concept of the oneness	of a married couple may reflect an abiding belief that the communion between	husband and wife is such that their actions are not always to be	regarded by the criminal law as if there were no marriage.	8.533813192928882
5994. by	making inroads in the name of law enforcement into the protection which	congress has afforded to the marriage relationship the court today	continues in the path charted by the recent decision in wyatt	v united states 362 us 525 where the court held that	under the circumstances of that case a wife could be compelled to	testify against her husband over her objection.	8.181112349045975
5995. one need not waver in	his belief in virile law enforcement to insist that there are other	things in american life which are also of great importance and to which	even law enforcement must accommodate itself.	8.33679476614116
5996. one of these is the	solidarity and the confidential relationship of marriage.	21.35934006449195
5997. the court's	opinion dogmatically asserts that the husband-wife conspiracy doctrine	does not in fact protect this relationship and that hence the doctrine	enthrones an unreality into a rule of law.	7.9194897122132115
5998. i am not	easily persuaded that a rule accepted by so many people for so many centuries	can be so lightly dismissed.	13.176729684209526
5999. but in any event i submit that	the power to depose belongs to congress not to this court.	12.2985070892661
6000. petitioner who claims to be a conscientious objector was convicted	of violating  12 of the universal military training and service	act by refusing to be inducted into the armed forces.	9.483636604129078
6001. he claims	that he was denied due process of law in violation of the fifth amendment	because at a hearing before a hearing officer of the department	of justice he was not permitted to rebut statements attributed	to him by the local board and at the trial he was denied the right	to have the hearing officer's report and the original report of	the federal bureau of investigation as to his claim.	8.698475091892858
6002. held:	on the record in this case the administrative procedures prescribed	by the act were fully complied with; petitioner was not denied due	petitioner	was not denied due process in the administrative proceedings	because the statement in question was in his file to which he had access	and he had opportunities to rebut it both before the hearing officer	of the department of justice and before the appeal board.	9.276661549528761
6003. pp	petitioner was not entitled to have the hearing officer's	notes and report especially since he failed to show any particular	need for them and he did have a copy of the department of justice's	petitioner was not entitled either in the administrative hearing at	the department of justice or at his trial to inspect the original report	of the federal bureau of investigation since he was furnished	a resume of it did not challenge its accuracy and showed no particular	need for the original report.	8.474449505573126

6016. petitioner registered with	local board no 9 boulder colorado on march 17 1952.	10.635267499930531

6019. on november	13 1952 he was classified in class 1-a.	14.340333782216247
6020. on november 22	1952 he wrote the board protesting this classification.	17.111647983976454
6021. he again stated	that he was a regular minister; that he was devoting	an average	of 100 hours a month to actual preaching publicly in addition to	50 to 75 hours in other ministerial duties and that he opposed war in	any form.	8.699480064993272

6043. nevertheless he had ample opportunity	to contest the statement before the appeal board.	10.01381971267754
6044. after the recommendation	of the department is forwarded to the appeal board that is the	appropriate place for a registrant to lodge his denial.	12.00959658063547
6045. we found in gonzales v united states supra that this	was the controlling reason why copies of the recommendation should be	furnished a registrant.	9.395944134311138
6046. we said there that it was necessary that	a registrant be given an opportunity to rebut the department's	recommendation when it comes to the appeal board the agency with the	ultimate responsibility for classification.	12.063293010804998
6047. we fail to see how such procedure resulted in any prejudice to petitioner's	contention which was considered by the appeal board and	denied by it.	9.434373464433083
6048. as was said in gonzales it is the appeal board	which renders the selective service determination considered 'final'	in the courts not to be overturned unless there is no basis in fact.	11.357225306546214
6049. estep v united states 327 us 114.	11.118618003375188
6050. 348	u	s at 412-413.	18.919390992859817
6051. but there are other contentions which might	be considered more difficult.	22.307369995297506
6052. at his trial petitioner sought to secure	through subpoena duces tecum the longhand notes of the department's	hearing officer evensen as well as his report thereon.	11.209689093614697
6053. petitioner	also claimed at trial the right to inspect the original federal	bureau of investigation reports to the department of justice.	11.135333448180393
6054. he alleged no specific procedural errors or evidence withheld; nor	did he elaborate just what favorable evidence the federal bureau of	investigation reports might disclose.	11.497671768514193
6055. section 6 of the	act	as we have held does require the department's recommendation to	be placed in a registrant's file.	8.536810242711947
6056. gonzales v united states	supra.	16.6462465444584
6057. but there is nothing in the act requiring the hearing	officer's report to be likewise turned over to the registrant.	16.89030426295369
6058. while	the regulations formerly required that the hearing officer's report	be placed in the registrant's file this requirement was eliminated	in 1952.	10.199987225902532
6059. moreover the hearing officer's report is but intradepartmental	is directed to the attorney general and of course is not	the recommendation of the department.	11.255335941528637
6060. it is not essentially different	from a memorandum of an attorney in the department of justice of	which the attorney general receives many and to which he may give	his approval or rejection.	14.745929574137289
6061. it is but part of the whole process within	the department that goes into the making of the final recommendation	to the appeal board.	15.95279880239472
6062. it is also significant that neither this	report nor the hearing officer's notes were furnished to the appeal	board.	15.535634227469462
6063. hence the petitioner had full opportunity to traverse the only	conclusions of the department on file with the board.	11.06283852093769
6064. petitioner	knew that the department's recommendation was based not on the hearing	officer's report but on the statement of the local board in his	file.	11.010906136097084
6065. having had every opportunity to rebut the finding of the local	board before both the hearing officer and the appeal board petitioner	cannot now claim that he was denied due process because he did not succeed.	8.006222804100185
6066. it appears to us that the same reasoning applies to the	production of the hearing officer's report and notes at the trial.	12.591262364392456
6067. in addition petitioner has failed to show any particular need for the	report and notes.	13.995829689404383
6068. while there are now allegations of the withholding	of favorable evidence developed at the hearing and a denial of	a full and fair hearing no such claim was made by petitioner at	any stage of the administrative process.	9.819745382407794
6069. moreover his testimony at	trial never developed any such facts.	12.132340491810675
6070. in the light of these circumstances	as well as the fact that the issue at trial in this respect centered	entirely on the department's recommendation which petitioner	repudiated but which both the appeal board and the courts below found	supported by the record we find no relevancy in the hearing officer's	report and notes.	11.508090407892787
6071. finally petitioner says that he was entitled	to inspect the fbi report during the proceedings before the	hearing officer as well as at the trial.	10.428950982850354
6072. he did receive a resume of	it- the same that was furnished the appeal board- and he made no	claim of its inaccuracy.	13.147535362247371
6073. even now no such claim is asserted.	14.459971960481784
6074. he bases	his present contention on the general right to explore indicating that	he hopes to find some discrepancy in the resume.	11.402211918112066
6075. but this is fully	answered by united states v nugent supra.	18.224663534944504
6076. there we held	that the statutory scheme for review within the selective service	system h entitles conscientious objectors to no guarantee	that	the fbi reports must be produced for their inspection.	10.320575806130957
6077. even if we were not bound by nugent petitioner	here would not be entitled to the report.	13.524280778933955
6078. the recommendation of	the department- as well as the decision of the appeal board- was	based entirely on the local board file not on an fbi report.	11.82959558123692
6079. with this enlarged role in	mind i should like to make a few suggestions: what we in the united	states do or do not do will make a very large difference in what	happens in the rest of the world.	11.203710262542911
6080. we in this department must think about	foreign policy in its total context.	15.104909325408414
6081. we cannot regard foreign policy	as something left over after defense policy or trade policy or fiscal	policy has been extracted.	9.68848064886208
6082. foreign policy is the total involvement	of the american people with peoples and governments abroad.	12.931880155135639
6083. that	means that if we are to achieve a new standard of leadership we must	think in terms of the total context of our situation.	12.682240901842567
6084. it is the concern	of the department of state that the american people are safe and	secure- defense is not a monopoly concern of the department of defense.	20.454868256666852
6085. it is also the concern of the department of state that our	trading relationships with the rest of the world are vigorous profitable	and active- this is not just a passing interest or a matter of	concern only to the department of commerce.	16.479694457271435
6086. we can no longer rely on	interdepartmental machinery somewhere upstairs to resolve differences	between this and other departments.	14.852792098802231
6087. assistant secretaries of	state will now carry an increased burden of active formulation and coordination	of policies.	8.875519561448924
6088. means must be found to enable us to keep in	touch as regularly and as efficiently as possible with our colleagues	in other departments concerned with foreign policy.	9.762220552947062
6089. i think we	need to concern ourselves also with the timeliness of action.	13.861459511745588
6090. every	policy officer cannot help but be a planning officer.	11.793662721363662
6091. unless we keep	our eyes on the horizon ahead we shall fail to bring ourselves on target	with the present.	9.031328976717537
6092. the movement of events is so fast the pace so	severe that an attempt to peer into the future is essential if we are	to think accurately about the present.	9.733932821009546
6093. if there is anything which we	can do in the executive branch of the government to speed up the processes	by which we come to decisions on matters on which we must act	promptly that in itself would be a major contribution to the conduct	of our affairs.	11.4233974396433
6094. action taken today is often far more valuable than action	taken several months later in response to a situation then out of	control.	11.164335426742218
6095. there will of course be times for delay and inaction.	23.55710344705893

6097. i also hope that we can	do something about reducing the infant mortality rate of ideas- an affliction	of all bureaucracies.	9.9789661687423
6098. we want to stimulate ideas from the bottom	to the top of the department.	23.79695113216575

6100. i hope no one	expects that only presidential appointees are looked upon as sources	of ideas.	13.674023786873345
6101. the responsibility for taking the initiative in generating	ideas is that of every officer in the department who has a policy function	regardless of rank.	10.828137405184387
6102. further i would hope that we could	pay attention to little things.	13.886462683990771
6103. while observing the operations of	our government in various parts of the world i have felt that in many	situations where our policies were good we have tended to ignore minor	problems which spoiled our main effort.	9.722601367140374
6104. to cite only a few examples:	the wrong man in the wrong position perhaps even in a junior	position	abroad can be a source of great harm to our policy; the attitudes	of a un delegate who experiences difficulty in finding adequate	housing in new york city or of a foreign diplomat in similar	circumstances in our capital can be easily be directed against the united	states and all that it stands for.	11.216442953007778

6369. the task of providing a reasonable level of military	strength without endangering other vital aspects of our security	is greatly complicated by the swift pace of scientific progress.	8.950940478233589
6370. the	last few years have witnessed what have been perhaps the most rapid advances	in military technology in history.	10.512387588911063
6371. some weapons systems have	become obsolescent while still in production and some while still under	development.	10.28238949363653
6372. furthermore unexpectedly rapid progress or a	technological break-through on any one weapon system in itself often	diminishes the relative importance of other competitive systems.	9.254023890597805

6382. the impact of technological factors	is also illustrated by the history of the high-energy fuel program.	17.200143473521717

6443. this broad delegation leaves within our discretion	both the determination	of what degree of interference shall be considered excessive and the	methods by which such excessive interference shall be avoided.	8.001514491340126
6444. the present proceeding is concerned with the standard broadcast	band from 540 kc to 1600 kc.	15.126708397176124
6445. whenever two or more standard	broadcast stations operate simultaneously on the same or closely adjacent	frequencies each interferes to some extent with reception of	the other.	9.449610226019214
6446. the extent of such interference- which may be so slight	as to be undetectable at any point where either of the stations renders	a usable signal or may be so great as to virtually destroy the service	areas of both stations- depends on many factors among the principal	ones being the distance between the stations their respective	radiated power and of particular significance here the time of day.	9.443967957665402
6447. other factors playing a part in the the extent of am service	and interference are the frequency involved the time of year the position	of the year in the sunspot cycle ground conductivity along	the	transmission path atmospheric and manmade noise and others.	9.084147796518598
6448. with the	existence of these many factors some of them variable it obviously	has never been and is not now possible for the commission to make assignments	of am stations on a case-to-case basis which will insure	against any interference in any circumstances.	9.775002288578413
6449. rather such assignments	are made as they must be on the basis of certain overall rules	and standards representing to some extent a statistical approach to	the problem taking into account for each situation some of the variables	and averaging out others	in order to achieve the balance which must be struck between protection	against destructive interference and the assignment of a number of	stations large enough to afford optimum radio service to the nation.	8.894553069669048
6450. an example of the overall standards applied is the 20-to-1 ratio established	for the determination of that degree of cochannel interference	which is regarded as objectionable.	11.279609109597365
6451. by this standard it is determined	that where two stations operating on the same frequency are involved	objectionable interference from station a exists at any point within	the service area of station b where station a's signal	is of an intensity one-twentieth or more of the strength of station b's	signal at that point.	8.398680149620548
6452. the 20-to-1 ratio for cochannel	interference embodies one of the fundamental limiting principles which	we must always take into account in am assignments and allocations-	that signals from a particular station are potential sources	of objectionable interference over an area much greater than that within	which they provide useful service.	8.896253630473446
6453. a second fundamental principle	is that involved particularly in the present proceeding- the difference	between nighttime and daytime propagation conditions with respect	to the standard broadcast frequencies.	9.169145758850293
6454. this is a phenomenon familiar	to all radio listeners resulting from reflection of skywave signals at	night from the ionized layer in the upper atmosphere known as the ionosphere.	12.358023437490031
6455. all am stations radiate both skywave and groundwave signals	at all hours; but during the middle daytime hours these skywave	radiations are not reflected in any substantial quantity and during	this portion of the day both skywave service and skywave interference	are in general negligible.	8.524306027239053
6456. but during nighttime hours the skywave	radiations are reflected from the ionosphere thereby creating the possibility	of one station's rendering service via skywave at a much	greater distance than it can through its groundwave signal and at the	same time vastly complicating the interference problem because of the	still greater distance over which these skywave signals may cause interference	to the signals of stations on the same and closely adjacent	frequencies.	8.968911785749434
6457. because of the difference between daytime and nighttime	propagation conditions it has been necessary to evolve different allocation	structures for daytime and nighttime broadcasting in the am	band with many more stations operating during the day than at night.	10.571946320261931
6458. it was recognized years ago that the transition from daytime	to nighttime propagation conditions and vice versa is not an instantaneous	process but takes place over periods of time from roughly	2 hours before sunset until about 2 hours after sunset and again from	roughly 2 hours before sunrise until some 2 hours after sunrise.	9.767726963148593
6459. during	the period of about 4 hours around sunset skywave transmission conditions	are building up until full nighttime conditions prevail; during	the same period around sunrise skywave transmission is declining	until at about 2 hours after sunrise it reaches a point where it becomes	of little practical significance.	7.180054594365896
6460. however in this case as elsewhere	it was necessary to arrive at a single standard to be applied to	all situations representing an averaging of conditions and thus to	fix particular points in time which would be considered the dividing points	between daytime and nighttime conditions.	11.508139669295277
6461. it was determined that	the hours of sunrise and sunset respectively should be used for this	purpose.	16.540937586475135
6462. accordingly the 1938-39 rules adopted these hours as limitations	upon the operation of daytime stations.	12.955202999815834
6463. class 2 stations	operating on clear channels are required to cease operation or operate	under nighttime restrictions beginning either at local sunset	or sunset at the location of the dominant	class 1 station where located west of the class 2 station	.	0.0
6464. the same restrictions apply	after local sunset in the case of class 3 stations operating on	regional channels which after that time are required to operate under	nighttime restrictions in order to protect each other.	12.473885301655931
6465. with respect	to nighttime assignments the degree of skywave service and interference	is determined by skywave curves	giving average skywave values.	10.051081963911168
6466. these curves were derived	by an analysis of extensive skywave measurement data.	13.034410421526688
6467. it was recognized	that skywave signals because of their reflected nature are of great	variability and subject to wide fluctuations in strength.	11.856977005260697
6468. for this	reason the more uncertain skywave service was denominated secondary	in our rules as compared to the steadier more reliable groundwave	primary service and for both skywave service and skywave	interference signal strength is expressed in terms of percentage of	time a particular signal-intensity level is exceeded- 50 percent of	the time for skywave service 10 percent of the time for skywave interference.	9.873232745033398
6469. as mentioned the allocation	of am stations represents a balance between protection against	interference and the provision of opportunity for an adequate number	of stations.	9.250609199572734
6470. the rules and policies to be applied in this process of	course must be based on objectives which represent what is to be desired	if radio service is to be of maximum use to the nation.	11.801029566924171
6471. our objectives	to provide some	to provide as many choices of	to provide service	of local origin to as many listeners as possible.	8.66762321517122
6472. since broadcast	frequencies are very limited in number these objectives are to some	extent inconsistent in that not all of them can be fully realized and	to the extent that each is realized there is a corresponding reduction	of the possibilities for fullest achievement of the others.	10.357631976064532
6473. accordingly	the commission has recognized that an optimum allocation pattern	for one frequency does not necessarily represent the best pattern	for other frequencies and has assigned different frequencies for use	by different classes of stations.	7.213992261087735
6474. some 45 frequencies are assigned for	use primarily by dominant class 1- a or class 1-	b clear-channel stations designed to operate with adequate	power and to provide service- both groundwave and skywave-	over large areas and at great distances being protected against	interference to the degree necessary to achieve this objective.	8.896344352702915
6475. in dealing	with these frequencies the objective listed first above- provision	of service to all listeners- was predominant; the other objectives	were subordinated to it.	8.856646330041947
6476. the class 1 stations on these clear	channels are protected to their 0.	13.2746380816454
6477. 1-mvm groundwave contours	against daytime cochannel interference.	11.867291106449708
6478. with respect to skywave service	rendered at night class 1- a stations are the only stations	permitted to operate in the united states on clear channels specified	for class 1- a operation and so render skywave service	free	from cochannel interference whereever they may be received; class	1- b stations are protected at night to their 0.	9.833815705634343
6479. 5-mvm	50-percent	time skywave contours against cochannel interference.	11.867291106449708
6480. since	the provision of skywave service requires adequate freedom from interference	only class 1 stations are capable of rendering skywave service.	10.011221978713197
6481. but nighttime operation by stations of other classes of course	entails skywave interference to groundwave service interference which	is substantial unless steps are taken to minimize it.	9.622584461095489
6482. with	respect to other frequencies these are designated as regional or local	and assigned for use by class 3 and class 4 stations respectively	stations operating generally with lower power.	8.826896954946323
6483. in the allocation	pattern worked out for these frequencies the provision of long-range	service has to some extent been subordinated to the other two objectives-	assignment of multiple facilities and assignment of stations	in as many communities as possible.	9.157738782043996
6484. as mentioned the primary	allocation objective to be followed in the allocation of stations	on clear channels is the provision of widespread service free from	destructive interference.	10.249471396796938
6485. during nighttime hours because of the intense	skywave propagation then prevailing no large number of stations can	be permitted to operate on one of these channels if the wide area	service for which these frequencies are assigned is to be rendered satisfactorily	by the dominant stations which must be relied upon to render	it.	9.07102439897389
6486. therefore under our longstanding allocation rules on some of	these channels no station other than the dominant	station is permitted to operate at night so that the 1- a	station can render service interference free wherever it can be received.	9.728813572038947
6487. on the remainder of the clear channels the dominant	stations are protected as described above and the relatively	small number of secondary stations permitted to operate	on these channels at night are required to operate directionally	andor with reduced power so as to protect the class 1 stations.	9.68367688182339
6488. in the daytime on the other hand since skywave transmission is relatively	inefficient it is possible to assign a substantially larger number	of stations on these channels.	16.28786343257252
6489. additional class 2 assignments	for daytime operation can be made without causing destructive interference	to the class 1 stations or to each other and by their operation	provide additional service on these channels and additional local	outlets for a large number of communities.	9.79535765295793
6490. such additional daytime	class 2 assignments are appropriate if optimum use is to be made	of these frequencies and the commission has over the years made a large	number of them.	10.826514245884367
6491. similarly on the regional channels many class 3	stations have been assigned either to operate daytime only or to operate	nighttime with directional antennas andor lower power.	7.828810831110529
6492. essentially the question presented for decision in the present daytime	skywave proceeding is whether our decision in 1938-1939 to	assign stations on the basis of daytime conditions from sunrise to sunset	is sound as a basis for am allocations or whether in the light	of later developments and new understanding skywave transmission	is of such significance during the hours immediately before sunset and	after sunrise that this condition should be taken into account and	some stations required to afford protection to other stations during these	hours.	0.0
6493. the decision	reached in 1938-39 was made after the accumulation of a large amount	of data and thorough study thereof.	10.43135427689265
6494. since then there has been a notable	increase in the number of stations and also the accumulation of additional	data and the development of new techniques for using it leading	to a better understanding of propagation phenomena.	13.258531228906566
6495. in 1947 affidavits	were filed with the commission by various clear-channel stations	alleging that extensive interference was being caused to the service	areas of these stations during daylight hours from class 2 stations	whose signals were being reflected from the ionosphere so as to	create skywave intereference.	7.494465246344

6546. the deductions	allowed in determining adjusted gross income put all taxpayers on	a comparable basis.	12.010194183656237

6580. the one- or two-season hunt of which there have been too many recently	may do more harm than good; for such programs raise hopes of assistance	toward achieving excellence in scholarship and the arts which	are dashed when the programs are discontinued; and they are dashed	no less by lack of skill in making selections of men and women for development	toward the highest reaches of the mind and spirit.	9.250744817540506
6581. for	the making of selections on the basis of excellence requires that any	foundation making the selections shall have available the judgments	of a corps of advisors whose judgments are known to be good: such judgments	can be known to be good only by the records of those selected	by records made subsequent to their selection over considerable periods	of time.	7.810590022855699
6582. the central group of the foundation's advisors	are at any one period of time the members of our advisory board	consisting now of thirty-six men and women.	14.034995925326276
6583. they are chosen by the	foundation's board of trustees on the bases of their own first-rate	accomplishments in their different fields of scholarship and the arts.	10.072722102499608
6584. their locations in all parts of the united states and their locations	in the several kinds of educational and research institutions	that are the principal homes of our intellectual and artistic strengths	also are factors in the trustees' minds.	12.953867914434229
6585. for this concept of an	advisory board ancillary to the board of trustees we are indebted	to the late president of harvard university a lawrence lowell	a master of the subject of the structure of cultural institutions	and their administration.	11.075051688149248
6586. that we had the wit and wisdom to adopt mr	lowell's concept and make it the base for our processes of selection	is one reason why our selections have been it may be said truly	pretty uniformly good.	11.743190323077632
6587. for in accordance with mr lowell's	concept of an advisory board our selections are made by experienced	selectors who give both constancy and consistency to our processes	and our choices.	9.549348483160792
6588. and lest we should become too consistent in the	sense of becoming heedless of new fields of scholarship and new points	of view in the arts the foundation's board of trustees maintains	a trickle- not a flow!- of new members through the advisory board.	10.140376776070358
6589. two committees of members of the advisory board constitute	the committees of selection- one for the selection of fellows	from canada the united states and the english-speaking caribbean	area and one for the selection of fellows from the latin american	republics and the republic of the philippines.	9.86184859464356
6590. to the members	of our advisory board and most specially to its members who constitute	our committees of selection the foundation is indebted for its	successes of choice of fellows.	10.421433360798918
6591. we are as we know utterly dependent	on the quality of advice we get; and quality of advice added to	devotion to the foundation's purposes and ideals we do get from	our advisory board in measures so full that they can be appreciated	only by those of us who work here every day.	10.295624666042489
6592. but the facts about	our advisory board and its members' duties are only one of several	sets of facts about the quest for advice both reliable and imaginative	on which to base our selections of fellows.	11.251112306494027
6593. for example the	interest of past members of the foundation's advisory board remains	such that they place their knowledge and judgments at our disposal	much as they had done when they were formally members of that board.	9.094093793828431
6594. and besides there are a large number of scholars artists composers	of music novelists poets essayists choreographers lawyers servants	of government and men of affairs- hundreds indeed- who serve	the foundation well with the advice they give us freely and gratis	out of their experience.	11.247546619711121
6595. to all the foundation gives the kind	of thanks which are more than thanks: to them we are grateful beyond	the possibility of conveying in words how grateful we are.	8.490600739721163
6596. it is a truism of business that no business can be better than	its board of directors and its top management.	15.425044969414909
6597. the same is true of	every foundation.	21.168577419809772
6598. during the biennium reviewed in this report our	board of trustees named able men younger than the rest of us to the	board and to top management to insure future continuance of the first-class	administration of the foundation's affairs:   dr	james brown fisk physicist president of the bell telephone laboratories	was elected to the board of trustees.	11.575833744012263
6599. he is a member	both of the national academy of sciences and of the american philosophical	society; and he has served our country well as a scientific	statesman on international commissions.	12.636970711815833
6600. dr gordon n	ray provost vice-president and professor of english in the university	of illinois was appointed associate secretary general.	10.188749122868447
6601. the trustees of the foundation appointed dr ray to that position	with the stated expectation that he would succeed the present secretary	general upon the latter's eventual retirement.	8.939964905138517
6602. dr ray is	a fellow of the foundation- appointed thrice to assist his studies	of william makepeace thackeray and of h g wells- and	before his appointment to the foundation's executive staff had been	given our highest scholarly accolade appointment to the advisory board.	8.320524254217032
6603. referring further to the foundation's officers dr	james f mathias for eleven years our discerning colleague as	associate secretary was promoted to be secretary.	8.308506731501172
6604. he is a historian	with the great merit of a historian's long view.	17.7129700558099
6605. also appointed	to the foundation's staff as assistant secretary is mr	j kellum smith jr.	9.557776961493426
6606. mr smith like the present secretary	general is a lawyer; and lawyers- with the great virtues	that they are trained to read the fine print carefully and are	able out of professional experience to arrive at imaginative solutions	to difficult problems in many fields- are indispensable even in a foundation	office.	9.124083815723493
6607. the present secretary general has been the	foundation's principal administrative officer continuously since the	foundation's establishment thirty-five years ago.	9.862715469176807
6608. but even he will	not last indefinitely and the above-noted new arrangements are quite	simply made to assure qualitative continuity in the foundation's	policies and practices.	11.120736351476541
6609. the effective recognition of excellence and	its nurture has to be learned and is not learned in a day nor even	in a year.	10.710501671803797
6610. we are not given to lamentations neither personally	nor in these reports.	19.421987438886447
6611. on the contrary if this be an apocalyptic	era as is commonly said we see it as an era of opportunity.	13.050635763265506
6612. for	granting that there are great present-day problems to be solved these	problems make great demands; and by their demanding tend to create	resources of men's minds and hearts which problems with easy answers	do not bring forth.	8.671127844238192
6613. of this examples are legion: pericles speaking	his funeral oration in ancient greece's extremity after thermopylae	and making it a testament of freedom; jefferson writing the	declaration of independence amid the catastrophes of revolution;	christ preaching the sermon on the mount close to his ultimate sacrifice;	shakespeare speaking with the indescribable gusto of the	elizabethan voice- keats's words- in the days of the spanish	armada's threats; isaac newton at the age of twenty-three	industriously calculating logarithms to two and fifty places during	the great plague year in england 1665; winston churchill's	olympian optimistic and resolute sayings when britain stood alone	against the armed forces of tyranny less than twenty years ago; the	present-day explorations of outer space answering age-old questions	of science and philosophy in the face of possible wars of extinction.	7.874787023876288
6614. forsan et haec olim meminisse iuvabit as the roman poet	virgil declared with much more historical sense than most writers	of today.	9.159936216703418
6615. it gives indeed cause for rejoicing to remember what many	catastrophes of the past produced; and it is to be noted also that	confidence should grow from remembering that great men often appeared	in the past to turn local catastrophe into future good for all mankind.	9.609707845223838
6616. for example out of the social evils of the english industrial	revolution came the novels of charles dickens; and his genius	moved his readers to seek solutions of those evils for all western men-	until today- in the industrialized west these social evils	substantially do not exist.	10.15291995380078
6617. the solutions were not arrived at by any	theoreticians of the karl marx stripe but by men of government- lawyers	most of them- and men of business.	8.359991737733168
6618. these were educated men	who as mr justice holmes was fond of saying formed their inductions	out of experience under the burden of responsibility.	10.504187999104893
6619. that is	to put it realistically they had to run their businesses at a profit	or they had to get the votes to get elected.	10.023415787128986
6620. nevertheless they made	naught of marx's prophecy that capitalism would never pay the workers-	to use marx's word- more than a subsistence wage with	the consequence that increased productivity must inevitably find its	way into the capitalists' pockets with the result in turn that the	gap between the rich and the poor would irrevocably widen and the misery	of the poor increase.	8.614574151534347
6621. but as all understand who have eyes	to see nothing of the kind has happened; indeed the contrary has	happened.	11.876074675428354
6622. the gulf between the rich and the poor has narrowed	in the industrialized western world to the point that the word	poor is hardly applicable.	11.43780070793399
6623. and the reason this could happen is	clear: men of government business men lawyers and all who concerned	themselves with the welfare of their fellow men did not let their	concern to run their businesses at a profit restrict the development of	freedom and opportunity.	8.729079799651423
6624. some would say that they were not permitted	to run their businesses only for profit; and even putting it that	way would not prove that marx was anything but wrong.	10.696305438763272
6625. sir henry	sumner maine a hundred years before communism was a force to be	reckoned with wrote his brilliant legal generalization that the	progress of society is from status to contract.	8.152056347706267
6626. the essence of contract	is that one is free to make a choice of what one will or will not	do.	13.645408673629904
6627. hence the condition of freedom is a necessary condition for choice.	12.490219319538266
6628. the greater the range of freedom for individual men the greater	the range of choice; the greater the range of choice the greater	the rate of change.	12.11117703556191
6629. for change is dependent on the possibilities that	individual men glimpse for the future.	12.716147131389784
6630. but when there is not freedom	and opportunity to choose men- individual men- must remain in status	and society does not cannot progress.	13.10279699675769
6631. the eternal truth	is that progress- due as it always is to individual creative genius-	is just as dependent on freedom as human life is dependent on the	beating of the heart.	8.072426973448911
6632. and lest anybody think that considerations	such as these are not germane in a foundation report let me enlighten	them with the truths that under communism there would have been	no capital with which to endow the foundation and that there would	not be that individual freedom within which the fellows might proceed	untrammeled in every way toward their discoveries their creative	efforts for the good of mankind.	9.954020696235105
6633. during the year 1959	we granted 354 fellowships; in 1960 we granted 334.	16.6071571266639
6634. as heretofore	our fellowships are available to assist research in all fields of	knowledge and creative effort in all the arts.	12.279296993448352
6635. we do not favor one field	over another: we think that all inquiry all scholarly and artistic	creation is good- provided only that it contributes to a sense	and understanding of the true ends of life as all first-rate scholarship	and artistic creation does.	9.48985075247035
6636. indeed if pressed we would say what	the late robert henri american painter said to a pupil anything	will do for a subject: it's what you do with it that counts.	9.93652802870721
6637. thus we have no part and want none in current discussions	of the relative importance of science the social studies the humanities	the creative arts.	9.044680852979823
6638. we want no part in such discussions because	we think them largely futile; and we think them largely futile because	for true excellence of accomplishment every scholar and every	artist must cross boundaries of knowledge and boundaries of points of	view.	10.153090345443246
6639. when the brown + sharpe manufacturing company reached its	125th year as a going industrial concern during 1958 it became an almost	unique institution in the mechanical world.	9.461465633075361
6640. with its history	standing astride all but the very beginnings of the industrial revolution	brown + sharpe has become over the years a singular monument	to the mechanical foresight of its founder joseph r brown and	a world-renowned synonym for precision and progress in metalworking technology.	9.636632839289195
6641. joseph r brown grew up in the bustle and enterprise	of new england between 1810 and 1830.	9.430392941896105
6642. he was early exposed to	the mechanical world and in his youth often helped his father david	brown master clock and watchmaker as he plied his trade.	11.149943584214672
6643. at the	age of 17 he became an apprentice machinist at the shop of walcott +	harris in valley falls rhode island and following two or three	other jobs in quick succession after graduation he went into business	for himself in 1831 making lathes and small tools.	7.76534377925249
6644. this enterprise	led to a father-and-son combination beginning in 1833 under the name	d brown + son a business which eventually grew into the modern	corporation we now call brown + sharpe.	9.200619687972655
6645. the years of joseph's	partnership with his father were numbered.	15.746249834817961
6646. in 1838 a devastating	fire gutted their small shop and soon thereafter david brown moved	west to illinois settling on a land grant in his declining years.	9.939143676091746
6647. joseph brown continued in business by himself quickly rebuilding	the establishment which had been lost in the fire and beginning those	first steps which were to establish him as a pioneer in raising the	standards of accuracy of machine shop practice throughout the world.	7.732741736410697
6648. much of his genius of course sprang from his familiarity with	clock movements.	15.165781587677479
6649. during these early years the repair of watches and	clocks and the building of special clocks for church steeples formed	an important part of the young man's occupation.	10.3648053924128
6650. he became particularly	interested in graduating and precision measurement during the 1840's	and his thinking along these lines developed considerably during	this period.	10.88941294141472
6651. but his business also grew and we are told that mr	brown found it	increasingly difficult to devote as much time to his	creative thinking as his inclinations led him to desire.	9.40659364799978
6652. it must have	been with some pleasure and relief that on september 12 1848 joseph	brown made the momentous entry in his job book in his characteristically	cryptic style lucian sharpe came to work for me this day	as an apprentice.	10.450607206973826
6653. the young apprentice apparently did well	by mr brown for in the third year of his apprenticeship lucian	was offered a full partnership in the firm; the company became j	r brown + sharpe and entered into a new and important	period of its development.	8.805168422160763
6654. mr sharpe's arrival in the business	did indeed provide what mr brown had most coveted- time for tinkering	and the opportunity of carrying out in the back room those	developments in precision graduation which most interested him at that	time.	9.895102405621952
6655. by 1853 the new partnership announced the precision	vernier caliper as the first fruit of their joint efforts.	9.836452891194703
6656. the basic	significance of this invention helped them to follow it rapidly in 1855	by the development of a unique precision gear cutting and dividing	engine.	11.08406054990517
6657. that development in turn formed the foundation of still more	significant expansions in later years- in gear cutting in circular	graduating in index drilling and in many other fields where accuracy	was a paramount requirement.	7.8894667845432265
6658. throughout their careers both	mr brown and mr sharpe were interested in the problem of setting	up standards of measurement for the mechanical trades.	12.449911227816324
6659. several	efforts were made in this direction and though not all of them survive	to this day the brown + sharpe wire gage system was eventually adopted	as the american standard and is still in common use today.	8.80380372954626
6660. as one development followed another the company's reputation for	precision in the graduating field brought it broader and broader opportunities	for expansion in precision manufacture.	10.160821930547701
6661. in 1858 the partnership	began manufacturing the willcox + gibbs sewing machine.	12.08839462150559
6662. as the story goes mr gibbs who originally came from the back	counties of the commonwealth of virginia saw an illustration in a	magazine of the famous howe sewing machine.	11.237740531795883
6663. curious as to what made	it work he built a crude model of it in wood and filed a piece of steel	until he succeeded in making a metal pickup for the thread enabling	the crude machine to take stitches.	8.239943154124234
6664. when he showed this model as his	solution as to how the howe sewing machine operated he was	told he was wrong and discovered to his amazement that the howe	machine which was unknown to him in detail used two threads while	the one that he had perfected used only one.	10.544721445705257
6665. thus was invented the	single thread sewing machine which mr gibbs in partnership with	mr willcox decided to bring to brown + sharpe with the proposal	that the small company undertake its manufacture.	7.607276063861843
6666. the new work	was a boon to the partnership not only for its own value but particularly	for the stimulation it provided to the imagination of j r	brown toward yet further developments for production equipment.	11.087556851560851
6667. the turret screw machine now known as the brown + sharpe hand	screw machine takes its ancestry directly from mr brown's efforts	to introduce equipment to simplify the manufacture of the sewing	machine.	9.152653344923385
6668. mr brown made important additions to the arts in screw machine	design by drastically improving the means for revolving the turret	by introducing automatic feeding devices for the stock and reversible	tap and die holders.	9.865546657586746
6669. in 1861 mr brown's attention	was called to yet another basic production problem- the manufacture	of twist drills.	10.058592376379565
6670. at that time during the civil war union muskets	were being manufactured in providence and the drills to drill them	were being hand-filed with rattail files.	0.0
6671. this process neither satisfied	the urgent production schedules nor mr brown's imagination	of the possibilities in the situation.	10.051040398458198
6672. the child of this problem was	mr brown's famous serial no 1 universal milling machine	the archtype from which is descended today's universal knee-type	milling machine used throughout the world.	10.120535695754949
6673. the original machine bearing	its famous serial number is still on exhibition at the brown + sharpe	precision center in providence.	9.522921261660029
6674. during the civil war	period mr brown also invented the brown + sharpe formed tooth	gear cutter a basic invention which ultimately revolutionized the world's	gear manufacturing industry by changing its basic economics.	10.478819940522483
6675. up until that time it had been possible to make cutters for making gear	teeth but they were good for only one sharpening.	11.033431375044579
6676. as soon as the	time came for re-sharpening the precise form of the gear tooth was lost	and a new cutter had to be made.	12.439279240351798
6677. this process made the economical	manufacture of gears questionable until some way could be found to permit	the repeated re-sharpening of gear tooth cutters without the loss	of the precision form.	7.921239730935255
6678. mr brown's invention achieved this and	as a byproduct formed the cornerstone of brown + sharpe's position	of leadership in the gear making equipment field which lasted until	the 1920's when superceded by other methods.	8.78929651784104
6679. the micrometer	caliper as a common workshop tool also owes much to j r brown.	10.490169973236336
6680. although mr brown was not himself its inventor	it is typical that his intuition first conceived the importance	of mass producing this basic tool for general use.	9.582871675199902
6681. so it was	that when mr brown and mr sharpe first saw the french tool	on exhibition in paris in 1868 they brought a sample with them to the	united states and started brown + sharpe in yet another field where	it retains its leadership to this day.	7.6923073885944335
6682. the final achievement	of mr brown's long and interesting mechanical career runs a	close second in importance to his development of the universal milling	machine.	11.148636256668306
6683. that achievement was his creation of the universal grinding	machine which made its appearance in 1876 at the philadelphia centennial	exposition.	9.07564579801177
6684. this machine like its milling counterpart was	the antecedent of a machine-family used to this very day in precision	metalworking shops throughout the world.	10.248186645599432
6685. along with j r brown's	other major developments the universal grinding machine was profoundly	influential in setting the course of brown + sharpe for many	years to come.	9.757349826153904
6686. following mr brown's death there came	forward in the brown + sharpe organization many other men who contributed	greatly to the development of the company.	11.44658609222022
6687. one such man was samuel	darling.	23.051606381223657
6688. as head of the firm darling + swartz mr	darling began by challenging brown + sharpe to its keenest competition	during the 1850's and early 60's.	12.7122635581675
6689. in 1868 however a truce	was called between the companies and the partnership of darling brown	+ sharpe was formed.	9.566762736688997
6690. between that year and the buying out of mr	darling's interest in 1892 a large portion of the company's precision	tool business was carried out under the name of darling brown	+ sharpe and to this day many old precision tools are in use still	bearing that famous trademark.	9.162792673865829
6691. perhaps the outstanding standard	bearer of mr brown's tradition for accuracy was mr oscar	j beale whose mechanical genius closely paralleled that of	mr brown and whose particular forte was the development of the exceedingly	accurate measuring machinery that enabled brown + sharpe	to manufacture gages and therefore its products with an accuracy exceeding	anything then available elsewhere in the world.	7.702498743356058
6692. also important	on the brown + sharpe scene at the turn of the century was	mr richmond viall works superintendent of the company from	1876 to 1910.	13.147290636889343
6693. mr viall possessed remarkable talents for the leadership	and development of men.	10.74730553741912
6694. he was an ardent champion of the brown	+ sharpe apprentice program and personal counselor to countless able	men who first developed their industrial talents with the company.	10.924596016381054
6695. in one sense it can be said that one of the most important brown + sharpe	products over the years has been the men who began work with the	company and subsequently came to places of industrial eminence throughout	the nation and even abroad.	12.341181339329454
6696. commencing with the death of	lucian sharpe in 1899 the name of henry d sharpe was for more	than 50 years closely interwoven with the destiny of the company.	9.574012663971168
6697. during	his presidency the company's physical plant was enormously expanded	and the length and breadth of the brown + sharpe machine tool	line became the greatest in the world.	8.234763109989746
6698. during the early part of this	century the brown + sharpe works in providence were unchallenged	as the largest single manufacturing facility devoted exclusively to	precision machinery and tool manufacture anywhere in the world.	12.226865256473316
6699. during these years the company's product line followed the basic tenets	laid down by mr brown.	12.23648868965027
6700. it expanded from hand screw machines	to automatic screw machines from simple formed-tooth gear cutting machines	to gear hobbing machines and a large contract gear manufacturing	business from rudimentary belt-driven universal milling machines to	a broad line of elaborately controlled knee-type and manufacturing type	milling machines.	9.116328473445664

6720. our research and development program	serving as it does an industry which must compete against low-cost	production throughout the world continues to have primary emphasis	at leesona.	0.0
6721. this program is based on the policy of designing	and building efficient machines which will help produce better textile	values- fabrics whose cost in relation to quality fashion and utility	provide the consumer with better textile products for the money.	9.634534749864875
6722. such policy involves continuing effort to improve on existing	mill equipment in terms of efficiency and versatility.	12.537773030127076

6740. the	uniconer has several outstanding features- it operates with much	greater efficiency than existing equipment; it incorporates an automatic	knot-tying device on each spindle and it will knot a break in	the yarn in 10 seconds as well as tie in new bobbins as the running end	is exhausted.	8.49529490330463

6792. the basic market for textiles is growing with the expansion of	the population that began 20 years ago.	12.02693549509071

6794. as in many other	industries rising costs and intense competition both domestic and	foreign have exerted increasing pressure on earnings of the textile industry	in recent years.	11.725119078938283
6795. in textiles as elsewhere	a major part of the solution lies in greater efficiency and	higher productivity.	13.601124686558515
6796. as a designer and manufacturer of textile	production machinery leesona and other companies in its industry have	sought to meet this challenge with new or improved equipment and methods	that would increase production yet maintain both quality and flexibility.	9.40077983457555
6797. the problem of efficient	production in textiles is complicated by the fact that the industry serves	large markets which shift quickly with changes of fashion in apparel	or home decoration.	11.073416458244264
6798. production must be adjusted accordingly at	minimum cost and quickly.	11.793662721363662

7058. it has recently become practical to use the	radio emission of the moon and planets as a new source of information	about these bodies and their atmospheres.	12.744952019855319
