7070. in spite of this the very large radio reflectors and	improved amplifying techniques which are now becoming available should	make it possible to observe the radio emission of most of the planets	in a few years.	12.10963773578497
7071. the study of the radio emission of the moon	and planets began with the detection of the thermal radiation of the moon	at 1.	12.596287178507753
7072. 25-cm wave length by dicke and beringer.	13.037321475654965
7073. this was	followed by a comprehensive series of observations of the 1.	11.28868602154132
7074. 25-cm	emission of the moon over three lunar cycles by piddington and minnett	.	11.597841447637746
7075. they deduced from their measurements that the radio emission	from the whole disk of the moon varied during a lunation in a roughly	sinusoidal fashion; that the amplitude of the variation was considerably	less than the amplitude of the variation in the infrared emission	as measured by pettit and nicholson;	and that the maximum of the radio emission came about 3-12 days after	full	moon which is again in contrast to the infrared emission which reaches	its maximum at full moon.	7.213373089591529
7076. piddington and minnett explained	their observations by pointing out that rocklike materials which are likely	to make up the surface of the moon would be partially transparent	to radio waves although opaque to infrared radiation.	10.928964628505279
7077. the infrared	emission could then be assumed to originate at the surface of the moon	while the radio emission originates at some depth beneath the surface	where the temperature variation due to solar radiation is reduced	in amplitude and shifted in phase.	8.163758222309843
7078. since the absorption of radio waves	in rocklike material varies with wave length it should be possible	to sample the temperature variation at different depths beneath the surface	and possibly detect changes in the structure or composition of the	lunar surface material.	9.5191942547028
7079. the radio emission of a planet was	first detected in 1955 when burke and franklin identified the	origin of interference-like radio noise on their records at about 15	meters wave length as emission from jupiter.	7.98423808682447
7080. this sporadic type of	planetary radiation is discussed by burke and gallet	.	13.236737574390107
7081. steady radiation which was presumably of thermal origin was	observed from venus at 3.	8.834168570742513
7082. 4 cm and from mars and jupiter	at 3.	14.19670681060324
7083. 15 cm in 1956	and from saturn at 3.	10.860837018830757
7084. 75 cm in 1957	.	17.434561775113806
7085. in the relatively short time since these early observations	venus has been observed at additional wave lengths in the range from	0.	10.144875890468164
7086. 2 cm and jupiter has been observed over the wave-length	range from 3.	12.609447510967088
7087. the observable characteristics of	planetary radio radiation are the intensity the polarization and the	direction of arrival of the waves.	8.998955821926716
7088. the maximum angular diameter of	any planetary disk as observed from the earth is about 1 minute of arc.	10.551876137849225
7089. this is much smaller than the highest resolution of even the very	large reflectors now under construction and consequently the radio emission	of different regions of the disk cannot be resolved.	9.562158089400938
7090. it should	be possible however to put useful limits on the diameters of the radio	sources by observing with large reflectors or with interferometers.	11.08299120998455
7091. measurements of polarization are presently limited by apparatus sensitivity	and will remain difficult because of the low intensity of the	planetary radiation at the earth.	8.18182507659557
7092. there have been few measurements specifically	for the determination of the polarization of planetary radiation.	19.177398912897083
7093. the measurements made with the nrl 50-foot reflector	which is altitude-azimuth-mounted would have shown a systematic change	with local hour angle in the measured intensities of venus and jupiter	if a substantial part of the radiation had been linearly polarized.	8.316722027230588
7094. recent interferometer measurements	have shown the 960-mc emission of jupiter to be partially	polarized	and to originate in a region of larger diameter than the visible	disk.	9.781632829737031
7095. other than this very significant result most of the information	now available about the radio emission of the planets is restricted	to the intensity of the radiation.	8.487262251156995
7096. the concept of apparent	black-body temperature is used to describe the radiation received from	the moon and the planets.	15.052873959572166
7097. the received radiation is compared with the	radiation from a hypothetical black body which subtends the same solid	angle as the visible disk of the planet.	8.18901342307388
7098. the apparent black-body	disk temperature is the temperature which must be assumed for the	black body in order that the intensity of its radiation should equal that	of the observed radiation.	10.561191715767016
7099. the use of this concept does not specify	the origin of the radiation and only if the planet really radiates	as a black body will the apparent black-body temperature correspond	to the physical temperature of the emitting material.	8.55628574761116
7100. the radio	radiation of the sun which is reflected from the moon and planets should	be negligible compared with their thermal emission at centimeter	wave lengths except possibly at times of exceptional outbursts of solar	radio noise.	8.99860236604713
7101. the quiescent level of centimeter wave-length solar radiation	would increase the average disk brightness temperature by less	than 1` k.	8.998955821926716
7102. at meter wave lengths and increase of the order of	10` k in the average disk temperatures of the nearer planets would	be expected.	12.170124863118888
7103. therefore neglecting the extreme outbursts reflected	solar radiation is not expected to cause sizable errors in the measurements	of planetary radiation in the centimeter- and decimeter-wave-length	range.	8.988956359708466
7104. radio observations	of the moon have been made over the range of wave lengths from 4.	14.673065557626568

7137. experiments were made on an electric arc applying a porous	graphite anode cooled by a transpiring gas.	8.29272515769823
7138. thus the	energy transferred from the arc to the anode was partly fed back into	the arc.	11.057874562640393
7139. it was shown that by proper anode design the net energy loss	of the arc to the anode could be reduced to approximately 15% of the	total arc energy a detailed energy balance of the anode was established.	9.451939416166258
7140. the anode ablation could be reduced to a negligible amount.	18.132911305128204
7141. the dependence	of the arc voltage upon the mass flow velocity of the transpirating	gas was investigated for various arc lengths and currents between	100 amp and 200 amp.	8.27425730033199
7142. qualitative observations were made and	high-speed motion pictures were taken to study flow phenomena in the	arc at various mass flow velocities.	9.159936216703418
7143. the high heat	fluxes existing at the electrode surfaces of electric arcs necessitate	extensive cooling to prevent electrode ablation.	10.523674005895941
7144. the cooling requirements	are particularly severe at the anode.	15.227221353292695
7145. in free burning electric	arcs for instance approximately 90% of the total arc power is transferred	to the anode giving rise to local heat fluxes in excess of	f as measured by the authors- the exact value depending on the arc	atmosphere.	8.15861915858892
7146. in plasma generators as currently commercially available	for industrial use or as high temperature research tools often more than	50% of the total energy input is being transferred to the co0ling	medium of the anode.	9.843864423210972
7147. the higher heat transfer rates at the anode	compared with those at the cathode can be explained by the physical	phenomena occurring in free burning arcs.	9.576736697071984
7148. in plasma generators the	superimposed forced convection may modify the picture somewhat.	14.174449266743885
7149. the heat	transfer to the anode is due to the following effects: 1.	13.771085206143976
7150. heat	of condensation plus kinetic energy of the electrons impinging	on the anode.	10.957705180640192
7151. this energy transfer depends on the current the	temperature in the arc column the anode material and the conditions	in the anode sheath.	9.739751097545792
7152. heat transfer by molecular conduction as well	as by radiation from the arc column.	10.550898587259717
7153. the heat transfer to	the anode in free burning arcs is enhanced by a hot gas jet flowing from	the cathode towards the anode with velocities up f.	8.197614673473888
7154. this phenomenon	has been experimentally investigated in detail by maecker	.	14.666783238248009
7155. the pressure gradient producing the jet is due to the nature of the	magnetic field in the arc	.	15.399089633120147
7156. hence the flow conditions at the anode of free	burning arcs resemble those near a stagnation point.	11.791527870581819
7157. it is apparent	from the above and from experimental evidence that the cooling requirements	for the anode of free burning arcs are large compared with	those for the cathode.	10.142795113481844
7158. the gas flow through a plasma generator will modify	these conditions; however the anode is still the part receiving	the largest heat flux.	10.951222191930302
7159. an attempt to improve the life of the anodes	or the efficiency of the plasma generators must therefore aim at	a reduction of the anode loss.	10.27094378511282
7160. the following possibilities exist for	achieving this: 1.	18.43958767319159
7161. the use of high voltages and low currents by proper	design to reduce electron heat transfer to the anode for a given	power output.	9.548243461765395
7162. continuous motion of the arc contact area at the anode	by flow or magnetic forces.	10.23294824414389
7163. feed back of the energy transferred	to the anode by applying gas transpiration through the anode.	10.096308098400353
7164. the third method was to our knowledge successfully applied for the	first time by c sheer and co-workers.	13.972026857148693
7165. the purpose of	the present study is to study the thermal conditions and to establish	an energy balance for a transpiration cooled anode as well as the effect	of blowing on the arc voltage.	9.433384028542411
7166. gas injection through a porous anode	not only feeds back the energy transferred	to the anode by the above mentioned processes but also modifies the conditions	in the arc itself.	8.944329220900824
7167. a detailed study of this latter phenomenon	was not attempted in this paper.	10.30958330947291
7168. argon was used as a blowing gas to	exclude any effects of dissociation or chemical reaction.	12.109129107062502
7169. the anode	material was porous graphite.	16.994033841028205
7170. sintered porous metals should be usable	in principle.	13.037321475654965
7171. however technical difficulties arise by melting at local	hot spots.	12.141374508485978

7238. a band viscometer is shown in figure 2.	18.635873179024852
7239. it consists of two blocks	with flat surfaces held apart by shims.	17.35627838807679
7240. there is a small well in	the top in which the fluid or paste to be tested is placed.	18.382589151011874
7241. a tape	of cellulose acetate is pulled between the blocks and the tape pulls the	fluid or paste with it between the parallel faces of the blocks.	8.243158953099586
7242. in	normal use weights are hung on the end of the tape and allowed to pull	the tape and the material to be tested between the blocks.	11.212205361765832
7243. after it	has reached terminal velocity the time for the tape to travel a known	distance is recorded.	11.631289171578754
7244. by the use of various weights data for a force-rate	of shear graph can be obtained.	14.972497867572779
7245. the instrument used for this	work was a slight modification of that previously described.	10.242653103537407
7246. in	this test a f tape was pulled between the blocks with a motor and	pulley at a rate of f with a clearance of 0.	10.249986732088232
7247. 002'' on each side of	the tape.	15.27570505724882
7248. this gives a rate of shear of f.	23.577851872083787
7249. this however can only	be considered	approximate as the diameter of the pulley was increased by the	build-up of tape and the tape was occasionally removed from the pulley	during the runs.	8.651327976846721
7250. the face of one block contained a hole 116''	in diameter which led to a	manometer for the measurement of the normal pressure.	11.984747810028223
7251. although	there were only four fluids tested it was apparent that there were	two distinct types.	9.367881756719601
7252. two of the fluids showed a high-positive normal pressure	when undergoing shear and two showed small negative pressures	which were negligible in comparison with the amount of the positive pressures	generated by the other two.	11.991686161888168
7253. figure 3 shows the data on	a silicone fluid labeled 12500 cps which gave a high positive normal	pressure.	8.1523940120599
7254. although the tape was run for over 1 hr a steady	state was not reached and it was concluded that the reason for this was	that the back pressure of the manometer was built up from the material	fed from between the blocks and this was available at a very slow	rate.	10.77230966276907
7255. a system had to be used which did not depend upon the feeding of	the fluid into the manometer if measurements of the normal pressure	were to be made in a reasonable time.	11.233265297118443
7256. a back pressure was then introduced	and the rise or fall of the material in the manometer indicated	which was greater the normal pressure in the block or the back pressure.	11.070810315764804
7257. by this method it was determined that the normal pressure exerted	by a sample of polybutene was	over half an atmosphere.	10.754459671001449
7258. the actual pressure was not determined because	the pressure was beyond the upper limit of the apparatus on hand.	10.744351510671057
7259. the two fluids which gave the small negative pressures were polybutenes	with molecular weights which were stated to be 520 and 300.	9.0221396376245
7260. these are fluids which one would expect to be less viscoelastic or more	newtonian because of their lower molecular weight.	12.752577480597076
7261. the maximum suction	was 3.	19.440309286487764

7263. it is presumed	that this negative head was associated with some geometric factor	of the assembly since different readings were obtained with the same	fluid and the only apparent difference was the assembly and disassembly	of the apparatus.	9.9431060332894
7264. this negative pressure is not explained by the	velocity head f since this is not sufficient to explain the readings	by several magnitudes.	11.974578365374883
7265. these experiments can be considered	exploratory only.	14.095951777047294
7266. however they do demonstrate the presence of large	normal pressures in the presence of flat shear fields which were forecast	by the theory in the first part of the paper.	12.820272416174024
7267. they also give information	which will aid in the design of a more satisfactory instrument	for the measurement of the normal pressures.	13.54207268830873
7268. such an instrument would	be useful for the characterization of many commercial materials as well	as theoretical studies.	11.906931238058396
7269. the elasticity as a parameter of fluids	which	is not subject to simple measurement at present and it is a parameter	which is probably varying in an unknown manner with many commercial	materials.	9.198850262501198
7270. such an instrument is expected to be especially useful	if it could be used to measure the elasticity of heavy pastes such as	printing inks paints adhesives molten plastics and bread dough for	the elasticity is related to those various properties termed length	shortness spinnability etc which are usually judged	by subjective methods at present.	11.15212060460836
7271. the actual change f	caused by a shear field is calculated by multiplying the pressure differential	times the volume just as it is for any gravitational or osmotic	pressure head.	10.453417457247811
7272. if the volume is the molal volume then f is obtained	on a molal basis which is the customary terminology of the chemists.	12.591667943744202
7273. although the f calculation is obvious by analogy with that	for gravitational field and osmotic pressure it is interesting to confirm	it by a method which can be generalized to include related effects.	8.675835649138152
7274. consider a shear field with a height of h and a cross-sectional	area of a opposed by a manometer with a height of h	and a cross-sectional area	of a.	9.380711003487045

7467. chemistry of washing	although there is no question	but that the process of washing fabrics involves a number of phenomena	which are related together in an extremely complicated way and that	these phenomena and their interrelations are not well understood at the	present this section attempts to present briefly an up-to-date picture	of the physical chemistry of washing either fabrics or hard surfaces.	7.404339574899309
7468. the purpose of washing is obviously to remove soils which are arbitrarily	classed in the four major categories given below:	dirt which is here defined as particulate material which is usually	inorganic and is very often extremely finely divided so as to exhibit	colloidal properties.	9.583224589561302
7469. greasy soils which are typified by	hydrocarbons and fats.	10.530932308755343
7470. stains which include the wide variety of nonparticulate	materials which give color even when present in very low concentration	on the soiled object.	10.06418306575053
7471. miscellaneous soils which primarily	include sticky substances and colorless liquids which evaporate to leave	a residue.	8.62963042412541
7472. the dirt on the soiled objects is mechanically	held by surface irregularities to some extent.	11.636095537390238
7473. however a major factor	in binding dirt is the attraction between surfaces that goes under	the name of van der waal's forces.	8.650471366243508
7474. this is a theoretically complicated	dipole interaction which causes any extremely small uncharged particle	to agglomerate with other small uncharged particles or to stick	to an uncharged surface.	11.747058638310094
7475. obviously if colloidal particles bear charges	of opposite sign or if one kind is charged and the other kind is	not the attraction will be intensified and the tendency to agglomerate	will be greatly reinforced.	8.04768341219779
7476. likewise a charged particle will tend	to stick to an uncharged surface and vice versa and a charged particle	will be very strongly attracted to a surface exhibiting an opposite	charge.	8.877257962845048
7477. in addition dirt particles can be held onto a soiled surface	by sticky substances or by the surface tension of liquids including	liquid greases.	9.927809287838631
7478. greases stains and miscellaneous soils	are usually sorbed onto the soiled surface.	10.957705180640192
7479. in most cases these soils	are taken up as liquids through capillary action.	13.718019134696515
7480. in an essentially	static system an oil cannot be replaced by water on a surface unless	the interfacial tensions of the water phase are reduced by a surface-active	agent.	11.315919095932841
7481. the washing process whereby soils are removed consists	basically of applying mechanical action to loosen the dirt particles	and dried matter in the presence of water which helps to float off	the debris and acts to some extent as a dissolving and solvating	agent.	7.9548766281895205
7482. greasy soils are hardly removed by washing in plain water;	and	natural waters in addition often contain impurities such as calcium	salts which can react with soils to make them more difficult to remove.	8.801760919635912
7483. the detergent active is that substance	which primarily acts to remove greasy soils.	10.61385277229228
7484. the other constituents	in a built detergent assist in this and in the removal of dirty stains	and the hydrophilic sticky or dried soils.	12.293451215129286
7485. as is well known	detergent actives belong to the chemical class consisting of moderately	high molecular weight and highly polar molecules which exhibit the	property of forming micelles in solution.	8.759286319902372
7486. physicochemical investigations	of anionic surfactants including the soaps have shown that there	is little polymerization or agglomeration of the chain anions below	a certain region of concentration called the critical micelle concentration.	8.67961849226925
7487. below the critical micelle concentration monomers and some	dimers are present.	11.384626257889217
7488. in the critical micelle region there is	a rapid agglomeration or polymerization to give the micelles which have	a degree of polymerization averaging around 60-80.	12.0129040801555
7489. for anionics	these micelles appear to be roughly spherical assemblages in which	the hydrocarbon tails come together so that the polar groups	face outward towards the aqueous continuous phase.	9.282293058334462
7490. obviously	hydrophobic	substances such as greases oils or particles having	a greasy or oily surface are more at home in the center of a micelle	than in the aqueous phase.	12.99056785477373
7491. micelles can imbibe and hold a considerable	amount of oleophilic substances so that the micelle volume may be	increased as much as approximately two-fold.	8.868940334070393
7492. although the matter has	not been unequivocally demonstrated the available data show that micelles	in themselves do not contribute significantly to the detergency process.	10.459184728109657
7493. related to micelle formation is the technologically important	ability of detergent actives to congregate at oil-water interfaces	in such a manner that the polar end of the molecule is directed	towards the aqueous phase and the hydrocarbon chain towards the	oily phase.	7.657284361601814
7494. in the cleaning process sorbed greasy soils become coated	in this manner with an oriented film of surfactant.	12.88628409926433
7495. then during washing	the greasy soil rolls back at the edges so that emulsified droplets	can disengage themselves from the sorbed oil mass with the aid of	mechanical action and enter the aqueous phase.	8.766228733348418
7496. obviously a substance	which is permanently or temporarily sorbed on the surface in place of	the soil will tend to accelerate this process and effectively push off	the greasy soil.	9.190725948301429
7497. substances other than detergent actives also	tend to be strongly sorbed from aqueous media onto surfaces of other	contiguous condensed phases.	7.9139724503302755
7498. this is particularly true of highly charged	ions especially those ions which fall into the class of polyelectrolytes.	18.093766510194094
7499. whereas the usual organic surface-active agent is strongly	sorbed at oil-water interfaces the highly charged ions are most strongly	sorbed at interfaces between water and insoluble materials exhibiting	an ionic structure.	7.69669906756698
7500. thus for aqueous	media we can think of the idealized organic active as an oleophilic	or hydrophobic surface-active agent and of an idealized builder as	a oleophobic or hydrophilic surface-active agent.	10.76134079109159
7501. from the equilibrium	sorption data which are available it seems logical to expect	that polyphosphate ions would be strongly sorbed on the surface of	the dirt so as to give it a greatly increased	negative charge.	10.85845971070765
7502. the charged particles then repel each other and are	also repelled from the charged surface which almost invariably bears	a negative charge under washing conditions.	10.28790619381961
7503. the negatively charged dirt	particles then leave the surface and go into the aqueous phase.	10.157971055885024
7504. this	hypothesis is evolved in analogy to the demonstrated action of organic	actives in detergency.	10.94268621302811
7505. it does not consider the kinetic effects	of the phosphate builders on sorption-desorption phenomena which will	be discussed later.	13.006423405750578
7506. the crude picture of	the detergency process thus far developed can be represented as: f	the influence of mechanical action on the particles of free soil may	be compared to that of kinetic energy on a molecular scale.	9.61775181549428
7507. freed soil	must be dispersed and protected against flocculation.	10.530932308755343
7508. cleaned cloth	must be protected against the redeposition of dispersed soil.	11.33819267263277
7509. it is	evident that the requirements imposed by these effects upon any one	detergent constituent acting alone are severe.	10.511513581761168
7510. upon consideration	of the variety of soils and fabrics normally encountered in the washing	process it is little wonder that the use of a number of detergent	constituents having synergistic properties has gained widespread	acceptance.	11.246203135657286
7511. in the over-all process it is difficult to assign a	pure role to each constituent of a built-detergent formulation;	and indeed there is no more reason to separate the interrelated roles	of the active builder antiredeposition agent etc than there	is to assign individual actions to each of the numerous isomers making	up a given commercial organic active.	8.573689240405079
7512. the thermal exchange of chlorine between f and liquid f is	readily measurable at temperatures in the range of 180` and above.	11.257371233191828
7513. the	photochemical exchange occurs with a quantum yield of the order of	unity in the liquid phase at 65` using light absorbed only by the f.	9.226348002797831
7514. in the gas phase with f of f and f of f quantum yields	of the	order of f have been observed at 85`.	11.898021903107828
7515. despite extensive attempts	to obtain highly pure reagents serious difficulty was experienced in	obtaining reproducible rates of reaction.	9.170114922632786
7516. it appears possible to set	a lower limit of about f for the activation energy of the abstraction	of a chlorine atom from a carbon tetrachloride molecule by a chlorine	atom to form f radical.	9.830894265792951
7517. the rate of the gas phase exchange reaction	appears to be proportional to the first power of the absorbed light	intensity indicating that the radical intermediates are removed at	the walls or by reaction with an impurity rather than by bimolecular	radical combination reactions.	8.749689595510578
7518. because of the simplicity	of the molecules isotopic exchange reactions between elemental	halogens and the corresponding carbon tetrahalides would appear to offer	particularly fruitful possibilities for obtaining unambiguous basic	kinetic data.	11.943151313391144
7519. it would appear that it should be possible to determine	unique mechanisms for the thermal and photochemical reactions in both	the liquid and gas phases and to determine values for activation energies	of some of the intermediate reactions of atoms and free radicals	as well as information on the heat of dissociation of the carbon-halogen	bond.	9.152731898730075
7520. the reaction of chlorine with carbon tetrachloride seemed	particularly suited for such studies.	14.398846034872733
7521. it should be possible to prepare	very pure chlorine by oxidation of inorganic chlorides on a vacuum	system followed by multiple distillation of the liquid.	11.625013049622803
7522. it should be	possible to free carbon tetrachloride of any interfering substances by	the usual purification methods followed by prechlorination prior to	addition of radioactive chlorine.	12.311052817791758
7523. furthermore the exchange would not	be expected to be sensitive to trace amounts of impurities because it	would not be apt to be a chain reaction since the activation energy for	abstraction of chlorine by a chlorine atom would be expected to be	too high; also it would be expected that f would compete very effectively	with any impurities as a scavenger for f radicals.	7.641103479500217
7524. contrary	to these expectations we have found it impossible to obtain the degree	of reproducibility one would wish even with extensive efforts to prepare	especially pure reagents.	8.979646662218858
7525. we are reporting these investigations	here briefly because of their relevancy to problems of the study of apparently	simple exchange reactions of chlorine and because the results	furnish some information on the activation energy for abstraction of	chlorine atoms from carbon tetrachloride.	8.910437715208882

7585. the poynting-robertson effect	which is a retardation of the orbital motion of particles	by the relativistic aberration of the repulsive force of the impinging	solar radiation causes the dust to spiral into the sun in times much	shorter than the age of the earth.	7.619548827671368
7586. the radial velocity varies inversely	as the particle size- a 1000-|m-diameter particle near the	orbit of mars would reach the sun in about 60 million years.	10.095713654014379
7587. whipple	extends the effects to include the solar-corpuscular-radiation	pressure which increases both the minimum particle size and the drag.	8.489296170455487
7588. further the corpuscular radiation ie the solar-wind protons	must sputter away the surface atoms of the dust and cause a slow	diminution in size with a resultant increase in both the poynting-robertson	effect and the ratio of the repulsive force to the gravitational	force.	8.909545720156059
7589. the poynting-robertson effect causes the semi-major	axis of orbits to diminish more rapidly than the semi-minor axis	with a consequent tendency toward circular orbits as the particles move	toward the sun.	7.842562774759641
7590. also planetary gravitational attraction increases	the dust concentration near the plane of the ecliptic as the sun is	approached.	11.80928840443105
7591. at one astronomical unit from the sun	the dust orbits are probably nearly circular.	13.262619217504918
7592. if such is the case	the particles within a distance of about f km of the earth	will	have relative to the earth a kinetic energy less than their potential	energy and they will be captured into orbits about the earth.	10.80460466684659
7593. de	jager has calculated the times required for these particles	to reach the atmosphere under the influence of the poynting-robertson	effect which in this case causes the orbits to become more and more	eccentric	without changing the semi-major axis.	8.440801552716241
7594. this effect can give rise to	a blanket of micrometeorites around the earth.	12.696409780395436
7595. since there is	a continual loss of micrometeoritic material in space because of the	radiation effects there must be a continual replenishment: otherwise	micrometeorites would have disappeared from interplanetary space.	9.107855191980358
7596. there	are several possible sources.	18.969942067020153
7597. according to whipple cometary	debris is sufficient to replenish the material spiraling into the	sun maintaining a fairly steady state.	10.526441708826486
7598. asteroidal collisions are also	thought to contribute material.	13.037321475654965
7599. it is also possible that some of	the dust in the vicinity of the earth originated from meteoritic impacts	upon the moon.	17.397991170956
7600. one cannot make a very satisfactory guess about the micrometeorite	flux in space.	14.138958740472301
7601. even in the neighborhood of the earth where information	has been obtained both directly and indirectly the derived flux	values vary by at least four orders of magnitude.	12.511225063413253
7602. this large discrepancy	demonstrates the inadequacies of the experimental methods and the	lack of understanding of the various phenomena involved.	12.380444581336214
7603. beyond a	few million kilometers from the earth but still in the region of the	earth's orbit a prediction of the flux of dust is even more unreliable.	9.133778889202572
7604. at greater distances from the sun the situation is still less	certain.	16.45768016552597
7605. there are several sources of evidence on the micrometeorite	environment.	18.8521949047822

7607. in addition the size	distribution obtained from visual and radar observations of meteors may	be extrapolated to the micrometeorite domain.	11.844575242639491
7608. from the brightness of	the f component of the solar corona and the brightness of the zodiacal	light an estimate of the particle sizes concentrations and spatial	distribution can be derived for regions of space near the ecliptic	plane.	10.250058571776036
7609. another important source of evidence only recently receiving	much attention is the analysis of atmospheric dust for a meteoritic	component.	8.43828865832834
7610. the cores of deep-sea sediments and content of collectors	in remote regions are valuable in this category.	11.026675696446196
7611. the data provide a	measure of the total mass of cosmic material incident upon the earth.	10.374937985916516
7612. the direct evidence on the micrometeorite environment near the	earth is	obtained from piezoelectric sensors	and from wire gages; these instruments are installed on rockets satellites	and space probes.	9.488339800308188
7613. statistically the most significant data have	been collected from the sensors on 1958 alpha	1958 delta 2.	8.555377644495325
7614. these	vehicles with large sensitive areas have collected data for long enough	times to give reliable impact rates for the periods of exposure.	9.051154372622117
7615. many other vehicles with smaller sensitive-area exposure-time products	contribute some information.	11.93359137447661

7617. the data show daily and diurnal	variations.	15.260583014183545

7641. the threshold	mass of about f corresponds to a 10-|m-diameter sphere of	density f.	10.61385277229228

7646. the diurnal variation in the observed flux	may be partly due to the dependence of the detector sensitivity on the	incident velocity.	11.028588892868669
7647. the flux of micrometeorites in the neighborhood	of the earth can be estimated by extrapolation from radar and	visual meteor data.	9.025768581614551
7648. a summary of meteorite data prepared by whipple	on the basis of photographic visual and radar evidence	is given in table 5-1.	10.922772903777382
7649. from an estimated mass of 25 g for a	zero-magnitude meteorite the other masses are derived with the assumption	of a mass decrease by a factor of 2.	8.449815832267134
7650. 512 for each unit increase in	magnitude.	13.915190642667962
7651. the radius is calculated from the mass by assuming spheres	of density f except for the smallest particles which must have a	higher mass density to remain in the solar system in the presence of	solar-radiation pressure.	9.208374757430414
7652. the flux values are for all particles with	masses greater than the given mass and are based on an estimate of the	numbers of visual meteors.	10.521269240431813
7653. it is assumed that the flux values increase	by a factor of 2.	18.022828241229305
7654. 512 per magnitude in accordance with the opinion	that the total mass flux in each unit range in magnitude is constant.	10.234601587964507
7655. the values agree with the data from 1958 alpha and 1959 eta.	11.110131585198689
7656. the figures	in the next-to-last column are derived with the assumption of 50	per cent shielding by the earth; hence these figures apply immediately	above the earth's atmosphere.	9.488339800308188
7657. the unshielded flux is given	in the last column; these figures constitute the best estimate for the	flux in interplanetary space near the earth.	8.409778452916047
7658. of course if there	is a dust blanket around the earth the fluxes in interplanetary space	should be less than the figures given here.	13.242520286389306
7659. note that the mass	scale is one to two orders of magnitude greater than some previously	used; for example jacchia derived a scale of 0.	8.878766917997735
7660. 15 g for	a f zero-magnitude meteorite.	14.439924787463871
7661. the older scales were based on theoretical	estimates of the conversion efficiency of kinetic energy into	light.	9.97313087631216
7662. the mass scale used in table 5-1 was derived on the assumption	that the motion of the glowing trail is related to the momentum	transfer to the trail by the meteorite permitting the calculation of	the mass if the velocity is known.	9.12015798582493
7663. a concentration distribution has been derived from radar observations	sensitive to the fifteenth magnitude.	9.966061740790925
7664. extrapolation of this relationship through the thirtieth magnitude covers	the range of micrometeorites.	10.635267499930531

7669. the extrapolation may be in error for	several reasons.	15.70353153522731
7670. the observational data determining the concentration	distribution have a range of error which is magnified in the extension	into the micrometeorite region.	10.552736946158015
7671. the solar-electromagnetic- and	corpuscular-radiation	pressure and the associated poynting-robertson effect	increase in effectiveness as the particle size decreases and modify	the distribution and limit sizes to larger than a few microns.	8.138215495683314
7672. also	it has been suggested that the source of all or part of the dust may	not be the same as that for visual or radar meteorites	and the same distribution would not be expected.	11.863369686035151
7673. of micrometeorite flux	a measure of the total mass accretion	of meteoritic material by the earth is obtained from analyses of	deep-sea sediments and dust collected in remote regions	.	8.6965454070931
7674. most meteoritic material by the time it reaches the earth's	surface has been reduced to dust or to spherules of ablated material	in its passage through the atmosphere.	11.357879883540681
7675. for all meteorites the average	nickel content is about 2.	14.969097324807317
7676. this is much higher than the	nickel content of terrestrial dusts and sediments and provides a basis	for the determination of the meteoritic mass influx.	12.396211040527273

7678. biological warfare is the intentional use of	living microorganisms or their toxic products for the purpose of destroying	or reducing the military effectiveness of man.	9.878197341912797
7679. it is the exploitation	of the inherent potential of infectious disease agents by scientific	research and development resulting in the production of bw	weapons systems.	12.804536574791952
7680. man may also be injured secondarily by damage to	his food crops or domestic animals.	13.25433223931114
7681. biological warfare is considered	to be primarily a strategic weapon.	10.057988591011652
7682. the major reason for this	is that it has no quick-kill effect.	17.285116122372166
7683. the incubation period of infectious	disease plus a variable period of illness even before a lethal effect	render this weapon unsuitable for hand-to-hand encounter.	8.409778452916047
7684. a man	can be an effective fighting machine throughout the incubation period	of most infectious diseases.	11.339107725659472
7685. thus an enemy would probably use this weapon	for attack on static population centers such as large cities.	9.399299589835328
7686. an important operational procedure in bw for an enemy would	be to create an areosol or cloud of agent over the target area.	9.519639727796076
7687. this	concept has stimulated much basic research concerning the behavior of	particulate biological materials the pathogenesis of respiratory infections	the medical management of such diseases and defense against their	occurrence.	7.358893154931528
7688. the biological and physical properties of infectious	particles have been studied intensively during the past fifteen	years.	12.605919892000712
7689. much new equipment and many unique techniques have been developed	for the quantitative exposure of experimental animals to aerosols	of infectious agents contained in particles of specified dimensional	characteristics.	7.977690681124178
7690. much information has been gathered relative to quantitative	sampling and assesment techniques.	12.878017281082306
7691. much of the older experimental	work on respiratory infections was accomplished by very artificial	procedures.	15.796891661003519
7692. the intranasal instillation of a fluid suspension of infectious	agent in an anesthetized animal is far different from exposure	through natural respiration to aerosolized organisms.	9.725942325839862
7693. the	importance of particle size in such aerosols has been thoroughly demonstrated.	9.528667773037851
7694. the natural anatomical and physiological defensive features	of the upper respiratory tract such as the turbinates of the nose and	the cilia of the trachea and larger bronchi are capable of impinging	out the larger particles to which we are ordinarily exposed in our daily	existence.	9.617278231652884
7695. very small particles however in a size range of 1 to	4 microns in diameter are capable of passing these impinging barriers	and entering the alveolar bed of the lungs.	7.816023603538525
7696. this area is highly susceptible	to infection.	18.474861091230572
7697. the entrance and retention of infectious particles	in the alveoli amounts almost to an intratissue inoculation.	11.5768921603531
7698. the	relationship between particle size and infectious dose is illustrated	in table 1.	10.957705180640192
7699. in considering bw defense it must be recognized	that a number of critical meterological parameters must be met for	an aerosol to exhibit optimum effect.	9.99023649078237
7700. for example bright sunlight	is rapidly destructive for living microorganisms suspended in air.	15.485394254321793
7701. there	are optimal humidity requirements for various agents when airborne.	10.900188788523568
7702. neutral or inversion meteorological conditions are necessary for a	cloud to travel along the surface.	10.63218492720835
7703. it will rise during lapse conditions.	26.45803100104439
7704. there are of course certain times during the 24-hour daily cycle	when most of these conditions will be met.	15.805057507923273
7705. certain other properties	of small particles in addition to those already mentioned in	connection with penetration of the respiratory tract are noteworthy	in defense considerations.	9.086003269368616
7706. the smaller the particle the further it will	travel downwind before settling out.	12.445450562798397
7707. an aerosol of such small particles.	13.924735272543572
7708. moreover diffuses through structures in much the same manner as	a gas.	20.738805175618904
7709. there may be a number of secondary effects resulting from diffusion	through buildings such as widespread contamination of kitchens	restaurants food stores hospitals etc.	12.258648180472937
7710. depending on the organism	there may be multiplication in some food or beverage products ie	in milk for example.	10.547945318673932
7711. the secondary consequences from this could	be very serious and must be taken into consideration in planning for	defense.	14.338101317261026
7712. something of the behavior of clouds of small particles	can be illustrated by the following field trials:   in the	first trial an inert substance was disseminated from a boat travelling	some ten miles off shore under appropriately selected meteorological	conditions.	9.453893945641962
7713. zinc cadmium sulfide in particles of 2 microns in size were	disseminated.	9.345058977386529
7714. this material fluoresces under ultraviolet light which	facilitates its sampling and assessment.	13.236737574390107
7715. four hundred and fifty pounds	was disseminated while the ship was traveling a distance of 156	miles.	10.65637107945682
7716. figure 1 describes the results obtained in this trial.	11.793662721363662
7717. the particles traveled a maximum detected distance of some 450 miles.	11.050834287616778
7718. from these dosage isopleths it can be seen that an area of over 34000	square miles was covered.	14.434639754256331
7719. these dosages could have been increased	by increasing the source strength which was small in this case.	9.720789525590934
7720. the behavior of a biological aerosol on a much smaller scale is illustrated	by a specific field trial conducted with a non-pathogenic organism.	10.330612848793074
7721. an aqueous suspension of the spores of b subtilis var	niger generally known as bacillus globigii was aerosolized	using commercially available nozzles.	8.706102967351535
7722. a satisfactory cloud was produced	even though these nozzles were only about 5 per cent efficient in	producing an initial cloud in the size range of 1 to 5 microns.	10.972548037353597
7723. in this	test 130 gallons of a suspension having a count of f organisms	per ml or a total of approximately f spores was aerosolized.	9.322660983633986
7724. the	spraying operation was conducted from the rear deck of a small naval	vessel cruising two miles off-shore and vertical to an on-sure breeze.	9.376668190559428
7725. spraying continued along a two-mile course.	11.867291106449708
7726. this operation	was started at 5:00 pm and lasted for 29 minutes.	13.236737574390107
7727. there was	a slight lapse condition a moderate fog and 100 per cent relative	humidity.	13.593870648562953
7728. a network of sampling stations had been set up on shore.	15.395477400205008
7729. these	were located at the homes of government employees in government	offices buildings and reservations within the trial area.	8.1523940120599
7730. a rough	attempt was made to characterize the vertical profile of the cloud by	taking samples from outside the windows on the first ninth and fifteenth	floors of a government office building.	11.118226796951603
7731. all samplers were	operated for a period of two hours except one which was operated	for four hours.	11.776955636074408
7732. in this instance there was a dosage of 562 during the	first two hours and a total dosage of 1980 for the four-hour period	a four-fold increase.	11.806182882212001
7733. this suggests that the sampling period particularly	at the more distant locations should have been increased.	10.591869705701038
7734. as can be seen from figure 2 an extensive area was covered by this	aerosol.	15.964626374702071
7735. the maximum distance sampled was 23 miles from the source.	11.572314230763848

7737. it is quite likely that	an even greater area was covered particularly downwind.	17.507815094431344

7739. a number of unique medical	problems might be created when man is exposed to an infectious	agent through the respiratory route rather than by the natural portal	of entry.	10.31653320765105
7740. some agents have been shown to be much more toxic or infectious	to experimental animals when exposed to aerosols of optimum particle	size than by the natural portal.	9.956533265375025
7741. botulinal toxin for example is several	thousand-fold more toxic by this route than when given per os.	8.29272515769823
7742. in some instances a different clinical disease picture may result from	this route of exposure making diagnosis difficult.	13.404419283147236
7743. in tularemia produced	by aerosol exposure one would not expect to find the classical	ulcer of rabbit fever on a finger.	11.028226782847888
7744. an enemy would obviously	choose an agent that is believed to be highly infectious.	15.008294463525765
7745. agents	that are known to cause frequent infections among laboratory workers	such as those causing q fever tularemia brucellosis glanders	coccidioidomycosis etc belong in this category.	7.8554728956294655
7746. an agent	would	likely be selected which would possess sufficient viability and virulence	stability to meet realistic minimal logistic requirements.	10.315426272035957
7747. it	is obviously a proper goal of research to improve on this property.	10.050130201827185
7748. in this connection it should be capable of being disseminated without	excessive destruction.	22.656214084886525
7749. moreover it should not be so fastidious in	its growth requirements as to make production on a militarily significant	scale improbable.	10.419475369222518
7750. an aggressor would use an agent against	which there was a minimal naturally acquired or artificially induced	immunity in a target population.	10.495558630917538
7751. a solid immunity is the one effective	circumstance whereby attack by a specific agent can be neutralized.	10.523112268714994
7752. it must be remembered however that there are many agents for which	there is no solid immunity and a partial or low-grade immunity may be	broken by an appropriate dose of agent.	12.355503056825265
7753. there is a broad spectrum	of organisms from which selection for a specified military purpose	might be made.	14.874637500988793
7754. an enemy might choose an acutely debilitating microorganism	a chronic disease producer or one causing a high rate of lethality.	10.364937814119978
7755. it is possible that certain mutational forms may be produced	such as antibiotic resistant strains.	18.34742613882179
7756. mutants may also be developed	with changes in biochemical properties that are of importance in	identification.	11.226523635125076
7757. all of these considerations are of critical importance	in considering defense and medical management.	13.512077245205779
7758. biological agents	are of course highly host-specific.	13.915190642667962
7759. they do not destroy physical	structures as is true of high explosives.	18.01451992530244
7760. this may be of overriding	importance in considering military objectives.	25.225175657833617
7761. the question	of epidemic disease merits some discussion.	13.974661317959146
7762. only a limited effort has	been devoted to this problem.	16.541722145750583
7763. some of those who question the value	of bw have assumed that the only potential would be in the establishment	of epidemics.	14.324119255288176
7764. they then point out that with our present lack	of knowledge of all the factors concerned in the rise and fall	of epidemics it is unlikely that a planned episode could be initiated.	10.303506456107511
7765. they argue further that our knowledge	and resources in preventive medicine would make it possible to control	such an outbreak of disease.	9.291205925491846
7766. this is why this approach to bw	defense has not been given major attention.	18.08716967382576
7767. our major problem	is what an enemy might accomplish in an initial attack on a target.	9.78291066135918
7768. this	of course does not eliminate from consideration for this purpose	agents that are associated naturally with epidemic disease.	9.559225930701576
7769. a hypothetical	example will illustrate this point.	14.566660921827188
7770. let us assume that it would	be possible for an enemy to create an aerosol of the causative agent	of epidemic typhus over city a and	that a large number of cases of typhus fever resulted therefrom.	11.294562035884969
7771. no epidemic	was initiated nor was one expected because the population in city	a was not lousy.	9.5257324697952
7772. lousiness is a prerequisite for epidemic typhus.	13.037321475654965
7773. in this case then the military objective was accomplished with	an epidemic agent solely through the results secured in the initial	attack.	10.958776729892339
7774. this was done with full knowledge that there would be no epidemic.	21.30702490312707
7775. on the other hand a similar attack might have been made on city	b whose population was known to be lousy.	16.541850880272378
7776. one might expect some	spread of the disease in this case resulting in increased effectiveness	of the attack.	14.157298824281892
7777. the major defensive problems are concerned	with the possibility of overt military delivery of biological agents from	appropriate disseminating devices.	10.329414882029608
7778. it should be no more difficult	to deliver such devices than other weapons.	23.084780744738566
7779. the same delivery vehicles-	whether they be airplanes submarines or guided missiles- should	be usable.	11.382045727296116
7780. if it is possible for an enemy to put an atomic bomb on	a city it should be equally possible to put a cloud of biological agent	over that city.	14.183885418709913
7781. biological agents are moreover suitable	for delivery through enemy sabotage which imposes many problems in defense.	8.450640073948662
7782. a few obvious target areas of great importance might be mentioned.	14.741680090071405
7783. the air conditioning and ventilating systems of large buildings are	subject to attack.	11.889408092888727
7784. america is rapidly becoming a nation that uses	processed precooked and even predigested foods.	12.11855572438216
7785. this is an enormous	industry that is subject to sabotage.	20.436910423801155
7786. one must include the preparation	of soft drinks and the processing of milk and milk products.	12.803869227519057
7787. huge	industries are involved also in the production of biological products	drugs and cosmetics which are liable to this type of attack.	9.867242652498833
