7853. successive 1-ml fractions were then drawn off with a	hypodermic syringe starting at the top of the tube and tested for agglutinin	activity.	11.678273778841445
7854. other methods will be described below.	15.725705363633404
7855. the insoluble material which precipitated	during dialysis against starting buffer always showed intense agglutinin	activity regardless of the blood group of the donor.	9.962656751443156
7856. with either	of the gradients described chromatography on deae-cellulose	separated agglutinins of the abo series into at least three regions	: one of extremely low anionic binding capacity	one of low anionic binding capacity and one of high anionic binding	capacity.	9.888366350338126
7857. these have been labeled regions 1 2 and 4 respectively	in fig 1.	10.420642243356971
7858. when the early part of the gradient was flattened	either by using the gradient shown in fig 2 or by allowing the cone-sphere	gradient to become established more slowly region 2 activity	could sometimes be separated into two areas	.	12.271586389140486
7859. the latter	procedure gave rise to a small active protein peak between	regions 1 and 2.	12.349704046457687
7860. in 2 of 15 experiments on whole serum a region of	agglutinin activity with intermediate anionic binding capacity was detected	.	10.97580523298895
7861. moreover after concentration using negative	pressure dialysis agglutinin activity could sometimes be detected	in the region designated 2a	.	9.367614614804978
7862. not all these regions exhibited equal	agglutinating activity as evidenced by titer and the extent of the	active areas.	13.763951338406928
7863. in all cases most of the activity lay in the region of	high anionic binding capacity.	15.343402655044008
7864. this was particularly noticeable in group	a and group b sera in which cases activity in regions 1	and 2 was usually not detectable without prior concentration and occasionally	could not be detected at all.	9.556589666771359
7865. there appeared to be no difference	in the distribution of anti-a and anti-b activity in group	o serum though in two group o donors	only one type of agglutinin was found in the regions of low anionic	binding capacity.	10.233187436152765
7866. several samples of	citrated plasma were fractionated in our laboratory by method 6 of cohn	et al.	10.658425710564716
7867. these fractions were tested for abo agglutinin	activity using fractions from group ab plasma as a control.	9.037923827668624
7868. as expected most of the activity was found in fraction f with	slight activity seen in fraction 4-1.	13.1912848104154
7869. a sample of fraction f	from group o plasma was dissolved in starting buffer dialyzed against	this buffer and subjected to chromatography using the gradient shown	in fig 2.	8.36886144432519
7870. once again both anti-a and anti-b activities	were found in the insoluble material precipitated during dialysis.	13.949433576505239
7871. similarly both types of antibodies were found in three regions of the	chromatographic eluate having extremely low low and high anionic	binding capacity respectively.	8.105337966302569
7872. chromatography of	whole sera revealed that the areas of rh antibody activity were generally	continuous and wide.	10.407659722371127
7873. the incomplete antibody activity appeared	in the early part of the chromatogram; the complete in the latter	part.	12.818373166344816
7874. the serum containing the mixed type of complete and incomplete	antibodies showed activity in both regions.	11.311263844877574
7875. in all cases	the activity against f cells was spread over a wider area than that	with f cells regardless of the type of test	used for comparison.	11.173344653863879
7876. the insoluble material resulting	from dialysis against starting buffer always showed strong activity.	12.445450562798397
7877. in	fact agglutination of f cells in saline could be produced by the	insoluble material from sera containing only incomplete antibody	activity.	7.96629078878188
7878. this was later known to be the result of concentrating the	minute amount of complete antibody found in these sera; when the insoluble	fraction was suspended in a volume of saline equal to that of	the original serum sample no complete antibody activity could be detected.	10.41727721043954
7879. apart from the honeybee practically all bees and bumblebees	hibernate in a state of torpor.	14.190474580174778
7880. occasionally you may come across one	or two bumblebees in the cold season when you are turning over sods	in your garden but you have to be a really keen observer to see them	at all.	11.173924409947338
7881. they keep their wings and feet pressed tightly against their	bodies and in spite of their often colorful attire you may very well	mistake them for lumps of dirt.	8.884397900653026
7882. i must add at once that these animals	are what we call queens young females that have mated in the previous	summer or autumn.	10.96361225419634
7883. it is on them alone that the future of their	race depends for all their relatives	have perished with the arrival of the cold weather.	14.387778554040327
7884. even some of the queens will die before the winter is over falling	prey to enemies or disease.	12.751945476594434
7885. the survivors emerge on some nice sunny	day in march or april when the temperature is close to 50` f	and there is not too much wind.	10.83931799697532
7886. now the thing for us to do is to find	ourselves a couple of those wonderful flowering currants such as the	red ribes sanguineum of our pacific northwest or otherwise a	good sloe tree or perhaps some nice pussy willow in bloom preferably	one with male or staminate catkins.	10.18408943168061
7887. the blooms of ribes and of	the willow and sloe are the places where large numbers of our early insects	will assemble: honeybees bumblebees and other wild bees and	also various kinds of flies.	8.393062588562403
7888. it is a happy buzzing crowd.	39.89123106056627
7889. each	male willow catkin is composed of a large number of small flowers.	14.821308925565956
7890. it is not difficult to see that the stamens of the catkin are always	arranged in pairs and that each individual flower is nothing but one	such pair standing on a green black-tipped little scale.	13.686187497372426
7891. by scrutinizing	the flowers one can also notice that the scale bears one or two	tiny warts.	9.379267787495897
7892. those are the nectaries or honey glands	.	16.11857002761021
7893. the staminate willow catkins then provide their visitors with	both nectar and pollen; a marvelous arrangement for it provides	exactly what the bee queens need to make their beebread a combination	of honey and pollen with which the young of all species are fed.	7.660537958543056
7894. the	only exception to this is certain bees that have become parasites.	11.06897560844949
7895. i	will deal with these later on.	11.867291106449708
7896. quite often honeybees form a	majority on the willow catkins.	12.827017622004428
7897. as we have already seen in the first	chapter bumblebees are bigger hairier and much more colorful than honeybees	exhibiting various combinations of black yellow white and	orange.	11.512210872174442
7898. let us not try to key them out at this stage of the game and	let us just call them bombus; there must be several dozen species	in the	united states alone.	12.024189266469763
7899. if you really insist on knowing their names	an excellent book on the north american species is bumblebees and	their ways by o e plath.	10.779725954329056
7900. if we manage to keep track	of a bombus queen after she has left her feeding place we may	discover the snug little hideout which she has fixed up for herself	when she woke up from her winter sleep.	9.783843956273879
7901. as befits a queen a bumblebee	female is rather choosy and may spend considerable time searching for	a suitable nesting place.	9.232528732235574
7902. most species seem to prefer a ready-made	hollow such as a deserted mouse nest a bird house or the hole made	by a woodpecker; some show a definite liking for making their nest in	moss.	9.320679599087798
7903. once she has made up her mind the queen starts out by constructing	in her chosen abode a small floor of dried grass or some	woolly material.	8.158319700067347
7904. on this she builds an egg compartment or egg	cell which is filled with that famous pollen-and-nectar mixture	called beebread.	12.03831392629446
7905. she also builds one or two waxen cups which she fills	with honey.	12.819930202168532
7906. then a group of eggs is deposited in a cavity in the	beebread loaf and the egg compartment is closed.	11.543089521841024
7907. the queen afterward	keeps incubating and guarding her eggs like a mother hen taking a sip	from time to time from the rather liquid honey in her honey pots.	9.100518993237722
7908. when	the larvae hatch they feed on the beebread although they also receive	extra honey meals from their mother.	9.960270133986333
7909. she continues to add to the	pollen supply as needed.	15.499492439725875
7910. the larvae kept warm by the queen	are full grown in about ten days.	12.010194183656237
7911. each now makes a tough papery cocoon	and pupates.	12.141006964183084
7912. after another two weeks the first young emerge four	to eight small daughters that begin to play the role of worker bees	collecting pollen and nectar in the field and caring for the new young	generation while the queen retires to a life of egg laying.	10.916522572436179
7913. the first	worker bees do not mate or lay eggs; males and mating females do not	emerge until later in the season.	9.497720915943663
7914. the broods of workers that appear	later tend to be bigger than the first ones probably because they are	better fed.	12.119337550618875
7915. by the middle of the summer many of the larvae apparently	receive such a good diet that it is optimal and it is then	that young queens begin to appear.	12.920090175852236
7916. simultaneously males or drones are	produced mostly from the unfertilized eggs of workers although a	few may be produced by the queen.	9.239528494510049
7917. the young queens and drones leave the	nest and mate and after a short period of freedom the fertilized	young	queens will begin to dig in for the winter.	8.840766393113183
7918. it is an amazing fact that	in some species this will happen while the summer is still in full	swing for instance in august.	14.73048796887976
7919. the temperature then is still very	high.	16.15319076460511
7920. at the old nest the queen will in the early fall cease to lay	the fertilized eggs that will produce females.	12.83699352915984
7921. as a result the proportion	of males increases and eventually the old	colony will die out completely.	14.163441042575835
7922. the nest itself the structure that	in some cases housed about 2000 individuals when the season was at its	peak is now rapidly destroyed by the scavenging larvae of certain	beetles and moths.	9.279183334061178
7923. not always though does the development of	a bumblebee colony take place in the smooth fashion we have just described.	11.76962088072691
7924. some members of the bee family have become idlers social parasites	that live at the expense of their hardworking relatives.	15.359459221121792
7925. bumblebees	can thus suffer severely from the onslaughts of psithyrus the	cuckoo-bumblebee as it is called in some european countries.	9.146705695508242
7926. female individuals of psithyrus look deceptively like the workers	and queens of the bumblebees they victimize.	9.908939338115298
7927. the one sure way to tell	victim and villain apart is to examine the hind legs which in the	case of the idler psithyrus lack the pollen baskets- naturally!	the female parasite spends much time in her efforts to find a nest	of her host.	8.539089432876999
7928. when she succeeds she usually manages to slip in unobtrusively	to deposit an egg on a completed loaf of beebread before the	bumblebees seal the egg compartment.	10.377239877710995
7929. the hosts never seem to recognize	that something is amiss so that the compartment afterward is sealed	normally.	10.327694244401066
7930. thus the larvae of the intruder can develop at the expense	of the rightful inhabitants and the store of beebread.	11.785676951088865
7931. later on they	and the mother psithyrus are fed by the bombus workers.	11.909192886702892
7932. worse still in a number of cases it has been claimed that the psithyrus	female kills off the bombus queen.	11.376049534454378
7933. but let us return	after this gruesome interlude to our willow catkins in the spring;	there are other wild bees that command our attention.	9.450727253726056
7934. it	is almost certain that some of these usually a trifle smaller than the	honeybees are andrenas or mining bees.	12.45445246066886
7935. there are about 200 different	kinds of andrena in europe alone.	18.355309196898887
7936. one of my favorites is a	armata a species very common in england where it is sometimes	referred to as the lawn bee.	14.604908143886247
7937. the females like to burrow in the short	turf of well-kept lawns where their little mounds of earth often appear	by the hundreds.	8.535996319710994
7938. almost equal in size to a honeybee.	15.540642501959478
7939. a armata	is much more beautiful in color at least in the female of the species:	a rich velvety rusty red.	11.404815684809401
7940. the males are much duller.	19.926638570224114
7941. after having mated an andrena female digs a hole straight down	into the ground forming a burrow about the size of a lead pencil.	10.771961283601271
7942. the bottom part of a burrow has a number of side tunnels or cells	each of which is provided with an egg plus a store of beebread.	12.87772895002187
7943. the	development of the andrena larvae is very rapid so that by the	end of spring they have already pupated and become adults.	7.97789933048673
7944. but they	are still enclosed in their larval cells and remain there throughout	the summer fall and winter.	11.827068246062383
7945. their appearance next spring coincides	in an almost uncanny way with the flowering of their host plants.	9.164617100996999
7946. in the sacramento valley in california for instance it has been observed	that there was not one day's difference between the emergence	of the andrenas and the opening of the willow catkins.	13.563131764945668
7947. this must be	due to a completely identical response to the weather in the plant and	the animal.	11.5451381833246
7948. after the male and female andrenas have mated	the cycle is repeated.	15.196421165643706
7949. although andrena is gregarious so that we	may find hundreds and hundreds of burrows together we must still call	it a solitary bee.	8.468305173730915
7950. its life history is much simpler than that of the	truly colonial bumblebees and can serve as an example of the life	cycle of many other species.	13.168709101888469
7951. after all social life in the group of	the bees is by no means general although it certainly is a striking	feature.	14.638729544406177
7952. on the basis of its life history we like to think that andrena	is more primitive than the bumblebees.	16.411019383973493
7953. the way in which it transports	its pollen is not so perfect either.	22.777478160221424
7954. it lacks pollen baskets	and possesses only a large number of long branched hairs on its legs	on which the pollen grains will collect.	14.068492561076694
7955. still andrena will	do a reasonably good job so that an animal with a full pollen load looks	like a gay little piece of yellow down floating in the wind.	8.693107184615842
7956. closely related to the andrenas are the nomias or alkali bees.	13.359497576365479
7957. nomia	melanderi can be found in tremendous numbers in certain parts of	the united states west of the great plains for example in utah	and central washington.	11.765389673962064
7958. in the united states department of agriculture's	yearbook of agriculture 1952 which is devoted entirely	to insects george e bohart mentions a site in utah which	was estimated to contain 200000 nesting females.	11.974080177948375
7959. often the burrows	are only an inch or two apart and the bee cities cover several acres.	9.249540383940145
7960. the life history of the alkali bee is similar to that of andrena	but the first activity of the adults does not take place until summer	and the individuals hibernate in the prepupal stage.	10.950543737959357
7961. in most places	there are two generations a year a second brood of adults appearing	late in the summer.	10.533854592986541
7962. i must plead guilty to a special sympathy	for nomias.	17.68995883069911
7963. this may just be pride in my adopted state of washington	but certainly i love to visit their mound cities near yakima and	prosser in july or august when the bees are in their most active	period.	8.332785025599273
7964. the name alkali bee indicates that one has to look for	them in rather inhospitable places.	14.71351022218605
7965. sometimes although by no means	always these are indeed alkaline.	11.299183009606992
7966. the thing is that these bees love	a fine-grained soil that is moist; yet the water in the ground should	not be stagnant either.	11.853416344108572
7967. where does	one find such conditions?	16.395301430259657
7968.  the best chance of course is offered by	gently sloping terrain where the water remains close to the surface and	where the air is dry so that a high evaporation leaves salty deposits	which permit only sparse plant growth.	10.935624007198443
7969. many other snakes at maturity are already more	than half their final length.	10.903229058624204
7970. laurence m klauber put length at maturity	at two thirds the ultimate length for some rattlesnakes and charles	c carpenter's data on michigan garter and ribbon snakes	show that the smallest gravid females are more than	half as long as the biggest adults.	8.878242117176734
7971. felix kopstein states that when	the snake reaches its maturity it has already reached about its maximal	length but goes on to cite the reticulate python as an exception	with maximum length approximately three times that at maturity.	7.246741796690732
7972. it is hard to understand how he concluded that most snakes do not grow	appreciably after attaining maturity; he was working with species	of java so perhaps some tropical snakes are unusual in this respect.	13.13901640509693
7973. certain individual giants recorded later did fail to show a reasonable	difference after maturity but it is impossible to know whether this	is due to captive conditions.	9.19732181283435
7974. additional records of slow growth have	been omitted.	14.101411152628298
7975. it is possible to make a few generalizations about	the six giants themselves.	25.426892672098766
7976. there seems to be a rough correlation	between the initial and ultimate lengths starting with the smallest	and ending with the largest.	16.511278741072424
7977. data on the	former are scanty but there can be little doubt that the latter is sometimes	born at a length greater than that of any of the others thereby	lending support to the belief that the anaconda does indeed attain	the greatest length.	11.368702110712746
7978. for four of the six	there is also a correlation	between size at maturity and maximum length the boa constrictor	being the smallest and the indian python the next in size at the	former stage.	10.119162731720289
7979. let us speculate a little on the maximum size	of the anaconda.	16.470655618636307
7980. if in a certain part of the range it starts life 1	foot longer than do any of the other giants and reaches	maturity at let us guess 18 inches longer than the others a	quadrupling of the maturity length would result in a maximum of	40 feet.	11.738403722156837
7981. when it comes to rate of early growth the indian	python leads with a figure of about 3 feet 6 inches per year for the	first two years more or less.	10.22148562433179
7982. the african rock python a close second	is followed in turn by the reticulate python.	11.636095537390238
7983. there are few data	on the boa constrictor those for the anaconda are unconvincing and	there is nothing at all on the amethystine python.	12.635404742301338
7984. it seems likely that	the indian python comes out ahead because records of its growth have	been made more carefully and frequently; it responds exceptionally	well to captivity and does not reach proportions that make it hard to	keep.	10.577401292427284
7985. i cannot make sense out of the figures for post maturity	growth; at best the annual increase appears to be a matter of inches	rather than feet.	12.24891860967275
7986. until better records have been kept over longer	periods of time and much more is known about the maximum dimensions	it will be wise to refrain from drawing conclusions.	10.098351093279467
7987. it is often	stated	that the largest snakes require five years to attain maturity but	this apparently is an overestimation.	12.911050914630081
7988. the best way to determine the	correct figure is by direct observation of pairs isolated	from birth a method that produced surprising results: maturing of	a male indian python in less than two years his mate in less than three;	data on the boa constrictor about match this.	10.465446717464218
7989. another approach	is to estimate from the rate of growth and the smallest size at	maturity.	10.23752223229208
7990. results from this approach amply confirm the direct observations:	about three years are required there being a possible slight	difference between males and females in the time required.	8.958922857694244
7991. only the	amethystine python and the anaconda must be excluded for lack or paucity	of data.	9.88459132164739
7992. the following information on snakes varying greatly	in size shows when considered	with the foregoing that there is probably no correlation between	the length of a snake and the time required for it to mature.	10.4804257624531
7993. oliver	in his summary of the habits of the snakes of the united states	could supply data on the maturing period for only three species in addition	to the rattlers which i shall consider separately.	8.963379168435443
7994. these three	were much alike: lined snake one year and	nine months; red-bellied snake two years; cottonmouth	two years.	10.597568724640876
7995. klauber investigated the rattlesnakes	carefully himself and also summarized what others have found.	9.070074471681158
7996. he	concluded that in the southern species which are rapidly growing types	females mate at the age of two and a half and bear the first young	when they are three.	12.006157534613804
7997. other herpetologists have ascertained that in	the northern united states the prairie rattlesnake may not give first	birth until it is four or even five years old and that the young may	be born every other year rather than annually.	8.541661108595024
7998. carpenter's study	showed that female common garter and ribbon snakes of michigan mature	at about the age of two.	10.419071640506745
7999. oversized monsters are	never brought home either alive or preserved and field measurements	are obviously open to doubt because of the universal tendency to exaggerate	dimensions.	8.18182507659557
8000. measurements of skins are of little value; every	snake hide is noticeably longer than its carcass and intentional stretching	presents no difficulty to the unscrupulous explorer.	8.943044632218623
8001. in	spite of all the pitfalls there is a certain amount of agreement on	some of the giants.	10.232110534663809
8002. the anaconda proves to be the fly in the ointment	but the reason for this is not clear; the relatively wild conditions	still found in tropical south america might be responsible.	12.547918129812254
8003. there are three levels on which to treat the subject.	23.059092734444718
8004. the first is	the strictly scientific which demands concrete proof and therefore may	err on the conservative side by waiting for evidence in the flesh.	10.888379940903679
8005. this	approach rejects virtually all field measurements.	11.867291106449708
8006. the next level	attempts to weigh varied evidence and come to a balanced sensible conclusion;	field measurements by experienced explorers are not rejected	and even reports of a less scientific nature are duly evaluated.	10.530329506076454
8007. the third level leans on a belief that a lot of smoke means some fire.	11.969198005325058
8008. the argument against this last approach is comparable to that which	rejects stories about hoop snakes about snakes that break themselves	into many pieces and join up again or even of ghosts that chase people	out of graveyards; the mere piling up of testimony does not prove	to the scientific mind the existence of hoop snakes joint snakes	or ghosts.	8.914504823634505
8009. oliver has recently used the second-level approach	with the largest snakes and has come to these conclusions: the anaconda	reaches a length of at least 37 feet the reticulate python 33	the african rock python 25 the amethystine python at least 22 the indian	python 20 and the boa constrictor 18-12.	7.03782394777876
8010. bernard heuvelmans	also treats of the largest snakes but on the third level and	is chiefly concerned with the anaconda.	12.133151532067252
8011. he reasons that as anacondas	30 feet long are often found some might be 38 and occasional monstrous	freaks over 50.	9.522885957569553
8012. he rejects dimensions of 70 feet and more.	16.477994707361407
8013. his thirteenth chapter includes many exciting accounts of huge serpents	with prodigious strength but these seem to be given to complete his	picture not to be believed.	10.378449203879947
8014. detailed information on record	lengths of the giants is given in the section that follows.	12.18545591313694
8015. of the six giants	discussions of the giants one by one will include	as far as possible data on these aspects of growth: size at which	life is started and at which sexual maturity is reached; time required	to reach maturity; rate of growth both before and after this crucial	stage; and maximum length with confirmation or amplification	of oliver's figures.	7.738992994852292
8016. definite information on the growth of senile	individuals is lacking.	13.943087155564434
8017. at birth this species varies	considerably in size.	15.612137863886977
8018. a brood of twenty-eight born at brookfield	zoo near chicago ranged in length from 22 to 33-12 inches and averaged	29 inches.	9.976524862873173
8019. lawrence e griffin gives measurements of nineteen	young anacondas presumably members of a brood from south america;	the extreme measurements of these fall between the lower limit	of the brookfield brood and its average.	7.513901455922771
8020. raymond l ditmars	had	two broods that averaged 27 inches.	12.505157322409175
8021. r r mole and f w	urich give approximately 20 inches as the average length of a brood	of thirty from the region of the orinoco estuaries.	7.7450939447884
8022. william beebe	reports 26 inches and 2.	15.969432818563234
8023. 4 ounces	for the length and the weight of a young anaconda from british guiana.	11.21717637641319
8024. in contrast ditmars recorded the average length of seventy-two	young of a 19-foot female as 38 inches and four young were born in london	at a length of 35 or 36 inches and a weight of from 14 to 16 ounces.	9.560665323183285
8025. beebe had a 3-foot anaconda that weighed only 9.	10.398790326988289
8026. a difference	between subspecies might explain the great range in size.	13.12566368285538
8027. i have little information on the anaconda's rate of growth.	15.253542563333623
8028. hans	schweizer had one that increased from 19-12 inches to 5 feet 3 inches	in five years and j j quelch records a growth of from less	than 4 feet to nearly 10 in about six years.	8.718634491685233
8029. it is very unlikely that	either of these anacondas was growing at a normal rate.	15.105123196608007
8030. in 1948	afranio do amaral the noted brazilian herpetologist wrote a	technical paper on the giant snakes.	12.141706617637393
8031. he concluded that the anaconda's	maximum length is 12 or 13 meters which would approximate	from 39 to 42 feet.	9.394903394107072
8032. thus	his estimate lies between oliver's suggestion of at least 37 feet	and the 50-foot monstrous freaks intimated by heuvelmans.	10.165936950100981
8033. the most convincing recent measurement of an anaconda was made in	eastern colombia by roberto lamon a petroleum geologist of the richmond	oil company and reported in 1944 by emmett r dunn.	8.112509887477728
8034. however	as a field measurement it is open to question.	12.711272124042397
8035. oliver's 37-12	feet is partly based on this report and can be accepted as probable.	9.95380622327286
8036. however many herpetologists remain skeptical and would prefer	a tentative maximum of about 30 feet.	11.592477973745268
8037. it is possible that especially	large anacondas will prove to belong to subspecies limited to	a small area.	19.538819210689976
8038. in snakes difference in size is a common characteristic	of subspecies.	15.508675890424705
8039. a colombian female's brood	of sixteen boa constrictors born in the staten island zoo averaged	20 inches.	10.893397201130895
8040. this birth length seems to be typical.	20.74901840677139
8041. when some thirteen	records of newly and recently born individuals are collated little	or no correlation between length and distribution can be detected.	8.879535181671486
8042. the	range is from 14 to 25 inches; the former figure is based on a somewhat	unusual birth of four by a central american female	the latter on a normal	newly born individual.	9.47934631705628
8043. however as so many of the records are	not certainly based on newborn snakes these data must be taken tentatively;	final conclusions will have to await the measurements of broods	from definite localities.	11.006532284851316
8044. alphonse r hoge's measurements	of several very young specimens from brazil suggest that at birth the	female is slightly larger than the male.	9.361953784848135
8045. i have surprisingly little	information on the size and age at maturity.	15.821964919484449
8046. carl kauffeld has	written to me of sexual activity in february 1943 of young born in march	1940.	9.723773562266802
8047. one female collected on an island off the coast of nicaragua	was gravid and measured 4 feet 8 inches from snout to vent	.	8.67117762651165
8048. the female from central	america which gave birth to four was only 3 feet 11 inches long.	11.825265946678792
8049. what data there are on growth indicate considerable variation	in rate; unfortunately no one has kept complete records of one individual	whereas many have been made for a very short period of time.	9.128029526911925
8050. the results are too varied to allow generalization.	16.566743820444294
8051. the bronchus and pulmonary artery in this lung type maintain a close	relationship throughout.	10.242653103537407
8052. the pulmonary vein however without the limiting	supportive tissue septa as in type 1 follows a more direct	path	to the hilum and does not maintain this close relationship	.	9.995705776064328
8053. another marked difference is noted here.	13.246711965542852
8054. the pulmonary artery	in addition to supplying the distal portion of the respiratory bronchiole	the alveolar duct and the alveoli continues on and directly supplies	the thin pleura.	10.312205753949476
8055. the bronchial artery except for a	small number of short branches in the hilum contributes none of the	pleural blood supply.	8.828385447606417
8056. it does as in type 1 supply the hilar lymph	nodes the pulmonary artery the pulmonary vein the bronchi and the	bronchioles- terminating in a common capillary bed with the pulmonary	artery at the level of the respiratory bronchiole.	11.62967006902824
8057. no bronchial artery-pulmonary	artery anastomoses were noted in this group.	11.981852367567186
8058. lung	type 3 is to some degree a composite of types 1	and 2.	12.022492348684999
8059. it is characterized by the presence of incompletely developed	secondary lobules; well defined but haphazardly arranged interlobular	septa and a thick remarkably vascular pleura.	12.061235556481398
8060. the	most distal airways are similar to those found in type 1 being	composed of numerous apparently true terminal bronchioles and occasional	poorly developed respiratory bronchioles.	9.172164668110682
8061. in this	instance because of incomplete septation the secondary lobule does	not constitute in itself what appears to be a small individual lung	as in type 1.	10.660755887430145
8062. air-drifts from one area to another are therefore	conceivable.	12.3482207866056
8063. distally the bronchus is situated between a pulmonary artery	on one side and a pulmonary vein on the other as in type 1	.	8.879665443869268
8064. this relationship however is not maintained centrally.	18.441123241812942
8065. here the pulmonary vein as in type 2 is noted to draw away from	the bronchus and to follow a more direct independent course to the	hilum.	8.874364978744321
8066. the bronchial artery in its course and distribution	differs somewhat from that found in other mammals.	11.311263844877574
8067. as seen in	types 1 and 2 it supplies the hilar lymph nodes vasa vasorum	to the pulmonary artery and vein the bronchi and the terminal bronchioles.	8.384363625555597
8068. as in type 1 it provides arterial blood to the interlobular	septa and an extremely rich anastomotic pleural supply is seen	.	12.20839308979402
8069. this pleural supply is derived both from hilar and interlobular	bronchial artery branches.	10.827878305075057
8070. such a dual derivation was strikingly	demonstrated during the injection process where initial filling	would be noted to occur in several isolated pleural vessels at once.	10.08571829187401
8071. some	of these were obviously filling from interlobular branches of the	bronchial arteries while others were filling from direct hilar branches	following along the pleural surface.	7.959655609188863
8072. with completion of filling net-like	anastomoses were noted to be present between these separately	derived branches.	12.606385477421934
8073. an unusual increase in the number of bronchial arteries	present within the substance of the lung was noted.	13.372808544354731
8074. this was accounted	for primarily by the presence of a bronchial artery closely following	the pulmonary artery.	15.65277650024597
8075. the diameter of this bronchial artery was	much too large for it to be a mere vasa vasorum.	11.543089943955875
8076. in distal regions its diameter would be one-fourth to one-fifth that	of the pulmonary artery.	12.539645154163946
8077. this vessel could be followed to the parenchyma	where it directly provided bronchial arterial blood to the alveolar	capillary bed.	10.029359683858594
8078. also three other direct pathways	of alveolar bronchial arterial supply were noted: via the pleura;	through the interlobular septa; and along the terminal bronchiole	.	10.125146180779174
8079. one bronchial arteriolar-pulmonary arteriolar	anastomosis was noted at the terminal bronchiolar level.	11.65298483791174
8080. it is evident that many marked and striking differences	exist between lungs when an inter-species comparison is made.	15.92661979001771
8081. the	significance of these differences has not been studied nor has the existence	of corresponding physiologic differences been determined.	9.129030637199381
8082. however	the dynamics of airflow from morphologic considerations alone	may conceivably be different in the monkey than in the horse.	10.805771483212954
8083. the volume	and perhaps even the characteristics of bronchial arterial blood	flow might be different in the dog than in the horse.	10.627469242618764
8084. also interlobular	air drifts may be all but nonexistent in the cow; probably occur	in the horse much as in the human being; and in contrast are present	to a relatively immense degree on a segmental basis in the dog where	lobules are absent.	9.404482019669967
8085. a reason	for such wide variation in the pulmonary morphology is entirely lacking	at present.	9.966061740790925
8086. within certain wide limits anatomy dictates function	and if one is permitted to speculate potential pathology should	be included in this statement as well.	10.883034927948376
8087. for example the marked susceptibility	of the monkey to respiratory infection might be related to its	delicate long alveolar ducts and short large bronchioles situated	within a parenchyma entirely lacking in protective supportive tissue	barriers such as those found in types 1 and 3.	8.544928671812851
8088. one might also	wonder if monkeys are capable of developing bronchiolitis as we know	it in man or the horse.	12.917604076545079
8089. in addition it would be difficult to imagine	chronic generalized emphysema occurring in a cow considering its marked	lobular development but conversely not difficult to imagine this	occurring in the horse or the dog.	10.475724676486367
8090. anatomically the horse lung	appears to be remarkably like that of man insofar as this can be ascertained	from comparison of our findings in the horse with those of	others in the human being.	10.082649166739161
8091. the only area in which	one might find major disagreement in this matter is in regard to the alveolar	distribution of the bronchial arteries.	13.554388774730317
8092. as early as 1858 le	fort claimed an alveolar distribution of the bronchial arteries in human	beings.	15.192277454848806
8093. in 1951 this was reaffirmed by cudkowicz.	16.37525627429589
8094. the opposition	to this point of view has its staunchest support in the work of miller	.	18.014653387906115
8095. apparently however miller has relied heavily on the	anatomy in dogs and cats and he has been criticized for using pathologic	human material in his normal study.	8.775408903199805
8096. although miller	noted in 1907 that a difference in the pleural blood supply existed	between animals nowhere in his published works is it found that he	did a comparative study of the intrapulmonary features of various mammalian	lungs other than in the dog and cat.	10.47938231992521
8097. the meaning of this variation in distribution of the bronchial	artery as found in the horse is not clear.	14.05077723263533
8098. however this artery is known	to be a nutrient vessel with a distribution primarily to the proximal	airways and supportive tissues of the lung.	10.806689460848526
8099. the alveoli and respiratory	bronchioles are primarily diffusing tissues.	12.98623016976681
8100. theoretically they	are capable of extracting their required oxygen either from the surrounding	air or from pulmonary arterial	blood.	9.723773562266802
8101. therefore an explanation of this alveolar	bronchial artery supply might be the nutritive requirement of an increased	amount of supportive tissue not primarily diffusing in nature	in the region of the alveolus.	8.10860803254633
8102. if this be true the possibility exists	that an occlusive lesion of the bronchial arteries might cause widespread	degeneration of supportive tissue similar to that seen in generalized	emphysema.	10.875993471418642
8103. one would not expect such an event to occur in animals	possessing lungs of types 1 or 2.	9.544498515510758
8104. the presence of normally	occurring bronchial artery-pulmonary artery anastomoses was first	noted in 1721 by ruysch and thereafter by many others.	11.763405330398179
8105. nakamura	verloop von	hayek have all claimed their normal but	relatively nonfunctional existence in the human being.	9.55759188591782
8106. miller	is the principal antagonist of this viewpoint.	13.037321475654965
8107. in criticism of the latter's	views his conclusions were based upon dog lung injection studies	in which all of the vascular channels were first filled with a solution	under pressure and then were injected with various sized colored	particles designed to stop at the arteriolar level.	8.054595116758833
8108. as early as 1913	ghoreyeb and karsner demonstrated with perfusion studies in dogs	that bronchial artery flow would remain constant at a certain low level	when pressure was maintained in the pulmonary artery and vein but that	increases in bronchial artery flow would occur in response to a relative	drop in pulmonary artery pressure.	9.714507408706279
8109. berry brailsford and daly	in 1931 and nakamura in 1958 reaffirmed this.	9.345058977386529
8110. our own studies in which	bronchial artery-pulmonary artery anastomoses were demonstrated	were accomplished by injecting the bronchial artery first with no pressure	on the pulmonary artery or vein and then by injecting the pulmonary	artery and vein afterwards.	8.638544486771263
8111. it is distinctly possible therefore	that simultaneous pressures in all three vessels would have rendered	the shunts inoperable and hence uninjectable.	11.56142235613621
8112. this viewpoint is further	supported by verloop's demonstration of thickened bronchial	artery and arteriolar muscular coats which are capable of acting	as valves.	10.761869065041624
8113. in other words the anastomoses between the bronchial artery	and pulmonary artery should be considered as functional or demand	shunts.	13.295859786868355
8114. in addition little work has been done on a comparative	basis in regard to the normal existence of bronchial artery-pulmonary	artery anastomoses.	16.73304832610625
8115. verloop found these shunts	in the human being but was unable to find them in rats.	9.39778994459402
8116. ellis grindlay	and edwards also were unable to find them in rats.	10.957705180640192
8117. nakamura	was unable to demonstrate their existence either by anatomic	or physiologic methods in dogs.	8.968411200837055
8118. the possibility that the absence	or presence of these shunts is species-dependent is therefore inferred.	14.365987694249409
8119. certainly the mere fact of failing to demonstrate them in one	or another species does not conclusively deny their existence in that	species.	8.225835482890563
8120. it is however highly suggestive and agrees well with our own	findings in which we also failed to demonstrate normally occurring	bronchial artery-pulmonary artery shunts in certain species especially	the dog.	12.227159796506669
8121. in conclusion these findings suggest the need for	a comparative physiology pathology and histology of mammalian lungs.	10.058592376379565
8122. in addition a detailed interspecies survey of the incidence of generalized	pulmonary emphysema in mammals would be interesting and pertinent.	13.44481439770733
8123. also for the present great caution should be exercised in the	choice of an experimental animal for pulmonary studies if they are to	be applied to man.	9.22757125637684
8124. this is especially so if the dog cat or monkey are	to be used in view of their marked anatomical differences from man.	15.230636965907161
8125. finally it is suggested that in many respects the horse lung may be	anatomically more comparable to that of the human than any other presently	known species.	12.005380954752178
8126. the main subgross anatomical features	of the lungs of various mammals are presented.	13.298726768299371
8127. a tabulation of these	features permits the lungs to be grouped into three distinctive subgross	types.	9.670330484383054
8128. type 1 is represented by the cow sheep and pig;	type 2 by the dog cat and monkey; type 3 by the horse.	9.97054730343156
8129. lobularity is extremely well developed in type 1; absent in type	2; imperfectly developed in type 3.	8.29272515769823
8130. the pleura and interlobular	septa are thick in types 1 and 3.	12.957840546200554
8131. the pleura is extremely	thin in type 2 and septa are absent.	11.050834287616778
8132. arterial supply to the pleura	in types 1 and 3 is provided by the bronchial artery and	in type 2 by the pulmonary artery.	9.271329388213159
8133. in types 1 2 and 3	the bronchial artery terminates in a capillary bed shared in common	with the pulmonary artery at the level of the distal bronchiole.	9.950408994726931
8134. in	type 3 the bronchial artery also provides blood directly to the	alveolar capillary bed.	10.358652090748608
8135. true terminal bronchioles comprise the most frequent	form taken by the distal airways in types 1 and 3 although	small numbers of poorly developed respiratory bronchioles are present.	8.180469553502272
8136. well developed respiratory bronchioles on the other hand appear	to be the only form taken by the distal airways in type 2.	13.494472104091713
8137. in	type 1 the pulmonary vein closely follows the course of the bronchus	and the pulmonary artery from the periphery to the hilum.	9.532208636155053
8138. this maybe	due to the heavy interlobular connective tissue barriers present.	14.62975866861027
8139. in	type 3 this general relationship is maintained peripherally but	not centrally where the pulmonary vein follows a more independent path	to the hilum as is the case throughout the lung in type 2.	7.542689547924482
8140. some of the features of the top portions of figure 1 and figure	2 were mentioned in discussing table 1.	16.295407172769934
8141. first the onset profile	spreads across approximately 12 years for boys and 10 years for girls.	10.740108933856845
8142. in contrast 20 of the 21 lines in the completion profile	are bunched and extend over a	much shorter period approximately 30 months for boys and 40 months for	girls.	9.949074441911211
8143. the maturity chart for each sex demonstrates clearly that	onset is a phenomenon of infancy and early childhood whereas completion	is a phenomenon of the later portion of adolescence.	8.212529769504565
8144. second for	both sexes the 21 transverse lines in the onset profile vary more	in individual spread than those in the completion profile.	10.78627012502947
8145. although	the standard deviation values on which spread of the lines are based	are relatively larger for those centers which begin to ossify early	there are considerable differences in this value between	centers having the closely timed onsets.	7.836278696075707
8146. third the process of calcification	is seen to begin later and to continue much longer for these	boys than for the girls a fact which confirms data for other groups of	children.	10.451470727786948
8147. the onset profile and completion profile are constructed	to serve as norms for children.	10.242653103537407
8148. it is convenient to classify	a child's onset ages and completion ages as advanced moderate	or delayed according to whether the child's	age equivalent dots appeared to the left of upon or	to the right of the appropriate short transverse line.	12.324761827845334
8149. when a dot	appears close to the end of the transverse line the moderate	rating may be further classified according to the position of the dot	with respect to the vertical marking denoting the mean age.	13.681913602116659
8150. such classifications	may be called somewhat advanced or somewhat delayed	as the case may be reserving moderate for dots upon or close	to the mean.	10.277311992145647
8151. in the lower portion of each chart the skeletal	age of boy 34 and girl 2 may be similarly classified.	11.60307017859835
8152. there the middle one of the three curves denotes mean skeletal age	for the maturity series boys and girls.	17.01481083503889
8153. the upper curve denotes	the mean plus one standard deviation and the lower curve represents	the mean minus one standard deviation.	9.003374223945919
8154. thus a child's skeletal	age dots may be classified as advanced when they appear above	the middle curve moderate when they appear immediately above	or below the middle curve and delayed when they appear below	the lower curve.	9.284839556104194
8155. to summarize the purpose of the skeletal maturity	chart: each contains two kinds of skeletal maturity norms which	show two quite different methods of depicting developmental level	of growth centers.	9.075516102734882
8156. first the upper portion requires series of films	for every child consisting of those from hand elbow shoulder knee	and foot.	11.076023088234148
8157. the lower portion necessitates only films of hand.	13.611054240998833
8158. second the upper portion permits comparison of maturity levels of an	equal number of growth centers from the long short and round bones	of the five regions.	9.342951313482567
8159. the lower portion permits comparison of maturity	levels of short and round bones predominantly since only two long bones	are included in hand and wrist as a region.	8.420275648759473
8160. third the upper portion	deals with only two indicators of developmental level onset and	completion.	12.183244542634215
8161. the lower portion utilizes the full complement of intermediate	maturity indicators of each hand center as well as their onset	and completion.	10.082284143098871
8162. fourth the two indicators are for the most part	widely separated chronologically with the extensive age gap occurring	during childhood for all but one growth center.	9.776026287533035
8163. the lower portion provides	a rating at any stage between infancy and adulthood.	10.994603211347957
8164. onsets	completions and skeletal ages of boy 34 and girl 2	may be directly compared and classified using only those skeletal ages	which appear immediately below the onset profile and the completion	profile.	8.443382555482197
8165. it may be assumed that differences in ratings due to selection	of growth centers from specific regions of the body will be small	according to existing tables of onset age and completion age for	centers throughout the body.	9.6874300922679
8166. accordingly maturity level ratings by	means of the upper portion and lower portion of the chart respectively	should be somewhat similar since skeletal age assessments are dependent	upon onsets during infancy and upon completions during adolescence.	9.541312744408007
8167. it is clear that there are some differences in the ratings but	there is substantial agreement.	20.658912088213604
8168. since a skeletal age rating can	be made at any age during growth from elbow shoulder knee or foot	as well as hand it seems to be the method of choice when one wishes	to study most aspects of skeletal developmental progress during childhood.	10.727366200913007
8169. as stated earlier in the paper onsets and completions-	particularly the former- provide a different tool or indicator of expectancy	in osseous development each within a limited age period.	8.374978905760777
8170. such	an indicator or indicators are needed as means of recognizing specific	periods of delay in skeletal developmental progress.	9.559225930701576
8171. it	was stated earlier that one purpose of this study was to extend the analysis	of variability of onset and completion in each of the 21 growth	centers somewhat beyond that provided by the data in tables 1 and	2.	8.505356873307889
8172. as one approach to doing this figures 3 and 4 have been constructed	from the mean ages and the individual onset and completion ages for	boy 34 and girl 2.	9.699596211335466
8173. the differences between onset age and completion age	with respect to the corresponding mean age have been brought into juxtaposition	by means of a series of arrows.	9.272638300062724
8174. the data for boy 34 appear	in figure 3 and for girl 2 in figure 4.	11.311263844877574
8175. the numbering system used	in tables 1 and 2 and figures 1 and 2 was continued for the 21 growth	centers.	8.828385447606417
8176. the dot on one end of each arrow indicates	extent of difference in months between the child's onset age and the	corresponding mean age for the growth center.	10.550805859017666
8177. the tip of the	arrow represents extent of difference between the child's completion	age and the corresponding mean age for the growth center.	9.595591995364074
8178. thus the	alignment of the dots and tips respectively indicate individual	variability of the 21 growth centers of each child with respect	to the mean values for these boys and girls.	9.278959384109818
8179. the direction in which	the arrow points shows how the maturity level of the growth center was	changed at completion from the level at onset.	8.98052793222422
8180. when the dot	and tip coincide the classification used in this paper is same	schedule.	14.139789064987115
8181. the length of the arrow indicates amount of slowing or	acceleration at completion over that at onset and the difference	in months can be read roughly by referring the arrow to the age scale	along the base of each figure or more precisely by referring to the	original data in the appropriate tables.	7.953267547226351
8182. the difference between	the sequence of onset of ossification for the sexes governs the numbering	sequence in figures 3 and 4.	11.492181051613539
8183. this difference is readily clarified	by referring to table 1.	13.604873360190716
8184. for example arrow 17 in figure 3 portrays	the proximal radial epiphysis for boy 34 whereas the same epiphysis	for girl 2 is portrayed by arrow 18 in figure 4.	10.257732985553922
8185. for the boy	this epiphysis was markedly delayed at onset but near the mean at completion.	11.139491122895025
8186. thus the span of its ossification was shortened and the center's	ability to catch up in ossification is demonstrated.	11.365391386226362
8187. in	contrast for the girl the epiphysis was slightly advanced at onset	and delayed at completion.	8.62963042412541
8188. obviously the slowing for her may have	occurred at any point between onset and completion.	12.005501282371853
8189. the skeletal	age curve in the lower portion of figure 2 shows that slowing may have	occurred for her during the prepubescent period.	8.935189222267525
8190. length of the shaft	of these arrows may be evaluated according to the standard deviation	values for each center in table 1.	11.108215164282347
8191. we have attempted to simplify	the extensive task of analyzing onset ages and completion ages of	each child- more than 1700 values for the entire group- by constructing	figures for each of the 21 centers so that the data for all 34	boys and 34 of the girls will appear together for each growth center.	8.59784327336951
8192. figures 5 and 6 are examples of our method of analyzing the results for	each growth center.	10.162305985298431
8193. forty other figures similar to 5 and 6 and the	original data used in the construction of all figures and tables in this	monograph have been included in the appendix.	9.545599069747125
8194. the principles	used in making each arrow for figures 3 and 4 were applied to the	construction of figures 5 and 6 as well as all figures in the appendix.	10.599891994944592
8195. one growth center in a short bone- distal phalanx of the second	finger- was chosen as an example for discussion here primarily because	epiphyseal-diaphyseal fusion the maturity indicator for completion	in long and short bones occurs in this center for girls near the	menarche and for boys near their comparable pubescent stage.	7.848744784922532
8196. its completion	thus becomes one of the convenient maturity indicators to include	in studies of growth dietary patterns and health during adolescence.	10.613815357775831
8197. the following summary based on figures 5 and 6 is an	example of one way of interpreting the 42 figures constructed from onset	ages and completion ages of individual children with respect to the	appropriate mean age for each growth center.	7.973719098262031
8198. at the top of figure 5	for example the onset range and completion range lines for the chosen	growth center have been drawn for girls according to their mean and	standard deviation values in table 1.	11.583811695590848
8199. the 34 arrows denoting onset	age plus completion age deviations have been arrayed in an onset	sequence which begins with girl 18 who had the earliest onset of the	34 girls.	7.842562774759641
8200. the growth center depicted here in the distal phalanx of the	second finger is listed as the fifth of those in the seven short bones.	12.155094761121273
8201. the mean onset age was 25.	15.260583014183545
8202. 3 months and the average	span of the osseous stage was 133 months.	12.527355887668785
8203. the correlation	between onset age and completion age was +.	12.204673387645432

8205. with due consideration for the limits of precision	in assessing expected rate of change in ossification of girls age	2 years and the known variations in rate of ossification of these	children as described in our preceding paper in the supplement each	arrow with a shaft length of four months or less was selected as	indicating same schedule at onset and completion for this particular	epiphysis.	7.097047280639339

8207. it seems clear from	the counter-balanced shape of the series of arrows in figure 5 that	there was about an equal number of early and late onsets and completions	for the 34 girls.	11.225577505375272
8208. accordingly if epiphyseal-diaphyseal fusion	occurs in this phalanx near menarche early and late menarches might	have been forecast rather precisely at the time of onset of ossification	for the 18 girls with same schedule.	10.404479536982048
8209. as an example of the interpretation	of an arrow in the figure which exceeds four months in shaft	length in conjunction with its position in the figure: girl 2 had	a delayed onset and further delayed completion.	10.768298091776314
8210. it is of interest	that her menarche was somewhat later than the average for the girls	in this group.	18.620414079900208
8211. a similar analysis of figure 6 for the 34 boys	would necessitate quite a different conclusion about the predictive value	of onset age in forecasting their attainment of the pubescent stage.	7.932152792822336

8215. after the 42 figures	had been drawn like figures 5 and 6 classifications of the onset	ages and completion ages were summarized from them.	9.219612017067979
8216. interestingly enough the effect of the digitalis glycosides is inhibited	by a high concentration of potassium in the incubation medium and	b.	11.595583738817288
8217. organification	the precise mechanism for organification of iodine	in the thyroid is not as yet completely understood.	10.406722099111738
8218. however the formation	of organically bound iodine mainly mono-iodotyrosine can be	accomplished in cell-free systems.	13.277338463523417
8219. in the absence of additions to the	homogenate the product formed is an iodinated particulate protein	and kirkwood 1953; taurog potter and chaikoff 1955;	taurog potter tong and chaikoff 1956; serif and kirkwood	.	9.35202461627593
8220. this iodoprotein does not	appear	to be the same as what is normally present in the thyroid and there	is no evidence so far that thyroglobulin can be iodinated in vitro	by cell-free systems.	11.19391067282235
8221. in addition the iodoamino acid formed in largest	quantity in the intact thyroid is di-iodotyrosine.	13.883989561079305
8222. if tyrosine	and a system generating hydrogen peroxide are added to a cell-free homogenate	of the thyroid large quantities of free mono-iodotyrosine can	be formed.	10.475808612214703
8223. it is not clear whether this system	bears any resemblance to the in vivo iodinating mechanism and a system	generating peroxide has not been identified in thyroid tissue.	12.319659098105136
8224. on chemical	grounds it seems most likely that iodide is first converted to	f and then to f as the active iodinating species.	11.3267658759633
8225. in the thyroid	gland it appears that proteins are iodinated	and that free tyrosine and thyronine are not iodinated.	11.269635117119007
8226. iodination of	tyrosine however is not enough for the synthesis of hormone.	14.54197169776415
8227. the mono-	and di-iodotyrosine must be coupled to form tri-iodothyronine and	thyroxine.	11.572314230763848
8228. the mechanism of this coupling has been studied in some detail	with non-enzymatic systems in vitro and can be simulated by certain	di-iodotyrosine analogues.	10.568260720551194
8229. there	is so far no evidence to indicate conclusively that this coupling is	under enzymatic control.	9.599934881973276
8230. the chemical nature of the iodocompounds	is discussed below.	18.208035131740157
8231. little is known of the synthetic mechanisms for formation of	thyroglobulin.	10.884076676961827
8232. its synthesis has not been demonstrated in cell-free systems	nor has its synthesis by systems with intact thyroid cells in	vitro been unequivocally proven.	9.91479023003372
8233. there is some reason to think that thyroglobulin	synthesis may proceed independently of iodination for in	certain transplantable tumours of the rat thyroid containing essentially	no iodinated thyroglobulin a protein that appears to be thyroglobulin	has been observed in ultracentrifuge experiments	.	10.612023651223783
8234. similar findings have been noted in a patient with	congenital absence of the organification enzymes whose thyroid tissue	could only concentrate iodide.	10.450100136969525
8235. in addition depending on availability	of dietary iodine thyroglobulin may contain varying quantities of	iodine.	13.201869741795111
8236. since the circulating thyroid hormones are	the amino acids thyroxine and tri-iodothyronine	it is clear that some mechanism must exist in the thyroid gland for their	release from proteins before secretion.	10.283836024368597
8237. the presence of several proteases	and peptidases has been demonstrated in the thyroid.	12.754831829567818
8238. one of	the proteases has ph optimum of about 3.	16.930564899452293
8239. 7 and another of about 5.	14.11156078930634
8240. the finding that the concentration of one of these proteases	is increased in thyroid glands from tsh-treated animals suggests	that this protease may be active in vivo.	12.142190505439583
8241. there is no conclusive	evidence yet that either of the proteases has been prepared in highly	purified form nor is their specificity known.	12.844808202798225
8242. a study of their activity	on thyroglobulin has shown that thyroxine is not preferentially released	and that the degradation proceeds stepwise with the formation	of macromolecular intermediates.	10.509531199025869
8243. besides proteolytic enzymes the thyroid possesses de-iodinating enzymes.	11.82864881442657
8244. a microsomal de-iodinase with a ph optimum of around 8 and requiring	reduced triphosphopyridine nucleotide for activity has been	identified in the thyroid.	9.824429447122283
8245. this de-iodinating enzyme	is effective against mono- and di-iodotyrosine but does not de-iodinate	thyroxine or tri-iodothyronine.	10.628701801055547
8246. it is assumed that the iodine released	from the iodotyrosines remains in the iodide pool of the thyroid	where it is oxidised and re-incorporated into thyroglobulin.	12.591724214014052
8247. the thyroxine	and tri-iodothyronine released by proteolysis and so escaping	de-iodination presumably diffuse into the blood stream.	10.017116788685238
8248. it has been	shown that thyroglobulin binds thyroxine but the binding does not appear	to be particularly strong.	14.644181976737311
8249. it has been suggested that the plasma	thyroxine-binding proteins which have an extremely high affinity for	thyroxine compete with thyroglobulin for thyroxine	.	13.472991674986746
8250. antithyroid drugs are of two	general types.	13.915190642667962
8251. one type has a small univalent anion of the	thiocyanate-perchlorate-fluoroboride	type.	12.975174798099733
8252. this ion inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis	by interfering with iodide concentration in the thyroid.	12.237996316355508
8253. it does	not appear to affect the iodinating mechanism as such.	15.043753046630679
8254. the other	group of antithyroid agents or drugs is typified by thiouracil.	12.957840546200554
8255. these	drugs have no effect on the iodide concentrating mechanism but they	inhibit organification.	10.32081168182117
8256. the mechanism of action of these drugs has not	been completely worked out but certain of them appear to act by reducing	the oxidised form of iodine before it can iodinate thyroglobulin	.	9.033691828414252
8257. on the other hand there are a few antithyroid drugs	of this same general type such as resorcinol possessing no reducing	activity and possibly acting through formation of a complex with molecular	iodine.	11.681470809702192
8258. any of the antithyroid drugs of either type if given	in large enough doses for a long period of time will cause goitre owing	to inhibition of thyroid hormone synthesis with production of hypothyroidism.	12.488936347866163
8259. the anterior lobe of the pituitary then responds by an increased	output of tsh causing the thyroid to enlarge.	8.998955821926716
8260. the effect	of drugs that act on the iodide-concentrating mechanism can be counteracted	by addition of relatively large amounts of iodine to the diet.	10.201372470684875
8261. the antithyroid drugs of the thiouracil type however are not antagonised	by such means.	10.242653103537407
8262. besides those of the thiouracil and resorcinol	types certain antithyroid drugs have been found in naturally occurring	foods.	13.935541531463011
8263. the most conclusively identified is l-5-vinyl-2-thio-oxazolidone	which was isolated from rutabaga.	13.118587711743347
8264. it is presumed	to occur in other members of the brassica family.	26.318430008123002
8265. there is some	evidence that naturally occurring goitrogens may play a role in the development	of goitre particularly in tasmania and australia	.	14.200842114640333
8266. there it seems that the goitrogen ingested by	dairy	animals is itself inactive but is converted in the animal to an active	goitrogen which is then secreted in the milk.	10.966569661449102
8267. besides the presence of goitrogens in the diet the level of	iodine itself in the diet plays a major role in governing the activity	of the thyroid gland.	8.971735076809349
8268. in the experimental animal and in man gross	deficiency in dietary iodine causes thyroid hyperplasia hypertrophy and	increased thyroid activity	.	12.516812272569503
8269. in man the normal level of iodine in the diet and the level necessary	to prevent development of goitre is about 100 |mg per day.	8.59231672095137
8270. with	lower levels thyroid hypertrophy and increased thyroid blood-flow	enable the thyroid to accumulate a larger proportion of the daily intake	of iodine.	9.550584856950406
8271. further the gland is able to re-use a larger fraction	of the thyroid hormone de-iodinated peripherally.	10.481365332798502
8272. in the presence of	a low iodine intake thyroglobulin labelled in vivo with f is found	to contain more mono-iodotyrosine than normal the amounts of di-iodotyrosine	and iodothyronines being correspondingly reduced.	11.021448821124741
8273. this appears	to result from both a reduced amount of the iodine substrate and a more	rapid secretion of newly iodinated thyroglobulin.	9.166018824928134
8274. if the deficiency	persists long enough it is reasonable to suppose that the f label	will reflect the f distribution in the thyroglobulin.	14.289894954223488
8275. similar results	might be expected from the influence of drugs or pathological conditions	that limit iodide trapping or organification or accelerate thyroglobulin	proteolysis.	8.90446306396145
8276. the	name thyroid-stimulating hormone has been given to a substance	found in the anterior pituitary gland of all species of animal so	far	tested for its presence.	9.486104171575855
8277. the hormone has also been called thyrotrophin	or thyrotrophic hormone.	12.812859666480197
8278. at the present time we do not know by what	biochemical mechanism tsh acts on the thyroid but for bio-assay	of the hormone there are a number of properties by which its activity	may be estimated including release of iodine from the thyroid increase	in thyroid weight increase in mean height of the follicular cells	and increase in the thyroidal uptake of f.	0.0
8279. here we shall restrict	discussion to those methods that appear sufficiently sensitive and precise	for determining the concentration of tsh in blood.	9.277599693432087
8280. brown	has reviewed generally the various methods of assaying tsh	and the reader is referred to her paper for further information on	the subject.	9.418454839960127
8281. tsh	as long ago as 1851 it was pointed out by niepce	that there is a connection between the pituitary and the thyroid.	8.60977467386111
8282. this connection was clarified by smith and smith who showed	that saline extracts of fresh bovine pituitary glands could re-activate	the atrophied thyroids of hypophysectomised tadpoles.	9.712333998600402
8283. the first attempts	to isolate tsh came a decade later when janssen and loeser	used trichloroacetic acid to separate the soluble tsh	from insoluble impurities.	9.095020937052693
8284. after their work other investigators applied	salt-fractionation techniques to the problem as well as fractionation	with organic solvents such as acetone.	13.746916945307017
8285. albert has concluded	that the most active preparations of tsh made during this period	from 1931 to 1945 were probably about 100 to 300 times as potent	as the starting material.	7.338199913424672
8286. much of this work has been reviewed by	white.	24.181972537530477
8287. developments up to about 1957 have	been discussed by sonenberg.	11.272586159751768
8288. in the last few years	the application of chromatographic and other modern techniques to the	problem of isolating tsh has led to further purification	.	14.715641608577831
8289. the most	active preparations obtained by these two groups of investigators	appear to be similar in potency composition and physical properties.	8.828385447606417
8290. two problems present themselves in considering any hormone in	blood.	13.404683361367372
8291. first is the circulating form of the hormone the same as that	found in the gland where it is synthesised and stored?	10.279432575306602
8292.  second what	is its concentration in normal circumstances and in what circumstances	will this concentration depart from the normal level and in which direction?	10.586611470237468
8293. 	it is therefore necessary to consider the properties of pituitary	tsh if the fragmentary chemical information about blood	tsh is to be discussed rationally.	8.525917401627602
8294. the importance of knowing in	what chemical forms the hormone may exist is accentuated by the recent	observation that there exists an abnormally long-acting tsh in	blood drawn from many thyrotoxic patients.	9.960172089828276
8295. whether this	abnormal tsh differs chemically from pituitary tsh or	is alternatively normal tsh with its period of effectiveness	modified	by some other blood constituent cannot be decided without chemical	study of the activity in the blood of these patients and a comparison	of the substance responsible for the blood activity with pituitary	tsh.	7.467238637038142
8296. in evaluating data on the concentration of tsh	in blood one must examine critically the bio-assay methods used	to obtain them.	12.477374245944851
8297. the introduction of the united states pharmacopoeia	reference standard in 1952 and the redefinition and equating of the	usp and international units of thyroid-stimulating activity have	made it possible to compare results published by different investigators	since that time.	9.425361654498104
8298. we should like to re-emphasise the importance of	stating results solely in terms of international units of tsh activity	and of avoiding the re-introduction of biological units.	11.869851428166019
8299. for	the most part this discussion will be confined to results obtained since	a.	9.156393179952055
8300. standard preparations	the international	unit	adopted to make possible the comparison of results from different	laboratories has been defined as the	amount of activity present in 13.	9.3548994422792
8301. 5 mg of the international standard	preparation.	19.556312557672953
8302. the international unit is equipotent with the usp	unit adopted in 1952 which was defined as the amount of activity	present in 20 mg of the usp reference substance.	10.120466999967386
8303. muscle weakness is now recognized as an uncommon though	serious complication of steroid therapy with most of the synthetic	adrenal corticosteroids in clinical use.	8.546574077408936
8304. although biopsies have	shown structural changes in some of the reported cases of steroid-induced	weakness this case provides the only example known to us in which	necropsy afforded the opportunity for extensive study of multiple muscle	groups.	9.907253512146301
8305. the case described in this paper is that of an older man	who developed disabling muscular weakness while receiving a variety of	steroids for a refractory anemia.	9.718488358873435
