9589. analysis means the evaluation of subparts the comparative	ratings of parts the comprehension of the meaning of isolated elements.	9.78608604667884
9590. analysis in roleplaying is usually done for the purpose of understanding	strong and weak points of an individual or as a process to	eliminate weak parts and strengthen good parts.	10.335767022075341
9591. up to this point stress has been placed on roleplaying in terms	of individuals.	14.700827247419753
9592. roleplaying can be done for quite a different purpose:	to evaluate procedures regardless of individuals.	12.457908737315682
9593. for example:	a sales presentation can be analyzed and evaluated through roleplaying.	11.47281509929062
9594. let us now put some flesh on the theoretical bones	we have assembled by giving illustrations of roleplaying used for evaluation	and analysis.	11.071246574719058
9595. one should keep in mind that many of the exciting	possiblities of roleplaying are largely unexplored and have not been	used in industry to the extent that they have been in military and other	areas.	12.906344503751894
9596. the president of a small firm selling restaurant	products had considerable difficulty in finding suitable salesmen	for his business.	14.233580432201974
9597. interviewing checking references training the	salesmen having them go with more experienced salesmen was expensive-	and the rate of attrition due to resignations or unsatisfactory	performance was too high.	7.859868164022279
9598. it was his experience that only one good salesman	was found out of every seven hired- and only one was hired out	of every seven interviewed.	12.895792913714804
9599. roleplaying was offered as a solution-	and the procedure worked as follows: all candidates were invited	to a hotel conference room where the president explained the difficulty	he had and how unnecessary it seemed to him to hire people who	just did not work out.	7.190463929466826
9600. in place of asking salesmen to fill questionnaires	checking their references interviewing them asking them to	be tried out he told them he would prefer to test them.	11.178486246677386
9601. each person	was to enter the testing room carrying a suitcase of samples.	11.326924905405464
9602. each salesman	was to read a sheet containing a description of the product.	16.2269535842736
9603. in	the testing room he was to make successively three presentations	to three different people.	11.355757428530968
9604. in the testing room three of the veteran	salesmen served as antagonists.	19.556424362412343
9605. one handled the salesman in a	friendly manner another in a rough manner and the third in a hesitating	manner.	9.936961324245127
9606. each was told to purchase material if he felt like it.	12.278630237849624
9607. the	antagonists came in one at a time and did not see or hear the other	presentations.	11.401292627424878
9608. after each presentation the antagonist wrote his judgment	of the salesmen; and so did the observers consisting of the	president three of his salesmen and a psychologist.	9.917802389492007
9609. ten salesmen	were tested in the morning and ten more in the afternoon.	15.647596217001475
9610. this procedure	was repeated one day a month for four months.	20.32190677318781
9611. the batting average	of one success out of seven increased to one out of three.	11.833392450394928
9612. the president	of the firm calculating expenses alone felt his costs had dropped	one-half while success in selection had improved over one hundred	per cent.	11.245898617901863
9613. the reason for the value of this procedure was simply	that the applicants were tested at work in different situations	by the judgment of a number of experts who could see how the salesmen	conducted themselves with different but typical restaurant owners	and managers.	9.943323703071304
9614. they were in a sense tried out in realistic situations.	25.2511384333004
9615. from the point of view of the applicants less time	was wasted in being evaluated- and they got a meal out of it as well	as some insights into their performances.	11.737456575248826
9616. another use of roleplaying	for evaluation illustrates how this procedure can be used in	real life situations without special equipment or special assistants during	the daily course of work.	9.95689687724601
9617. the position of receptionist was	opened in a large office and an announcement was made to the other	girls already working that they could apply for this job which had higher	prestige and slightly higher salary than typing and clerking positions.	10.135782038749298
9618. all applicants were generally familiar with the work of the receptionist.	20.97955928135454
9619. at the end of work one day the personnel man took the applicants	one at a time asked them to sit behind the receptionist's desk	and he then played the role of a number of people who might come to	the receptionist with a number of queries and for a number of purposes.	12.805670758596428
9620. each girl was independently tested by the personnel man and	he served not only as the director but as the antagonist and the observer.	11.240669508533346
9621. somewhat to his surprise he found that one girl whom	he would never have considered for the job since she had appeared somewhat	mousy and also had been in the office a relatively short time did	the most outstanding job of playing the role of receptionist showing	wit sparkle and aplomb.	8.302963049573412
9622. she was hired and was found to be entirely	satisfactory when she played the role eight hours a day.	12.039614131241997
9623. in considering roleplaying for analysis we enter a more complex area	since we are now no longer dealing with a simple over-all decision	but rather with the examination and evaluation of many elements seen	in dynamic functioning.	8.630459825511101
9624. some cases in evidence of the use of roleplaying	for analysis may help explain the procedure.	13.949820755699756
9625. an engineer	had been made the works manager of a firm supplanting a retired employee	who had been considered outstandingly successful.	8.932327563379724
9626. the engineer had	more than seven years of experience in the firm was well trained was	considered a hard worker was respected by his fellow engineers for	his technical competence and was regarded as a comer.	11.045694065099942
9627. however	he turned out to be a complete failure in his new position.	15.898848380674586
9628. he seemed	to antagonize everyone.	25.66056898750899
9629. turnover rates of personnel went up production	dropped and morale was visibly reduced.	9.070074471681158
9630. despite the fact that he	was regarded as an outstanding engineer he seemed to be a very poor	administrator although no one quite knew what was wrong with him.	16.266888300162627
9631. at	the insistence of his own supervisor- the president of the firm he	enrolled in a course designed to develop leaders.	10.710334321778824
9632. he played	a number of typical situations before observers other supervisors who	kept notes and then explained to him in detail what he did they thought	was wrong.	11.537832642777731
9633. entirely concerned with efficiency he was merciless in	criticizing people who made mistakes condemning them to too great an	extent.	8.026882005052693
9634. he did not really listen to others had little interest in their	ideas and wanted to have his own way- which was the only right	way.	15.996293751760502
9635. the entire group of managers explained in great detail a number	of human relations errors that he made.	9.625474991728858
9636. one by one these	errors were discussed and one by one he rejected accepting them as errors.	13.825014304523112
9637. he admitted his behavior and defended it.	15.231465433954329
9638. he refused to change	his approach and instead he attacked high and low- the officials for	their not backing him and subordinates for their laxness stupidity	and stubbornness.	9.803396931973506
9639. after the diagnosing he left the course convinced	that it could do him no good.	12.47638323995676
9640. we may say that his problem	was diagnosed but that he refused treatment.	16.417742217903754
9641. the engineer turned works	manager had a particular view of life- and refused to change it.	10.817702353179955
9642. we	may say that his attitude was foolish since he may have been a success	had he learned some human relations skills; or we may say that	his attitude was commendable showing his independence of mind in his	refusal to adjust to the opinions of others.	9.246191403409371
9643. in any case he refused	to accept the implications of the analysis that he needed to be made	over.	12.867200394632384
9644. another case may be given in illustration of a successful	use of analysis and also of the employment of a procedure for intensive	analysis.	10.747901268200886
9645. in a course for supermarket operators a district manager	who had been recently appointed to his position after being outstandingly	successful as a store manager found that in supervising other	managers he was having a difficult time.	8.155694885198978
9646. on playing some typical situations	before a jury of his peers he showed some characteristics rated	as unsatisfactory.	11.972993158022506
9647. he was told he displayed for example a sense	of superiority- and he answered: well i am supposed to know	all the answers aren't i?	9.909403934758586
9648.  he was criticized for his curtness	and abruptness- and he answered: i am not working to become	popular.	14.059310915344689
9649. on being criticized for his arbitrary behavior- he answered:	i have to make decisions.	11.696103978849662
9650. in short	as frequently happens in analyses the individual feels threatened and	defends himself.	13.53780763738168
9651. however in this case the district manager was led	to see the errors of his ways.	14.175853827186106
9652. the necessary step between diagnosis and	training is acceptance of the validity of the criticisms.	15.926370692743143
9653. how this	was accomplished may be described since this sometimes is a crucial	problem.	10.645258980112507
9654. the director helped tailor-make a check list of the district	manager's errors by asking various observers to write out sentences	commenting on the mistakes they felt he made.	10.968334976663295
9655. these errors were	then collected and written on a blackboard condensing similar ideas.	10.100086864412003
9656. eighteen errors were located and then the director asked each individual	to vote whether or not they felt that this manager had made the	particular errors.	10.90123135154762
9657. they were asked to vote true if they thought	they had seen him make the error false if they thought he had	not; and cannot say if they were not certain.	9.288939888133184
9658. the manager	sat behind the group so he could see and count the hands that went	up and the director wrote the numbers on the blackboard.	10.351843785236357
9659. no comments	were made during the voting.	14.899382480025864
9660. the results looked as follows: f.	19.79923841577052
9661. the first eight of these eighteen statements which received	at least one-half of the votes were duplicated to form an analysis	checklist for the particular manager and when this particular manager	roleplayed in other situations the members checked any items that appeared.	8.212445289096639
9662. to prevent the manager from deliberately controlling himself	only during the sessions they were rather lengthy	the situations were imperfectly described to the manager so that	he would not know what to expect new antagonists were brought on the	scene unexpectedly and the antagonists were instructed to deliberately	behave in such ways as to upset the manager and get him to operate in	a manner for which he had been previously criticized.	9.47960213767271
9663. after	every session the check marks were totaled up and graphed and in this	way the supervisor's progress was charted.	8.026882005052693
9664. in life	we learn to play our roles and we freeze into patterns which become	so habitual that we are not really aware of what we do.	12.191253656845689
9665. we can see	others more clearly than we can see ourselves and others can see us	better than we see ourselves.	10.552669987043382
9666. to learn what we do is the first step	for improvement.	15.656934517697971
9667. to accept the validity of the judgments of others is	the second step.	14.251926688570894
9668. to want to change is the third step.	17.797308820546554
9669. to practice new	procedures under guided supervision and with constant feedback is the	fourth step.	10.348303960455212
9670. to use these new ways in daily life is the last step.	13.562092939331109
9671. roleplaying used for analysis follows these general steps leading to	training.	9.669550099771405
9672. when an evaluative situation is set up and no concern	is with the details that lead to an over-all estimate we say that	roleplaying is used for evaluation.	11.383363764946722
9673. observers can see a person engaged	in spontaneous behavior and watch him operating in a totalistic fashion.	8.61869229186204
9674. this behavior is more veridical- or true than other	testing behavior for some types of evaluation and so can give quick and	accurate estimates of complex functioning.	9.88976263206359
9675. while roleplaying	for testing is not too well understood at the present time it represents	one of the major uses of this procedure.	0.0
9676. training	the objective of this chapter is to clarify	the distinctions between spontaneity theory and other training concepts.	10.125147890601434
9677. in addition the basic approach utilized in applying roleplaying will	be reviewed.	17.000400718489775
9678. the goal will be to provide the reader with an integrated	rationale to aid him in applying roleplaying techniques in this	unique training area.	11.840893748964605
9679. the reasons for extracting this particular roleplaying	application from the previous discussion of training are twofold:	spontaneity training theory is unique and relatively new.	9.782508071278205
9680. it is not easy for the therapist to discern when in the patient's	communicating an introject has appeared and is holding sway.	16.055786078400967
9681. one	learns to become alert to changes in his vocal tone- to his voice's	suddenly shifting to a quality not like his usual one a quality	which sounds somehow artificial or in some instances parrotlike.	7.469389687977654
9682. the	content of his words may lapse back into monotonous repetition as	if a phonograph needle were stuck in one groove; only seldom is it so	simple as to be a matter of his obviously parroting some timeworn axiom	common to our culture which he has evidently heard over and over	from a parent until he experiences it as part of him.	9.411731739018052
9683. one hebephrenic	woman often became submerged in what felt to me like a somehow	phony experience of pseudo-emotion during which despite her wracking	sobs and streaming cheeks i felt only a cold annoyance with her.	8.30632930441514
9684. eventually such incidents became more sporadic and more sharply demarcated	from her day-after-day behavior and in one particular session	after several minutes of such behavior- which as usual went on	without any accompanying words from her- she asked eagerly did	you see granny?	8.374395021424876
9685.  at first i did not know what she meant; i	thought she must be seeing me as some one who had just come from	seeing	her grandmother in their distant home-city.	10.381743019500924
9686. then i realized that	she had been deliberately showing me this time what granny was like;	and when i replied in this spirit she corroborated my hunch.	10.130880989159342
9687. at another phase in the therapy when a pathogenic mother-introject	began to emerge more and more upon the investigative scene she muttered	in a low but intense voice to herself i hate that woman inside	me! i could evoke no further elaboration from her about this;	but a few seconds later she was standing directly across the room	from me looking me in the eyes and saying in a scathingly condemnatory	tone your	father despises you! again i at first misconstrued	this disconcertingly intense communication and i quickly cast	through my mind to account for her being able to speak with such utter	conviction of an opinion held by my father now several years deceased.	6.975848415126124
9688. then i replied coldly if you despise me why don't you	say so directly?	13.430565410340128
9689.  she looked confused at this and i felt sure	it had been a wrong response for me to make.	10.516409745435464
9690. it then occurred to me to	ask is that what that woman told you?	15.384040762164279
9691.  she clearly agreed	that this had been the case.	15.23704424123961
9692. i realized now that she had been showing	me in what impressed me as being a very accurate way something her	mother had once said to her; it was as if she was showing me one of	the reasons why she hated that woman inside her.	9.307250729369251
9693. what had been an unmanageably	powerful introject was now despite its continuing charge	of energy disconcerting to me sufficiently within control of her ego	that she could use it to show me what this introjected mother was like.	8.149230433455084
9694. earlier this woman had been so filled with a chaotic variety	of introjects that at times when she was in her room alone it would	sound to a passerby as though there were several different persons in	the room as she would vocalize in various kinds of voice.	9.673017706396973
9695. a somewhat	less fragmented hebephrenic patient of mine who used to often seclude	herself in her room often sounded through the closed door- as i	would find on passing by between our sessions- for all the world	like two persons a scolding mother and a defensive child.	7.411833463682986
9696. particularly	hard for the therapist to grasp are those instances in which	the patient is manifesting an introject traceable to something in the	therapist some aspect of the therapist of which the latter is himself	only poorly aware and the recognition of which as a part of himself	he finds distinctly unwelcome.	10.44676791999982
9697. i have found time and again that	some bit of particularly annoying and intractable behavior on the part	of a patient rests in the final analysis on this basis; and only	when i can acknowledge this to myself as being indeed an aspect of	my personality does it cease to be a prominently troublesome aspect of	the patient's behavior.	8.213592142627272
9698. for example one hebephrenic man used to	annoy me month after month by saying whenever i got up to leave and	made my fairly steoreotyped comment that i would be seeing him on the	following day or whenever you're welcome in a notably condescending	fashion- as though it were his due for me to thank him	for the privilege of spending the hour with him and he were thus pointing	up my failure to utter a humbly grateful thank you to him	at the end of each session.	9.714856116199929
9699. eventually it became clear to me partly	with the aid of another schizophrenic patient who could point out my	condescension to me somewhat more directly that this man with his	condescending	you're welcome was very accurately personifying	an element of obnoxious condescension which had been present in my own	demeanor over these months on each of these occasions when i had	bid him good-bye with the consoling note each time that the healing	christ would be stooping to dispense this succor to the poor suffered	again on the morrow.	7.153473780319125
9700. another patient a paranoid woman for many	months infuriated not only me but the ward-personnel and her fellow	patients by arrogantly behaving as though she owned the whole building	as though she were the only person in it whose needs were to be met.	9.265895490527749
9701. this behavior on her part subsided only after i had come to see the	uncomfortably close similarity between on the one hand her arranging	the ventilation of the common living room to her own liking or turning	the television off or on without regard to the wishes of the others	and on the other hand my own coming stolidly into her room despite	her persistent and vociferous objections bringing my big easy chair	with me usually shutting the windows of her room which she preferred	to keep in a very cold state and plunking myself down in my chair-	in short behaving as if i owned her room.	7.78829508900578
9702. here a variety of meanings and emotions are concentrated or reduced	in their communicative expression to some comparatively simple-seeming	verbal or nonverbal statement.	11.09943746855014
9703. one finds for example	that a terse and stereotyped	verbal expression seeming at first to be	a mere hollow convention reveals itself over the months of therapy	as the vehicle for expressing the most varied and intense feelings and	the most unconventional of meanings.	7.564115084626706
9704. more than anything it is the	therapist's intuitive sensing of these latent meanings in the stereotype	which helps these meanings to become revealed something like a spread-out	deck of cards on sporadic occasions over the passage of the	patient's and his months of work together.	9.570868615402722
9705. one cannot assume of course	that all these accumulated meanings were inherent in the stereotype	at the beginning of the therapy or at any one time later on when	the stereotype was uttered; probably it is correct to think of it as	a matter of a well-grooved stereotyped mode of expression- and no	or but a few other communicational grooves as yet- being there	available for the patient's use as newly-emerging emotions and	ideas well up in him over the course of months.	8.369006275294103
9706. but it is true that the	therapist can sense when he hears this stereotype that there are	at this moment many emotional determinants at work in it a blurred babel	of indistinct voices which have yet to become clearly delineated from	one another.	12.036409387614489
9707. sometimes it is not a verbal stereotype- a	how are you now?	15.612540294179587
9708.  or an i want to go home or whatever-	but a nonverbal one which reveals itself gradually as the condensed	expression of more than one latent meaning.	12.533143778841218
9709. a hebephrenic man used	to give a repetitious wave of his hand a number of times during his	largely-silent	hours with his therapist.	9.22714845677061
9710. when the therapist came to feel	on sufficiently sure ground with him to ask him what is that	bill- hello or farewell?	12.473717628470618
9711.  the patient replied both dearie-	two in one.	15.448137229179506
9712. of all the possible forms of nonverbal expression	that which seems best to give release and communicational expression	to complex and undifferentiated feelings is laughter.	11.335190725128493
9713. it is	no coincidence that the hebephrenic patient the most severely dedifferentiated	of all schizophrenic patients shows as one of his characteristic	symptoms laughter- laughter which now makes one feel scorned	or hated which now makes one feel like weeping or which now gives	one a glimpse of the bleak and empty expanse of man's despair; and	which more often than all these conveys a welter of feelings which	could in no way be	conveyed by any number of words words which are so	unlike this welter in being formed and discrete from one another.	7.554239410890506
9714. to	a much less full extent the hebephrenic person's belching or flatus	has a comparable communicative function; in working with these patients	the therapist eventually gets to do some at least private mulling	over of the possible meaning of a belch or the passage of flatus	not only because he is reduced to this for lack of anything else to analyze	but also because he learns that even these animal-like sounds constitute	forms of communication in which from time to time quite different	things are being said long before the patient can become sufficiently	aware of these as distinct feelings and concepts to say them	in words.	8.256879854858667
9715. as i have been intimating in the schizophrenic-	and perhaps also in the dreams of the neurotic; this is a question	which i have no wish to take up- condensation is a phenomenon in which	one finds not a condensed expression of various feelings and ideas	which are at an unconscious level well sorted out but rather a condensed	expression of feelings and ideas which even in the unconscious	have yet to become well differentiated from one another.	8.14434528079651
9716. freeman	cameron and mcghie in their description of the disturbances of thinking	found in chronic schizophrenic patients say in regard to condensation	that h the lack of adequate discrimination between the	self and the environment and the objects contained therein h in itself	is the prototypical condensation.	9.154473347287153
9717. in my experience a	great many of the patient's more puzzling verbal communications are	so for the reason that concrete meanings have not become differentiated	from figurative meanings in his subjective experience.	9.421261180246672
9718. thus he may	be referring to some concrete thing or incident in his immediate environment	by some symbolic-sounding hyperbolic reference to transcendental	events on the global scene.	9.771403120053224
9719. recently for example a paranoid woman's	large-scale philosophizing in the session about the intrusive	curiosity which has become in her opinion a deplorable characteristic	of mid-twentieth-century human culture developed itself before the	end of the session into a suspicion that i was surreptitiously peeking	at her partially exposed breast as indeed i was.	7.333086056787253
9720. or equally	often a concretistic-seeming particularistic-seeming statement may consist	with its mundane exterior in a form of poetry- may be full	of meaning and emotion when interpreted as a figurative expression:	a metaphor a smile an allegory or some other symbolic mode of speaking.	9.351594144157502
9721. of such hidden meanings the patient himself is more often	than not entirely unaware.	11.228049622321159
9722. his subjective experience may be a remarkably	concretistic one.	15.933779352900387
9723. one hebephrenic women confided to me i	live in a world of words as if to her words were fully concrete	objects; burnham in his excellent article concerning schizophrenic	communication includes mention of similar clinical material.	9.10152424202935
9724. a borderline schizophrenic young man told me that to him the various	theoretical concepts about which he had been expounding in a most articulate	fashion during session after session with me were like great	cubes of almost tangibly solid matter up in the air above him; as he	spoke i was reminded of the great bales of cargo which are swung high	in the air from a docked steamship.	9.721524957487015
9725. the many linguistic techniques for reducing the amount of dictionary	information that have been proposed all organize the dictionary's	contents around prefixes stems suffixes etc.	9.519235923390848
9726. a significant	reduction	in the voume of store information is thus realized especially	for a highly inflected language such as russian.	10.331010770606548
9727. for english the reduction	in size is less striking.	13.609016979205112
9728. this approach requires that:	each text word be separated into smaller elements to establish a correspondence	between the occurrence and dictionary entries and the information	retrieved from several entries in the dictionary be synthesized	into a description of the particular word.	10.44177795990109
9729. the logical scheme used	to accomplish the former influences the placement of information in	the dictionary file.	9.646584389395406
9730. implementation of the latter requires storage of	information needed only for synthesis.	14.816750301984575
9731. we suggest the application	of certain data-processing techniques as a solution to the problem.	12.9372129620693
9732. but first we must define two terms so that their meaning will be	clearly understood:  form- any unique sequence of alphabetic	characters that can appear in a language preceded and followed	by a space.	9.506529901672298
9733. occurrence- an instance of a form in text.	10.530932308755343
9734. we propose a method for selecting only dictionary information	required by the text being translated and a means for passing the information	directly to the occurrences in text.	9.666762164744704
9735. we accomplish this by compiling	a list of text forms as text is read by the computer.	9.833174109624084
9736. a random-storage	scheme based on the spelling of forms provides an economical	way to compile this text-form list.	11.945970697687185
9737. dictionary forms found to match	forms in the text list are marked.	9.345058977386529
9738. a location in the computer store	is also named for each marked form; dictionary information about the	form stored at this location can be retrieved directly by occurrences	of the form in text.	8.910884728010025
9739. finally information is retrieved from the dictionary	as required by stages of the translation process- the grammatic	description for sentence-structure determination equivalent-choice	information for semantic analysis and target-language equivalents	for output construction.	7.841393323919072
9740. the dictionary is a form dictionary	at least in the sense that complete forms are used as the basis for matching	text occurrences with dictionary entries.	16.13321421452561
9741. also the dictionary	is divided into at least two parts: the list of dictionary forms and	the file of information that pertains to these forms.	10.257501148037221
9742. a more detailed	description of dictionary operations- text lookup and dictionary	modification- give a clearer picture.	12.296021707234328
9743. text lookup as we will	describe it consists of three steps.	11.378780338421992
9744. the first is compiling a list	of text forms assigning an information cell to each and replacing text	occurrences with the information cell assigned to the form of each	occurrence.	10.796625962503985
9745. for this step the computer memory is separated into three	regions: cells in the w-region are used for storage of the forms	in the text-form list; cells in the x-region and y region	are reserved as information cells for text forms.	7.881788930789685
9746. when an occurrence	f is isolated during text reading a random memory address f	the address of a cell in the x-region is computed from the form	of f.	9.696981859400154
9747. let f denote the form of f.	19.16350798751663
9748. if cell f has not previously	been assigned as the information cell of a form in the text-form	list it is now assigned as the information cell of f.	10.594283653460662
9749. the form itself	is stored in the next available cells of the w-region beginning	in cell f.	13.255445807050117
9750. the address f and the number of cells required to	store the form are written in f; the information cell f is saved	to represent the text occurrence.	11.318746374200517
9751. text reading continues with the next	occurrence.	11.867291106449708
9752. let us assume that f is identical to the form	of an occurrence f which preceded f in the text.	11.551348807723544
9753. when this situation	exists the address f will equal f which was produced from f.	11.50188505177375
9754. if f was assigned as the information cell for f the routine can	detect that f is identical to f by comparing f with the form	stored at location f.	9.659090496756573
9755. the address f is stored in the cell f.	12.204673387645432
9756. when	as in this case the two forms match the address f is saved to	represent the occurrence f.	10.937130340964535
9757. text reading continues with the next	occurrence.	11.867291106449708
9758. a third situation is possible.	22.071666207767368
9759. the formula for computing	random addresses from the form of each occurrence will not give a	distinct address for each distinct form.	10.006956367629824
9760. thus when more than one distinct	form leads to a particular cell in the x-region a chain of	information cells must be created to accommodate the forms one cell	in the chain for each form.	10.241253456573949
9761. if f leads to an address f that is equal	to the address computed from f even though f does not match f	the chain of information cells is extended from f by storing the	address of the next available cell in the y-region f in f.	7.593382857873045
9762. the	cell f becomes the second information cell in the chain and is assigned	as the information cell of f.	9.412054727957594
9763. a third cell can be added by storing	the address of another y-cell in f; similarly as many cells	are added as are required.	9.18988997023239
9764. each information cell in the chain contains	the address of the y-cell where the form to which it is assigned	is stored.	12.006869101738951
9765. each cell except the last in the chain also contains	the address of the y-cell that is the next element of the chain;	the absence of such a link in the last cell indicates the end of the	chain.	9.768094494376909
9766. hence when the address f is computed from f the cell f	and	all y-cells in its chain must be inspected to determine whether	f is already in the form list or whether it should be added to the form	list and the chain.	10.487889360196874
9767. when the information cell for f has been determined	it is saved as a representation of f.	10.803537984830022
9768. text reading continues	with the next occurrence.	13.915190642667962
9769. text reading is terminated when	a pre-determined number of forms have been stored in the text-form list.	8.29272515769823
9770. this initiates the second step of glossary lookup- connecting the	information cell of forms in the text-form list to dictionary forms.	10.48620007506182
9771. each form represented by the dictionary is looked up in the text-form	list.	13.188666762563013
9772. each time a dictionary form matches a text form the information	cell of the matching text form is saved.	10.625339245406959
9773. the number of dictionary	forms skipped since the last one matched is also saved.	14.701848624334346
9774. these two pieces	of information for each dictionary form that is matched by a text	form constitute the table of dictionary usage.	10.43193895125053
9775. if each text form is	marked when matched with a dictionary form the text forms not contained	in the dictionary can be identified when all dictionary forms have	been read.	8.331558999077057
9776. the appropriate action for handling these forms can be taken	at that time.	12.818500345915622
9777. each dictionary form is looked up in the text-form	list by the same method used to look up a new text occurrence in	the form list during text reading.	9.363436047383692
9778. a random address f that lies within	the x-region of memory mentioned earlier is computed from the	i-th dictionary form.	10.331010770606548
9779. if cell f is an information cell it and	any information cells in the y-region that have been linked to f	each contain an address in the w-region where a potentially matching	form is stored.	8.083607816693855
9780. the dictionary form is compared with each of these	text forms.	14.82755956311037
9781. when a match is found an entry is made in the table of	dictionary usage.	13.833946735069613
9782. if cell f is not an information cell we conclude	that the i-th dictionary form is not in the text list.	13.870866209505621
9783. these	two steps essentially complete the lookup operation.	11.118618003375188
9784. the final step	merely uses the table of dictionary usage to select the dictionary information	that pertains to each form matched in the text-form list and	uses the list of information cells recorded in text order to attach	the appropriate information to each occurrence in text.	8.944221160015212
9785. the list of	text forms in the w-region of memory and the contents of the information	cells in the x and y-regions are no longer required.	8.677007509580344
9786. only	the assignment of the information cells is important.	13.124727071899564
9787. the	first stage of translation after glossary lookup is structural analysis	of the input text.	9.442064507626279
9788. the grammatical description of each occurrence in	the text must be retrieved from the dictionary to permit such an analysis.	10.351870993004653
9789. a description of this process will serve to illustrate how any	type of information can be retrieved from the dictionary and attached	to each text occurrence.	9.239416239795414
9790. the grammatic descriptions of all forms	in the dictionary are recorded in a separate part of the dictionary	file.	11.95431889504004
9791. the order is identical to the ordering of the forms they describe.	12.776686676726651
9792. when entries are being retrieved from this file the table of dictionary	usage indicates which entries to skip and which entries to store	in the computer.	9.946474180143396
9793. this selection-rejection process takes place as the	file is read.	12.508271769542546
9794. each entry that is selected for storage is written into	the next available cells of the w-region.	10.590283081361788
9795. the address of the	first cell and the number of cells used is written in the information	cell for the form.	12.393021208566594
9796. when the complete file has been	read the grammatic descriptions for all text forms found in the dictionary	have been stored in the w-region; the information cell assigned	to each text form contains the address of the grammatic description	of the form it represents.	9.694063208346838
9797. hence the description of each text	occurrence can be retrieved by reading the list of text-ordered information-cell	addresses and outputting the description indicated by the information	cell for each occurrence.	9.347760840630936
9798. the only requirements on	dictionary information made by the text-lookup operation are that each	form represented by the dictionary be available for lookup in the text-form	list and that information for each form be available in a sequence	identical with the sequence of the forms.	10.188092959591897
9799. this leaves the ordering	of entries variable.	15.755914550576229
9800. two very useful ways for modifying a form-dictionary	are the addition to the dictionary of complete paradigms	rather than single forms and the application of a single change to more	than one dictionary form.	10.13747203832327
9801. the former is intended to decrease the amount	of work necessary to extend dictionary coverage.	11.248477477411878
9802. the latter is useful	for modifying information about some or all forms of a word hence	reducing the work required to improve dictionary contents.	12.619705703930842
9803. applying	the techniques developed at harvard for generating a paradigm from	a representative form and its classification we can add all forms of	a word to the dictionary at once.	7.5253734427739
9804. an extension of the principle would	permit entering a grammatic description of each form.	13.664686243965894
9805. equivalents could	be assigned to the paradigm either at the time it is added to the	dictionary or after the word has been studied in context.	9.955473071706257
9806. thus one can	think of a dictionary entry as a word rather than a form.	13.046296339527323
9807. if	all forms of a paradigm are grouped together within the dictionary	a considerable reduction in the amount of information required is possible.	8.838184801819748
9808. for example the inflected forms of a word can be represented	insofar as regular inflection allows by a stem and a set of endings to	be attached.	12.639814982517795
9809. the full forms can be derived from such information	just prior to the lookup of the form in the text-form list.	10.511987875993992
9810. similarly if the equivalents for the forms of a word do not vary the	equivalents need be entered only once with an indication that they	apply	to each form.	9.362718968525545
9811. the dictionary system is in no way dependent upon	such summarization or designed around it.	10.962864524965967
9812. when irregularity and variation	prevent summarizing information is written in complete detail.	13.838615833370469
9813. entries	are summarized only when by doing so the amount of information	retained in the dictionary is reduced and the time required for dictionary	operations is decreased.	8.080139376337113
9814. in sentences patterns of stress are determined by complex combinations	of influences that can only be suggested here.	11.909012793224992
9815. the tendency is toward	putting dominant stress at the end.	12.204673387645432
9816. there is a parallel to this tendency	in the assignment of time in long-known hymn tunes.	21.52306330005694
9817. thus the	first lines of one of charles wesley's hymns are as follows.	13.15179892743178
9818. a charge to keep i have a god to glorify.	14.786088380021804
9819. in the	tune to which this hymn is most often sung boylston the syllables	have and fy ending their lines have twice the time any	other syllables have.	8.476399237487897
9820. dominant stress is of course more than extended	duration and normally centers on syllables that would have primary stress	or phrase stress if the words or longer units they are parts of	were spoken alone: a dominant stress given to glorify would normally	center on its first syllable rather than its last.	8.457112550018365
9821. but the parallel	is significant.	28.987746445070243
9822. when the answer to what's wrong now?	25.811654499803765
9823.  is bill's	broken a chair dominant stress will usually be on the complement	a chair.	11.283686619270213
9824. from the point of view of syntactic analysis the	head word in the statement is the predicator has broken and from	the point of view of meaning it would seem that the trouble centers	in the breaking; but dominant stress will be assigned to broken	only in rather exceptional versions of the sentence.	11.82865097816116
9825. in i know one	thing dominant stress will usually be on the complement one thing;	in one thing i know it will usually be on the predicator know.	9.981165395596813
9826. in small-town people are very friendly dominant stress will	generally be on the complement very friendly; in the double sentence	the smaller the town the friendlier the people it will generally	be on the subjects the town and the people.	9.241728179818672
9827. in what's	a linguist?	28.00994552289681
9828.  dominant stress will generally be on the subject	a linguist; in who's a linguist?	10.971173409318752
9829.  it will generally be on	the complement a linguist.	20.541796642112335
9830. dominant stress is on her luggage	both in that's her luggage where her luggage is the complement	and in there's her luggage where it is the subject.	10.200757826826257
9831. adverbial	second complements however are likely not to have dominant stress	when they terminate sentences.	9.403959211459474
9832. if the answer to what was that noise?	24.409571533279873
9833. 	is george put the cat out dominant stress will ordinarily	be on the first complement the cat not the second complement	out.	8.76702917753222
9834. final adjuncts may or may not have dominant stress.	18.871453068887742
9835. if the	answer to what was that noise?	16.122160126925362
9836.  is george reads the news emotionally	dominant stress may or may not be on the adjunct emotionally.	15.487567530455335
9837. when prepositional complements are divided as in what are you	looking for?	11.801985816950635
9838.  they are likely to lose dominant stress.	25.181019185709186
9839. context	is of extreme importance.	14.19641732877796
9840. what is new in the context is likely	to be made more prominent than what is not.	15.695263957884
9841. thus in a context in which	there has been discussion of snow but mention of local conditions is	new dominant stress will probably be on here in it rarely snows	here but in a context in which there has been discussion of local	weather but no mention of snow dominant stress will probably be on snows.	8.68084994267561
9842. the personal pronouns and substitute one are normally unstressed	because they refer to what is prominent in the immediate context.	11.839945775772456
9843. in i'll go with george dominant stress is probably on george;	but if george has just been mentioned prominently	what is said is probably	i'll go with him and dominant stress is probably on the preposition	with.	8.238210901657986
9844. when a gesture accompanies who's he?	23.602766992012366
9845.  the personal	pronoun has dominant stress because he has not been mentioned	previously.	13.003301136325648
9846. if both george and a piece of information george	does not have are prominent in the context but the idea of telling george	is new then dominant stress will probably be on tell in why	not tell george?	10.980588902048254
9847.  but when what is new in a particular context	is also fairly obvious there is normally only light stress or no stress	at all.	9.943590547721948
9848. thus the unstressed it of it rarely snows here gets	its significance from its use with snows: nothing can snow snow	but it.	10.685034531074768
9849. in there aren't many young people in the neighborhood	the modifier young takes dominant stress away from its head	people: the fact that the young creatures of interest are people	seems rather obvious.	9.767769893952947
9850. if women replaced people it would normally	have dominant stress.	16.150820779199535
9851. in i have things to do the word things	makes little real contribution to meaning and has weaker stress	than do.	10.116916825998953
9852. if work is substituted for things	it will have dominant stress.	16.130641940767262
9853. in i	know one thing dominant stress is likely to go to one rather than	to semantically pale thing.	13.048048054550643
9854. in i knew you when you were a child	and you were pretty then dominant stress on then implies that	the young woman spoken to is still pretty.	10.234820400326466
9855. dominant stress on pretty	would be almost insulting here.	10.530932308755343
9856. in the written language then	can be underlined or italicized to guide the reader here but much	of the time the written language simply depends on the reader's alertness	and a careless reader will have to back up and reread.	11.601443113570392
9857. often dominant stress simply indicates a centering of attention or emotion.	10.213895751192704
9858. thus in it's incredible what that boy can eat dominant stress	is likely to be on incredible and eat will have strong	stress also.	11.882329286263163
9859. in she has it in for george dominant stress will ordinarily	be on in where the notion of stored-up antipathy seems to	center.	9.0082069863666
9860. in we're painting at our garage strong stress on at	indicates that the job being done is not real painting but simply an	effort at painting.	10.07506465980604
9861. where there is comparison or contrast dominant	stresses normally operate to center attention.	11.254374053366822
9862. thus in his friends	are stranger than his sisters' strong stresses are normal for his	and sisters' but in his friends are stranger than his sisters	strong stresses are normal for friends and sisters.	9.66549728365765
9863. in	he's hurting himself more than he's hurting you both himself	and you have stronger stress than they would ordinarily have if	there were no contrast.	7.556878632736834
9864. in is she chinese or japanese?	20.472413001720973
9865.  the	desire to contrast the first parts of words which are alike in their last	components produces an exceptional disregard of the normal patterns	of stress of chinese and japanese.	7.302391158290319
9866. sometimes strong stress	serves to focus an important secondary relationship.	13.249045993286838
9867. thus in mary	wrote an account of the trip first strong stress on mary marks	mary as the first in a series of people who wrote accounts of the trip	strong stress on wrote marks the writing as the first of a series	of actions of mary's concerned with an account of her trip	and strong stress	on trip makes the trip the first of a series of subjects about	which mary wrote accounts.	10.617952766350236
9868. in hunger stimulates man too the situation	is very similar.	15.872057262990682
9869. strong stress on hunger treats hunger as	an additional stimulus strong stress on stimulates treats stimulation	as an additional effect of hunger strong stress on man treats	man as an additional creature who responds to the stimulation of hunger.	6.965981032758054
9870. here again in the written language it is possible to help the	reader get his stresses right by using underlining or italics but much	of the time there is simply reliance on his understanding in the light	of context.	10.942799504461982
9871. when a word represents a larger construction of	which it is the only expressed part it normally has more stress than	it would have in fully expressed construction.	9.937048309806933
9872. thus when yes i	have is the response to have you finished reading the paper?	12.646165227783504
9873. 	the stress on have which here represents have finished reading	the paper is quite strong.	8.62963042412541
9874. in mack's the leader at camp but	jack is here the is of the second main declarative represents	is the leader and therefore has stress.	10.781313030068256
9875. mack's the leader at	camp but jack's here with this is deprived of stress makes	here the complement in the clause.	7.9139724503302755
9876. in of all the suggestions that	were made his was the silliest the possessive his represents	his suggestion and is stressed.	11.91343137667445
9877. when go represents itself and	a complement in which	boat did jack go on?	11.288807818081464
9878.  it has strong stress; when it represents	only itself and on which is its complement	on has stronger stress	than go does.	13.54965732200279
9879. omission of a subordinator pronoun however does	not result in an increase in stress on a prepositional adverb for which	the subordinator pronoun would be object.	8.073251234231604
9880. thus to has light stress	both in that was the conclusion that i came to and in that	was the conclusion i came to.	13.173943612897949
9881. but when to represents to consciousness	in that was the moment that i came to and similarly	in that was the moment i came to there is much stronger stress	on to.	11.899720573696943
9882. in i wanted to tell him but i was afraid to the final	to is lightly stressed because it represents to tell him.	12.779609974939337
9883. in	to tell him of course to is normally unstressed.	11.689200547222619
9884. when i	have instructions to leave is equivalent in meaning to i	have instructions that i am to leave this place dominant stress	is ordinarily on leave.	10.22991156812183
9885. when the same sequence is equivalent in	meaning to i have instructions which i am to leave dominant stress	is ordinarily on instructions.	9.843021608289266
9886. it is clear that patterns	of stress sometimes	show construction unambiguously in the spoken language where	without the help of context it would be ambiguous in the written.	15.767604830023785
9887. i'll come by tuesday.	8.045217248147326
9888. i	can't be happy long without drinking water.	13.037321475654965
9889. in the first of these	sentences if by is the complement of come and tuesday is	an adjunct of time equivalent to on tuesday there will be strong	stress on by in the spoken language; but if a complement for	come is implied and by tuesday is a prepositional unit used as	an adjunct by will be unstressed or lightly stressed at most.	8.173940656764035
9890. in	the second sentence if drinking water is a gerundial clause and	without drinking water is roughly equivalent in meaning to unless	i drink water there will be stronger stress on water than on	drinking; but if drinking is a gerundial noun modifying water	and without drinking water is equivalent to without water	for drinking there will be stronger stress on drinking than on	water.	8.34685265491676
9891. but the use of stress in comparison and contrast for example	can undermine distinctions such as these.	12.357274392836828
9892. and patterns of stress	are not always unambiguous by any means.	14.002188100682323
9893. in the steiners have	busy	lives without visiting relatives only context can indicate whether visiting	relatives is equivalent in meaning to paying visits to relatives	or to relatives who are visiting them and in i looked	up the number and i looked up the chimney only the meanings	of number and chimney make it clear that up is syntactically	a second complement in the first sentence and a preposition followed	by its object in the second.	7.789708486556248
9894. syllables are	linguistic units centering in peaks which are usually vocalic but as	has been noted are consonantal under certain circumstances and which	may or may not be combined with preceding andor following consonants	or combinations of consonants.	9.081699650036743
9895. syllables are genuine units but division	of words and sentences into them presents great difficulties.	8.62963042412541
9896. sometimes	even the number of syllables is not clear.	14.571505980234376
9897. doubt on this point	is strongest before l and  or r.	9.669550099771405
9898. from the point of view	of	word formation real might be expected to have two syllables.	18.711222955654975
9899. historically	re is the formative that is employed also in republic	and al is the common suffix.	8.450640073948662
9900. when ity is added	real clearly has two syllables.	16.531820773994568
9901. but there is every reason to regard	deal as a monosyllable and because of the fact that l commonly	has the quality of  when it follows vowel sounds deal seems	to be a perfectly satisfactory rhyme with real.	12.679453568399959
9902. it is obvious enough that linguists in general have been less	successful in coping with tone systems than with consonants or vowels.	13.559190610536644
9903. no single explanation is adequate to account for this.	12.836443431242241
9904. improvement	however is urgent and at least three things will be needed.	11.880263214180378
9905. the first is a wide-ranging sample of successful tonal analyses.	13.384391640401992
9906. even	beginning students in linguistics are made familiar with an appreciable	variety of consonant systems both in their general outlines and in	many specific details.	9.158114121967879
9907. an advanced student has read a considerable	number of descriptions of consonantal systems including some of the more	unusual types.	9.795088060860449
9908. by contrast even experienced linguists commonly know	no more of the range of possibilities in tone systems than the over-simple	distinction between register and contour languages.	11.546266294244749
9909. this limited	familiarity with the possible phenomena has severely hampered work	with tone.	11.84218474686041
9910. tone analysis will continue to be difficult and unsatisfactory	until a more representative selection of systems is familar to	every practicing field linguist.	10.70002138800984
9911. papers like these four if widely read	will contribute importantly to improvement of our analytic work.	8.450640073948662
9912. the second need is better field techniques.	18.796424706970367
9913. the great majority	of present-day linguists fall into one or more of a number of overlapping	types: those who are convinced that tone cannot be analysed those who	are personally scared of tone and tone languages generally those who	are convinced that tone is merely an unnecessary marginal feature in	those languages where it occurs those who have no idea how to proceed	with tone analysis those who take a simplistic view of the whole	matter.	8.935686495570431
9914. the result has been neglect fumbling efforts or superficial	treatment.	20.65497344520202
9915. as these maladies overlap so must the cure.	14.828246733426681
9916. analyses such	as these four will simultaneously combat the assumptions that tone	is impossible and that it is simple.	12.890330113091768
9917. they will give suggestions that	can be worked up into field procedures.	13.474363830075538
9918. good field techniques will not	only equip linguists for better work but also help them overcome negative	attitudes.	10.737822901740167
9919. actually none of these papers says much directly about	field techniques.	12.012357678875505
9920. but it is worth pondering that very little has	been published on any phase of field techniques in linguistics.	15.916242023410398
9921. these	things have been disseminated by other means but always in the wake	of extensive publication of analytic results.	8.554739998967529
9922. the third need	is for better theory.	20.5532627245234
9923. we should expect that general phonologic theory	should be as adequate for tone as for consonants and vowels but it has	not been.	9.793530208465967
9924. this can only be for one of two reasons: either the two	are quite different and will require totally different theory	or our existing theories are insufficiently general.	12.22569447996998
9925. if as i suspect the problem is largely of the second sort then development	of a theory better able to handle tone will result automatically	in better theory for all phonologic subsystems.	8.906117806431904
9926. one issue	that must be faced is the relative difficulty of analysis of different	phonologic subsystems.	12.835829582102042
9927. since tone systems typically comprise fewer	units than either consonant or vowel systems we might expect that they	would be the easiest part of a phonologic analysis.	8.53901816522309
9928. actual practice	does not often work out this way.	12.3482207866056
9929. tone systems are certainly more complex	than the number of units would suggest and often analytically	more difficult than much larger consonantal systems.	8.357539397912783
9930. welmers has	suggested one explanation.	16.6462465444584
9931. tone languages use for linguistic contrasts	speech parameters which also function heavily in nonlinguistic use.	8.62963042412541
9932. this may both divert the attention of the uninitiate and cause confusion	for the more knowledgeable.	16.98540461316455
9933. the problem is to disentangle the	linguistic features of pitch from the co-occurring nonlinguistic	features.	14.308799129148639
9934. of course something of the same sort occurs with other sectors of	the phonology: consonantal articulations have both a linguistic and	an individual component.	13.373620950268485
9935. but in general the individual variation is	a small thing added onto basic linguistic features of greater magnitude.	12.237759813584656
9936. with tone individual differences may be greater than the linguistic	contrasts which are superimposed on them.	11.65559349365635
9937. pitch differences from	one speaker to another or from one emotional state to another may far	exceed the small differences between tones.	7.811867791937725
9938. however any such suggestion	accounts for only some of the difficulties in hearing tone or in	developing a realistic attitude about tone but not for the analytic	difficulties that occur even when tone is meticulously recorded.	9.848725985538454
9939. a second explanation is suggested by the material described in rowlands'	paper.	11.80298408026495
9940. tone and intonation often become seriously intermeshed.	13.037321475654965
9941. neither can be adequately systematized until we are able to separate	the two and assign the observed phenomena individually to one or the	other.	10.297802301646758
9942. other pairs of phonologic subsystems also interact or overlap	in this way; for example duration sometimes figures in both the	vowel system and the intonation.	9.9420411656164
9943. some phonetic features for example	glottal catch or murmur are sometimes to be assigned to segmental phonemics	and sometimes to accentual systems.	8.841694107637236
9944. but no other two phonologic	systems are as difficult to disentangle as are tone and intonation in	some languages.	12.26893143254399
9945. this explanation of tone difficulties however does	not apply in all languages.	11.28868602154132
9946. in some	interaction of tone and intonation is restricted to the ends of intonation	spans.	14.464296608871864
9947. in many of the syllables intonation can be safely ignored	and much of the tonal analysis can be done without any study of intonation.	13.750280700937022
9948. still even in such languages tone analysis has not been as	simple as one might expect.	11.930659242730638
9949. a third explanation is suggested	by richardson's analysis of sukuma tone.	12.358443222913962
9950. there we see a basically	simple phonemic system enmeshed in a very complex and puzzling morphophonemic	system.	15.186525978659857
9951. while the phonemes can be very easily stated no one	is likely to be satisfied with the statement until phonemic occurrences	can be related in some way to morphemic units ie until the morphophonemics	is worked out or at least far enough that it seems reasonable	to expect success.	9.008923854227268
9952. in the typical tone language	tonal morphophonemics is of the same order of complexity as consonantal	morphophonemics.	15.158848868010601
9953. the phonemic systems which must support these morphophonemic	systems however are very different.	11.022396334232088
9954. the inventory of tones	is much smaller and commonly the contrasts range along one single	dimension pitch level.	11.895378476131494
9955. consonantal systems are not merely larger they	are multidimensional.	11.735378700610609
9956. morphophonemic rules may be thought of as joining	certain points in the system.	12.71064859314332
9957. the possibilities in the consonantal	system are very numerous and only a small portion of them are actually	used.	10.915518055281774
9958. phonemes connected by a morphophonemic rule commonly show	a good bit of phonetic similarity possible because of the several dimensions	of contrast in the system.	9.593735817596315
9959. tonal morphophonemics in a common	case can do nothing but either raise or lower the tone.	8.450640073948662
9960. the possibilities	are few and the total number of rules may be considerably greater.	12.010194183656237
9961. often therefore there are a number of rules having the same	effect and commonly other sets of rules as well having the opposite	effect.	9.993341424127768
9962. tonal morphophonemics is much more confusing to the beginning	analyst than consonantal morphophonemics even when the total number	of rules is no greater.	10.06492765017907
9963. the difficulty of analysis of any subsystem	in the phonology is an inverse function of the size- smaller systems	are more troublesome- for any given degree of morphophonemic	complexity.	8.788473153385922
9964. this hypothesis will account for a large part of the difficulties	of tonal analysis as well as the fact that vowel systems are	often more puzzling than consonantal systems.	18.49311648490675
9965. the statement of the system	is a different matter.	19.12802793037202
9966. smaller systems can of course be stated	much more succinctly.	13.249540884807272
9967. a phonemic system can be stated without reference	to morphophonemics but it cannot always be found without morphophonemics.	9.246630530266595
9968. and the more complex the morphophonemic system is in relation	to the phonemic base the less easily a phonemic system will be analysed	without close attention to the morphophonemics- at least the less	satisfying will a phonemic statement be if it cannot be related through	morphophonemic rules to grammatically meaningful structures.	9.95754637058332
9969. the design of orthographies has received much less attention from	linguists than the problem deserves.	11.50172365674118
9970. there has been a tendency on the	part of many american linguists to assume that a phonemic transcription	will automatically be the best possible orthography and that the only	real problem will then be the social one of securing acceptance.	12.39510352547687
9971. most others have been content to give only the most	general attention to the broadest and most obvious features of the phonology	when designing orthographies.	9.889163879724617
9972. apparently the feeling is that	anything more would be involvement in technical abstrusenesses of possible	pedantic interest but of no visible significance in practical affairs.	9.616071439254972
9973. the result of this attitude has been the domination of many orthography	conferences by such considerations as typographic 'esthetics'	which usually turns out to be nothing more than certain prejudices	carried over from european languages.	12.075638480404058
9974. many of the suggested systems	seem to have only the most tenuous relationship to the language structures	that they purport to represent.	13.51563448275639
9975. linguists have not always been	more enlightened than practical people and sometimes have insisted	on incredibly trivial points while neglecting things of much greater	significance.	7.634437488545556
9976. as a result many people have been confirmed in their	conviction that orthography design is not an activity to which experts	can contribute anything but confusion.	13.585540648977402
9977. a e sharp	in vowel-length and syllabicity in kikuyu examines one set of related	orthographic questions and its phonologic background in detail.	8.50827903251417
9978. his	objective is merely to determine what distinctions of length and	syllabicity it may be desirable to make explicit in a kikuyu orthography	.	10.711913785051436
9979. to do so he finds it necessary to examine the relevant	parts of the phonology thoroughly and in detail.	14.931751323238407
9980. in the process he	develops some very significant observations about problems of a sort	that are often difficult.	16.06757606279908
9981. a few of his examples are of very great interest	and the whole discussion of some importance for theory.	11.1671466357069

9985. i hope his suggestions are	given the consideration they deserve in kikuyu circles.	12.034767651495988

9988. one other	paper deals with a phonologic problem: vowel harmony in igbo by	j carnochan.	12.585813937402614
